RBR , CC CS AT NN IN JJ NN RB , AT NN-TL IN-TL AT-TL VBN-TL NNS-TL RB VBD IN AT JJ NN AT `` NP-TL NN-TL '' IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL NNS-TL NN-TL , WDT MD HV RB VBN AT JJ NN IN AT NN-TL IN DTS NNS .
Next , let us consider briefly the program and administrative implications of a failure on our part to pursue our appeals .	RB , VB PPO VB RB AT NN CC JJ NNS IN AT NN IN PP$ NN TO VB PP$ NNS .
There is far too much at stake for all of the parties concerned to leave the matter hanging in midair .	EX BEZ QL QL AP IN NN IN ABN IN AT NNS VBN TO VB AT NN VBG IN NN .
The ramifications of the issue are enormous .	AT NNS IN AT NN BER JJ .
A decision to refer workers to jobs vacant because of a strike would have to be applied equally to nonagricultural situations , and might in effect place the public employment services in the position of acting as strikebreakers .	AT NN TO VB NNS IN NNS JJ RB IN AT NN MD HV TO BE VBN RB IN JJ NNS , CC NN IN NN VB AT JJ NN NNS IN AT NN IN VBG CS NNS .
The public interest is so dominant in such an issue that I cannot be so presumptuous as to attempt to settle it by an administrative order based upon conclusions reached in a summary action in one or two Superior Courts in the State .	AT JJ NN BEZ QL JJ IN ABL AT NN CS PPSS MD* BE QL JJ CS TO VB TO VB PPO IN AT JJ NN VBN IN NNS VBN IN AT NN NN IN CD CC CD JJ-TL NNS-TL IN AT NN-TL .
It is an issue which may well reach the Supreme Court of the United States before judicial finality is achieved .	PPS BEZ AT NN WDT MD RB VB AT JJ-TL NN-TL IN-TL AT-TL VBN-TL NNS-TL CS JJ NN BEZ VBN .
As an administrator , I cannot place the Employment Service in California in jeopardy of being out of compliance with the Federal laws by my failure to pursue the avenues of appeal open to me .	CS AT NN , PPSS MD* VB AT NN-TL NN-TL IN NP IN NN IN BEG RP IN NN IN AT JJ-TL NNS IN PP$ NN TO VB AT NNS IN NN JJ IN PPO .
To have applied statewide the decisions of the two cases heard in Superior Court , in my opinion , would have placed us clearly out of compliance with the Wagner-Peyser Act and would have immediately opened the way for the Secretary of Labor , were he so inclined , to notify the Governor of such noncompliance , set a date for hearing , and issue his finding .	TO HV VBN RB AT NNS IN AT CD NNS VBN IN JJ-TL NN-TL , IN PP$ NN , MD HV VBN PPO RB RP IN NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL CC MD HV RB VBN AT NN CS AT NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL , BED PPS RB VBN , TO VB AT NN-TL IN JJ NN , VB AT NN IN NN , CC VB PP$ NN .
The impact of noncompliance under the Wagner-Peyser Act is clear : the withdrawal of some $11 million a year of administrative funds which finance our employment service program or , as a corollary , the taking over by the Federal Government of its operation .	AT NN IN NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL BEZ JJ : AT NN IN RB NNS CD AT NN IN JJ NNS WDT VB PP$ NN NN NN CC , CS AT NN , AT VBG RP IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL IN PP$ NN .
Thus far , the cases which have come before the courts have involved only the issue of referral where the job is vacant due to a strike -- condition ( 1 ) in the Regulation of the Secretary .	QL RB , AT NNS WDT HV VBN IN AT NNS HV VBN RB AT NN IN NN WRB AT NN BEZ JJ RB IN AT NN -- NN ( CD ) IN AT NN-TL IN AT NN-TL .
None has yet arisen under condition ( 2 ) , relating to referral to jobs `` the filling of which is an issue in a labor dispute '' .	PN HVZ RB VBN IN NN ( CD ) , VBG IN NN IN NNS `` AT NN IN WDT BEZ AT NN IN AT NN NN '' .
Here the problem is essentially one of defining the word `` filling '' .	RB AT NN BEZ RB CD IN VBG AT NN `` VBG-NC '' .
Should it be defined in a narrow sense to include only such elements as job specifications , union membership , union jurisdiction , and the like ? ?	MD PPO BE VBN IN AT JJ NN TO VB RB JJ NNS CS NN NNS , NN NN , NN NN , CC AT JJ . .
Or should it have a broader connotation of including wage demands and other factors not necessarily associated with the mechanics of `` filling '' the job .	CC MD PPO HV AT JJR NN IN VBG NN NNS CC AP NNS * RB VBN IN AT NN IN `` VBG '' AT NN .
Because of the uncertainty of this definition , I solicited the interpretation of the Secretary of Labor .	RB IN AT NN IN DT NN , PPSS VBD AT NN IN AT NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL .
He has advised me that the narrower interpretation is the proper one ; ;	PPS HVZ VBN PPO CS AT JJR NN BEZ AT JJ CD . .
that is , that if wages , for example , is the only issue in a labor dispute , and no workers have left their jobs because of the dispute , we may continue to make referrals .	DT BEZ , CS CS NNS , IN NN , BEZ AT AP NN IN AT NN NN , CC AT NNS HV VBN PP$ NNS RB IN AT NN , PPSS MD VB TO VB NNS .
9 .	CD-HL .-HL
Martin and Stendler present evidence that infants and young children can and do solve many problems at a relatively simple perceptual level simply by combining objects and counting them .	NP CC NP VB NN CS NNS CC JJ NNS MD CC DO VB AP NNS IN AT QL JJ JJ NN RB IN VBG NNS CC VBG PPO .
After they have developed concepts , they are free from the necessity of manipulating objects ; ;	CS PPSS HV VBN NNS , PPSS BER JJ IN AT NN IN VBG NNS . .
they do symbolically what they once had to do concretely .	PPSS DO RB WDT PPSS RB HVD TO DO RB .
The ability to think seems to increase consistently with age .	AT NN TO VB VBZ TO VB RB IN NN .
One experiment showed the greatest one-year difference occurring between the eleventh and twelfth years .	CD NN VBD AT JJT NN NN VBG IN AT OD CC OD NNS .
10 .	CD-HL .-HL
Many studies indicate that elementary-school children's interests cover the whole field of science ; ;	AP NNS VB CS NN NNS$ NNS VB AT JJ NN IN NN . .
that their questions indicate a genuine interest in social processes and events ; ;	CS PP$ NNS VB AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS CC NNS . .
and that as they mature their interests and capabilities change and broaden .	CC CS CS PPSS VB PP$ NNS CC NNS VB CC VB .
Emotional characteristics	JJ-HL NNS-HL
How a child feels about himself , about other people , and about the tasks confronting him in school may have as much influence on his success in school as his physical and intellectual characteristics .	WRB AT NN VBZ IN PPL , IN AP NNS , CC IN AT NNS VBG PPO IN NN MD HV QL AP NN IN PP$ NN IN NN CS PP$ JJ CC JJ NNS .
A considerable amount of evidence exists to show that an unhappy and insecure child is not likely to do well in school subjects .	AT JJ NN IN NN VBZ TO VB CS AT JJ CC JJ NN BEZ * JJ TO DO RB IN NN NNS .
Emotional maturity is the result of many factors , the principal ones being the experiences of the first few years of the child's life .	JJ NN BEZ AT NN IN AP NNS , AT JJS NNS BEG AT NNS IN AT OD AP NNS IN AT NN$ NN .
However , the teacher who understands the influence of emotions on behavior may be highly influential in helping pupils gain confidence , security , and satisfaction .	RB , AT NN WPS VBZ AT NN IN NNS IN NN MD BE QL JJ IN VBG NNS VB NN , NN , CC NN .
Concerning this responsibility of the teacher , suggestions for helping children gain better control of the emotions are presented in Chapter 11 .	IN DT NN IN AT NN , NNS IN VBG NNS VB JJR NN IN AT NNS BER VBN IN NN-TL CD-TL .
The following generalizations about the emotional characteristics of elementary-school children may be helpful .	AT VBG NNS IN AT JJ NNS IN NN NNS MD BE JJ .
1 .	CD-HL .-HL
Typically , the young child's emotional reactions last for a relatively short time , as contrasted to those of an adult .	RB , AT JJ NN$ JJ NNS VB IN AT RB JJ NN , CS VBN IN DTS IN AT NN .
2 .	CD-HL .-HL
As the child grows older , his emotional reactions lead to `` moods '' , or emotional states drawn out over a period of time and expressed slowly , rather than in short , abrupt outbursts .	CS AT NN VBZ JJR , PP$ JJ NNS VB IN `` NNS '' , CC JJ NNS VBN RP IN AT NN IN NN CC VBN RB , RB CS IN JJ , JJ NNS .
3 .	CD-HL .-HL
Studies of the growth and decline of children's fears indicate that fears due to strange objects , noises , falling , and unexpected movement decline during the preschool years , but that fears of the dark , of being alone , and of imaginary creatures or robbers increase .	NNS IN AT NN CC NN IN NNS$ NNS VB CS NNS JJ IN JJ NNS , NNS , VBG , CC JJ NN VB IN AT JJ NNS , CC CS NNS IN AT NN , IN BEG RB , CC IN JJ NNS CC NNS VB .
4 .	CD-HL .-HL
Ridiculing a child for being afraid or forcing him to meet the feared situation alone are poor ways of dealing with the problem ; ;	VBG AT NN IN BEG JJ CC VBG PPO TO VB AT VBN NN RB BER JJ NNS IN VBG IN AT NN . .
more effective solutions include explanations , the example of another child , or conditioning by associating the feared object , place , or person with something pleasant .	QL JJ NNS VB NNS , AT NN IN DT NN , CC VBG IN VBG AT VBN NN , NN , CC NN IN PN JJ .
5 .	CD-HL .-HL
Children need help in learning to control their emotions .	NNS VB NN IN VBG TO VB PP$ NNS .
The young child learns from parents and teachers that temper tantrums , screaming , kicking , and hitting will not get him what he wants ; ;	AT JJ NN VBZ IN NNS CC NNS CS NN NNS , VBG , VBG , CC VBG MD * VB PPO WDT PPS VBZ . .
the older child learns that intense emotional outbursts will not win approval by his peers , and , therefore , makes a real effort to control his emotions .	AT JJR NN VBZ CS JJ JJ NNS MD * VB NN IN PP$ NNS , CC , RB , VBZ AT JJ NN TO VB PP$ NNS .
6 .	CD-HL .-HL
Children differ widely in their emotional responses .	NNS VB RB IN PP$ JJ NNS .
Among infants the patterns of emotional responses are similar ; ;	IN NNS AT NNS IN JJ NNS BER JJ . .
as the influence of learning and environment are felt , emotional behavior becomes individualized .	CS AT NN IN VBG CC NN BER VBN , JJ NN VBZ VBN .
Social characteristics	JJ-HL NNS-HL
Although no national norms exist for the social development of children , the teacher can find a great deal of information concerning types of social behavior normally displayed by children at various age levels .	CS AT JJ NNS VB IN AT JJ NN IN NNS , AT NN MD VB AT JJ NN IN NN IN NNS IN JJ NN RB VBN IN NNS IN AP NN NNS .
The following summary will give the student some idea about the social characteristics of elementary-school children ; ;	AT VBG NN MD VB AT NN DTI NN IN AT JJ NNS IN NN NNS . .
the student will certainly want to explore more deeply into the fascinating study of immature individuals , struggling to meet their developmental needs , and at the same time trying to learn the rules of the game in the ever-expanding number of groups in which they hold membership .	AT NN MD RB VB TO VB QL RB IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS , VBG TO VB PP$ JJ NNS , CC IN AT AP NN VBG TO VB AT NNS IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN NNS IN WDT PPSS VB NN .
1 .	CD-HL .-HL
During early childhood , children are more interested in the approval of their parents and teachers than they are in the approval of other children ; ;	IN JJ NN , NNS BER QL VBN IN AT NN IN PP$ NNS CC NNS CS PPSS BER IN AT NN IN AP NNS . .
after they have been in school a few years , their interest in playmates of their own age increases , and their interest in adults decreases ; ;	CS PPSS HV BEN IN NN AT AP NNS , PP$ NN IN NNS IN PP$ JJ NN VBZ , CC PP$ NN IN NNS VBZ . .
the child who had once considered it a treat to accompany his parents on picnics and family gatherings now considers it a bore .	AT NN WPS HVD RB VBN PPO AT NN TO VB PP$ NNS IN NNS CC NN NNS RB VBZ PPO AT NN .
In late childhood the influence of the group on the social behavior of the child continues to increase ; ;	IN JJ NN AT NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN VBZ TO VB . .
the group sets the styles in clothing , the kind of play engaged in , and the ideals of right and wrong behavior .	AT NN VBZ AT NNS IN NN , AT NN IN NN VBN IN , CC AT NNS IN JJ CC JJ NN .
2 .	CD-HL .-HL
In early childhood the choice of a companion is likely to be for another child of his own age or a year or two older , who can do the things he likes to do ; ;	IN JJ NN AT NN IN AT NN BEZ JJ TO BE IN DT NN IN PP$ JJ NN CC AT NN CC CD JJR , WPS MD DO AT NNS PPS VBZ TO DO . .
such factors as sex , intelligence , and status in the group do not influence his choice much at this time .	JJ NNS CS NN , NN , CC NN IN AT NN DO * VB PP$ NN RB IN DT NN .
3 .	CD-HL .-HL
In later childhood , an interest in team games replaces individual play ; ;	IN JJR NN , AT NN IN NN NNS VBZ JJ NN . .
loyalty to the group , a feeling of superiority over those who are not members , and unwillingness to play with members of the opposite sex become dominant traits .	NN IN AT NN , AT NN IN NN IN DTS WPS BER * NNS , CC NN TO VB IN NNS IN AT JJ NN VB JJ NNS .
4 .	CD-HL .-HL
During early childhood boys tease and bully , on the average , more than girls ; ;	IN JJ NN NNS VB CC VB , IN AT JJ , RBR CS NNS . .
those who feel inferior or insecure engage in these activities more than do well-adjusted children .	DTS WPS VB JJ CC JJ VB IN DTS NNS RBR CS DO JJ NNS .
5 .	CD-HL .-HL
During late childhood boys like to tease , jostle , and talk smart to girls ; ;	IN JJ NN NNS VB TO VB , VB , CC VB RB IN NNS . .
girls , who are more mature than boys , frown upon the youthful antics of boys of their own age .	NNS , WPS BER QL JJ CS NNS , VB IN AT JJ NNS IN NNS IN PP$ JJ NN .
6 .	CD-HL .-HL
By the time pupils reach the sixth grade , their ethical and moral standards are fairly well developed ; ;	IN AT NN NNS VB AT OD NN , PP$ JJ CC JJ NNS BER QL RB VBN . .
they exhibit a keen interest in social , political , and economic problems , but they frequently have vague and incorrect notions about the terms they use rather glibly in their routine school work .	PPSS VB AT JJ NN IN JJ , JJ , CC JJ NNS , CC PPSS RB HV JJ CC JJ NNS IN AT NNS PPSS VB QL RB IN PP$ JJ NN NN .
7 .	CD-HL .-HL
Between the ages of two and four years , negativism or resistance to adult authority is noticeable ; ;	IN AT NNS IN CD CC CD NNS , NN CC NN IN NN NN BEZ JJ . .
after the fourth year it begins to decline .	IN AT OD NN PPS VBZ TO VB .
However , as we have seen , in later childhood the child begins to substitute the standards of the peer group for those of parents and teachers .	RB , CS PPSS HV VBN , IN JJR NN AT NN VBZ TO VB AT NNS IN AT NN NN IN DTS IN NNS CC NNS .
8 .	CD-HL .-HL
The elementary-school child grows gradually in his ability to work in groups .	AT NN NN VBZ RB IN PP$ NN TO VB IN NNS .
The child in the primary grades can play harmoniously with one companion , but his desire to be first in everything gets him into trouble when the group gets larger ; ;	AT NN IN AT JJ NNS MD VB RB IN CD NN , CC PP$ NN TO BE OD IN PN VBZ PPO IN NN WRB AT NN VBZ JJR . .
he wants to be with people , but he hasn't yet learned to cooperate .	PPS VBZ TO BE IN NNS , CC PPS HVZ* RB VBN TO VB .
In the middle grades , however , he begins to participate more effectively in group activities such as selecting a leader , helping to make plans and carry on group activities , and setting up rules governing the enterprise .	IN AT JJ NNS , RB , PPS VBZ TO VB QL RB IN NN NNS JJ CS VBG AT NN , VBG TO VB NNS CC VB RP NN NNS , CC VBG RP NNS VBG AT NN .
Why the teacher should study the individual pupil	WRB-HL AT-HL NN-HL MD-HL VB-HL AT-HL JJ-HL NN-HL
Much progress has been made in the last two decades in developing techniques for understanding children , yet in almost any classroom today can be found children whose needs are not being met by the school program .	AP NN HVZ BEN VBN IN AT AP CD NNS IN VBG NNS IN VBG NNS , CC IN RB DTI NN NR MD BE VBN NNS WP$ NNS BER * BEG VBN IN AT NN NN .
Some are failing to achieve as much as their ability would permit ; ;	DTI BER VBG TO VB QL AP CS PP$ NN MD VB . .
others never seem able to enter fully into the life of the classroom .	NNS RB VB JJ TO VB RB IN AT NN IN AT NN .
These children have been described as those who were trying to say something to adults who did not understand .	DTS NNS HV BEN VBN CS DTS WPS BED VBG TO VB PN IN NNS WPS DOD * VB .
Many school systems now employ school psychologists and child guidance specialists .	AP NN NNS RB VB NN NNS CC NN NN NNS .
These specialists perform valuable services by helping teachers learn to identify children who need special attention , by suggesting ways of meeting the needs of individual children in the regular classroom , and by providing clinical services for severely maladjusted children .	DTS NNS VB JJ NNS IN VBG NNS VB TO VB NNS WPS VB JJ NN , IN VBG NNS IN VBG AT NNS IN JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN , CC IN VBG JJ NNS IN QL JJ NNS .
It is the classroom teacher , however , who has daily contacts with pupils , and who is in a unique position to put sound psychological principles into practice .	PPS BEZ AT NN NN , RB , WPS HVZ JJ NNS IN NNS , CC WPS BEZ IN AT JJ NN TO VB JJ JJ NNS IN NN .
Indeed , a study of the individual child is an integral part of the work of the elementary-school teacher , rather than merely an additional chore .	RB , AT NN IN AT JJ NN BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT NN NN , RB CS RB AT JJ NN .
Teachers and administrators in many elementary schools have assumed that dividing the pupils in any grade into groups on the basis of test scores solves the problem of meeting the needs of individuals .	NNS CC NNS IN AP JJ NNS HV VBN CS VBG AT NNS IN DTI NN IN NNS IN AT NN IN NN NNS VBZ AT NN IN VBG AT NNS IN NNS .
What they should recognize is that children who have been placed in one of these groups on a narrow academic basis still differ widely in attributes that influence success , and that they still must be treated as individuals .	WDT PPSS MD VB BEZ CS NNS WPS HV BEN VBN IN CD IN DTS NNS IN AT JJ JJ NN RB VB RB IN NNS WPS VB NN , CC CS PPSS RB MD BE VBN CS NNS .
Although the teacher must be concerned with maintaining standards , he must also be concerned about understanding differences in ability , background , and experience .	CS AT NN MD BE VBN IN VBG NNS , PPS MD RB BE VBN IN VBG NNS IN NN , NN , CC NN .
Factors that inhibit learning and lead to maladjustment	NNS-HL WPS-HL VB-HL VBG-HL CC-HL VB-HL IN-HL NN-HL
Studies conducted in various sections of the United States indicate that many children in elementary schools are maladjusted emotionally , and that many of them are failing to make satisfactory progress in school subjects .	NNS VBN IN AP NNS IN AT VBN-TL NNS-TL VB CS AP NNS IN JJ NNS BER JJ RB , CC CS AP IN PPO BER VBG TO VB JJ NN IN NN NNS .
One study , which involved 1,524 pupils in grades one to six , found that 12 percent of the pupils were seriously maladjusted and that 23 percent were reading a year below capacity .	CD NN , WDT VBD CD NNS IN NNS CD IN CD , VBD CS CD NN IN AT NNS BED QL JJ CC CS CD NN BED VBG AT NN IN NN .
It is apparent , therefore , that the teacher needs to know what factors have a vital bearing on the learning and adjustment of children .	PPS BEZ JJ , RB , CS AT NN VBZ TO VB WDT NNS HV AT JJ NN IN AT NN CC NN IN NNS .
When a child fails to meet the standards of the school in his rate of learning , insecurity , unhappiness , and other forms of maladjustment frequently follow .	WRB AT NN VBZ TO VB AT NNS IN AT NN IN PP$ NN IN VBG , NN , NN , CC AP NNS IN NN RB VB .
These maladjustments in turn inhibit learning , and a vicious cycle is completed .	DTS NNS IN NN VB VBG , CC AT JJ NN BEZ VBN .
It is easy for the teacher to rationalize that the child who is not achieving in accordance with his known ability is just plain lazy , or that the child who lacks interest in school , who dislikes the teacher , or who is overaggressive is a hopeless delinquent .	PPS BEZ JJ CS AT NN TO VB CS AT NN WPS BEZ * VBG IN NN IN PP$ VBN NN BEZ RB QL JJ , CC CS AT NN WPS VBZ NN IN NN , WPS VBZ AT NN , CC WPS BEZ JJ BEZ AT JJ NN .
The causes of retardation and maladjustment may be found in physical factors , such as defective speech or hearing , impaired vision , faulty motor coordination , a frail constitution , chronic disease , malnutrition , and glandular malfunctioning .	AT NNS IN NN CC NN MD BE VBN IN JJ NNS , JJ CS JJ NN CC NN , VBN NN , JJ NN NN , AT JJ NN , JJ NN , NN , CC JJ NN .
They may be caused by poor health habits , such as faulty eating and sleeping habits .	PPSS MD BE VBN IN JJ NN NNS , JJ CS JJ VBG CC VBG NNS .
They may be related to mental immaturity or lack of aptitude for certain types of school work .	PPSS MD BE VBN IN JJ NN CC NN IN NN IN AP NNS IN NN NN .
The curriculum may be too difficult for some and too easy for others .	AT NN MD BE QL JJ IN DTI CC QL JJ IN NNS .
Teaching methods , learning materials , and promotion policies may inhibit learning and lead to maladjustments for some children .	VBG NNS , VBG NNS , CC NN NNS MD VB VBG CC VB IN NNS IN DTI NNS .
Unwholesome family relations , broken homes , and undesirable community influences may also be contributing factors .	JJ NN NNS , VBN NNS , CC JJ NN NNS MD RB BE VBG NNS .
This is only a minimum list of the factors that inhibit learning and contribute to maladjustment among children .	DT BEZ RB AT JJ NN IN AT NNS WPS VB VBG CC VB IN NN IN NNS .
Moreover , these conditions do not influence all children in the same manner .	RB , DTS NNS DO * VB ABN NNS IN AT AP NN .
A vision handicap that may produce nervous tension and reading disability for one child may spur another child on to even greater achievement in reading .	AT NN NN WPS MD VB JJ NN CC VBG NN IN CD NN MD VB DT NN RP IN QL JJR NN IN VBG .
An impoverished home that may discourage one child may constitute the motivation causing another to work harder for successful achievement in school .	AT JJ NN WPS MD VB CD NN MD VB AT NN VBG DT TO VB RBR IN JJ NN IN NN .
At any rate , the teacher who recognizes common causes of retardation and maladjustment can frequently do a great deal to eliminate the causes of pupil discouragement , failure , and maladjustment .	IN DTI NN , AT NN WPS VBZ JJ NNS IN NN CC NN MD RB DO AT JJ NN TO VB AT NNS IN NN NN , NN , CC NN .
Sources of information about children	NNS-HL IN-HL NN-HL IN-HL NNS-HL
Successful teaching involves getting enough information about each pupil to understand why he behaves as he does in certain situations and how his achievement in school is being influenced by various factors in his environment .	JJ NN VBZ VBG AP NN IN DT NN TO VB WRB PPS VBZ CS PPS DOZ IN AP NNS CC WRB PP$ NN IN NN BEZ BEG VBN IN AP NNS IN PP$ NN .
The classroom teacher cannot be expected to be as proficient in the use of the techniques of child study as the clinical psychologist ; ;	AT NN NN MD* BE VBN TO BE QL JJ IN AT NN IN AT NNS IN NN NN CS AT JJ NN . .
he cannot be expected to administer all the tests and gather all the information needed about each child in his classroom .	PPS MD* BE VBN TO VB ABN AT NNS CC VB ABN AT NN VBN IN DT NN IN PP$ NN .
He can be expected , however , to examine and interpret the information already available ; ;	PPS MD BE VBN , RB , TO VB CC VB AT NN RB JJ . .
to refine and extend his own techniques for studying individual children ; ;	TO VB CC VB PP$ JJ NNS IN VBG JJ NNS . .
and to utilize opportunities , arising in connection with regular classroom activities , for gaining a better understanding of his pupils .	CC TO VB NNS , VBG IN NN IN JJ NN NNS , IN VBG AT JJR NN IN PP$ NNS .
This section deals with some of the sources of information that can be tapped by the classroom teacher ; ;	DT NN VBZ IN DTI IN AT NNS IN NN WPS MD BE VBN IN AT NN NN . .
Chapter 15 provides more detailed information about specific techniques used in evaluating pupil progress .	NN-TL CD-TL VBZ QL VBN NN IN JJ NNS VBN IN VBG NN NN .
Cumulative records	JJ-HL NNS-HL
Most school systems today maintain a system of cumulative records of pupils .	AP NN NNS NR VB AT NN IN JJ NNS IN NNS .
These records , when systematically maintained , provide much information about the children , which the teacher can use in guidance , instruction , grouping , and reporting to parents .	DTS NNS , WRB RB VBN , VB AP NN IN AT NNS , WDT AT NN MD VB IN NN , NN , VBG , CC VBG IN NNS .
Each teacher has in his classroom a metal file , equipped with a lock , which is used to store cumulative record folders .	DT NN HVZ IN PP$ NN AT NN NN , VBN IN AT NN , WDT BEZ VBN TO VB JJ NN NNS .
During summer vacation periods these records are stored in the office of the principal .	IN NN NN NNS DTS NNS BER VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN .
Only the teacher and other professional personnel are permitted to see or use these records .	RB AT NN CC AP JJ NNS BER VBN TO VB CC VB DTS NNS .
Each new teacher to whom the pupil goes is expected to study the information in the cumulative record and to bring it up to date .	DT JJ NN IN WPO AT NN VBZ BEZ VBN TO VB AT NN IN AT JJ NN CC TO VB PPO RP IN NN .
Some school systems provide written instructions to principals and teachers designating when certain information is to be recorded on cumulative record forms and explaining how the information is to be summarized and used .	DTI NN NNS VB VBN NNS IN NNS CC NNS VBG WRB AP NN BEZ TO BE VBN IN JJ NN NNS CC VBG WRB AT NN BEZ TO BE VBN CC VBN .
The Summary Report On Desegregation Progress In Education In The Middle-South Region , 1959 - 1960 '' clearly shows two pieces of information .	AT NN-TL NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL IN-TL AT-TL JJ-TL NN-TL , CD-TL IN-TL CD-TL '' RB VBZ CD NNS IN NN .
The Summary Report , which was prepared for this Conference , indicates , first , that actual or pending school desegregation is increasing ; ;	AT NN-TL NN-TL , WDT BEDZ VBN IN DT NN-TL , VBZ , RB , CS JJ CC JJ NN NN BEZ VBG . .
second , that both actual and pending desegregation is , with few exceptions , the product or result of court order .	RB , CS ABX JJ CC JJ NN BEZ , IN AP NNS , AT NN CC NN IN NN NN .
The Report together with other information suggests that desegregation in the schools is slow .	AT NN-TL RB IN AP NN VBZ CS NN IN AT NNS BEZ JJ .
The Middle-South Region , as defined by the National Association of Intergroup Relations Officials ( NAIRO ) , consists of the states of Kentucky , Maryland , Tennessee , West Virginia , Delaware , Virginia and the District of Columbia .	AT JJ-TL NN-TL , CS VBN IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL IN-TL JJ-TL NNS-TL NNS-TL ( NP ) , VBZ IN AT NNS IN NP , NP , NP , JJ-TL NP-TL , NP , NP CC AT NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL .
The states and the Nation's Capital all have some desegregation , in fact some dating back to 1954 ; ;	AT NNS CC AT NN$-TL NN-TL ABN HV DTI NN , IN NN DTI VBG RB IN CD . .
but the region also embraces some of the staunchest opposition .	CC AT NN RB VBZ DTI IN AT JJT NN .
Desegregation has been opposed by massive resistance , interposition , pupil assignment ( with no assignments of Negro children ) , and hate bombings .	NN HVZ BEN VBN IN JJ NN , NN , NN NN ( IN AT NNS IN NP NNS ) , CC NN NNS .
Desegregation and court order	NN-HL CC-HL NN-HL NN-HL
Now let's look at the evidence that shows the increase in desegregation and such increase as a result of court order .	RB VB+PPO VB IN AT NN WPS VBZ AT NN IN NN CC JJ NN CS AT NN IN NN NN .
First Kentucky .	RB NP .
Elementary school desegregation came to Owen and Union Counties , which already had high school desegregation .	JJ NN NN VBD IN NP CC NN-TL NNS-TL , WDT RB HVD JJ NN NN .
The action was a result of a court order , the citation for which ( and for other court action mentioned in this paper ) is taken from the Summary Report for this Conference .	AT NN BEDZ AT NN IN AT NN NN , AT NN IN WDT ( CC IN AP NN NN VBN IN DT NN ) BEZ VBN IN AT NN-TL NN-TL IN DT NN-TL .
In Maryland the Harford County Board of Education had prepared a desegregation plan which the Court approved but which a plaintiff had challenged ; ;	IN NP AT NP-TL NN-TL NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL HVD VBN AT NN NN WDT AT NN-TL VBD CC WDT AT NN HVD VBN . .
thus , county school board and Federal court joined hands here to promote school desegregation .	RB , NN NN NN CC JJ-TL NN VBD NNS RB TO VB NN NN .
Additional school desegregation in Tennessee resulted from a court order opening a school serving children of military personnel .	JJ NN NN IN NP VBD IN AT NN NN VBG AT NN VBG NNS IN JJ NNS .
Similarly , further desegregation may come from suits pending in three Tennessee cities , Chattanooga , Knoxville , and Memphis .	RB , AP NN MD VB IN NNS JJ IN CD NP NNS , NP , NP , CC NP .
In West Virginia the number of white and Negro children attending the same school has increased almost twofold .	IN JJ-TL NP-TL AT NN IN JJ CC NP NNS VBG AT AP NN HVZ VBN QL RB .
There are no court decisions here .	EX BER AT NN NNS RB .
As in Maryland , a District court has approved an official plan of school desegregation in Delaware .	CS IN NP , AT NN-TL NN HVZ VBN AT JJ NN IN NN NN IN NP .
As a result of the State Board of Education plan , Negro children entered heretofore white elementary schools in five districts .	CS AT NN IN AT NN-TL NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL NN , NP NNS VBD RB JJ JJ NNS IN CD NNS .
The Third Circuit Court of Appeals is reviewing an appeal from the plan .	AT OD-TL NN-TL NN-TL IN-TL NNS-TL BEZ VBG AT NN IN AT NN .
In Virginia court orders led to desegregation in Charlottesville and Floyd Counties .	IN NP NN NNS VBD IN NN IN NP-TL CC NP-TL NNS-TL .
Desegregation in Pulaski County is pending because of court order , although date of admission is not yet determined .	NN IN NP-TL NN-TL BEZ IN RB IN NN NN , CS NN IN NN BEZ * RB VBN .
Negro parents have filed application for admission of additional children to schools in Alexandria , Arlington , Fairfax , and Warren Counties .	NP NNS HV VBN NN IN NN IN JJ NNS IN NNS IN NP , NP , NP , CC NP-TL NNS-TL .
Desegregation can also result from additional suits brought by Negro plaintiffs against school boards in Newport News , Fairfax County , Arlington County , and Norfolk .	NN MD RB VB IN JJ NNS VBN IN NP NNS IN NN NNS IN NP NP , NP-TL NN-TL , NP-TL NN-TL , CC NP .
As a school district , the District of Columbia has had desegregated schools since 1954 , shortly after the Supreme Court decision .	CS AT NN NN , AT NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL HVZ HVN VBN NNS IN CD , RB IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL NN .
This recapitulation makes it clear that school desegregation continues , including the Old Dominion State , in spite of its stern resistance .	DT NN VBZ PPO JJ CS NN NN VBZ , IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL NN-TL , IN NN IN PP$ JJ NN .
The record is clear that increase in school desegregation last year came largely as a result of a court order ; ;	AT NN BEZ JJ CS NN IN NN NN AP NN VBD RB CS AT NN IN AT NN NN . .
that on the immediate horizon , if further large-scale ( relatively speaking ) desegregation comes , it will result from court orders on suits filed in several Middle-South states .	CS IN AT JJ NN , CS AP NN ( RB VBG ) NN VBZ , PPS MD VB IN NN NNS IN NNS VBN IN AP JJ NNS .
Knowledge that thousands of school districts are involved and observation that school desegregation has occurred in only a handful in 1959-1960 leads to a conclusion that desegregation-from-court-order is slow .	NN CS NNS IN NN NNS BER VBN CC NN CS NN NN HVZ VBN IN RB AT NN IN CD VBZ IN AT NN DT NN BEZ JJ .
Before turning to my views as to the problems and issues before us at this Regional Conference , I wish to note a small item in the Summary Report as it refers to the District of Columbia .	CS VBG IN PP$ NNS IN IN AT NNS CC NNS IN PPO IN DT JJ-TL NN-TL , PPSS VB TO VB AT JJ NN IN AT NN-TL NN-TL CS PPS VBZ IN AT NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL .
That reference in the Report is `` continuation of the trend toward an all-Negro school system '' , a remark apparently occasioned by the increase of Negro school population from 74.1 per cent to 76.7 per cent .	DT NN IN AT NN-TL BEZ `` NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN NN '' , AT NN RB VBN IN AT NN IN NP NN NN IN CD IN NN IN CD IN NN .
I see no real prospects for an all-Negro school population .	PPSS VB AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN NN .
West of Rock Creek Park is still monolithically white and is in fact increasingly white as a result of Georgetown's conversion-by-renovation housing program .	NR IN NN-TL NN-TL NN-TL BEZ RB RB JJ CC BEZ IN NN RB JJ CS AT NN IN NP$ NN VBG NN .
Nearby Foggy Bottom is ousting Negroes .	JJ JJ-TL NN-TL BEZ VBG NPS .
The large acreage in the Southwest Redevelopment area beckons white people -- what with high-priced town houses and elevator apartments .	AT JJ NN IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL NN VBZ JJ NNS -- WDT IN JJ NN NNS CC NN NNS .
The Capitol Hill rehabilitation , like Foggy Bottom , replaces Negroes with whites ( but also replaces some whites with other whites ) .	AT NN-TL NN-TL NN , CS JJ-TL NN-TL , VBZ NPS IN NNS ( CC RB VBZ DTI NNS IN AP NNS ) .
The sharpest break with tradition , the past and present of `` White Ring Around a Black Core '' , may come with the opening of nearby Montgomery County suburbs to Negro residents and , presumably , the consequent conclusion of some whites that they cannot escape the Negro by fleeing to the suburbs .	AT JJT NN IN NN , AT NN CC NN IN `` JJ NN IN AT JJ NN '' , MD VB IN AT NN IN JJ NP-TL NN-TL NNS IN NP NNS CC , RB , AT JJ NN IN DTI NNS CS PPSS MD* VB AT NP IN VBG IN AT NNS .
In fact , short of fleeing to Warrenton , Virginia , or Rockville , Maryland , white people may have to live with Negroes .	IN NN , JJ IN VBG IN NP , NP , CC NP , NP , JJ NNS MD HV TO VB IN NPS .
All of this must be taken into account before the image of an `` all-Negro '' D.C. public school system is conjured up .	ABN IN DT MD BE VBN IN NN CS AT NN IN AT `` JJ '' NP JJ NN NN BEZ VBN RP .
Problems to solve	NNS-HL TO-HL VB-HL
From the Summary Report before us at this Conference , a number of problems are apparent .	IN AT NN-TL NN-TL IN PPO IN DT NN-TL , AT NN IN NNS BER JJ .
They vex us and perplex us but generally do not divide us like the issues which follow the problems .	PPSS VB PPO CC VB PPO CC RB DO * VB PPO CS AT NNS WDT VB AT NNS .
First , how can we step up the desegregation movement ? ?	RB , WRB MD PPSS VB RP AT NN NN . .
It is slow .	PPS BEZ JJ .
I believe we all want more schools where white and Negro together can and do attend .	PPSS VB PPSS ABN VB AP NNS WRB JJ CC NP RB MD CC DO VB .
I believe we all want no child denied admission to a school on account of his color .	PPSS VB PPSS ABN VB AT NN VBN NN IN AT NN IN NN IN PP$ NN .
In general , members of NAIRO would certainly want a child admitted to a school nearest his residence or within his residence zone .	IN JJ , NNS IN NN MD RB VB AT NN VBN IN AT NN IN PP$ NN CC IN PP$ NN NN .
How to achieve this objective is a problem , but we are not divided on what we want .	WRB TO VB DT NN BEZ AT NN , CC PPSS BER * VBN IN WDT PPSS VB .
Second , as we increase the number of desegregated school districts and schools themselves , how can we achieve this action through school board action ? ?	RB , CS PPSS VB AT NN IN VBN NN NNS CC NNS PPLS , WRB MD PPSS VB DT NN IN NN NN NN . .
It may be county school board or state school board action , as well as that of municipal school boards .	PPS MD BE NN NN NN CC NN NN NN NN , QL RB CS DT IN JJ NN NNS .
Correlatively , can we reduce the role of the district courts , so that the action is that of the people of the community or other school district and not that of the law court ? ?	RB , MD PPSS VB AT NN IN AT NN NNS , CS CS AT NN BEZ DT IN AT NNS IN AT NN CC AP NN NN CC * DT IN AT NN NN . .
This is a problem , and I believe there is little difference of opinion that wherever possible a local school board should devise and effect a plan of desegregation .	DT BEZ AT NN , CC PPSS VB EX BEZ AP NN IN NN CS WRB JJ AT JJ NN NN MD VB CC VB AT NN IN NN .

not whether it should be done .	* CS PPS MD BE VBN .

Issue no. 1 .	NN-HL NN-HL CD-HL .-HL
Pupil assignment .	NN-HL NN-HL .-HL
Since on the one hand school desegregation has come in Virginia hand-in-glove with pupil assignment , shall we support the plan ? ?	CS IN AT CD NN NN NN HVZ VBN IN NP RB IN NN NN , MD PPSS VB AT NN . .

Issue no. 2 .	NN-HL NN-HL CD-HL .-HL
Teacher assignment in order to desegregate .	NN-HL NN-HL IN-HL NN-HL TO-HL VB-HL .-HL

We can argue that where residence makes pupil desegregation impossible teacher assignment can create a partially desegregated situation .	PPSS MD VB CS WRB NN VBZ NN NN JJ NN NN MD VB AT RB VBN NN .
Issue no. 3 .	NN-HL NN-HL CD-HL .-HL
The plaintiff in school desegregation cases .	AT-HL NN-HL IN-HL NN-HL NN-HL NNS-HL .-HL
The earlier part of my statement deals with the court orders that resulted in desegregation .	AT JJR NN IN PP$ NN VBZ IN AT NN NNS WPS VBD IN NN .

In thousands of school districts , indeed , in the entire State of Mississippi , no plaintiff has come forth .	IN NNS IN NN NNS , RB , IN AT JJ NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL , AT NN HVZ VBN RB .
And I have established that the action of municipal , county , or state school boards or boards of education is small , infinitesimally small in comparison with the number of districts .	CC PPSS HV VBN CS AT NN IN JJ , NN , CC NN NN NNS CC NNS IN NN BEZ JJ , QL JJ IN NN IN AT NN IN NNS .

Issue no. 4 .	NN-HL NN-HL CD-HL .-HL
Withholding of funds to schools that deny children on account of race .	VBG-HL IN-HL NNS-HL IN-HL NNS-HL WPS-HL VB-HL NNS-HL IN-HL NN-HL IN-HL NN-HL .-HL
This is the Powell Amendment , which in 1957 divided even a `` liberal '' group like the American Veterans Committee ( AVC ) .	DT BEZ AT NP-TL NN-TL , WDT IN CD VBD RB AT `` JJ '' NN CS AT JJ-TL NNS-TL NN-TL ( NP ) .

This is softer than earlier Powell amendments which would have denied funds to all segregated school districts .	DT BEZ JJR CS JJR NP NNS WDT MD HV VBN NNS IN ABN VBN NN NNS .
There is nonetheless considerable argument against the clause , softened though it be , on the grounds that Federal aid is so necessary to the public schools .	EX BEZ RB JJ NN IN AT NN , VBN CS PPS BE , IN AT NNS CS JJ-TL NN BEZ QL JJ IN AT JJ NNS .
The Federal funds limitation enlists the support of many , the opposition of quite a few .	AT JJ-TL NNS NN VBZ AT NN IN AP , AT NN IN ABL AT AP .
Issue no. 5 .	NN-HL NN-HL CD-HL .-HL
Required public education .	VBN-HL JJ-HL NN-HL .-HL
Should a political subdivision , state or county or municipality , be required to furnish public education ? ?	MD AT JJ NN , NN CC NN CC NN , BE VBN TO VB JJ NN . .
For the school year , 1959-1960 , the Prince Edward County ( Virginia ) Board of Supervisors voted not to provide funds for public education , and the school board therefore could provide no public education -- for white or Negro children .	IN AT NN NN , CD , AT NN-TL NP-TL NN-TL ( NP ) NN-TL IN-TL NNS-TL VBD * TO VB NNS IN JJ NN , CC AT NN NN RB MD VB AT JJ NN -- IN JJ CC NP NNS .
Is public education in this American democracy of such importance that no child should be denied public education ? ?	BEZ JJ NN IN DT JJ NN IN JJ NN CS AT NN MD BE VBN JJ NN . .
Or is this subject a matter of self-determination , a matter of states rights or county rights ? ?	CC BEZ DT NN AT NN IN NN , AT NN IN NNS NNS CC NN NNS . .

Issue no. 6 .	NN-HL NN-HL CD-HL .-HL

Should the government directly provide education for the children who want public education ? ?	MD AT NN RB VB NN IN AT NNS WPS VB JJ NN . .
The next question is whether board members favor their own social classes in their roles as educational policy-makers .	AT AP NN BEZ CS NN NNS VB PP$ JJ JJ NNS IN PP$ NNS CS JJ NNS .
On the whole , it appears that they do not favor their own social classes in an explicit way .	IN AT JJ , PPS VBZ CS PPSS DO * VB PP$ JJ JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN .
Seldom is there an issue in which class lines can be clearly drawn .	RB BEZ EX AT NN IN WDT NN NNS MD BE RB VBN .
A hypothetical issue of this sort might deal with the establishment of a free public junior college in a community where there already was a good private college which served the middle-class youth adequately but was too expensive for working-class youth .	AT JJ NN IN DT NN MD VB IN AT NN IN AT JJ JJ JJ NN IN AT NN WRB EX RB BEDZ AT JJ JJ NN WDT VBD AT NN NN RB CC BEDZ QL JJ IN NN NN .
In situations of this sort the board generally favors the expansion of free education .	IN NNS IN DT NN AT NN RB VBZ AT NN IN JJ NN .
Campbell studied the records of 172 school board members in twelve western cities over the period of 1931 - 40 and found `` little or no relationship between certain social and economic factors and school board competence '' , as judged by a panel of professional educators who studied the voting records on educational issues .	NP VBD AT NNS IN CD NN NN NNS IN CD JJ NNS IN AT NN IN CD IN CD CC VBD `` AP CC AT NN IN AP JJ CC JJ NNS CC NN NN NN '' , CS VBN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS WPS VBD AT VBG NNS IN JJ NNS .
The few cases of clear favoritism along social-class lines are as likely as not to involve representatives of the working class on the school board who favor some such practice as higher wages for janitors rather than pay increases for teachers , and such issues are not issues of educational policy .	AT AP NNS IN JJ NN IN NN NNS BER QL JJ CS * TO VB NNS IN AT VBG NN IN AT NN NN WPS VB DTI JJ NN CS JJR NNS IN NNS RB CS NN NNS IN NNS , CC JJ NNS BER * NNS IN JJ NN .
In general , it appears that trustees and board members attempt to represent the public interest in their administration of educational policy , and this is made easier by the fact that the dominant values of the society are middle-class values , which are generally thought to be valid for the entire society .	IN JJ , PPS VBZ CS NNS CC NN NNS VB TO VB AT JJ NN IN PP$ NN IN JJ NN , CC DT BEZ VBN JJR IN AT NN CS AT JJ NNS IN AT NN BER NN NNS , WDT BER RB VBN TO BE JJ IN AT JJ NN .
There have been very few cases of explicit conflict of interest between the middle class and any other class in the field of educational policy .	EX HV BEN QL AP NNS IN JJ NN IN NN IN AT JJ NN CC DTI AP NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
If there were more such cases , it would be easier to answer the question whether the policy-makers favor their own social classes .	CS EX BED AP JJ NNS , PPS MD BE JJR TO VB AT NN CS AT NNS VB PP$ JJ JJ NNS .
There is currently a major controversy of public education in which group interests and values are heavily engaged .	EX BEZ RB AT JJ NN IN JJ NN IN WDT NN NNS CC NNS BER RB VBN .
This is the issue of segregated schools in the South .	DT BEZ AT NN IN VBN NNS IN AT NR-TL .
In this case it is primarily a matter of conflict of racial groups rather than social-class groups .	IN DT NN PPS BEZ RB AT NN IN NN IN JJ NNS RB CS NN NNS .
Thus , the white middle and lower classes are arrayed against the Negro middle and lower classes .	RB , AT JJ JJ CC JJR NNS BER VBN IN AT NP JJ CC JJR NNS .
This conflict may be resolved in a way which will suit white middle-class people better than it suits white lower-class people .	DT NN MD BE VBN IN AT NN WDT MD VB JJ NN NNS RBR CS PPS VBZ JJ NN NNS .
If this happens , there may be some class conflict in the South , with school boards and school teachers taking the middle-class position .	CS DT VBZ , EX MD BE DTI NN NN IN AT NR-TL , IN NN NNS CC NN NNS VBG AT NN NN .
The educational profession	AT-HL JJ-HL NN-HL
The members of the educational profession have a major voice in the determination of educational policy , their position being strongest in the universities .	AT NNS IN AT JJ NN HV AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN , PP$ NN BEG JJT IN AT NNS .
They are mostly upper-middle- and lower-middle-class people , with a few in the upper class .	PPSS BER RB JJ CC NN NNS , IN AT AP IN AT JJ NN .
Do they make class-biased decisions ? ?	DO PPSS VB JJ NNS . .
In a society dominated by middle-class values and working in an institution which transmits and strengthens these social values , it is clear that the educational profession must work for the values which are characteristic of the society .	IN AT NN VBN IN NN NNS CC VBG IN AT NN WDT VBZ CC VBZ DTS JJ NNS , PPS BEZ JJ CS AT JJ NN MD VB IN AT NNS WDT BER JJ IN AT NN .
There is no problem here .	EX BEZ AT NN RB .
The problem arises , if it does arise , when the educator has to make a choice or a decision within the area of his professional competence , but which bears some relation to the social structure .	AT NN VBZ , CS PPS DOZ VB , WRB AT NN HVZ TO VB AT NN CC AT NN IN AT NN IN PP$ JJ NN , CC WDT VBZ DTI NN IN AT JJ NN .
For instance , in giving school grades or in making recommendations for the award of a college scholarship , does he consciously or unconsciously favor students of one or another social class ? ?	IN NN , IN VBG NN NNS CC IN VBG NNS IN AT NN IN AT NN NN , DOZ PPS RB CC RB VB NNS IN CD CC DT JJ NN . .
Again , in deciding on the content and method of his teaching , does he favor a curriculum which will make his students stronger competitors in the race for higher economic status , or does he favor a curriculum which strengthens students in other ways ? ?	RB , IN VBG IN AT NN CC NN IN PP$ NN , DOZ PPS VB AT NN WDT MD VB PP$ NNS JJR NNS IN AT NN IN JJR JJ NN , CC DOZ PPS VB AT NN WDT VBZ NNS IN AP NNS . .
The answers to questions such as these certainly depend to some extent upon the educator's own social-class position and also upon his social history , as well as upon his personality and what he conceives his mission to be as an educator .	AT NNS IN NNS JJ CS DTS RB VB IN DTI NN IN AT NN$ JJ NN NN CC RB IN PP$ JJ NN , QL RB CS IN PP$ NN CC WDT PPS VBZ PP$ NN TO BE CS AT NN .
In a set of case studies of teachers with various social-class backgrounds , Wattenberg illustrates a variety of approaches to students and to teaching which depend upon the teacher's personality as well as on his social-class background .	IN AT NN IN NN NNS IN NNS IN AP NN NNS , NP VBZ AT NN IN NNS IN NNS CC IN VBG WDT VB IN AT NN$ NN QL RB CS IN PP$ NN NN .
One upward-mobile teacher may be a hard taskmaster for lower-class pupils because she wants them to develop the attitudes and skills that will enable them to climb , while another upward-mobile teacher may be a very permissive person with lower-class pupils because he knows their disadvantages and deprivations at home , and he hopes to encourage them by friendly treatment .	CD JJ NN MD BE AT JJ NN IN NN NNS CS PPS VBZ PPO TO VB AT NNS CC NNS WPS MD VB PPO TO VB , CS DT JJ NN MD BE AT QL JJ NN IN NN NNS CS PPS VBZ PP$ NNS CC NNS IN NN , CC PPS VBZ TO VB PPO IN JJ NN .
One social-class factor which plays a large part in educational policy today is the fact that a great many school and college teachers are upward mobile from urban lower-class and lower-middle-class families .	CD NN NN WDT VBZ AT JJ NN IN JJ NN NR BEZ AT NN CS AT QL AP NN CC NN NNS BER RB JJ IN JJ NN CC NN NNS .
Their own experience in the social system influences their work and attitudes as teachers .	PP$ JJ NN IN AT JJ NN VBZ PP$ NN CC NNS CS NNS .
While this influence is a complex matter , depending upon personality factors in the individual as well as upon his social-class experience , there probably are some general statements about social-class background and educational policy that can be made with a fair degree of truth .	CS DT NN BEZ AT JJ NN , IN IN NN NNS IN AT NN QL RB CS IN PP$ NN NN , EX RB BER DTI JJ NNS IN NN NN CC JJ NN WPS MD BE VBN IN AT JJ NN IN NN .
Teachers who have been upward mobile probably see education as most valuable for their students if it serves students as it has served them ; ;	NNS WPS HV BEN RB JJ RB VB NN CS QL JJ IN PP$ NNS CS PPS VBZ NNS CS PPS HVZ VBN PPO . .
that is , they are likely to favor a kind of education that has vocational-advancement value .	DT BEZ , PPSS BER JJ TO VB AT NN IN NN WPS HVZ NN NN .
This does not necessarily mean that such teachers will favor vocational education , as contrasted with liberal education , but they are likely to favor an approach to liberal education which has a maximal vocational-advancement value , as against a kind of `` pure '' liberal education that is not designed to help people get better jobs .	DT DOZ * RB VB CS JJ NNS MD VB JJ NN , CS VBN IN JJ NN , CC PPSS BER JJ TO VB AT NN IN JJ NN WDT HVZ AT JJ NN NN , CS IN AT NN IN `` JJ '' JJ NN WPS BEZ * VBN TO VB NNS VB JJR NNS .
There is no doubt that higher education since World War 2 , has moved away from `` pure '' liberal education toward greater emphasis on technology and specialization .	EX BEZ AT NN CS JJR NN IN NN-TL NN-TL CD-TL , HVZ VBN RB IN `` JJ '' JJ NN IN JJR NN IN NN CC NN .
There are several causes for this , one being rapid economic development with increasing numbers of of middle-class positions requiring engineering or scientific training .	EX BER AP NNS IN DT , CD BEG JJ JJ NN IN VBG NNS IN IN NN NNS VBG VBG CC JJ NN .
But another cause may lie in the experience of so many new postwar faculty members with their own use of education as a means of social advancement .	CC DT NN MD VB IN AT NN IN QL AP JJ JJ NN NNS IN PP$ JJ NN IN NN CS AT NN IN JJ NN .
Compared with the college and university faculty members of the period from 1900 to 1930 , the new postwar faculty members consist of more children of immigrants and more children of urban working-class fathers .	VBN IN AT NN CC NN NN NNS IN AT NN IN CD IN CD , AT JJ JJ NN NNS VB IN AP NNS IN NNS CC AP NNS IN JJ NN NNS .
Their experience is quite in contrast with that of children of upper- and upper-middle-class native-born parents , who are more likely to regard education as good for its own sake and to discount the vocational emphases in the curriculum .	PP$ NN BEZ RB IN NN IN DT IN NNS IN JJ CC NN JJ NNS , WPS BER QL JJ TO VB NN CS JJ IN PP$ JJ NN CC TO VB AT JJ NNS IN AT NN .
The `` public interest '' groups	AT `` JJ NN '' NNS
Educational policies are formed by several groups who are officially or unofficially appointed to act in the public interest .	JJ NNS BER VBN IN AP NNS WPS BER RB CC RB VBN TO VB IN AT JJ NN .
Legislators are one such group , and state legislators have major responsibility for educational legislation .	NNS BER CD JJ NN , CC NN NNS HV JJ NN IN JJ NN .
They generally vote so as to serve their own constituency , and if the constituency should be solidly middle class or solidly lower class , they might be expected to vote and work for middle- or for lower-class interests in education .	PPSS RB VB CS CS TO VB PP$ JJ NN , CC CS AT NN MD BE RB JJ NN CC RB JJR NN , PPSS MD BE VBN TO VB CC VB IN JJ CC IN NN NNS IN NN .
However , there are relatively few such political constituencies , and , as has been pointed out , there is seldom a clear-cut distinction between the educational interests of one social class and those of another .	RB , EX BER QL AP JJ JJ NNS , CC , CS HVZ BEN VBN RP , EX BEZ RB AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NNS IN CD JJ NN CC DTS IN DT .
Another public interest group is the commission of laymen or educators which is appointed to study an educational problem and to make recommendations .	DT JJ NN NN BEZ AT NN IN NNS CC NNS WDT BEZ VBN TO VB AT JJ NN CC TO VB NNS .
Generally these commissions work earnestly to represent the interest of the entire society , as they conceive it .	RB DTS NNS VB RB TO VB AT NN IN AT JJ NN , CS PPSS VB PPO .
Nevertheless , their conclusions and recommendations cannot please everybody , and they often represent a particular economic or political point of view .	RB , PP$ NNS CC NNS MD* VB PN , CC PPSS RB VB AT AP JJ CC JJ NN IN NN .
For instance , there have been two Presidential Commissions on higher education since World War 2 .	IN NN , EX HV BEN CD JJ-TL NNS-TL IN JJR NN IN NN-TL NN-TL CD .
President Truman's Commission on Higher Education tended to take a liberal , expansionist position , while President Eisenhower's Committee on Education Beyond the High School was slightly more conservative .	NN-TL NP$ NN-TL IN-TL JJR-TL NN-TL VBD TO VB AT JJ , NN NN , CS NN-TL NP$ NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL RB-TL AT-TL JJ-TL NN-TL BEDZ QL QL JJ .
Both Commissions consisted of upper-middle- and upper-class people , who attempted to act in the public interest .	ABX NNS-TL VBD IN JJ CC NN NNS , WPS VBD TO VB IN AT JJ NN .
An example of a more definite class bias is noted in proceedings of the Commission on the Financing of Higher Education sponsored by the Association of American Universities and supported by the Rockefeller Foundation and the Carnegie Corporation .	AT NN IN AT QL JJ NN NN BEZ VBN IN NNS IN AT NN-TL IN-TL AT-TL NN-TL IN-TL JJR-TL NN-TL VBN IN AT NN-TL IN-TL JJ NNS-TL CC VBN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL CC AT NP-TL NN-TL .
This Commission recommended against the use of federal government funds for the assistance of private universities and against a broad program of government-supported scholarships .	DT NN-TL VBD IN AT NN IN JJ NN NNS IN AT NN IN JJ NNS CC IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS .
This might be said to be an upper- or an upper-middle-class bias , but the Commission published as one of its staff studies a book by Byron S. Hollingshead entitled Who Should Go To College ? ?	DT NN BE VBN TO BE AT JJ CC AT NN NN , CC AT NN-TL VBD CS CD IN PP$ NN NNS AT NN IN NP NP NP VBN WPS-TL MD-TL VB-TL IN-TL NN-TL . .
Which recommended a federal government scholarship program .	WDT VBD AT JJ NN NN NN .
Furthermore , the Commission set up the Council for Financial Aid to Education as a means of encouraging private business to increase its support of private higher education .	RB , AT NN-TL VBD RP AT NN-TL IN-TL JJ-TL NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL CS AT NN IN VBG JJ NN TO VB PP$ NN IN JJ JJR NN .
Thus , the Commission acted with a sense of social responsibility within the area of its own convictions about the problem of government support to private education .	RB , AT NN-TL VBD IN AT NN IN JJ NN IN AT NN IN PP$ JJ NNS IN AT NN IN NN NN IN JJ NN .
Then there are the trustees and officers of the great educational foundations , who inevitably exert an influence on educational decisions by their support or refusal to support various educational programs , experiments , and demonstrations .	RB EX BER AT NNS CC NNS IN AT JJ JJ NNS , WPS RB VB AT NN IN JJ NNS IN PP$ NN CC NN TO VB AP JJ NNS , NNS , CC NNS .
These people are practically always upper- or upper-middle-class persons , who attempt to act in what they regard as the interest of the entire society .	DTS NNS BER QL RB JJ CC NN NNS , WPS VB TO VB IN WDT PPSS VB CS AT NN IN AT JJ NN .
Finally there are the parent organizations and the laymen's organizations such as the National Association of Parents and Teachers , and the Citizens Committee on Public Schools .	RB EX BER AT NN NNS CC AT NNS$ NNS JJ CS AT JJ-TL NN-TL IN-TL NNS-TL CC-TL NNS-TL , CC AT NNS-TL NN-TL IN-TL JJ-TL NNS-TL .
These have an upper-middle-class leadership and a middle-class membership , with rare exceptions , where working-class parents are active in local P.-T.A. matters .	DTS HV AT NN NN CC AT NN NN , IN JJ NNS , WRB NN NNS BER JJ IN JJ NP NNS .
Like the other policy-making groups , these are middle class in their educational attitudes , and they attempt to act in the general public interest , as they see it .	CS AT AP JJ NNS , DTS BER JJ NN IN PP$ JJ NNS , CC PPSS VB TO VB IN AT JJ JJ NN , CS PPSS VB PPO .
In general , it appears that educational decisions and educational policies are made by people who intend to act in the interests of the society as a whole .	IN JJ , PPS VBZ CS JJ NNS CC JJ NNS BER VBN IN NNS WPS VB TO VB IN AT NNS IN AT NN CS AT NN .
They are predominantly middle- and upper-class people , and undoubtedly share the values and attitudes of those classes .	PPSS BER RB JJ CC NN NNS , CC RB VB AT NNS CC NNS IN DTS NNS .
They may be unaware of the existence of lower-class values and consequently fail to take them into account .	PPSS MD BE JJ IN AT NN IN NN NNS CC RB VB TO VB PPO IN NN .
But there is very little frank and conscious espousal of the interests of any one social class by the people who have the power to make decisions in education .	CC EX BEZ QL AP JJ CC JJ NN IN AT NNS IN DTI CD JJ NN IN AT NNS WPS HV AT NN TO VB NNS IN NN .
They think of themselves as trustees for the entire society and try to serve the entire society .	PPSS VB IN PPLS CS NNS IN AT JJ NN CC VB TO VB AT JJ NN .
Attempts to influence social structure through education	NNS-HL TO-HL VB-HL JJ-HL NN-HL IN-HL NN-HL
Educational policy in the United States has as an explicit goal the maximization of economic and cultural opportunity .	JJ NN IN AT VBN-TL NNS-TL HVZ CS AT JJ NN AT NN IN JJ CC JJ NN .
In so far as this goal is achieved , the society becomes more fluid , artificial barriers to social mobility are reduced , and people at the lower end of the social hierarchy share more fully in the material and cultural goods of society .	IN QL RB CS DT NN BEZ VBN , AT NN VBZ QL JJ , JJ NNS IN JJ NN BER VBN , CC NNS IN AT JJR NN IN AT JJ NN VB QL RB IN AT NN CC JJ NNS IN NN .
On the other hand , there is a counterbalancing purpose in education which is to pass on the advantages of the parents to their children .	IN AT AP NN , EX BEZ AT VBG NN IN NN WDT BEZ TO VB RP AT NNS IN AT NNS IN PP$ NNS .
This leads to efforts at exclusiveness through private schools and to the maintenance of social stratification in the schools .	DT VBZ IN NNS IN NN IN JJ NNS CC IN AT NN IN JJ NN IN AT NNS .
Both of these purposes exist side by side without much overt conflict under present conditions .	ABX IN DTS NNS VB NN IN NN IN AP JJ NN IN JJ NNS .
Maximizing economic and cultural opportunity	VBG-HL JJ-HL CC-HL JJ-HL NN-HL
The broad expansion of free education results both in raising the average economic and cultural level of the society and in promoting fluidity within the social structure .	AT JJ NN IN JJ NN VBZ ABX IN VBG AT JJ JJ CC JJ NN IN AT NN CC IN VBG NN IN AT JJ NN .
Fifty years ago the general raising of the school-leaving age to sixteen was an example of this movement .	CD NNS RB AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN IN CD BEDZ AT NN IN DT NN .
During the past decade the program has been carried on through expansion of free higher education in state universities , state colleges , and community colleges .	IN AT AP NN AT NN HVZ BEN VBN RP IN NN IN JJ JJR NN IN NN NNS , NN NNS , CC NN NNS .
The reaffirmation of American faith in the comprehensive high school , as expressed in the Conant study , is another indication of the liveliness of the ideal of maximizing opportunity through the equalizing of educational opportunity .	AT NN IN JJ NN IN AT JJ JJ NN , CS VBN IN AT NP NN , BEZ DT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN IN VBG NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
The recent federal government's student-loan program is another step in the direction of making higher education more available to lower-status youth .	AT JJ JJ NN$ NN NN BEZ DT NN IN AT NN IN VBG JJR NN QL JJ IN NN NN .
It is probably more effective than the expanded scholarship programs of the past decade , because the scholarship programs mainly aided the students with the best academic records ( who were usually middle-class ) , and these students tended to use the scholarship funds to go to more expensive colleges .	PPS BEZ RB QL JJ CS AT VBN NN NNS IN AT AP NN , CS AT NN NNS RB VBD AT NNS IN AT JJT JJ NNS ( WPS BED RB NN ) , CC DTS NNS VBD TO VB AT NN NNS TO VB IN QL JJ NNS .
Meanwhile , the private colleges have increased their tuition rates so much that they have raised an economic barrier which dwarfs their scholarship funds .	RB , AT JJ NNS HV VBN PP$ NN NNS QL RB CS PPSS HV VBN AT JJ NN WDT VBZ PP$ NN NNS .
The gains in educational opportunity during the past decade have taken place largely in the publicly supported institutions .	AT NNS IN JJ NN IN AT AP NN HV VBN NN RB IN AT RB VBN NNS .
Unfortunately , however , and for reasons to be discussed in the following chapter , no rate relationships can be made completely nondiscriminatory as long as all or some of the rates must be set above marginal costs in order to yield adequate revenues .	RB , RB , CC IN NNS TO BE VBN IN AT VBG NN , AT NN NNS MD BE VBN QL JJ QL RB CS ABN CC DTI IN AT NNS MD BE VBN IN JJ NNS IN NN TO VB JJ NNS .
And this fact may explain some of the disagreements among the experts as to the more rational formulas for the apportionment of total costs among different units of service .	CC DT NN MD VB DTI IN AT NNS IN AT NNS IN IN AT QL JJ NNS IN AT NN IN JJ NNS IN JJ NNS IN NN .
One such disagreement , which will receive attention in this next chapter , concerns the question whether rates for different kinds of service , in order to avoid the attribute of discrimination , must be made directly proportional to marginal costs , or whether they should be based instead on differences in marginal costs .	CD JJ NN , WDT MD VB NN IN DT AP NN , VBZ AT NN CS NNS IN JJ NNS IN NN , IN NN TO VB AT NN IN NN , MD BE VBN RB JJ IN JJ NNS , CC CS PPSS MD BE VBN RB IN NNS IN JJ NNS .
Here , the choice is that between the horns of a dilemma .	RB , AT NN BEZ DT IN AT NNS IN AT NN .
Two major types of fully distributed cost analysis	CD-HL JJ-HL NNS-HL IN-HL RB-HL VBN-HL NN-HL NN-HL
1 .	CD-HL .-HL
The double-step type	AT-HL NN-HL NN-HL
Despite an ambiguity due to its failure clearly to define `` relative costs '' , the above exposition of fully distributed costing goes about as far as one can go toward expressing the basic philosophy of the practice .	IN AT NN JJ IN PP$ NN RB TO VB `` JJ NNS '' , AT JJ NN IN RB VBN NN VBZ RB QL RB CS PN MD VB IN VBG AT JJ NN IN AT NN .
For more explicit expositions , one must distinguish different types of analyses .	IN QL JJ NNS , PN MD VB JJ NNS IN NNS .
By all means the most important distinction is that between those total-cost apportionments which superimpose a distribution of admittedly unallocable cost residues on estimates of incremental or marginal costs , and those other apportionments which recognize no difference between true cost allocation and mere total-cost distribution .	IN ABN NNS AT QL JJ NN BEZ DT IN DTS NN NNS WDT VB AT NN IN RB JJ NN NNS IN NNS IN JJ CC JJ NNS , CC DTS AP NNS WDT VB AT NN IN JJ NN NN CC JJ NN NN .
The first , or double-step , type might also be called the `` railroad type '' because of its application to railroads ( and other transportation agencies ) by the Cost Section of the Interstate Commerce Commission .	AT OD , CC NN , NN MD RB BE VBN AT `` NN NN '' RB IN PP$ NN IN NNS ( CC AP NN NNS ) IN AT NN-TL NN-TL IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL NN-TL .
The Cost Section distinguishes between ( directly ) variable costs and constant costs in a manner noted in the preceding chapter .	AT NN-TL NN-TL VBZ IN ( RB ) JJ NNS CC JJ NNS IN AT NN VBN IN AT VBG NN .
The variable costs alone are assigned to the different units of freight traffic as representing `` long-run out-of-pocket costs '' -- a term with a meaning here not distinctly different from that of the economist's `` long-run marginal costs '' .	AT JJ NNS RB BER VBN IN AT JJ NNS IN NN NN CS VBG `` NN JJ NNS '' -- AT NN IN AT NN RB * RB JJ IN DT IN AT NN$ `` NN JJ NNS '' .
There remains a residue of total costs , or total `` revenue requirements '' which , since it is found to behave as if it were constant over substantial variations in traffic density , is strictly unallocable on a cost-finding basis .	EX VBZ AT NN IN JJ NNS , CC JJ `` NN NNS '' WDT , CS PPS BEZ VBN TO VB CS CS PPS BED JJ IN JJ NNS IN NN NN , BEZ RB JJ IN AT JJ NN .
Nevertheless , because the Cost Section has felt impelled to make some kind of a distribution of total costs , it has apportioned this residue , which it sometimes calls `` burden '' , among the units of carload traffic on a basis ( partly ton , partly ton-mile ) which is concededly quite arbitrary from the standpoint of cost determination .	RB , CS AT NN-TL NN-TL HVZ VBN VBN TO VB DTI NN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS , PPS HVZ VBN DT NN , WDT PPS RB VBZ `` NN '' , IN AT NNS IN NN NN IN AT NN ( RB NN , RB NN ) WDT BEZ RB QL JJ IN AT NN IN NN NN .
In recent years , this burden ( which includes allowances for revenue deficiencies in the passenger business and in less-than-carload freight traffic ! !	IN JJ NNS , DT NN ( WDT VBZ NNS IN NN NNS IN AT NN NN CC IN JJ NN NN . .
) has amounted to about one third of those total revenue requirements which the carload freight business is supposed to be called upon to meet .	) HVZ VBN IN RB CD NN IN DTS JJ NN NNS WDT AT NN NN NN BEZ VBN TO BE VBN RB TO VB .
Since this book is concerned only incidentally with railroad rates , it will not attempt to analyze the methods by which the staff of the Interstate Commerce Commission has estimated out-of-pocket costs and apportioned residue costs .	CS DT NN BEZ VBN RB RB IN NN NNS , PPS MD * VB TO VB AT NNS IN WDT AT NN IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL NN-TL HVZ VBN JJ NNS CC VBN NN NNS .
Suffice it to say that the usefulness of the latter apportionment is questionable .	VB PPO TO VB CS AT NN IN AT AP NN BEZ JJ .
But in any event , full credit should be given to the Cost Section for its express and overt recognition of a vital distinction too often ignored in utility-cost analyses : namely , that between a cost allocation designed to reflect the actual behavior of costs in response to changes in rates of output of different classes of utility service ; ;	CC IN DTI NN , JJ NN MD BE VBN IN AT NN-TL NN-TL IN PP$ JJ CC JJ NN IN AT JJ NN QL RB VBN IN NN NNS : RB , DT IN AT NN NN VBN TO VB AT JJ NN IN NNS IN NN IN NNS IN NNS IN NN IN JJ NNS IN NN NN . .
and a mere cost apportionment which somehow spreads among the classes and units of service even those costs that are strictly unallocable from the standpoint of specific cost determination .	CC AT JJ NN NN WDT RB VBZ IN AT NNS CC NNS IN NN RB DTS NNS WPS BER RB JJ IN AT NN IN JJ NN NN .
2 .	CD-HL .-HL
The single-step type	AT-HL NN-HL NN-HL
We turn now to a type of fully distributed cost analysis which , unlike the `` railroad type '' , draws no distinction between cost allocation and cost apportionment : the single-step type .	PPSS VB RB IN AT NN IN RB VBN NN NN WDT , IN AT `` NN NN '' , VBZ AT NN IN NN NN CC NN NN : AT NN NN .
It might be called the `` public utility '' type because of the considerable use to which it has been put in gas and electric utility rate cases .	PPS MD BE VBN AT `` JJ NN '' NN RB IN AT JJ NN IN WDT PPS HVZ BEN VBN IN NN CC NN NN NN NNS .
Here no attempt is made , first to determine out-of-pocket or marginal costs and then to superimpose on these costs `` reasonably distributed '' residues of total costs .	RB AT NN BEZ VBN , RB TO VB JJ CC JJ NNS CC RB TO VB IN DTS NNS `` RB VBN '' NNS IN JJ NNS .
Instead , all of the total costs are treated as variable costs , although these costs are divided into costs that are deemed to be functions of different variables .	RB , ABN IN AT JJ NNS BER VBN CS JJ NNS , CS DTS NNS BER VBN IN NNS WPS BER VBN TO BE NNS IN JJ NNS .
Moreover , whereas in Interstate Commerce Commission parlance `` variable cost '' means a cost deemed to vary in direct proportion to changes in rate of output , in the type of analysis now under review `` variable cost '' has been used more broadly , so as to cover costs which , while a function of some one variable ( such as output of energy , or number of customers ) , are not necessarily a linear function .	RB , CS IN JJ-TL NN-TL NN-TL NN `` JJ NN '' NNS AT NN VBN TO VB IN JJ NN IN NNS IN NN IN NN , IN AT NN IN NN RB IN NN `` JJ NN '' HVZ BEN VBN QL RB , CS CS TO VB NNS WDT , CS AT NN IN DTI CD JJ ( JJ CS NN IN NN , CC NN IN NNS ) , BER * RB AT JJ NN .
As already noted in an earlier paragraph , the more familiar cost analyses of utility enterprises or utility systems divide the total costs among a number of major classes of service , such as residential , commercial , industrial power , street lighting , etc. .	CS RB VBN IN AT JJR NN , AT QL JJ NN NNS IN NN NNS CC NN NNS VB AT JJ NNS IN AT NN IN JJ NNS IN NN , JJ CS JJ , JJ , JJ NN , NN NN , RB .
This `` grand division '' permits many costs to be assigned in their entirety to some one class , such as street lighting , or at least to be excluded completely from some important class or classes .	DT `` JJ NN '' VBZ AP NNS TO BE VBN IN PP$ NN IN DTI CD NN , JJ CS NN NN , CC IN AP TO BE VBN RB IN DTI JJ NN CC NNS .
High-tension industrial power service , for example , would not be charged with any share of the maintenance costs or capital costs of the low-tension distribution lines .	NN JJ NN NN , IN NN , MD * BE VBN IN DTI NN IN AT NN NNS CC NN NNS IN AT NN NN NNS .
But the major portions of the total costs of a utility business are common or joint to all , or nearly all , classes of customers ; ;	CC AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ NNS IN AT NN NN BER JJ CC JJ IN ABN , CC RB ABN , NNS IN NNS . .
and these costs must somehow be apportioned among the various classes and then must somehow be reapportioned among the units of service in order to report unit costs that can serve as tentative measures of reasonable rates .	CC DTS NNS MD RB BE VBN IN AT AP NNS CC RB MD RB BE VBN IN AT NNS IN NN IN NN TO VB NN NNS WPS MD VB CS JJ NNS IN JJ NNS .
The general basis on which these common costs are assigned to differently measured units of service will be illustrated by the following highly simplified problem of an electric-utility cost analysis .	AT JJ NN IN WDT DTS JJ NNS BER VBN IN RB VBN NNS IN NN MD BE VBN IN AT VBG QL VBN NN IN AT NN NN NN .
But before turning to this example , we must distinguish two subtypes of analysis , both of which belong to the single-step type rather than to the double-step type .	CC CS VBG IN DT NN , PPSS MD VB CD NNS IN NN , ABX IN WDT VB IN AT NN NN RB CS IN AT NN NN .
In the first subtype , the analyst ( following the practice of railroad analysis in this particular respect ) distributes both total operating costs and total annual capital costs ( including an allowance for `` cost of capital '' or `` fair rate of return '' ) among the different classes and units of service .	IN AT OD NN , AT NN ( VBG AT NN IN NN NN IN DT AP NN ) VBZ ABX JJ VBG NNS CC JJ JJ NN NNS ( IN AT NN IN `` NN IN NN '' CC `` JJ NN IN NN '' ) IN AT JJ NNS CC NNS IN NN .
Here , an apportionment , say , of $5,000,000 of the total costs to residential service as a class would include an allowance of perhaps 6 per cent as the cost of whatever capital is deemed to have been devoted to the service of the residential consumers .	RB , AT NN , UH , IN NNS IN AT JJ NNS IN JJ NN CS AT NN MD VB AT NN IN RB CD IN NN CS AT NN IN WDT NN BEZ VBN TO HV BEN VBN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NNS .
But in the second subtype , which I take to be the one more frequently applied , only the operating expenses and not the `` cost of capital '' or `` fair return '' are apportioned directly among the various classes of service .	CC IN AT OD NN , WDT PPSS VB TO BE AT CD QL RB VBN , RB AT VBG NNS CC * AT `` NN IN NN '' CC `` JJ NN '' BER VBN RB IN AT AP NNS IN NN .
To be sure , the capital investments in ( or , alternatively , the estimated `` fair values '' of ) the plant and equipment are apportioned among the different classes , as are also the gross revenues received from the sales of the different services .	TO BE JJ , AT NN NNS IN ( CC , RB , AT VBN `` JJ NNS '' IN ) AT NN CC NN BER VBN IN AT JJ NNS , CS BER RB AT JJ NNS VBN IN AT NNS IN AT JJ NNS .
But any resulting excess of revenues received from a given class of service over the operating costs imputed to this class is reported as a `` return '' realized on the capital investment attributed to the same service .	CC DTI VBG NN IN NNS VBN IN AT VBN NN IN NN IN AT VBG NNS VBN IN DT NN BEZ VBN CS AT `` NN '' VBN IN AT NN NN VBN IN AT AP NN .
Thus , during any given year ( A ) if the revenues from the residential service are $7,000,000 , ( B ) if the operating expenses imputed to this class of service come to $5,000,000 , and ( C ) if the net investment in ( or value of ) the plant and equipment deemed devoted to this service amounts to $30,000,000 , the cost analyst will report that residential service , in the aggregate , has yielded a return of $2,000,000 or 6-2/3 per cent .	RB , IN DTI VBN NN ( NP ) CS AT NNS IN AT JJ NN BER NNS , ( NP ) CS AT VBG NNS VBN IN DT NN IN NN VB IN NNS , CC ( NP ) CS AT JJ NN IN ( CC NN IN ) AT NN CC NN VBN VBN IN DT NN VBZ IN NNS , AT NN NN MD VB CS JJ NN , IN AT NN , HVZ VBN AT NN IN NNS CC CD IN NN .
Other services will show different rates of return , some probably much lower and some higher .	AP NNS MD VB JJ NNS IN NN , DTI RB QL JJR CC DTI JJR .
There are obvious reasons of convenience for this practice of excluding `` cost of capital '' from the direct apportionment of annual costs among the different classes of service -- notably , the avoidance of the controversial question what rate of return should be held to constitute `` cost of capital '' or `` fair rate of return '' .	EX BER JJ NNS IN NN IN DT NN IN VBG `` NN IN NN '' IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS IN AT JJ NNS IN NN -- RB , AT NN IN AT JJ NN WDT NN IN NN MD BE VBN TO VB `` NN IN NN '' CC `` JJ NN IN NN '' .
But the practice is likely to be misleading , since it may seem to support a conclusion that , as long as the revenues from any class of service cover the imputed operating expenses plus some return on capital investment , however low , the rates of charge for this service are compensatory .	CC AT NN BEZ JJ TO BE VBG , CS PPS MD VB TO VB AT NN CS , QL RB CS AT NNS IN DTI NN IN NN VB AT VBN VBG NNS IN DTI NN IN NN NN , WQL JJ , AT NNS IN NN IN DT NN BER JJ .
Needless to say , any such inference would be quite unwarranted .	JJ TO VB , DTI JJ NN MD BE QL JJ .
For the reason just suggested , I shall assume the use of the first subtype of fully distributed cost apportionment in the following simplified example .	IN AT NN RB VBN , PPSS MD VB AT NN IN AT OD NN IN RB VBN NN NN IN AT VBG VBN NN .
That is to say , an allowance for `` cost of capital '' will be assumed to be included directly in the cost apportionment .	DT BEZ TO VB , AT NN IN `` NN IN NN '' MD BE VBN TO BE VBN RB IN AT NN NN .
Three-part analysis of the costs of an electric utility business	JJ-HL NN-HL IN-HL AT-HL NNS-HL IN-HL AT-HL NN-HL NN-HL NN-HL
In order to simplify the exposition of a typical fully apportioned cost analysis , let us assume the application of the analysis to an electric utility company supplying a single city with power generated by its own steam-generation plant .	IN NN TO VB AT NN IN AT JJ RB VBN NN NN , VB PPO VB AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN NN NN VBG AT AP NN IN NN VBN IN PP$ JJ NN NN .
Let us also assume the existence of only one class or type of service , all of which is supplied at the same voltage , phase , etc. to residential , commercial , and industrial customers .	VB PPO RB VB AT NN IN RB CD NN CC NN IN NN , ABN IN WDT BEZ VBN IN AT AP NN , NN , RB IN JJ , JJ , CC JJ NNS .
This latter assumption will permit us to center attention on the most controversial aspect of modern public utility cost analysis -- the distinction among costs that are functions of outputs of the same service measured along different dimensions .	DT AP NN MD VB PPO TO VB NN IN AT QL JJ NN IN JJ JJ NN NN NN -- AT NN IN NNS WPS BER NNS IN NNS IN AT AP NN VBN IN JJ NNS .
Since the company under review is supplying what we are here regarding as only one kind of service , we might suppose that the problem of total cost apportionment would be very simple ; ;	CS AT NN IN NN BEZ VBG WDT PPSS BER RB VBG CS RB CD NN IN NN , PPSS MD VB CS AT NN IN JJ NN NN MD BE QL JJ . .
indeed , that it would be limited to a finding of the total annual operating and capital costs of the business , followed by a calculation of this total in terms of annual cost per kilowatt-hour of consumption .	RB , CS PPS MD BE VBN IN AT NN IN AT JJ JJ VBG CC NN NNS IN AT NN , VBN IN AT NN IN DT NN IN NNS IN JJ NN IN NN IN NN .
In fact , however , the problem is not so simple .	IN NN , RB , AT NN BEZ * QL JJ .
For a statement of costs per kilowatt-hour would ignore the fact that many of these costs are not a function of kilowatt-hour output ( or consumption ) of energy .	CS AT NN IN NNS IN NN MD VB AT NN CS AP IN DTS NNS BER * AT NN IN NN NN ( CC NN ) IN NN .
A recognition of multiple cost functions is therefore required .	AT NN IN JJ NN NNS BEZ RB VBN .
The simplest division , and the one most frequently used ( with subdivisions ) in gas and electric rate cases , is a threefold division of the total operating and capital costs into `` customer costs '' , `` energy '' or `` volumetric costs '' , and `` demand '' or `` capacity '' costs .	AT JJT NN , CC AT CD QL RB VBN ( IN NNS ) IN NN CC NN NN NNS , BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT JJ VBG CC NN NNS IN `` NN NNS '' , `` NN '' CC `` JJ NNS '' , CC `` NN '' CC `` NN '' NNS .
If this threefold division of costs were to have its counterpart in the actual rates of charge for service , as it actually does have in some rates , there would result a three-part rate for any one class of service .	CS DT JJ NN IN NNS BED TO HV PP$ NN IN AT JJ NNS IN NN IN NN , CS PPS RB DOZ HV IN DTI NNS , EX MD VB AT JJ NN IN DTI CD NN IN NN .
For example , the monthly bill of a residential consumer might be the sum of a $1 customer charge , a $5 charge for 250 kilowatt-hours of energy at	IN NN , AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN MD BE AT NN IN AT NN NN NN , AT NN NN IN CD NNS IN NN IN
per kilowatt-hour , and a $2 charge for a maximum demand of 2 kilowatts during the month at the rate of $1 per kilowatt -- a total bill of $8 for that month .	IN NN , CC AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN IN CD NNS IN AT NN IN AT NN IN NN IN NN -- AT JJ NN IN NNS IN DT NN .
But our present interest lies in the measurement of costs of service , and only indirectly in rates that may or may not be designed to cover these costs .	CC PP$ JJ NN VBZ IN AT NN IN NNS IN NN , CC RB RB IN NNS WPS MD CC MD * BE VBN TO VB DTS NNS .
Let us therefore consider each of the three types of cost in turn , recognizing that this simplified classification is used only for illustrative purposes ; ;	VB PPO RB VB DT IN AT CD NNS IN NN IN NN , VBG CS DT VBN NN BEZ VBN RB IN JJ NNS . .
costs actually vary in much more complex ways .	NNS RB VB IN QL QL JJ NNS .
1 .	CD-HL .-HL
The customer costs	AT-HL NN-HL NNS-HL
These are those operating and capital costs found to vary with number of customers regardless , or almost regardless , of power consumption .	DTS BER DTS VBG CC NN NNS VBN TO VB IN NN IN NNS RB , CC RB RB , IN NN NN .
Included as a minimum are the costs of metering and billing along with whatever other expenses the company must incur in taking on another consumer .	VBN CS AT NN BER AT NNS IN VBG CC NN RB IN WDT AP NNS AT NN MD VB IN VBG RP DT NN .
These minimum costs may come to $1 per month , more or less , for residential and small commercial customers , although they are substantially higher for large industrial users , who require more costly connections and metering devices .	DTS JJ NNS MD VB IN NN IN NN , AP CC AP , IN JJ CC JJ JJ NNS , CS PPSS BER QL JJR IN JJ JJ NNS , WPS VB QL JJ NNS CC VBG NNS .
While costs on this order are sometimes separately charged for in residential and commercial rates , in the form of a mere `` service charge '' , they are more frequently wholly or partly covered by a minimum charge which entitles the consumer to a very small amount of gas or electricity with no further payment .	CS NNS IN DT NN BER RB RB VBN IN IN JJ CC JJ NNS , IN AT NN IN AT JJ `` NN NN '' , PPSS BER QL RB RB CC RB VBN IN AT JJ NN WDT VBZ AT NN IN AT QL JJ NN IN NN CC NN IN AT AP NN .
But the really controversial aspect of customer-cost imputation arises because of the cost analyst's frequent practice of including , not just those costs that can be definitely earmarked as incurred for the benefit of specific customers but also a substantial fraction of the annual maintenance and capital costs of the secondary ( low-voltage ) distribution system -- a fraction equal to the estimated annual costs of a hypothetical system of minimum capacity .	CC AT QL JJ NN IN NN NN VBZ RB IN AT NN NN$ JJ NN IN VBG , * RB DTS NNS WPS MD BE RB VBN CS VBN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS CC RB AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN CC NN NNS IN AT JJ ( NN ) NN NN -- AT NN JJ IN AT VBN JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN .
The preconditions of sociology have remained largely unexamined by the sociologist .	AT NNS IN NN HV VBN RB JJ IN AT NN .
Like primitive numbers in mathematics , the entire axiological framework is taken to rest upon its operational worth .	CS JJ NNS IN NN , AT JJ JJ NN BEZ VBN TO VB IN PP$ JJ NN .
But what is the operational worth of a sociology which mimetically reproduces the idea of physical models ? ?	CC WDT BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN WDT RB VBZ AT NN IN JJ NNS . .
