Is it not the task of philosophy to see what intelligible meaning can be assigned to the most sacred canons in social science ? ?	BEZ PPS * AT NN IN NN TO VB WDT JJ NN MD BE VBN IN AT QL JJ NNS IN JJ NN . .
It has become painfully clear that the very attempt to make the language of social research free of values by erecting mathematical and physical models , is itself a conditioned response to a world which pays a premium price for technological manipulation .	PPS HVZ VBN QL JJ CS AT AP NN TO VB AT NN IN JJ NN JJ IN NNS IN VBG JJ CC JJ NNS , BEZ PPL AT VBN NN IN AT NN WDT VBZ AT NN NN IN JJ NN .
This push to confine the study of mass behaviour to the measurements of parameters involved in differential equations has led sociology perilously close to the reduction of the word `` mass '' to mean a small group in which certain relations between all pairs of individuals in such a group can be studied .	DT NN TO VB AT NN IN NN NN IN AT NNS IN NNS VBN IN JJ NNS HVZ VBN NN QL RB IN AT NN IN AT NN `` NN-NC '' TO VB AT JJ NN IN WDT AP NNS IN ABN NNS IN NNS IN ABL AT NN MD BE VBN .
( cf. Rapoport , 1959 : :	( VB NP , CD . .
Ch. 11 .	NN CD .
) Here I think the role of the philosopher becomes apparent .	) RB PPSS VB AT NN IN AT NN VBZ JJ .
The simple pragmatic success of the sociology of small groups needs to be questioned .	AT JJ JJ NN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS VBZ TO BE VBN .
For if the small group notion involves the implicit claim that the phenomena of sociological investigations are of atomic or subatomic proportions , the philosopher needs to know the extent to which such entities are valid .	CS CS AT JJ NN NN VBZ AT JJ NN CS AT NNS IN JJ NNS BER IN JJ CC JJ NNS , AT NN VBZ TO VB AT NN IN WDT JJ NNS BER JJ .
The mere exploration of the unconscious ground of present-day sociology offers a rich vein of philosophical and logical investigation .	AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN VBZ AT JJ NN IN JJ CC JJ NN .
( cf. Brodbeck , 1959 : :	( VB NP , CD . .
Ch. 12 .	NN-TL CD-TL .
)	)
A parallel function for philosophy is the study of the relation between perceptions experientially received and conceptions logically formed .	AT JJ NN IN NN BEZ AT NN IN AT NN IN NNS RB VBN CC NNS RB VBN .
Philosophy can supply adequate criteria of meaning in the selection of socially viable categories .	NN MD VB JJ NNS IN NN IN AT NN IN RB JJ NNS .
This involves a sifting of the empirical and rational elements entering into each social science statement .	DT VBZ AT NN IN AT JJ CC JJ NNS VBG IN DT JJ NN NN .
Merton's functional sociology may have great practical use in the study of different cultures , yet it is perfectly clear , as Nagel ( 1957 : :	NP$ JJ NN MD HV JJ JJ NN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS , CC PPS BEZ QL JJ , CS NP ( CD . .
247 - 83 ) and Hempel ( 1959 : :	CD IN CD ) CC NP ( CD . .
271 - 307 ) indicate , that the concept of function in sociology has been built up from physiological and biological models , in which the notions of teleology , i.e. , metaphysical purpose , are central .	CD IN CD ) VB , CS AT NN IN NN IN NN HVZ BEN VBN RP IN JJ CC JJ NNS , IN WDT AT NNS IN NN , RB , JJ NN , BER JJ .
( cf. Chapter 9 .	( VB NN-TL CD-TL .
) Functionalism as a sociological credo is , therefore , not a direct consequence of observations , but rather an indirect consequence of philosophical inference and judgment .	) NN CS AT JJ NN BEZ , RB , * AT JJ NN IN NNS , CC RB AT JJ NN IN JJ NN CC NN .
The purpose of this sort of philosophical study of sociology is not to tyrannize but to clarify the principles of social science .	AT NN IN DT NN IN JJ NN IN NN BEZ * TO VB CC TO VB AT NNS IN JJ NN .
It is absurd to speak of philosophy as a superior enterprise to sociology , since the former is a logical , rational discipline , where sociology is essentially descriptive and empirical .	PPS BEZ JJ TO VB IN NN CS AT JJ NN IN NN , CS AT AP BEZ AT JJ , JJ NN , WRB NN BEZ RB JJ CC JJ .
Such a position entails the negation of philosophy in its Platonic form as something soaring above and embracing the empirical and mathematical sciences .	ABL AT NN VBZ AT NN IN NN IN PP$ JJ NN CS PN VBG IN CC VBG AT JJ CC JJ NNS .
But contrary to Whitehead , philosophy is not a synonym for Plato .	CC JJ IN NP , NN BEZ * AT NN IN NP .
The uses of philosophy as a logical clearing house are manifest to any approach that does not descend to pure sensationalism .	AT NNS IN NN CS AT JJ VBG NN BER JJ IN DTI NN WPS DOZ * VB IN JJ NN .
However , when philosophy attempts to stand above the sciences , to dictate the conditions of empirical research , it becomes formal metaphysics ; ;	RB , WRB NN VBZ TO VB IN AT NNS , TO VB AT NNS IN JJ NN , PPS VBZ JJ NN . .
shaping the contours of life to fit the needs of legends .	VBG AT NNS IN NN TO VB AT NNS IN NNS .
The notion of philosophy as Queen Bee may fit well with authoritarian modes of political ideology , but it has been noted that the price of such an imperial notion of philosophy is the frustration and flagellation of the social sciences .	AT NN IN NN CS NN-TL NN-TL MD VB RB IN JJ NNS IN JJ NN , CC PPS HVZ BEN VBN CS AT NN IN ABL AT JJ NN IN NN BEZ AT NN CC NN IN AT JJ NNS .
( cf. Wetter , 1952 : :	( VB NP , CD . .
Pt. 2 , Ch. 5 ; ;	NN-TL CD-TL , NN-TL CD-TL . .
Horowitz 1957b .	NP CD .
)	)
Metaphysics is no longer a direct grappling with nature as it was in antiquity .	NN BEZ QL RBR AT JJ NN IN NN CS PPS BEDZ IN NN .
It has surrendered any claims of description in favor of psychological accounts of nothingness , as in Heidegger's system ( 1929 ) .	PPS HVZ VBN DTI NNS IN NN IN NN IN JJ NNS IN NN , CS IN NP$ NN ( CD ) .
Science is mocked for wishing to know nothing of Nothing , in a last ditch effort to save the gods at the expense of men .	NN BEZ VBN IN VBG TO VB PN IN PN-TL , IN AT AP NN NN TO VB AT NNS IN AT NN IN NNS .
It is not positivism which has isolated metaphysics from reality by distinguishing between description and prescription .	PPS BEZ * NN WDT HVZ VBN NN IN NN IN VBG IN NN CC NN .
It is simply revealing the state to which metaphysical thinking has fallen during this century .	PPS BEZ RB VBG AT NN IN WDT JJ NN HVZ VBN IN DT NN .
Consider the traditional `` four fields '' of philosophy : logic , ethics , epistemology and esthetics .	VB AT JJ `` CD NNS '' IN NN : NN , NN , NN CC NN .
It is a commonplace that to the degree these special preserves of past philosophic hunting grounds establish an empirical content and suitable methodological criteria , they move away from philosophy as such .	PPS BEZ AT NN CS IN AT NN DTS JJ NNS IN AP JJ VBG NNS VB AT JJ NN CC JJ JJ NNS , PPSS VB RB IN NN CS JJ .
What is left to traditional systems of philosophy is , in effect , only the history of these fields prior to their becoming rigorous enough to abide by the canons of scientific method .	WDT BEZ VBN IN JJ NNS IN NN BEZ , IN NN , RB AT NN IN DTS NNS RB IN PP$ VBG JJ QLP TO VB IN AT NNS IN JJ NN .
In this situation , philosophy has survived by separating itself from metaphysics , by showing the ultimate questions to be the meaningless questions .	IN DT NN , NN HVZ VBN IN VBG PPL IN NN , IN VBG AT JJ NNS TO BE AT JJ NNS .
The relinquishing by philosophy of pretentious claims to empirical priority gives it an ability to treat problems of meaning and truth which in the past it was unable to examine because of its missionary attitude to knowledge of more humble sorts .	AT NN IN NN IN JJ NNS IN JJ NN VBZ PPO AT NN TO VB NNS IN NN CC NN WDT IN AT NN PPS BEDZ JJ TO VB RB IN PP$ JJ NN IN NN IN QL JJ NNS .
In the new situation , philosophy is able to provide the social sciences with the same guidance that mathematics offers the physical sciences , a reservoir of logical relations that can be used in framing hypotheses having explanatory and predictive value .	IN AT JJ NN , NN BEZ JJ TO VB AT JJ NNS IN AT AP NN WPO NN VBZ AT JJ NNS , AT NN IN JJ NNS WPS MD BE VBN IN VBG NNS HVG JJ CC JJ NN .
Beyond this , philosophy may urge the social sciences forward by asking the type of question that falls outside the present scope of social inquiry , but within its potential domain of relevance .	IN DT , NN MD VB AT JJ NNS RB IN VBG AT NN IN NN WPS VBZ IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN , CC IN PP$ JJ NN IN NN .
In this connection , it might be noted that the theory of games was a mathematical discovery long before its uses in political science were exploited .	IN DT NN , PPS MD BE VBN CS AT NN IN NNS BEDZ AT JJ NN RB IN PP$ NNS IN JJ NN BED VBN .
Likewise , Kant formulated the nebular hypothesis , according to which the solar system was evolved from a rotating mass of incandescent gas , nearly a half century before its scientific value was made plain by Laplace in his Systeme Du Monde .	RB , NP VBD AT JJ NN , IN IN WDT AT JJ NN BEDZ VBN IN AT VBG NN IN JJ NN , RB AT ABN NN IN PP$ JJ NN BEDZ VBN JJ IN NP IN PP$ FW-NN-TL FW-IN+AT-TL FW-NN-TL .
This does not mean that philosophy resolves the problems it generates , any more so than Riemann's geometry settled the physical status of the space-time continuum .	DT DOZ * VB CS NN VBZ AT NNS PPS VBZ , QL RBR RB CS NP$ NN VBD AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN .
But the forceful presentation of new issues for the sciences to work on is itself a monumental task .	CC AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS IN AT NNS TO VB IN BEZ PPL AT JJ NN .
To those raised on Marcel's Homo Viator and Heidegger's das Nichtige , this may seem a modest role for philosophy .	IN DTS VBN IN NP$ FW-NN-TL FW-NN-TL CC NP$ FW-AT-TL FW-NN-TL , DT MD VB AT JJ NN IN NN .
However , modesty and triviality are different qualities .	RB , NN CC NN BER JJ NNS .
Philosophy conceived of as servant to the sciences might appear as less dramatic than philosophy which jeers as the sciences evolve .	NN VBN IN CS NN IN AT NNS MD VB CS QL JJ CS NN WDT VBZ CS AT NNS VB .
The ceaseless effort to understand and measure the distance mankind has traversed since its primitive anthropological status offers a more durable sort of drama .	AT JJ NN TO VB CC VB AT NN NN HVZ VBN IN PP$ JJ JJ NN VBZ AT QL JJ NN IN NN .
By clarifying fundamental premises in the social sciences , and defining the logical problems emergent at the borderlands of each new scientific discipline , philosophy can offer the sort of distinction that can accelerate growth in human understanding .	IN VBG JJ NNS IN AT JJ NNS , CC VBG AT JJ NNS JJ IN AT NNS IN DT JJ JJ NN , NN MD VB AT NN IN NN WPS MD VB NN IN JJ VBG .
Philosophy can prevent the working scientist from becoming slothful and self-content by noting the assumptions and level at which a hypothesis or theory is framed .	NN MD VB AT VBG NN IN VBG JJ CC JJ IN VBG AT NNS CC NN IN WDT AT NN CC NN BEZ VBN .
The dissection of scientific theory , the examination of a theory from the vantage-points of language , epistemology , and ethics , is itself a distinct contribution to knowledge , no less so because of its removal from empirical research .	AT NN IN JJ NN , AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NNS IN NN , NN , CC NN , BEZ PPL AT JJ NN IN NN , QL AP RB RB IN PP$ NN IN JJ NN .
The realm of science , whatever the degree of precision in formulations , covers the range of prediction and explanation .	AT NN IN NN , WDT AT NN IN NN IN NNS , VBZ AT NN IN NN CC NN .
( cf. Hempel and Oppenheim , 1948 : :	( VB NP CC NP , CD . .
135 - 75 .	CD IN CD .
) Whatever philosophy is conceived to be , its rationalist , logistic attitude to evidence should make it clear that it is something other than science .	) WDT NN BEZ VBN TO BE , PP$ NN , JJ NN IN NN MD VB PPO JJ CS PPS BEZ PN AP CS NN .
For some forms of philosophy , this very division between the empirical and the rational becomes a sign of the metaphysical superiority of the latter .	IN DTI NNS IN NN , DT AP NN IN AT JJ CC AT JJ VBZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT AP .
Bergson and Leroy announce that `` the secret is the center of a philosophy '' and thereafter a hundred followers declare secrecy a higher verity .	NP CC NP VB CS `` AT NN BEZ AT NN IN AT NN '' CC RB AT CD NNS VB NN AT JJR NN .
This is simply a confession of intellectual sterility spruced up to look virtuous .	DT BEZ RB AT NN IN JJ NN VBN RP TO VB JJ .
For as Merleau-Ponty indicated ( 1953 ) , it is not the secret which is important , but the removal of secrecy .	CS CS NP VBD ( CD ) , PPS BEZ * AT NN WDT BEZ JJ , CC AT NN IN NN .
In this , philosophy and science share a common goal .	IN DT , NN CC NN VB AT JJ NN .
The hypostatization of the secret nonetheless guarantees that the division of analytical and synthetic philosophies shall not be overcome by even the most persuasive argument ; ;	AT NN IN AT NN RB VBZ CS AT NN IN JJ CC JJ NNS MD * BE VBN IN RB AT QL JJ NN . .
for this division is but an abstract representation of the social struggle between mysticism and science .	CS DT NN BEZ RB AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN IN NN CC NN .
The mystification of metaphysical systems does not imply the demise of philosophy , only the close of a philosophic age which demanded metaphysics to be rational and logical .	AT NN IN JJ NNS DOZ * VB AT NN IN NN , RB AT NN IN AT JJ NN WDT VBD NN TO BE JJ CC JJ .
The tenacity with which present metaphysical attitudes fetishize private intuition offers the strongest evidence that the gulf between scientific and delphic ways of philosophizing is built into the present conflict over the limits and purpose of science , religion and ideology .	AT NN IN WDT JJ JJ NNS VB JJ NN VBZ AT JJT NN CS AT NN IN JJ CC JJ NNS IN VBG BEZ VBN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NNS CC NN IN NN , NN CC NN .
( cf. McGlynn : 1958 .	( VB NP : CD .
) Scientific systems , and this includes even the relation of mechanist to relativist physics , are built upon , refined and corrected .	) JJ NNS , CC DT VBZ RB AT NN IN NN IN NN NN , BER VBN IN , VBN CC VBN .
Philosophic systems , by the very nature of their completeness , are overthrown by rival systems .	JJ NNS , IN AT AP NN IN PP$ NN , BER VBN IN NN NNS .
In addition to the incompleteness of science and the completeness of metaphysics , they differ in that science is essentially descriptive , while philosophy in its inherited forms , tends to be goal-oriented , teleological and prescriptive .	IN NN IN AT NN IN NN CC AT NN IN NN , PPSS VB IN CS NN BEZ QL JJ , CS NN IN PP$ VBN NNS , VBZ TO BE JJ , JJ CC JJ .
The threadbare notion that belief , unlike behaviour , is not subject to objective analysis , has placed intuitive metaphysics squarely against the sociology of knowledge , since it is precisely the job of the sociology of knowledge to treat beliefs as social facts no less viable than social behaviour .	AT JJ NN CS NN , IN NN , BEZ * JJ IN JJ NN , HVZ VBN JJ NN RB IN AT NN IN NN , CS PPS BEZ RB AT NN IN AT NN IN NN TO VB NNS CS JJ NNS QL QL JJ CS JJ NN .
When dealing with the actual relation of philosophy to the sociology of knowledge , or better the role of philosophy in assisting research on the social sources of ideas , one has to become necessarily selective .	WRB VBG IN AT JJ NN IN NN IN AT NN IN NN , CC RBR AT NN IN NN IN VBG NN IN AT JJ NNS IN NNS , PN HVZ TO VB RB JJ .
Certain features we have touched upon : philosophy as a logical , deductive system from which a social science methodology can be built up ; ;	AP NNS PPSS HV VBN IN : NN CS AT JJ , JJ NN IN WDT AT JJ NN NN MD BE VBN RP . .
philosophic analysis of the assumptions and presumptions of the social sciences ; ;	JJ NN IN AT NNS CC NNS IN AT JJ NNS . .
and philosophy as a guide to possible integration of supposedly disparate sociological investigations .	CC NN CS AT NN IN JJ NN IN RB JJ JJ NNS .
The objection will be raised that the most important role of philosophy in relation to social science has been omitted , namely the status of ultimate value questions and norms operative in the social sciences .	AT NN MD BE VBN CS AT QL JJ NN IN NN IN NN IN JJ NN HVZ BEN VBN , RB AT NN IN JJ NN NNS CC NNS JJ IN AT JJ NNS .
Specifically , it will be asked whether the `` real '' questions people ask are not the `` ultimate '' questions that social science finds itself impotent in the face of .	RB , PPS MD BE VBN CS AT `` JJ '' NNS NNS VB BER * AT `` JJ '' NNS WPO JJ NN VBZ PPL JJ IN AT NN IN .
What then is the status of such questions as : is society the ground of human existence or a means to an individual goal ? ?	WDT RB BEZ AT NN IN JJ NNS CS : BEZ NN AT NN IN JJ NN CC AT NN IN AT JJ NN . .
Do societies develop according to cosmic patterns or are they subject only to the free choice of individuals ? ?	DO NNS VB IN IN JJ NNS CC BER PPSS JJ RB IN AT JJ NN IN NNS . .
Does society really exist as an entity over and above the agglomeration of men ? ?	DOZ NN RB VB CS AT NN IN CC IN AT NN IN NNS . .
I think it must be said that , contrary to metaphysical insistence , these are questions so framed as to defy either empirical exploration or rational solutions .	PPSS VB PPS MD BE VBN CS , JJ IN JJ NN , DTS BER NNS RB VBN CS TO VB CC JJ NN CC JJ NNS .
As Simmel ( 1908 ) and Dilthey ( 1922 ) indicated , questions of whether the value of life is individual or social are not questions , but assertions of faith made to appear as legitimate questions .	CS NP ( CD ) CC NP ( CD ) VBD , NNS IN CS AT NN IN NN BEZ JJ CC JJ BER * NNS , CC NNS IN NN VBN TO VB CS JJ NNS .
Such pseudo-questions assume that answers of concrete significance can be supplied to statements involving undefined universals .	JJ NNS VB CS NNS IN JJ NN MD BE VBN IN NNS VBG JJ NNS .
Social theory has no more right to expect results from meaningless questions , than physics has the right to expect a theological solution to the wave-particle controversy .	JJ NN HVZ QL AP NN TO VB NNS IN JJ NNS , CS NN HVZ AT NN TO VB AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN .
It is not that such questions are not asked .	PPS BEZ * CS JJ NNS BER * VBN .
It is rather that introducing them into social analysis reflects not so much a search for truth as for certainty .	PPS BEZ RB CS VBG PPO IN JJ NN VBZ * QL AP AT NN IN NN CS IN NN .
An operational approach to sociology can never expect abstract certainty , since it is certainty which every new discovery in science either replaces or reshapes .	AT JJ NN IN NN MD RB VB JJ NN , CS PPS BEZ NN WDT AT JJ NN IN NN CC VBZ CC VBZ .
To raise the added objection that men require certainty on psychological grounds , answers to ultimate questions having an irrational rather than scientific basis , is in a real sense to undermine the objection itself .	TO VB AT VBN NN CS NNS VB NN IN JJ NNS , VBZ IN JJ NNS HVG AT JJ RB CS JJ NN , BEZ IN AT JJ NN TO VB AT NN PPL .
For what concerns all scientific disciplines is precisely that which can be captured for the rational , i.e. , for the scientific determination of what in past ages was considered ultimate and irrational .	CS WDT VBZ ABN JJ NNS BEZ RB DT WDT MD BE VBN IN AT JJ , RB , IN AT JJ NN IN WDT IN AP NNS BEDZ VBN JJ CC JJ .
A philosophy which attempts to supply ultimate answers in an ultimate way reveals its acquiescence in the shortcomings of men , an impatience with partial , tentative solutions .	AT NN WDT VBZ TO VB JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN VBZ PP$ NN IN AT NNS IN NNS , AT NN IN JJ , JJ NNS .
Men have always lived in a tentative world , and in suspension of ultimate judgments where and when necessary .	NNS HV RB VBN IN AT JJ NN , CC IN NN IN JJ NNS WRB CC WRB JJ .
Uncertainty overcoming itself is the precondition of the quest for new and more precise information about the world .	NN VBG PPL BEZ AT NN IN AT NN IN JJ CC QL JJ NN IN AT NN .
Without such uncertainty we are left with a set of dogmas and myths .	IN JJ NN PPSS BER VBN IN AT NN IN NNS CC NNS .
The functional interplay of philosophy and science should , as a minimum , guarantee a meaningful option to myth-making .	AT JJ NN IN NN CC NN MD , CS AT JJ , NN AT JJ NN IN NN .
A degree of indefiniteness is a salutary condition for the growth of science .	AT NN IN NN BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN NN .
But neither was the statement empirical , for goodness was not a quality like red or squeaky that could be seen or heard .	CC CC BEDZ AT NN JJ , CS NN BEDZ * AT NN CS JJ CC JJ WPS MD BE VBN CC VBN .
What were they to do , then , with these awkward judgments of value ? ?	WDT BED PPSS TO DO , RB , IN DTS JJ NNS IN NN . .
To find a place for them in their theory of knowledge would require them to revise the theory radically , and yet that theory was what they regarded as their most important discovery .	TO VB AT NN IN PPO IN PP$ NN IN NN MD VB PPO TO VB AT NN RB , CC RB DT NN BEDZ WDT PPSS VBD CS PP$ QL JJ NN .
It appeared that the theory could be saved in one way only .	PPS VBD CS AT NN MD BE VBN IN CD NN RB .
If it could be shown that judgments of good and bad were not judgments at all , that they asserted nothing true or false , but merely expressed emotions like `` Hurrah '' or `` Fiddlesticks '' , then these wayward judgments would cease from troubling and weary heads could be at rest .	CS PPS MD BE VBN CS NNS IN NN CC NN BED * NNS IN ABN , CS PPSS VBD PN JJ CC JJ , CC RB VBD NNS CS `` UH-NC '' CC `` UH-NC '' , RB DTS JJ NNS MD VB IN VBG CC JJ NNS MD BE IN NN .
This is the course the positivists took .	DT BEZ AT NN AT NNS VBD .
They explained value judgments by explaining them away .	PPSS VBD NN NNS IN VBG PPO RB .
Now I do not think their view will do .	RB PPSS DO * VB PP$ NN MD DO .
But before discussing it , I should like to record one vote of thanks to them for the clarity with which they have stated their case .	CC CS VBG PPO , PPSS MD VB TO VB CD NN IN NNS IN PPO IN AT NN IN WDT PPSS HV VBN PP$ NN .
It has been said of John Stuart Mill that he wrote so clearly that he could be found out .	PPS HVZ BEN VBN IN NP NP NP CS PPS VBD QL RB CS PPS MD BE VBN RP .
This theory has been put so clearly and precisely that it deserves criticism of the same kind , and this I will do my best to supply .	DT NN HVZ BEN VBN QL RB CC RB CS PPS VBZ NN IN AT AP NN , CC DT PPSS MD DO PP$ JJT TO VB .
The theory claims to show by analysis that when we say , `` That is good '' , we do not mean to assert a character of the subject of which we are thinking .	AT NN VBZ TO VB IN NN CS WRB PPSS VB , `` DT BEZ JJ '' , PPSS DO * VB TO VB AT NN IN AT NN IN WDT PPSS BER VBG .
I shall argue that we do mean to do just that .	PPSS MD VB CS PPSS DO VB TO DO RB DT .
Let us work through an example , and the simpler and commoner the better .	VB PPO VB IN AT NN , CC AT JJR CC JJR AT JJR .
There is perhaps no value statement on which people would more universally agree than the statement that intense pain is bad .	EX BEZ RB AT NN NN IN WDT NNS MD QL RB VB CS AT NN CS JJ NN BEZ JJ .
Let us take a set of circumstances in which I happen to be interested on the legislative side and in which I think every one of us might naturally make such a statement .	VB PPO VB AT NN IN NNS IN WDT PPSS VB TO BE VBN IN AT JJ NN CC IN WDT PPSS VB AT CD IN PPO MD RB VB ABL AT NN .
We come upon a rabbit that has been caught in one of the brutal traps in common use .	PPSS VB IN AT NN WPS HVZ BEN VBN IN CD IN AT JJ NNS IN JJ NN .
There are signs that it has struggled for days to escape and that in a frenzy of hunger , pain , and fear , it has all but eaten off its own leg .	EX BER NNS CS PPS HVZ VBN IN NNS TO VB CC CS IN AT NN IN NN , NN , CC NN , PPS HVZ ABN IN VBN RP PP$ JJ NN .
The attempt failed : the animal is now dead .	AT NN VBD : AT NN BEZ RB JJ .
As we think of the long and excruciating pain it must have suffered , we are very likely to say : `` It was a bad thing that the little animal should suffer so '' .	CS PPSS VB IN AT JJ CC JJ NN PPS MD HV VBN , PPSS BER QL JJ TO VB : `` PPS BEDZ AT JJ NN CS AT JJ NN MD VB RB '' .
The positivist tells us that when we say this we are only expressing our present emotion .	AT NN VBZ PPO CS WRB PPSS VB DT PPSS BER RB VBG PP$ JJ NN .
I hold , on the contrary , that we mean to assert something of the pain itself , namely , that it was bad -- bad when and as it occurred .	PPSS VB , IN AT JJ , CS PPSS VB TO VB PN IN AT NN PPL , RB , CS PPS BEDZ JJ -- JJ WRB CC CS PPS VBD .
Consider what follows from the positivist view .	VB WDT VBZ IN AT NN NN .
On that view , nothing good or bad happened in the case until I came on the scene and made my remark .	IN DT NN , PN JJ CC JJ VBD IN AT NN CS PPSS VBD IN AT NN CC VBD PP$ NN .
For what I express in my remark is something going on in me at the time , and that of course did not exist until I did come on the scene .	CS WDT PPSS VB IN PP$ NN BEZ PN VBG RP IN PPO IN AT NN , CC DT IN NN DOD * VB CS PPSS DOD VB IN AT NN .
The pain of the rabbit was not itself bad ; ;	AT NN IN AT NN BEDZ * PPL JJ . .
nothing evil was happening when that pain was being endured ; ;	PN NN BEDZ VBG WRB DT NN BEDZ BEG VBN . .
badness , in the only sense in which it is involved at all , waited for its appearance till I came and looked and felt .	NN , IN AT AP NN IN WDT PPS BEZ VBN IN ABN , VBD IN PP$ NN CS PPSS VBD CC VBD CC VBD .
Now that this is at odds with our meaning may be shown as follows .	RB CS DT BEZ IN NNS IN PP$ NN MD BE VBN CS VBZ .
Let us put to ourselves the hypothesis that we had not come on the scene and that the rabbit never was discovered .	VB PPO VB IN PPLS AT NN CS PPSS HVD * VBN IN AT NN CC CS AT NN RB BEDZ VBN .
Are we prepared to say that in that case nothing bad occurred in the sense in which we said it did ? ?	BER PPSS VBD TO VB CS IN DT NN PN JJ VBD IN AT NN IN WDT PPSS VBD PPS DOD . .
Clearly not .	RB * .
Indeed , we should say , on the contrary , that the accident of our later discovery made no difference whatever to the badness of the animal's pain , that it would have been every whit as bad whether a chance passer-by happened later to discover the body and feel repugnance or not .	RB , PPSS MD VB , IN AT JJ , CS AT NN IN PP$ JJR NN VBD AT NN WDT IN AT NN IN AT NN$ NN , CS PPS MD HV BEN AT NN QL JJ CS AT NN NN VBD RBR TO VB AT NN CC VB NN CC * .
If so , then it is clear that in saying the suffering was bad we are not expressing our feelings only .	CS RB , RB PPS BEZ JJ CS IN VBG AT NN BEDZ JJ PPSS BER * VBG PP$ NNS RB .
We are saying that the pain was bad when and as it occurred and before anyone took an attitude toward it .	PPSS BER VBG CS AT NN BEDZ JJ WRB CC CS PPS VBD CC CS PN VBD AT NN IN PPO .
The first argument is thus an ideal experiment in which we use the method of difference .	AT OD NN BEZ RB AT JJ NN IN WDT PPSS VB AT NN IN NN .
It removes our present expression and shows that the badness we meant would not be affected by this , whereas on positivist grounds it should be .	PPS VBZ PP$ JJ NN CC VBZ CS AT NN PPSS VBD MD * BE VBN IN DT , CS IN NN NNS PPS MD BE .
The second argument applies the method in the reverse way .	AT OD NN VBZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN .
It ideally removes the past event , and shows that this would render false what we mean to say , whereas on positivist grounds it should not .	PPS RB VBZ AT AP NN , CC VBZ CS DT MD VB JJ WDT PPSS VB TO VB , CS IN NN NNS PPS MD * .
Let us suppose that the animal did not in fact fall into the trap and did not suffer at all , but that we mistakenly believe it did , and say as before that its suffering was an evil thing .	VB PPO VB CS AT NN DOD * IN NN VB IN AT NN CC DOD * VB IN ABN , CC CS PPSS RB VB PPS DOD , CC VB CS RB CS PP$ NN BEDZ AT JJ NN .
On the positivist theory , everything I sought to express by calling it evil in the first case is still present in the second .	IN AT NN NN , PN PPSS VBD TO VB IN VBG PPO JJ IN AT OD NN BEZ RB RB IN AT OD .
In the only sense in which badness is involved at all , whatever was bad in the first case is still present in its entirety , since all that is expressed in either case is a state of feeling , and that feeling is still there .	IN AT AP NN IN WDT NN BEZ VBN IN ABN , WDT BEDZ JJ IN AT OD NN BEZ RB RB IN PP$ NN , CS ABN WPS BEZ VBN IN DTX NN BEZ AT NN IN NN , CC DT NN BEZ RB RB .
And our question is , is such an implication consistent with what we meant ? ?	CC PP$ NN BEZ , BEZ ABL AT NN JJ IN WDT PPSS VBD . .
Clearly it is not .	RB PPS BEZ * .
If anyone asked us , after we made the remark that the suffering was a bad thing , whether we should think it relevant to what we said to learn that the incident had never occurred and no pain had been suffered at all , we should say that it made all the difference in the world , that what we were asserting to be bad was precisely the suffering we thought had occurred back there , that if this had not occurred , there was nothing left to be bad , and that our assertion was in that case mistaken .	CS PN VBD PPO , CS PPSS VBD AT NN CS AT NN BEDZ AT JJ NN , CS PPSS MD VB PPO JJ IN WDT PPSS VBD TO VB CS AT NN HVD RB VBN CC AT NN HVD BEN VBN IN ABN , PPSS MD VB CS PPS VBD ABN AT NN IN AT NN , CS WDT PPSS BED VBG TO BE JJ BEDZ RB AT NN PPSS VBD HVD VBN RB RB , CS CS DT HVD * VBN , EX BEDZ PN VBN TO BE JJ , CC CS PP$ NN BEDZ IN DT NN VBN .
The suggestion that in saying something evil had occurred we were after all making no mistake , because we had never meant anyhow to say anything about the past suffering , seems to me merely frivolous .	AT NN CS IN VBG PN JJ HVD VBN PPSS BED IN ABN VBG AT NN , CS PPSS HVD RB VBN RB TO VB PN IN AT AP NN , VBZ IN PPO RB JJ .
If we did not mean to say this , why should we be so relieved on finding that the suffering had not occurred ? ?	CS PPSS DOD * VB TO VB DT , WRB MD PPSS BE QL VBN IN VBG CS AT NN HVD * VBN . .
On the theory before us , such relief would be groundless , for in that suffering itself there was nothing bad at all , and hence in its nonoccurrence there would be nothing to be relieved about .	IN AT NN IN PPO , JJ NN MD BE JJ , CS IN DT NN PPL EX BEDZ PN JJ IN ABN , CC RB IN PP$ NN EX MD BE PN TO BE VBN IN .
The positivist theory would here distort our meaning beyond recognition .	AT NN NN MD RB VB PP$ NN IN NN .
So far as I can see , there is only one way out for the positivist .	QL RB CS PPSS MD VB , EX BEZ RB CD NN RP IN AT NN .
He holds that goodness and badness lie in feelings of approval or disapproval .	PPS VBZ CS NN CC NN VB IN NNS IN NN CC NN .
And there is a way in which he might hold that badness did in this case precede our own feeling of disapproval without belonging to the pain itself .	CC EX BEZ AT NN IN WDT PPS MD VB CS NN DOD IN DT NN VB PP$ JJ NN IN NN IN VBG IN AT NN PPL .
The pain in itself was neutral ; ;	AT NN IN PPL BEDZ JJ . .
but unfortunately the rabbit , on no grounds at all , took up toward this neutral object an attitude of disapproval and that made it for the first time , and in the only intelligible sense , bad .	CC RB AT NN , IN AT NNS IN ABN , VBD RP IN DT JJ NN AT NN IN NN CC DT VBD PPO IN AT OD NN , CC IN AT AP JJ NN , JJ .
This way of escape is theoretically possible , but since it has grave difficulties of its own and has not , so far as I know , been urged by positivists , it is perhaps best not to spend time over it .	DT NN IN NN BEZ RB JJ , CC CS PPS HVZ JJ NNS IN PP$ JJ CC HVZ * , QL RB CS PPSS VB , BEN VBN IN NNS , PPS BEZ RB JJT * TO VB NN IN PPO .
I come now to a third argument , which again is very simple .	PPSS VB RB IN AT OD NN , WDT RB BEZ QL JJ .
When we come upon the rabbit and make our remark about its suffering being a bad thing , we presumably make it with some feeling ; ;	WRB PPSS VB IN AT NN CC VB PP$ NN IN PP$ VBG BEG AT JJ NN , PPSS RB VB PPO IN DTI NN . .
the positivists are plainly right in saying that such remarks do usually express feeling .	AT NNS BER QL JJ IN VBG CS JJ NNS DO RB VB VBG .
But suppose that a week later we revert to the incident in thought and make our statement again .	CC VB CS AT NN RBR PPSS VB IN AT NN IN NN CC VB PP$ NN RB .
And suppose that the circumstances have now so changed that the feeling with which we made the remark in the first place has faded .	CC VB CS AT NNS HV RB QL VBN CS AT NN IN WDT PPSS VBD AT NN IN AT OD NN HVZ VBN .
The pathetic evidence is no longer before us ; ;	AT JJ NN BEZ QL RBR IN PPO . .
and we are now so fatigued in body and mind that feeling is , as we say , quite dead .	CC PPSS BER RB QL VBN IN NN CC NN CS VBG BEZ , CS PPSS VB , QL JJ .
In these circumstances , since what was expressed by the remark when first made is , on the theory before us , simply absent , the remark now expresses nothing .	IN DTS NNS , CS WDT BEDZ VBN IN AT NN WRB RB VBN BEZ , IN AT NN IN PPO , RB JJ , AT NN RB VBZ PN .
It is as empty as the word `` Hurrah '' would be when there was no enthusiasm behind it .	PPS BEZ QL JJ CS AT NN `` UH-NC '' MD BE WRB EX BEDZ AT NN IN PPO .
And this seems to me untrue .	CC DT VBZ IN PPO JJ .
When we repeat the remark that such suffering was a bad thing , the feeling with which we made it last week may be at or near the vanishing point , but if we were asked whether we meant to say what we did before , we should certainly answer Yes .	WRB PPSS VB AT NN CS JJ NN BEDZ AT JJ NN , AT NN IN WDT PPSS VBD PPO AP NN MD BE IN CC IN AT VBG NN , CC CS PPSS BED VBN CS PPSS VBD TO VB WDT PPSS DOD RB , PPSS MD RB VB RB .
We should say that we made our point with feeling the first time and little or no feeling the second time , but that it was the same point we were making .	PPSS MD VB CS PPSS VBD PP$ NN IN VBG AT OD NN CC AP CC AT NN AT OD NN , CC CS PPS BEDZ AT AP NN PPSS BED VBG .
And if we can see that what we meant to say remains the same , while the feeling varies from intensity to near zero , it is not the feeling that we primarily meant to express .	CC CS PPSS MD VB CS WDT PPSS VBD TO VB VBZ AT AP , CS AT NN VBZ IN NN IN IN CD , PPS BEZ * AT NN WPO PPSS RB VBD TO VB .
I come now to a fourth consideration .	PPSS VB RB IN AT OD NN .
We all believe that toward acts or effects of a certain kind one attitude is fitting and another not ; ;	PPSS ABN VB CS IN NNS CC NNS IN AT AP NN CD NN BEZ VBG CC DT * . .
but on the theory before us such a belief would not make sense .	CC IN AT NN IN PPO ABL AT NN MD * VB NN .
Broad and Ross have lately contended that this fitness is one of the main facts of ethics , and I suspect they are right .	NP CC NP HV RB VBN CS DT NN BEZ CD IN AT JJS NNS IN NN , CC PPSS VB PPSS BER JJ .
But that is not exactly my point .	CC DT BEZ * RB PP$ NN .
My point is this : whether there is such fitness or not , we all assume that there is , and if we do , we express in moral judgments more than the subjectivists say we do .	PP$ NN BEZ DT : CS EX BEZ JJ NN CC * , PPSS ABN VB CS EX BEZ , CC CS PPSS DO , PPSS VB IN JJ NNS AP CS AT NNS VB PPSS DO .
Let me illustrate .	VB PPO VB .
In his novel The House Of The Dead , Dostoevsky tells of his experiences in a Siberian prison camp .	IN PP$ NN AT-TL NN-TL IN-TL AT-TL NN-TL , NP VBZ IN PP$ NNS IN AT JJ NN NN .
Whatever the unhappy inmates of such camps are like today , Dostoevsky's companions were about as grim a lot as can be imagined .	WDT AT JJ NNS IN JJ NNS BER CS NR , NP$ NNS BED RB QL JJ AT NN CS MD BE VBN .
`` I have heard stories '' , he writes , `` of the most terrible , the most unnatural actions , of the most monstrous murders , told with the most spontaneous , childishly merry laughter '' .	`` PPSS HV VBN NNS '' , PPS VBZ , `` IN AT QL JJ , AT QL JJ NNS , IN AT QL JJ NNS , VBN IN AT QL JJ , RB JJ NN '' .
Most of us would say that in this delight at the killing of others or the causing of suffering there is something very unfitting .	AP IN PPO MD VB CS IN DT NN IN AT NN IN NNS CC AT NN IN VBG EX BEZ PN QL JJ .
If we were asked why we thought so , we should say that these things involve great evil and are wrong , and that to take delight in what is evil or wrong is plainly unfitting .	CS PPSS BED VBN WRB PPSS VBD RB , PPSS MD VB CS DTS NNS VB JJ NN CC BER JJ , CC CS TO VB NN IN WDT BEZ JJ CC JJ BEZ RB JJ .
Now on the subjectivist view , this answer is ruled out .	RB IN AT NN NN , DT NN BEZ VBN RP .
For before someone takes up an attitude toward death , suffering , or their infliction , they have no moral quality at all .	CS CS PN VBZ RP AT NN IN NN , VBG , CC PP$ NN , PPSS HV AT JJ NN IN ABN .
There is therefore nothing about them to which an attitude of approval or condemnation could be fitting .	EX BEZ RB PN IN PPO IN WDT AT NN IN NN CC NN MD BE VBG .
They are in themselves neutral , and , so far as they get a moral quality , they get it only through being invested with it by the attitude of the onlooker .	PPSS BER IN PPLS JJ , CC , QL RB CS PPSS VB AT JJ NN , PPSS VB PPO RB IN BEG VBN IN PPO IN AT NN IN AT NN .
But if that is true , why is any attitude more fitting than any other ? ?	CC CS DT BEZ JJ , WRB BEZ DTI NN QL JJ CS DTI AP . .
Would applause , for example , be fitting if , apart from the applause , there were nothing good to applaud ? ?	MD NN , IN NN , BE JJ CS , RB IN AT NN , EX BED PN JJ TO VB . .
Would condemnation be fitting if , independently of the condemnation , there were nothing bad to condemn ? ?	MD NN BE JJ CS , RB IN AT NN , EX BED PN JJ TO VB . .
In such a case , any attitude would be as fitting or unfitting as any other , which means that the notion of fitness has lost all point .	IN ABL AT NN , DTI NN MD BE QL JJ CC JJ CS DTI AP , WDT VBZ CS AT NN IN NN HVZ VBN ABN NN .
Indeed , we are forced to go much farther .	RB , PPSS BER VBN TO VB QL RBR .
If goodness and badness lie in attitudes only and hence are brought into being by them , those men who greeted death and misery with childishly merry laughter are taking the only sensible line .	CS NN CC NN VB IN NNS RB CC RB BER VBN IN BEG IN PPO , DTS NNS WPS VBD NN CC NN IN RB JJ NN BER VBG AT AP JJ NN .
If there is nothing evil in these things , if they get their moral complexion only from our feeling about them , why shouldn't they be greeted with a cheer ? ?	CS EX BEZ PN JJ IN DTS NNS , CS PPSS VB PP$ JJ NN RB IN PP$ NN IN PPO , WRB MD* PPSS BE VBN IN AT NN . .
To greet them with repulsion would turn what before was neutral into something bad ; ;	TO VB PPO IN NN MD VB WDT RB BEDZ JJ IN PN JJ . .
it would needlessly bring badness into the world ; ;	PPS MD RB VB NN IN AT NN . .
and even on subjectivist assumptions that does not seem very bright .	CC RB IN NN NNS DT DOZ * VB QL JJ .
On the other hand , to greet them with delight would convert what before was neutral into something good ; ;	IN AT AP NN , TO VB PPO IN NN MD VB WDT RB BEDZ JJ IN PN JJ . .
it would bring goodness into the world .	PPS MD VB NN IN AT NN .
The injured German veteran was a former miner , twenty-four years old , who had been wounded by shrapnel in the back of the head .	AT VBN JJ NN BEDZ AT AP NN , CD NNS JJ , WPS HVD BEN VBN IN NN IN AT NN IN AT NN .
This resulted in damage to the occipital lobe and very probably to the left side of the cerebellum also .	DT VBD IN NN IN AT JJ NN CC QL RB IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN RB .
In any event , the extraordinary result of this injury was that he became `` psychically blind '' , while at the same time , apparently , the sense of touch remained essentially intact .	IN DTI NN , AT JJ NN IN DT NN BEDZ CS PPS VBD `` RB JJ '' , CS IN AT AP NN , RB , AT NN IN NN VBD RB JJ .
Psychical blindness is a condition in which there is a total absence of visual memory-images , a condition in which , for example , one is unable to remember something just seen or to conjure up a memory-picture of the visible appearance of a well-known friend in his absence .	JJ NN BEZ AT NN IN WDT EX BEZ AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS , AT NN IN WDT , IN NN , PN BEZ JJ TO VB PN RB VBN CC TO VB RP AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN IN PP$ NN .
This circumstance in the patient's case plus the fact that his tactual capacity remained basically in sound working order constitutes its exceptional value for the problem at hand since the evidence presented by the authors is overwhelming that , when the patient closed his eyes , he had absolutely no spatial ( that is , third-dimensional ) awareness whatsoever .	DT NN IN AT NN$ NN IN AT NN CS PP$ JJ NN VBD RB IN JJ VBG NN VBZ PP$ JJ NN IN AT NN IN NN CS AT NN VBN IN AT NNS BEZ JJ CS , WRB AT NN VBD PP$ NNS , PPS HVD RB AT JJ ( DT BEZ , JJ ) NN RB .
The necessary inference , as the authors themselves interpret it , would seem to be this : `` ( ( 1 ) Spatial qualities are not among those grasped by the sense of touch , as such .	AT JJ NN , CS AT NNS PPLS VB PPO , MD VB TO BE DT : `` ( ( CD ) JJ NNS BER * IN DTS VBN IN AT NN IN NN , CS JJ .
We do not arrive at spatial images by means of the sense of touch by itself .	PPSS DO * VB IN JJ NNS IN NN IN AT NN IN NN IN PPL .
( 2 ) Spatiality becomes part of the tactual sensation only by way of visual representations ; ;	( CD ) NN VBZ NN IN AT JJ NN RB IN NN IN JJ NNS . .
that is , there is , in the true sense , only a visual space '' .	DT BEZ , EX BEZ , IN AT JJ NN , RB AT JJ NN '' .
The underlying assumption , of course , is that only sight and touch enable us , in any precise and fully dependable way , to locate objects in space beyond us , the other senses being decidedly inferior , if not totally inadequate , in this regard .	AT VBG NN , IN NN , BEZ CS AP NN CC VB VB PPO , IN DTI JJ CC QL JJ NN , TO VB NNS IN NN IN PPO , AT AP NNS BEG RB JJ , CS * RB JJ , IN DT NN .
This is an assumption with which few would be disposed to quarrel .	DT BEZ AT NN IN WDT AP MD BE VBN TO VB .
Therefore , if the sense of touch is functioning normally and there is a complete absence of spatial awareness in a psychically-blind person when the eyes are closed and an object is handled , the conclusion seems unavoidable that touch by itself cannot focus and take possession of the third-dimensionality of things and that actual sight or visual representations are necessary . The force of the authors' analysis ( if indeed it has any force ) can be felt by the reader , I believe , only after three questions have been successfully answered .	AT NN IN AT NNS$ NN ( CS RB PPS HVZ DTI NN ) MD BE VBN IN AT NN , PPSS VB , RB CS CD NNS HV BEN RB VBN .
( 1 ) What allows us to think that the patient had no third-dimensional representations when his eyes were closed ? ?	( CD ) WDT VBZ PPO TO VB CS AT NN HVD AT JJ NNS WRB PP$ NNS BED VBN . .
( 2 ) What evidence is there that he was psychically blind ? ?	( CD ) WDT NN BEZ EX CS PPS BEDZ RB JJ . .
( 3 ) How can we be sure that his sense of touch was not profoundly disturbed by his head injury ? ?	( CD ) WRB MD PPSS BE JJ CS PP$ NN IN NN BEDZ * RB VBN IN PP$ NN NN . .
We shall consider these in the inverse order of their presentation .	PPSS MD VB DTS IN AT JJ NN IN PP$ NN .
Obviously , a satisfactory answer to the third question is imperative , if the argument is to get under way at all , for if there is any possibility of doubt whether the patient's tactual sensitivity had been impaired by the occipital lesion , any findings whatsoever in regard to the first question become completely ambiguous and fail altogether , of course , as evidence to establish the desired conclusion . The answer the authors give to it , therefore , is of supreme importance .	AT NN AT NNS VB IN PPO , RB , BEZ IN JJ NN .
It is as follows : `` The usual sensitivity tests showed that the specific qualities of skin-perceptiveness ( pressure , pain , temperature ) , as well as the kinesthetic sensations ( muscular feelings , feelings in the tendons and joints ) , were , as such , essentially intact , although they seemed , in comparison with normal reactions , to be somewhat diminished over the entire body . The supposed tactual sense of spatial location and orientation in the patient and his ability to specify the location of a member , as well as the direction and scope of a movement , passively executed ( with one of his members ) , proved to have been , on the contrary , very considerably affected '' . The authors insist , however , that these abnormalities in the sense of touch were due absolutely to no organic disorders in that sense faculty but rather to the injuries which the patient had sustained to the sense of sight . First of all , what is their evidence that the tactual apparatus was fundamentally undamaged ? ?	OD IN ABN , WDT BEZ PP$ NN CS AT JJ NN BEDZ RB JJ . .
( 1 ) When an object was placed in the patient's hand , he had no difficulty determining whether it was warm or cold , sharp or blunt , rough or smooth , flexible , soft , or hard ; ;	( CD ) WRB AT NN BEDZ VBN IN AT NN$ NN , PPS HVD AT NN VBG CS PPS BEDZ JJ CC JJ , JJ CC JJ , JJ CC JJ , JJ , JJ , CC JJ . .
and he could tell , simply by the feel of it , whether it was made of wood , iron , cloth , rubber , and so on .	CC PPS MD VB , RB IN AT NN IN PPO , CS PPS BEDZ VBN IN NN , NN , NN , NN , CC RB RP .
And he could recognize , by touch alone , articles which he had handled immediately before , even though they were altogether unfamiliar to him and could not be identified by him ; ;	CC PPS MD VB , IN NN RB , NNS WDT PPS HVD VBN RB RB , RB CS PPSS BED RB JJ IN PPO CC MD * BE VBN IN PPO . .
that is , he was unaware what kind of objects they were or what their use was .	DT BEZ , PPS BEDZ JJ WDT NN IN NNS PPSS BED CC WDT PP$ NN BEDZ .
( 2 ) The patient attained an astonishing efficiency in a new trade .	( CD ) AT NN VBD AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN .
Because of his brain injury and the extreme damage suffered to his sight , the patient had to train himself for a new line of work , that of a portfolio-maker , an occupation requiring a great deal of precision in the making of measurements and a fairly well-developed sense of form and contour . It seems clear , when one takes into consideration the exceedingly defective eyesight of the patient ( we shall describe it in detail in connection with our second question , the one concerning the psychical blindness of the patient ) , that he had to rely on his sense of touch much more than the usual portfolio-maker and that consequently that faculty was most probably more sensitive to shape and size than that of a person with normal vision . If the argument is accepted as essentially sound up to this point , it remains for us to consider whether the patient's difficulties in orienting himself spatially and in locating objects in space with the sense of touch can be explained by his defective visual condition . In what ways , then , did the patient's psychical blindness manifest itself ? ?	IN WDT NNS , RB , DOD AT NN$ JJ NN VB PPL . .
He could not see objects as unified , self-contained , and organized figures , as a person does with normal vision .	PPS MD * VB NNS CS VBN , JJ , CC VBN NNS , CS AT NN DOZ IN JJ NN .
The meaning of this , as we shall see , is that he had no fund of visual memory-images of objects as objects ; ;	AT NN IN DT , CS PPSS MD VB , BEZ CS PPS HVD AT NN IN JJ NNS IN NNS CS NNS . .
and , therefore , he could not recognize even long-familiar things upon seeing them again .	CC , RB , PPS MD * VB RB JJ NNS IN VBG PPO RB .
Instead , he constantly became lost in parts and components of them , confused some of their details with those of neighboring objects , and so on , unless he allowed time to `` trace '' the object in question through minute movements of the head and hands and in this way to discover its contours .	RB , PPS RB VBD VBN IN NNS CC NNS IN PPO , VBD DTI IN PP$ NNS IN DTS IN VBG NNS , CC RB RP , CS PPS VBD NN TO `` VB '' AT NN IN NN IN JJ NNS IN AT NN CC NNS CC IN DT NN TO VB PP$ NNS .
According to his own testimony , he never actually saw things as shaped but only as generally amorphous `` blots '' of color of a more or less indefinite size ; ;	IN IN PP$ JJ NN , PPS RB RB VBD NNS CS VBN CC RB CS RB JJ `` NNS '' IN NN IN AT QL CC QL JJ NN . .
at their edges they slipped pretty much out of focus altogether .	IN PP$ NNS PPSS VBD QL RB RP IN NN RB .
But by the tracing procedure , he could , in a strange obviously kinesthetic manner , find the unseen form ; ;	CC IN AT VBG NN , PPS MD , IN AT JJ RB JJ NN , VB AT JJ NN . .
could piece , as it were , the jumbled mass together into an organized whole and then recognize it as a man or a triangle or whatever it turned out to be .	MD VB , CS PPS BED , AT VBN NN RB IN AT VBN NN CC RB VB PPO CS AT NN CC AT NN CC WDT PPS VBD RP TO BE .
If , however , the figure to be discerned were complicated , composed of several interlocking subfigures , and so on , even the tracing process failed him , and he could not focus even relatively simple shapes among its parts .	CS , RB , AT NN TO BE VBN BED VBN , VBN IN AP VBG NNS , CC RB RP , RB AT VBG NN VBD PPO , CC PPS MD * VB RB QL JJ NNS IN PP$ NNS .
This meant , concretely , that the patient could not read at all without making writing-like movements of the head or body , became easily confused by `` hasher marks '' inserted between hand-written words and thus confused the mark for one of the letters , and could recognize a simple straight line or a curved one only by tracing it . The patient himself denied that he had any visual imagery at all ; ;	AT NN PPL VBD CS PPS HVD DTI JJ NN IN ABN . .
and there was ample evidence of the following sort to corroborate him .	CC EX BEDZ JJ NN IN AT VBG NN TO VB PPO .
After a conversation with another man , he was able to recount practically everything that had been said but could not describe at all what the other man looked like .	IN AT NN IN DT NN , PPS BEDZ JJ TO VB RB PN WPS HVD BEN VBN CC MD * VB IN ABN WDT AT AP NN VBD CS .
Nor could he call up memory-pictures of close friends or relatives .	CC MD PPS VB RP NNS IN JJ NNS CC NNS .
In short , both his own declarations and his figural blindness , when he looked at objects , seem to present undeniable evidence that he had simply no visual memory at all .	IN JJ , ABX PP$ JJ NNS CC PP$ JJ NN , WRB PPS VBD IN NNS , VB TO VB JJ NN CS PPS HVD RB AT JJ NN IN ABN .
He was oblivious of the form of the object actually being viewed , precisely because he could not assign it to a visual shape , already learned and held in visual memory , as persons of normal vision do . He could not recognize it ; ;	PPS MD * VB PPO . .
he was absolutely unfamiliar with it because he had no visual memory at all .	PPS BEDZ QL JJ IN PPO CS PPS HVD AT JJ NN IN ABN .
Therefore , his only recourse was to learn the shape all over again for each new visual experience of the same individual object or type of object ; ;	RB , PP$ AP NN BEDZ TO VB AT NN QL RP RB IN DT JJ JJ NN IN AT AP AP NN CC NN IN NN . .
and this he could do only by going over its mass with the tracing procedure .	CC DT PPS MD DO RB IN VBG IN PP$ NN IN AT VBG NN .
Then he might finally recognize it , apparently by combining the visual blot , actually being seen , with tactual feelings in the head or body accompanying the tracing movements .	RB PPS MD RB VB PPO , RB IN VBG AT JJ NN , RB BEG VBN , IN JJ NNS IN AT NN CC NN VBG AT VBG NNS .
This would mean , it can readily be seen , that , again , for each new visual experience , the tracing motions would have to be repeated because of the absence of visual imagery .	DT MD VB , PPS MD RB BE VBN , CS , RB , IN DT JJ JJ NN , AT VBG NNS MD HV TO BE VBN RB IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
As one would surmise , the procedure , however , could be repeated with the same object or with the same type of object often enough , so that the corresponding visual blots and the merest beginning of the tracing movement would provide clues as to the actual shape , which the patient then immediately could determine by a kind of inference .	CS PN MD VB , AT NN , RB , MD BE VBN IN AT AP NN CC IN AT AP NN IN NN RB QLP , CS CS AT JJ JJ NNS CC AT JJT NN IN AT VBG NN MD VB NNS IN IN AT JJ NN , WDT AT NN RB RB MD VB IN AT NN IN NN .
Men , trees , automobiles , houses , and so on -- objects continually confronted in everyday life -- had each its characteristic blot-appearance and became easily recognizable , at the very beginning of tracing , by an inference as to what each was . Dice , for example , he inferred from black dots on a white surface .	NNS , IN NN , PPS VBD IN JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN .
He evidently could not actually see the corners of these objects , but their size and the dots gave them away .	PPS RB MD * RB VB AT NNS IN DTS NNS , CC PP$ NN CC AT NNS VBD PPO RB .
And the authors give numerous instances of calculated guessing on the patient's part to show how large a role it played in his process of readapting himself and how proficient he became at it . Often he seems even to have been able to guess correctly , without the tracing motions , solely on the basis of qualitative differences among the blot-like things which appeared in his visual experience . Perhaps the very important question -- What is , then , exactly the role of kinesthetic sensations in the patient's ability to recognize forms and shapes by means of the tracing movements when he is actually looking at things ? ? -- has now been raised in the reader's mind and in the following form .	-- HVZ RB BEN VBN IN AT NN$ NN CC IN AT VBG NN .
If the patient can perceive figure kinesthetically when he cannot perceive it visually , then , it would seem , the sense of touch has immediate contact with the spatial aspects of things in independence of visual representations , at least in regard to two dimensions , and , as we shall see , even this much spatial awareness on the part of unaided touch is denied by the authors . How , then , do the kinesthetic sensations function in all this ? ?	WRB , RB , DO AT JJ NNS VB IN ABN DT . .
The authors set about answering this fundamental question through a detailed investigation of the patient's ability , tactually , ( 1 ) to perceive figure and ( 2 ) to locate objects in space , with his eyes closed ( or turned away from the object concerned ) . Quite naturally , they make the investigation , first , by prohibiting the patient from making any movements at all and then , later , by repeating it and allowing the patient to move in any way he wanted to . When the patient was not allowed to move his body in any way at all , the following striking results occurred .	WRB AT NN BEDZ * VBN TO VB PP$ NN IN DTI NN IN ABN , AT VBG JJ NNS VBD .
Whenever artists , indeed , turned to actual representations or molded three-dimensional figures , which were rare down to 800 B.C. , they tended to reflect reality ( see Plate 6a , 9b ) ; ;	WRB NNS , RB , VBD IN JJ NNS CC VBD JJ NNS , WDT BED JJ RP IN CD NP , PPSS VBD TO VB NN ( VB NN-TL CD-TL , CD-TL ) . .
a schematic , abstract treatment of men and animals , by intent , rose only in the late eighth century .	AT JJ , JJ NN IN NNS CC NNS , IN NN , VBD RB IN AT JJ OD NN .
To speak of this underlying view of the world is to embark upon matters of subjective judgment .	TO VB IN DT VBG NN IN AT NN BEZ TO VB IN NNS IN JJ NN .
At the least , however , one may conclude that Geometric potters sensed a logical order ; ;	IN AT AP , RB , PN MD VB CS JJ-TL NNS VBD AT JJ NN . .
their principles of composition stand very close to those which appear in the Homeric epics and the hexameter line .	PP$ NNS IN NN VB QL RB IN DTS WDT VB IN AT JJ NNS CC AT NN NN .
Their world , again , was a still simple , traditional age which was only slowly beginning to appreciate the complexity of life .	PP$ NN , RB , BEDZ AT RB JJ , JJ NN WDT BEDZ RB RB VBG TO VB AT NN IN NN .
And perhaps an observer of the vases will not go too far in deducing that the outlook of their makers and users was basically stable and secure .	CC RB AT NN IN AT NNS MD * VB QL RB IN VBG CS AT NN IN PP$ NNS CC NNS BEDZ RB JJ CC JJ .
The storms of the past had died away , and the great upheaval which was to mark the following century had not yet begun to disturb men's minds .	AT NNS IN AT NN HVD VBN RB , CC AT JJ NN WDT BEDZ TO VB AT VBG NN HVD * RB VBN TO VB NNS$ NNS .
Throughout the work of the later ninth century a calm , severe serenity displays itself .	IN AT NN IN AT JJR OD NN AT JJ , JJ NN VBZ PPL .
In the vases this spirit may perhaps at times bore or repel one in its internal self-satisfaction , but the best of the Geometric pins have rightly been considered among the most beautiful ever made in the Greek world .	IN AT NNS DT NN MD RB IN NNS VB CC VB PN IN PP$ JJ NN , CC AT JJT IN AT JJ-TL NNS HV RB BEN VBN IN AT QL JJ RB VBN IN AT JJ NN .
The ninth century was in its artistic work `` the spiritually freest and most self-sufficient between past and future '' , and the loving skill spent by its artists upon their products is a testimonial to their sense that what they were doing was important and was appreciated .	AT OD NN BEDZ IN PP$ JJ NN `` AT RB JJT CC QL JJ IN NN CC NN '' , CC AT VBG NN VBN IN PP$ NNS IN PP$ NNS BEZ AT NN IN PP$ NN CS WDT PPSS BED VBG BEDZ JJ CC BEDZ VBN .
The Aegean in 800 B.C.	AT-HL NP-HL IN-HL CD-HL NP-TL
Geometric pottery has not yet received the thorough , detailed study which it deserves , partly because the task is a mammoth one and partly because some of its local manifestations , as at Argos , are only now coming to light .	JJ-TL NN HVZ * RB VBN AT JJ , VBN NN WDT PPS VBZ , RB CS AT NN BEZ AT JJ CD CC RB CS DTI IN PP$ JJ NNS , CS IN NP , BER RB RB VBG IN NN .
From even a cursory inspection of its many aspects , however , the historian can deduce several fundamental conclusions about the progress of the Aegean world down to 800 B.C.	IN RB AT JJ NN IN PP$ AP NNS , RB , AT NN MD VB AP JJ NNS IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN RP IN CD NP
.	.
The general intellectual outlook which had appeared in the eleventh century was now consolidated to a significant degree .	AT JJ JJ NN WDT HVD VBN IN AT OD NN BEDZ RB VBN IN AT JJ NN .
Much which was in embryo in 1000 had become reasonably well developed by 800 .	AP WDT BEDZ IN NN IN CD HVD VBN QL RB VBN IN CD .
In this process the Minoan-Mycenaean inheritance had been transmuted or finally rejected ; ;	IN DT NN AT JJ NN HVD BEN VBN CC RB VBN . .
the Aegean world which had existed before 1000 differed from that which rises more clearly in our vision after 800 .	AT JJ NN WDT HVD VBN IN CD VBD IN DT WDT VBZ QL RB IN PP$ NN IN CD .
Those modern scholars who urge that we must keep in mind the fundamental continuity of Aegean development from earliest times -- granted occasional irruptions of peoples and ideas from outside -- are correct ; ;	DTS JJ NNS WPS VB CS PPSS MD VB IN NN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN IN JJT NNS -- VBN JJ NNS IN NNS CC NNS IN RB -- BER JJ . .
but all too many observers have been misled by this fact into minimizing the degree of change which took place in the early first millennium .	CC QL QL AP NNS HV BEN VBN IN DT NN IN VBG AT NN IN NN WDT VBD NN IN AT JJ OD NN .
The focus of novelty in this world now lay in the south-eastern districts of the Greek mainland , and by 800 virtually the entire Aegean , always excepting its northern shores , had accepted the Geometric style of pottery .	AT NN IN NN IN DT NN RB VBD IN AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN , CC IN CD RB AT JJ NP , RB IN PP$ JJ NNS , HVD VBN AT JJ-TL NN IN NN .
While Protogeometric vases usually turn up , especially outside Greece proper , together with as many or more examples of local stamp , these `` non-Greek '' patterns had mostly vanished by the later ninth century .	CS JJ NNS RB VB RP , RB IN NP JJ , RB IN QL AP CC AP NNS IN JJ NN , DTS `` JJ '' NNS HVD RB VBN IN AT JJR OD NN .
In their place came local variations within the common style -- tentative , as it were , in Protogeometric products but truly distinct and sharply defined as the Geometric spirit developed .	IN PP$ NN VBD JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN -- JJ , CS PPS BED , IN JJ NNS CC QL JJ CC RB VBN CS AT JJ-TL NN VBD .
Attica , though important , was not the only teacher of this age .	NP , CS JJ , BEDZ * AT AP NN IN DT NN .
One can take a vase of about 800 B.C. and , without any knowledge of its place of origin , venture to assign it to a specific area ; ;	PN MD VB AT NN IN RB CD NP CC , IN DTI NN IN PP$ NN IN NN , VB TO VB PPO IN AT JJ NN . .
imitation and borrowing of motifs now become ascertainable .	NN CC VBG IN NNS RB VB JJ .
The potters of the Aegean islands thus stood apart from those of the mainland , and in Greece itself Argive , Corinthian , Attic , Boeotian , and other Geometric sequences have each their own hallmarks .	AT NNS IN AT JJ NNS RB VBD RB IN DTS IN AT NN , CC IN NP PPL JJ , JJ , JJ , JJ , CC AP JJ-TL NNS HV DT PP$ JJ NNS .
These local variations were to become ever sharper in the next century and a half .	DTS JJ NNS BED TO VB RB JJR IN AT AP NN CC AT ABN .
The same conclusions can be drawn from the other physical evidence of the Dark ages , from linguistic distribution , and from the survivals of early social , political , and religious patterns into later ages .	AT AP NNS MD BE VBN IN AT AP JJ NN IN AT JJ-TL NNS , IN JJ NN , CC IN AT NNS IN JJ JJ , JJ , CC JJ NNS IN JJR NNS .
By 800 B.C. the Aegean was an area of common tongue and of common culture .	IN CD NP AT NP BEDZ AT NN IN JJ NN CC IN JJ NN .
On these pillars rested that solid basis for life and thought which was soon to be manifested in the remarkably unlimited ken of the Iliad .	IN DTS NNS VBD DT JJ NN IN NN CC NN WDT BEDZ RB TO BE VBN IN AT RB JJ NN IN AT NP .
Everywhere within the common pattern , however , one finds local diversity ; ;	RB IN AT JJ NN , RB , PN VBZ JJ NN . .
Greek history and culture were enduringly fertilized , and plagued , by the interplay of these conjoined yet opposed factors .	JJ NN CC NN BED RB VBN , CC VBN , IN AT NN IN DTS VBN CC VBN NNS .
Further we cannot go , for the Dark ages deserve their name .	RBR PPSS MD* VB , CS AT JJ-TL NNS VB PP$ NN .
Many aspects of civilization were not yet sufficiently crystallized to find expression , nor could the simple economic and social foundations of this world support a lofty structure .	AP NNS IN NN BED * RB RB VBN TO VB NN , CC MD AT JJ JJ CC JJ NNS IN DT NN VB AT JJ NN .
The epic poems , the consolidation of the Greek pantheon , the rise of firm political units , the self-awareness which could permit painted and sculptured representations of men -- all these had to await the progress of following decades .	AT JJ NNS , AT NN IN AT JJ NN , AT NN IN JJ JJ NNS , AT NN WDT MD VB VBN CC VBN NNS IN NNS -- ABN DTS HVD TO VB AT NN IN VBG NNS .
What we have seen in this chapter , we have seen only dimly , and yet the results , however general , are worth the search .	WDT PPSS HV VBN IN DT NN , PPSS HV VBN RB RB , CC RB AT NNS , WQL JJ , BER JJ AT NN .
These are the centuries in which the inhabitants of the Aegean world settled firmly into their minds and into their institutions the foundations of the Hellenic outlook , independent of outside forces .	DTS BER AT NNS IN WDT AT NNS IN AT JJ NN VBD RB IN PP$ NNS CC IN PP$ NNS AT NNS IN AT JJ NN , JJ IN JJ NNS .
To interpret , indeed , the era from 1000 to 800 as a period mainly of consolidation may be a necessary but unfortunate defect born of our lack of detailed information ; ;	TO VB , RB , AT NN IN CD IN CD CS AT NN RB IN NN MD BE AT JJ CC JJ NN VBN IN PP$ NN IN VBN NN . .
if we could see more deeply , we probably would find many side issues and wrong turnings which came to an end within the period .	CS PPSS MD VB QL RB , PPSS RB MD VB AP NN NNS CC JJ NNS WDT VBD IN AT NN IN AT NN .
The historian can only point out those lines which were major enough to find reflection in our limited evidence , and must hope that future excavations will enrich our understanding .	AT NN MD RB VB RP DTS NNS WDT BED JJ QLP TO VB NN IN PP$ VBN NN , CC MD VB CS JJ NNS MD VB PP$ NN .
Throughout the Dark ages , it is clear , the Greek world had been developing slowly but consistently .	IN AT JJ-TL NNS , PPS BEZ JJ , AT JJ NN HVD BEN VBG RB CC RB .
The pace could now be accelerated , for the inhabitants of the Aegean stood on firm ground .	AT NN MD RB BE VBN , CS AT NNS IN AT NP VBD IN JJ NN .
Chapter 5 the early eighth century	NN-HL CD-HL AT-HL JJ-HL OD-HL NN-HL
the landscape of Greek history broadens widely , and rather abruptly , in the eighth century B.C. , the age of Homer's `` rosy-fingered Dawn '' .	AT NN IN JJ NN VBZ RB , CC QL RB , IN AT OD NN NP , AT NN IN NP$ `` JJ NN-TL '' .
The first slanting rays of the new day cannot yet dispel all the dark shadows which lie across the Aegean world ; ;	AT OD VBG NNS IN AT JJ NN MD* RB VB ABN AT JJ NNS WDT VB IN AT NP NN . .
but our evidence grows considerably in variety and shows more unmistakably some of the lines of change .	CC PP$ NN VBZ RB IN NN CC VBZ QL RB DTI IN AT NNS IN NN .
For this period , as for earlier centuries , pottery remains the most secure source ; ;	IN DT NN , CS IN JJR NNS , NN VBZ AT QL JJ NN . .
the ceramic material of the age is more abundant , more diversified , and more indicative of the hopes and fears of its makers , who begin to show scenes of human life and death .	AT JJ NN IN AT NN BEZ QL JJ , QL VBN , CC QL JJ IN AT NNS CC NNS IN PP$ NNS , WPS VB TO VB NNS IN JJ NN CC NN .
Figurines and simple chapels presage the emergence of sculpture and architecture in Greece ; ;	NNS CC JJ NNS VB AT NN IN NN CC NN IN NP . .
objects in gold , ivory , and bronze grow more numerous .	NNS IN NN , NN , CC NN VB QL JJ .
Since writing was practiced in the Aegean before the end of the century , we may hope that the details of tradition will now be occasionally useful .	CS VBG BEDZ VBN IN AT NP IN AT NN IN AT NN , PPSS MD VB CS AT NNS IN NN MD RB BE RB JJ .
Though it is not easy to apply the evidence of the Iliad to any specific era , this marvelous product of the epic tradition had certainly taken definitive shape by 750 .	CS PPS BEZ * JJ TO VB AT NN IN AT NP IN DTI JJ NN , DT JJ NN IN AT NN NN HVD RB VBN JJ NN IN CD .
The Dipylon Geometric pottery of Athens and the Iliad are amazing manifestations of the inherent potentialities of Greek civilization ; ;	AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN IN NP CC AT NP BER JJ NNS IN AT JJ NNS IN JJ NN . .
but both were among the last products of a phase which was ending .	CC ABX BED IN AT AP NNS IN AT NN WDT BEDZ VBG .
Greek civilization was swirling toward its great revolution , in which the developed qualities of the Hellenic outlook were suddenly to break forth .	JJ NN BEDZ VBG IN PP$ JJ NN , IN WDT AT VBN NNS IN AT JJ NN BED RB TO VB RB .
The revolution was well under way before 700 B.C. , and premonitory signs go back virtually across the century .	AT NN BEDZ RB IN NN IN CD NP , CC JJ NNS VB RB RB IN AT NN .
The era , however , is Janus-faced .	AT NN , RB , BEZ JJ .
While many tokens point forward , the main achievements stand as a culmination of the simple patterns of the Dark ages .	CS AP NNS VB RB , AT JJS NNS VB CS AT NN IN AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ-TL NNS .
The dominant pottery of the century was Geometric ; ;	AT JJ NN IN AT NN BEDZ JJ-TL . .
political organization revolved about the basileis ; ;	JJ NN VBD IN AT FW-NN . .
trade was just beginning to expand ; ;	NN BEDZ RB VBG TO VB . .
the gods who protected the Greek countryside were only now putting on their sharply anthropomorphic dress .	AT NNS WPS VBD AT JJ NN BED RB RB VBG RP PP$ RB JJ NN .
The modern student , who knows what was to come next , is likely to place first the factors of change which are visible in the eighth century .	AT JJ NN , WPS VBZ WDT BEDZ TO VB RB , BEZ JJ TO VB RB AT NNS IN NN WDT BER JJ IN AT OD NN .
Not all men of the period would have accepted this emphasis .	* ABN NNS IN AT NN MD HV VBN DT NN .
Many potters clung to the past the more determinedly as they were confronted with radically new ideas ; ;	AP NNS VBD IN AT NN AT QL RB CS PPSS BED VBN IN RB JJ NNS . .
the poet of the Iliad deliberately archaized .	AT NN IN AT NP RB VBD .
Although it is not possible to sunder old and new in this era , I shall consider in the present chapter primarily the first decades of the eighth century and shall interpret them as an apogee of the first stage of Greek civilization .	CS PPS BEZ * JJ TO VB JJ CC JJ IN DT NN , PPSS MD VB IN AT JJ NN RB AT OD NNS IN AT OD NN CC MD VB PPO CS AT NN IN AT OD NN IN JJ NN .
On this principle of division I must postpone the evolution of sculpture , architecture , society , and politics ; ;	IN DT NN IN NN PPSS MD VB AT NN IN NN , NN , NN , CC NN . .
for the developments in these areas make sense only if they are connected to the age of revolution itself .	CS AT NNS IN DTS NNS VB NN RB CS PPSS BER VBN IN AT NN IN NN PPL .
The growing contacts between Aegean and Orient are also a phase which should be linked primarily to the remarkable broadening of Hellenic culture after 750 .	AT VBG NNS IN NP CC NP BER RB AT NN WDT MD BE VBN RB IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN IN CD .
We shall not be able entirely to pass over these connections to the East as we consider Ripe Geometric pottery , the epic and the myth , and the religious evolution of early Greece ; ;	PPSS MD * BE JJ RB TO VB IN DTS NNS IN AT NR-TL CS PPSS VB JJ-TL JJ-TL NN , AT NN CC AT NN , CC AT JJ NN IN JJ NP . .
the important point , however , is that these magnificent achievements , unlike those of later decades , were only incidentally influenced by Oriental models .	AT JJ NN , RB , BEZ CS DTS JJ NNS , IN DTS IN JJR NNS , BED RB RB VBN IN JJ-TL NNS .
The antecedents of Dipylon vases and of the Iliad lie in the Aegean past .	AT NNS IN NP NNS CC IN AT NP VB IN AT JJ NN .
Dipylon pottery	NP-HL NN-HL
the pottery of the first half of the eighth century is commonly called Ripe Geometric .	AT NN IN AT OD NN IN AT OD NN BEZ RB VBN JJ-TL JJ-TL .
The severe yet harmonious vases of the previous fifty years , the Strong Geometric style of the late ninth century , display as firm a mastery of the principles underlying Geometric pottery ; ;	AT JJ CC JJ NNS IN AT JJ CD NNS , AT JJ-TL JJ-TL NN IN AT JJ OD NN , VB QL JJ AT NN IN AT NNS VBG JJ-TL NN . .
but artists now were ready to refine and elaborate their inheritance .	CC NNS RB BED JJ TO VB CC VB PP$ NN .
The vases which resulted had different shapes , far more complex decoration , and a larger sense of style .	AT NNS WDT VBD HVD JJ NNS , QL QL JJ NN , CC AT JJR NN IN NN .
Beyond the aesthetic and technical aspects of this expansion we must consider the change in pottery style on broader lines .	IN AT JJ CC JJ NNS IN DT NN PPSS MD VB AT NN IN NN NN IN JJR NNS .
In earlier centuries men had had enough to do in rebuilding a fundamental sense of order after chaos .	IN JJR NNS NNS HVD HVN AP TO DO IN VBG AT JJ NN IN NN IN NN .
They had had to work on very simple foundations and had not dared to give rein to impulses .	PPSS HVD HVN TO VB IN QL JJ NNS CC HVD * VBN TO VB NN IN NNS .
The potters , in particular , had virtually eschewed freehand drawing , elaborate motifs , and the curving lines of nature , while yet expressing a belief that there was order in the universe .	AT NNS , IN JJ , HVD RB VBN JJ VBG , JJ NNS , CC AT VBG NNS IN NN , CS RB VBG AT NN CS EX BEDZ NN IN AT NN .
In their vases were embodied the basic aesthetic and logical characteristics of Greek civilization , at first hesitantly in Protogeometric work , and then more confidently in the initial stages of the Geometric style .	IN PP$ NNS BED VBN AT JJ JJ CC JJ NNS IN JJ NN , IN RB RB IN JJ NN , CC RB QL RB IN AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ-TL NN .
By 800 social and cultural security had been achieved , at least on a simple plane ; ;	IN CD JJ CC JJ NN HVD BEN VBN , IN AP IN AT JJ NN . .
it was time to take bigger steps , to venture on experiments .	PPS BEDZ NN TO VB JJR NNS , TO VB IN NNS .
Ripe Geometric potters continued to employ the old syntax of ornaments and shapes and made use of the well-defined though limited range of motifs which they had inherited .	JJ JJ-TL NNS VBD TO VB AT JJ NN IN NNS CC NNS CC VBD NN IN AT JJ CS VBN NN IN NNS WDT PPSS HVD VBN .
In these respects the vases of the early eighth century represent a culmination of earlier lines of progress .	IN DTS NNS AT NNS IN AT JJ OD NN VB AT NN IN JJR NNS IN NN .
To the ancestral lore , however , new materials were added .	IN AT JJ NN , RB , JJ NNS BED VBN .
Painters left less and less of a vase in a plain dark color ; ;	NNS VBD AP CC AP IN AT NN IN AT JJ JJ NN . .
instead they divided the surface into many bands or covered it by all-over patterns into which freehand drawing began to creep .	RB PPSS VBD AT NN IN AP NNS CC VBD PPO IN JJ NNS IN WDT JJ NN VBD TO VB .
Wavy lines , feather-like patterns , rosettes of indefinitely floral nature , birds either singly or in stylized rows , animals in solemn frieze bands ( see Plates 11 - 12 ) -- all these turned up in the more developed fabrics as preliminary signs that the potters were broadening their gaze .	JJ NNS , JJ NNS , NNS IN RB JJ NN , NNS CC RB CC IN VBN NNS , NNS IN JJ NN NNS ( VB NNS-TL CD-TL IN-TL CD-TL ) -- ABN DTS VBD RP IN AT QL VBN NNS CS JJ NNS CS AT NNS BED VBG PP$ NN .
The rows of animals and birds , in particular , suggest awareness of Oriental animal friezes , transmitted perhaps via Syrian silver bowls and textiles , but the specific forms of these rows on local vases and metal products are nonetheless Greek .	AT NNS IN NNS CC NNS , IN JJ , VB NN IN JJ-TL NN NNS , VBN RB IN JJ NN NNS CC NNS , CC AT JJ NNS IN DTS NNS IN JJ NNS CC NN NNS BER RB JJ .
Though the spread of this type of decoration in the Aegean has not yet been precisely determined , it seems to appear first in the Cyclades , which were among the leading exporters of pottery throughout the century .	CS AT NN IN DT NN IN NN IN AT NP HVZ * RB BEN RB VBN , PPS VBZ TO VB RB IN AT NPS , WDT BED IN AT VBG NNS IN NN IN AT NN .
As the material at the command of the potters grew and the volume of their production increased , the local variations within a common style became more evident .	CS AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NNS VBD CC AT NN IN PP$ NN VBD , AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN VBD QL JJ .
Plate 12 illustrates four examples , which are Ripe or Late Geometric work of common spirit but of different schools .	NN CD VBZ CD NNS , WDT BER JJ-TL CC JJ-TL JJ-TL NN IN JJ NN CC IN JJ NNS .
Cook had discovered a beef in his possession a few days earlier and , when he could not show the hide , arrested him .	NP HVD VBN AT NN IN PP$ NN AT AP NNS RBR CC , WRB PPS MD * VB AT NN , VBD PPO .
Thinking the evidence insufficient to get a conviction , he later released him .	VBG AT NN JJ TO VB AT NN , PPS RBR VBD PPO .
Even while suffering the trip to his home , Cook swore to Moore and Lane that he would kill the Indian .	RB CS VBG AT NN IN PP$ NN , NP VBD IN NP CC NP CS PPS MD VB AT JJ .
Three weeks later , following his recovery , armed with a writ issued by the Catskill justice on affidavits prepared by the district attorney , Cook and Russell rode to arrest Martinez .	CD NNS RBR , IN PP$ NN , VBN IN AT NN VBN IN AT NP NN IN NNS VBN IN AT NN NN , NP CC NP VBD TO VB NP .
Arriving at daybreak , they found Julio in his corral and demanded that he surrender .	VBG IN NN , PPSS VBD NP IN PP$ NN CC VBD CS PPS VB .
Instead , he whirled and ran to his house for a gun , forcing them to kill him , Cook reported .	RB , PPS VBD CC VBD IN PP$ NN IN AT NN , VBG PPO TO VB PPO , NP VBD .
Both Cook's and Russell's lives were threatened by the Mexicans following the killing , but the company officers felt that in the end , it would serve to quiet them despite their immediate emotion .	ABX NN$-TL CC NP$ NNS BED VBN IN AT NPS IN AT NN , CC AT NN NNS VBD CS IN AT NN , PPS MD VB TO VB PPO IN PP$ JJ NN .
General manager Pels even suggested that it might be wise to keep the Mexicans in suspense rather than accept their offers to sell out and move away , and try to have a few punished .	JJ NN NP RB VBD CS PPS MD BE JJ TO VB AT NPS IN NN RB CS VB PP$ NNS TO VB RP CC VB RB , CC VB TO HV AT AP VBN .
On February 17 , Russell and Cook were sent to the Pena Flor community on the Vermejo to see about renting out ranches the company had purchased .	IN NP CD , NP CC NP BED VBN IN AT NP NP NN IN AT NP TO VB IN VBG RP VBZ AT NN HVD VBN .
While talking with Julian M. Beall , Francisco Archuleta and Juan Marcus appeared , both heavily armed , and after watching the house for a while , rode away .	CS VBG IN NP NP NP , NP NP CC NP NP VBD , ABX RB VBN , CC CS VBG AT NN IN AT NN , VBD RB .
It was nearly sundown before they finished the business with Beall and began riding down the stream .	PPS BEDZ RB NN CS PPSS VBD AT NN IN NP CC VBD VBG IN AT NN .
They had traveled only a short distance when they spotted five Mexicans riding along a horse-trail across the stream just ahead of them .	PPSS HVD VBN RB AT JJ NN WRB PPSS VBD CD NPS VBG IN AT NN IN AT NN RB RB IN PPO .
Suspecting an ambush , the two deputies decided to ride up a side canyon taking a short cut into Catskill .	VBG AT NN , AT CD NNS VBD TO VB IN AT NN NN VBG AT JJ NN IN NP .
After spending two nights ( Wednesday and Thursday ) in Catskill , the deputies again headed for the Vermejo to finish their business .	CS VBG CD NNS ( NR CC NR ) IN NP , AT NNS RB VBD IN AT NP TO VB PP$ NN .
They stayed with a rancher Friday night and by eleven o'clock Saturday morning passed the old Garnett Lee ranch .	PPSS VBD IN AT NN NR NN CC IN CD RB NR NN VBD AT JJ NP NP NN .
Half a mile below at the mouth of Salyer's Canyon was an old ranch that the company had purchased from A. J. Armstrong , occupied by a Mexican , his wife , and an old trapper .	ABN AT NN RB IN AT NN IN NP$-TL NN-TL BEDZ AT JJ NN WPO AT NN HVD VBN IN NP NP NP , VBN IN AT JJ , PP$ NN , CC AT JJ NN .
There were three houses in Salyer's Canyon just at the foot of a low bluff , the road winding along the top , entering above , and then passing down in front of the houses , thence to the Vermejo . To the west of this road was another low bluff , forty or fifty feet high , covered with scrub oak and other brush .	IN AT NR IN DT NN BEDZ DT JJ NN , CD CC CD NNS JJ , VBN IN JJ NN CC AP NN .
As they were riding along this winding road on the bench of land between the two bluffs , a volley of rifle fire suddenly crashed around the two officers .	CS PPSS BED VBG IN DT VBG NN IN AT NN IN NN IN AT CD NNS , AT NN IN NN NN RB VBD IN AT CD NNS .
Not a bullet touched Cook who was nearer the ambush , but one hit Russell in the leg and another broke his arm , passing on through his body .	* AT NN VBD NP WPS BEDZ JJR AT NN , CC CD VBD NP IN AT NN CC DT VBD PP$ NN , VBG RP IN PP$ NN .
With the first reports , Russell's horse wheeled to the right and ran towards the buildings while Cook , followed by a hail of bullets , raced towards the arroyo of Salyer's Canyon immediately in front of him , just reaching it as his horse fell .	IN AT OD NNS , NP$ NN VBD IN AT NR CC VBD IN AT NNS CS NP , VBN IN AT NN IN NNS , VBD IN AT NN IN NP$-TL NN-TL RB IN NN IN PPO , RB VBG PPO CS PP$ NN VBD .
Grabbing his Winchester from its sheath , Cook prepared to fight from behind the arroyo bank .	VBG PP$ NP IN PP$ NN , NP VBD TO VB IN IN AT NN NN .
Bullets were so thick , throwing sand in his face , that he found it difficult to return the fire .	NNS BED QL JJ , VBG NN IN PP$ NN , CS PPS VBD PPO JJ TO VB AT NN .
Noticing Russell's horse in front of the long log building , he assumed his friend had slipped inside and would be able to put up a good fight , so he began working his way down the ditch to join him .	VBG NP$ NN IN NN IN AT JJ NN NN , PPS VBD PP$ NN HVD VBN RB CC MD BE JJ TO VB RP AT JJ NN , RB PPS VBD VBG PP$ NN IN AT NN TO VB PPO .
At a very shallow place , two Mexicans rushed into the open for a shot .	IN AT QL JJ NN , CD NPS VBD IN AT JJ IN AT NN .
Dropping to one knee , Cook felled one , and the other struggled off with his comrade , sending no further fire in his direction .	VBG IN CD NN , NP VBD CD , CC AT AP VBD RP IN PP$ NN , VBG AT AP NN IN PP$ NN .
Just before leaving the arroyo where he was partially concealed , he did hear shots down at the house .	RB CS VBG AT NN WRB PPS BEDZ RB VBN , PPS DOD VB NNS RP IN AT NN .
Russell had reached the house as Cook surmised , dismounted , but just as the old trapper opened the door to receive him , he fell into the trapper's arms -- dead .	NP HVD VBN AT NN CS NP VBD , VBN , CC RB CS AT JJ NN VBD AT NN TO VB PPO , PPS VBD IN AT NN$ NNS -- JJ .
A bullet fired by one of the Mexicans hiding in a little chicken house had passed through his head , tearing a hole two-inches square on the outgoing side .	AT NN VBN IN CD IN AT NPS VBG IN AT JJ NN NN HVD VBN IN PP$ NN , VBG AT NN NNS JJ IN AT JJ NN .
