Before daylight Sunday morning , a posse of twenty-three men under the leadership of Deputy Sheriff Frank MacPherson of Catskill followed the trail to the house of Francisco Chaves , where 100 to 150 Mexicans had gathered .	IN NN NR NN , AT NN IN CD NNS IN AT NN IN JJ-TL NN-TL NP NP IN NP VBD AT NN IN AT NN IN NP NP , WRB CD IN CD NPS HVD VBN .

the Mexicans not only refused to give them , but told the possemen if they wanted a fight they could have it .	AT NPS * RB VBD TO VB PPO , CC VBD AT NNS CS PPSS VBD AT NN PPSS MD HV PPO .
Since the strength of the Mexicans had been underrated , too small a posse had been collected , and since the deputy had not been provided with search warrants , MacPherson and his men decided it was much wiser to withdraw . The posse's retreat encouraged the Mexicans to be overbearing and impudent .	AT NN$ NN VBD AT NPS TO BE VBG CC JJ .
During the following week , six tons of hay belonging to one rancher were burned ; ;	IN AT VBG NN , CD NNS IN NN VBG IN CD NN BED VBN . .

Increasing threats on his life finally convinced Cook that he should leave New Mexico .	VBG NNS IN PP$ NN RB VBD NP CS PPS MD VB JJ-TL NP-TL .

Cattle stealing and killing , again serious during the spring of 1891 , placed the land grant company officers in a perplexing position .	NNS NN CC NN , RB JJ IN AT NN IN CD , VBD AT NN NN NN NNS IN AT JJ NN .
They were reluctant to appoint sheriffs to protect the property , thus running the risk of creating disturbances such as that on the Vermejo , and yet the cowboys protested that they got no salary for arresting cattle thieves and running the risk of being shot .	PPSS BED JJ TO VB NNS TO VB AT NN , RB VBG AT NN IN VBG NNS JJ CS DT IN AT NP , CC RB AT NNS VBD CS PPSS VBD AT NN IN VBG NNS NNS CC VBG AT NN IN BEG VBN .
And the law virtually ignored the situation .	CC AT NN RB VBD AT NN .
The judge became ill just as the Colfax District Court convened , no substitute was brought in , no criminal cases heard , only 5 out of 122 cases docketed were tried , and court adjourned sine die after sitting a few days instead of the usual three weeks . Pels complained : `` Litigants and witnesses were put to the expense and inconvenience of going long distances to transact business ; ;	NP VBD : `` NNS CC NNS BED VBN IN AT NN CC NN IN VBG JJ NNS TO VB NN . .

Word reached the company that the man behind these depredations was Manuel Gonzales , a man with many followers , including a number who were kept in line through fear of him .	NN VBD AT NN CS AT NN IN DTS NNS BEDZ NP NP , AT NN IN AP NNS , IN AT NN WPS BED VBN IN NN IN NN IN PPO .

Telephone and telegraph	NN-HL CC-HL NN-HL
Manchester's unusual interest in telegraphy has often been attributed to the fact that the Rev. J. D. Wickham , headmaster of Burr and Burton Seminary , was a personal friend and correspondent of the inventor , Samuel F. B. Morse .	NP$ JJ NN IN NN HVZ RB BEN VBN IN AT NN CS AT NP NP NP NP , NN IN NP-TL CC-TL NP-TL NN-TL , BEDZ AT JJ NN CC NN IN AT NN , NP NP NP NP .
At any rate , Manchester did not lag far behind the first commercial system which was set up in 1844 between Baltimore and Washington .	IN DTI NN , NP DOD * VB RB IN AT OD JJ NN WDT BEDZ VBN RP IN CD IN NP CC NP .
In 1846 Matthew B. Goodwin , jeweler and watchmaker , became the town's first telegrapher in a dwelling he built for himself and his business `` two doors north of the Equinox House '' or `` one door north of the Bank , Manchester , Vermont '' .	IN CD NP NP NP , NN CC NN , VBD AT NN$ OD NN IN AT NN PPS VBD IN PPL CC PP$ NN `` CD NNS NR IN AT NP-TL NN-TL '' CC `` CD NN NR IN AT NN-TL , NP , NP '' .

Shares of capital stock at $15 each in the latter company were payable at the Bank of Manchester or at various other Vermont banks .	NNS IN NN NN IN NNS DT IN AT AP NN BED JJ IN AT NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL CC IN AP AP NP NNS .
A message of less than fifteen words to Bennington cost twenty-five cents .	AT NN IN AP IN CD NNS IN NP VBD CD NNS .

Orvis even needed to hire an assistant , Clark J. Wait .	NP RB VBD TO VB AT NN , NP NP NP .
The Manchester Journal commented editorially on the surprising amount of local telegraphic business .	AT NP-TL NN-TL VBD RB IN AT VBG NN IN JJ JJ NN .
In the fall of 1878 , the `` Popular Telegraph Line '' was established between Manchester and Factory Point by the owners , Paul W. Orvis , Henry Gray , J. N. Hard , and Clark J. Wait .	IN AT NN IN CD , AT `` JJ-TL NN-TL NN-TL '' BEDZ VBN IN NP CC NN-TL NN-TL IN AT NNS , NP NP NP , NP NP , NP NP NP , CC NP NP NP .

Electric power	JJ-HL NN-HL
electricity plays such an important part in community life today that it is difficult to envision a time when current was not available for daily use .	NN VBZ ABL AT JJ NN IN NN NN NR CS PPS BEZ JJ IN VB AT NN WRB NN BEDZ * JJ IN JJ NN .
Yet one has to go back only some sixty years .	CC PN HVZ TO VB RB RB RB CD NNS .
The first mention of an electric plant in Manchester seems to be one installed in Reuben Colvin's and Houghton's gristmill on the West Branch in Factory Point .	AT OD NN IN AT JJ NN IN NP VBZ TO BE CD VBN IN NP NP$ CC NP$ NN IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL IN NN-TL NN-TL .
No records are available as to the date or extent of installation , but it may have been in 1896 .	AT NNS BER JJ IN IN AT NN CC NN IN NN , CC PPS MD HV BEN IN CD .
On June 14 , 1900 the Manchester Journal reported that an electrical engineer was installing an electric light plant for Edward S. Isham at `` Ormsby Hill '' .	IN NP CD , CD AT NP-TL NN-TL VBD CS AT JJ NN BEDZ VBG AT JJ NN NN IN NP NP NP IN `` NP-TL NN-TL '' .
This was working by the end of August and giving satisfactory service .	DT BEDZ VBG IN AT NN IN NP CC VBG JJ NN .
In November 1900 surveying was done under John Marsden on the east mountains to ascertain if it would be possible to get sufficient water and fall to operate an electric power plant .	IN NP CD VBG BEDZ VBN IN NP NP IN AT NR NNS TO VB CS PPS MD BE JJ TO VB JJ NN CC NN TO VB AT JJ NN NN .
Nothing came of it , perhaps due to lack of opportunity for water storage .	PN VBD IN PPO , RB RB IN NN IN NN IN NN NN .
The next step was construction by the Manchester Light and Power Company of a plant on the west bank of the Battenkill south of Union Street bridge .	AT AP NN BEDZ NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL CC-TL NN-TL NN-TL IN AT NN IN AT NR NN IN AT NP NR IN NN-TL NN-TL NN .
This was nearly completed May 23 , 1901 with a promise of lights by June 10 , but the first light did not go on until September 28 .	DT BEDZ RB VBN NP CD , CD IN AT NN IN NNS IN NP CD , CC AT OD NN DOD * VB RP IN NP CD .
It was at the end of the sidewalk in front of the Dellwood Cemetery cottage .	PPS BEDZ IN AT NN IN AT NN IN NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL NN .

Manchester then had two competing power companies until 1904 , when the Manchester Light and Power Company purchased the transmission system of the Vail Company .	NP RB HVD CD VBG NN NNS IN CD , WRB AT NP-TL NN-TL CC-TL NN-TL NN-TL VBD AT NN NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL .
This was fortunate , as the Vail plant burned in 1905 .	DT BEDZ JJ , CS AT NP NN VBD IN CD .
The Colonial Light and Power Company was succeeded by the Vermont Hydro-Electric Corporation , which in turn was absorbed by the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation .	AT JJ-TL NN-TL CC-TL NN-TL NN-TL BEDZ VBN IN AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL , WDT IN NN BEDZ VBN IN AT JJ-TL NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL NN-TL .
The latter now furnishes the area with electricity distributed from a modern sub-station at Manchester Depot which was put into operation February 19 , 1930 and was improved in January 1942 by the installation of larger transformers .	AT AP RB VBZ AT NN IN NN VBN IN AT JJ NN IN NP-TL NN-TL WDT BEDZ VBN IN NN NP CD , CD CC BEDZ VBN IN NP CD IN AT NN IN JJR NNS .
For a time following the abandonment of the local plant , electric current for Manchester was brought in from the south with an emergency tie-in with the Vermont Marble Company system to the north .	IN AT NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN , JJ NN IN NP BEDZ VBN RP IN AT NR IN AT NN NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL NN-TL NN IN AT NR .
Some who have written on Utopia have treated it as `` a learned diversion of a learned world '' , `` a phantasy with which More amused himself '' , `` a holiday work , a spontaneous overflow of intellectual high spirits , a revel of debate , paradox , comedy and invention '' .	DTI WPS HV VBN IN NP-TL HV VBN PPO CS `` AT VBN NN IN AT VBN NN '' , `` AT NN IN WDT NP VBD PPL '' , `` AT NN NN , AT JJ NN IN JJ JJ NNS , AT NN IN NN , NN , NN CC NN '' .
With respect to this view , two points are worth making .	IN NN IN DT NN , CD NNS BER JJ VBG .
First , it appears to be based on the fact that on its title page Utopia is described as `` festivus '' , `` gay '' .	RB , PPS VBZ TO BE VBN IN AT NN CS IN PP$ NN NN NP-TL BEZ VBN CS `` FW-JJ '' , `` JJ '' .
It overlooks the other fact that it is described as `` Nec minus salutaris quam festivus '' , `` no less salutary than gay '' .	PPS VBZ AT AP NN CS PPS BEZ VBN CS `` FW-CC FW-QL FW-JJ FW-CS FW-JJ '' , `` QL QL JJ CS JJ '' .
It also overlooks the fact that in a rational lexicon , and quite clearly in More's lexicon , the opposite of serious is not gay but frivolous , and the opposite of gay is not serious but solemn .	PPS RB VBZ AT NN CS IN AT JJ NN , CC QL RB IN NP$ NN , AT NN IN JJ-NC BEZ * JJ-NC CC JJ-NC , CC AT NN IN JJ-NC BEZ * JJ-NC CC JJ-NC .
More believed that a man could be both serious and gay .	NP VBD CS AT NN MD BE ABX JJ CC JJ .
That a writer who is gay cannot be serious is a common professional illusion , sedulously fostered by all too many academics who mistakenly believe that their frivolous efforts should be taken seriously because they are expressed with that dreary solemnity which is the only mode of expression their authors are capable of .	CS AT NN WPS BEZ JJ MD* BE JJ BEZ AT JJ JJ NN , RB VBN IN QL QL AP NNS WPS RB VB CS PP$ JJ NNS MD BE VBN RB CS PPSS BER VBN IN DT JJ NN WDT BEZ AT AP NN IN NN PP$ NNS BER JJ IN .
Secondly , to find a learned diversion and a pleasing joke in More's account of the stupid brutalities of early sixteenth century wars , of the anguish of the poor and dispossessed , of the insolence and cruelty of the rich and powerful requires a callousness toward suffering and sin that would be surprising in a moral imbecile and most surprising in More himself .	RB , TO VB AT VBN NN CC AT JJ NN IN NP$ NN IN AT JJ NNS IN JJ OD NN NNS , IN AT NN IN AT JJ CC VBN , IN AT NN CC NN IN AT JJ CC JJ VBZ AT NN IN VBG CC NN WPS MD BE VBG IN AT JJ NN CC QL JJ IN NP PPL .
Indeed , it is even surprising in the Canon of Christ Church and Regius Professor of Ecclesiastical History , who fathered this most peculiar view , and in the brilliant Professor of Medieval and Renaissance English at Cambridge , who inherited it and is now its most eminent proponent .	RB , PPS BEZ RB JJ IN AT NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL NN-TL CC NP-TL NN-TL IN-TL JJ-TL NN-TL , WPS VBD DT QL JJ NN , CC IN AT JJ NN-TL IN-TL JJ-TL CC NN-TL NP-TL IN NP , WPS VBD PPO CC BEZ RB PP$ QL JJ NN .
But to return to the main line of our inquiry , it is doubtful that Utopia is still widely read because More was medieval or even because he was a martyr -- indeed , it is likely that these days many who read Utopia with interest do not even know that its author was a martyr .	CC TO VB IN AT JJS NN IN PP$ NN , PPS BEZ JJ CS NP-TL BEZ RB RB VBN CS NP BEDZ JJ CC RB CS PPS BEDZ AT NN -- RB , PPS BEZ JJ CS DTS NNS AP WPS VB NP-TL IN NN DO * RB VB CS PP$ NN BEDZ AT NN .
Utopia is still widely read because in a sense More stood on the margin of modernity .	NP-TL BEZ RB RB VBN CS IN AT NN NP VBD IN AT NN IN NN .
And if he did stand on the margins of modernity , it was not in dying a martyr for such unity as Papal supremacy might be able to force on Western Christendom .	CC CS PPS DOD VB IN AT NNS IN NN , PPS BEDZ * IN VBG AT NN IN JJ NN CS JJ NN MD BE JJ TO VB IN JJ-TL NP-TL .
It was not even in writing Latin epigrams , sometimes bawdy ones , or in translating Lucian from Greek into Latin or in defending the study of Greek against the attack of conservative academics , or in attacking the conservative theologians who opposed Erasmus's philological study of the New Testament .	PPS BEDZ * RB IN VBG JJ NNS , RB JJ NNS , CC IN VBG NP IN NP IN NP CC IN VBG AT NN IN NP IN AT NN IN JJ NNS , CC IN VBG AT JJ NNS WPS VBD NP$ JJ NN IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL .
Similar literary exercises were the common doings of a Christian humanist of the first two decades of the sixteenth century .	JJ JJ NNS BED AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN IN AT OD CD NNS IN AT OD NN .
Had More's writings been wholly limited to such exercises , they would be almost as dimly remembered as those of a dozen or so other authors living in his time , whose works tenuously survive in the minds of the few hundred scholars who each decade in pursuit of their very specialized occasions read those works .	HVD NP$ NNS BEN RB VBN IN JJ NNS , PPSS MD BE RB QL RB VBN CS DTS IN AT NN CC RB AP NNS VBG IN PP$ NN , WP$ NNS RB VB IN AT NNS IN AT AP CD NNS WPS DT NN IN NN IN PP$ QL VBN NNS VB DTS NNS .
More stands on the margins of modernity for one reason alone -- because he wrote Utopia .	NP VBZ IN AT NNS IN NN IN CD NN RB -- CS PPS VBD NP-TL .
And the evidence that he does , indeed , stand there derives quite simply from the vigorous interest with which rather casual readers have responded to that book for the past century or so .	CC AT NN CS PPS DOZ , RB , VB RB VBZ QL RB IN AT JJ NN IN WDT QL JJ NNS HV VBN IN DT NN IN AT AP NN CC RB .
Only one other contemporary of More's evokes so immediate and direct a response , and only one other contemporary work -- Niccolo Machiavelli and The Prince .	RB CD AP NN IN NP$ VBZ QL JJ CC JJ AT NN , CC RB CD AP JJ NN -- NP NP CC AT-TL NN-TL .
Can we discover what it is in Utopia that has evoked this response ? ?	MD PPSS VB WDT PPS BEZ IN NP-TL WPS HVZ VBN DT NN . .
Remember that in seeking the modern in Utopia we do not deny the existence of the medieval and the Renaissance there ; ;	VB CS IN VBG AT JJ IN NP-TL PPSS DO * VB AT NN IN AT JJ CC AT NP RB . .
we do not even need to commit ourselves to assessing on the same inconceivable scale the relative importance of the medieval , the Renaissance , and the modern .	PPSS DO * RB VB TO VB PPLS IN VBG IN AT AP JJ NN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ , AT NP , CC AT JJ .
The medieval was the most important to Chambers because he sought to place Thomas More , the author of Utopia , in some intelligible relation with St. Thomas More , the martyr .	AT JJ BEDZ AT QL JJ IN NP CS PPS VBD TO VB NP NP , AT NN IN NP-TL , IN DTI JJ NN IN NN-TL NP NP , AT NN .
To others whose concern it is to penetrate the significance of Christian Humanism , the Renaissance elements are of primary concern .	IN NNS WP$ NN PPS BEZ TO VB AT NN IN JJ NN-TL , AT NP NNS BER IN JJ NN .
But here we have a distinctly modern preoccupation ; ;	CC RB PPSS HV AT RB JJ NN . .
we want to know why that book has kept on selling the way it has ; ;	PPSS VB TO VB WRB DT NN HVZ VBN RP VBG AT NN PPS HVZ . .
we want to know what is perennially new about Utopia .	PPSS VB TO VB WDT BEZ RB JJ IN NP-TL .
What is new about it ? ?	WDT BEZ JJ IN PPO . .
To that question the answer is simple ; ;	IN DT NN AT NN BEZ JJ . .
it can be made in two words , Utopian communism .	PPS MD BE VBN IN CD NNS , JJ-TL-NC NN-NC .
But it is an answer which opens the door wide to an onrush of objections and denials .	CC PPS BEZ AT NN WDT VBZ AT NN JJ IN AT NN IN NNS CC NNS .
Surely there is nothing new about communism .	RB EX BEZ PN JJ IN NN .
We find it in Plato's Republic , and in Utopia More acknowledges his debt to that book .	PPSS VB PPO IN NP$ NN-TL , CC IN NP-TL NP VBZ PP$ NN IN DT NN .
We find it in that `` common way of life pleasing to Christ and still in use among the truest societies of Christians '' , that is , the better monasteries which made it easier to convert the Utopians to Christianity .	PPSS VB PPO IN DT `` JJ NN IN NN JJ IN NP CC RB IN NN IN AT JJT NNS IN NPS '' , DT BEZ , AT JJR NNS WDT VBD PPO JJR TO VB AT NPS IN NP .
We find it in the later Stoic conception of man's natural condition which included the community of all possessions .	PPSS VB PPO IN AT JJR NP NN IN NN$ JJ NN WDT VBD AT NN IN ABN NNS .
This conception was taken up by the early Church Fathers and by canon lawyers and theologians in the Middle Ages ; ;	DT NN BEDZ VBN RP IN AT JJ NN-TL NNS-TL CC IN NN NNS CC NNS IN AT JJ-TL NNS-TL . .
and More was far too well read not to have come across it in one or several of the forms thus given it .	CC NP BEDZ QL QL RB VBN * TO HV VBN IN PPO IN CD CC AP IN AT NNS RB VBN PPO .
But although the idea of communism is very old even in More's day and did not spring full-clad from his imagination in 1515 , it is not communism as such that we are concerned with .	CC CS AT NN IN NN BEZ QL JJ RB IN NP$ NN CC DOD * VB JJ IN PP$ NN IN CD , PPS BEZ * NN CS JJ WPO PPSS BER VBN IN .
We are concerned not with the genus communism nor with other species of the genus : Platonic , Stoic , early Christian , monastic , canonist or theological communism ; ;	PPSS BER VBN * IN AT NN NN CC IN AP NNS IN AT NN : JJ , NP , JJ JJ , JJ , JJ CC JJ NN . .
we are concerned with Utopian communism -- that is , simply communism as it appears in the imaginary commonwealth of Utopia , as More conceived it .	PPSS BER VBN IN JJ NN -- DT BEZ , RB NN CS PPS VBZ IN AT JJ NN IN NP , CS NP VBD PPO .
Perhaps one way to sharpen our sense of the modernity of Utopian communism is to contrast it with the principal earlier types of communistic theory .	RB CD NN TO VB PP$ NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN BEZ TO VB PPO IN AT JJS JJR NNS IN JJ NN .
We will achieve a more vivid sense of what it is by realizing what it is not .	PPSS MD VB AT QL JJ NN IN WDT PPS BEZ IN VBG WDT PPS BEZ * .
In Plato's Republic communism is -- to speak anachronistically -- a communism of Janissaries .	IN NP$ NN-TL NN BEZ -- TO VB RB -- AT NN IN NPS .
Its function is to separate from the base ruled mass , among whom private ownership prevails , the governing warrior elite .	PP$ NN BEZ TO VB IN AT JJ VBN NN , IN WPO JJ NN VBZ , AT VBG NN NN .
Moreover , it is too readily forgotten that in the Republic what gave the initial impetus to Plato's excursus into the construction of an imaginary commonwealth with its ruling-class communism of goods , wives , and children , was his quest for a canon for the proper ordering of the individual human psyche ; ;	RB , PPS BEZ QL RB VBN CS IN AT NN-TL WDT VBD AT JJ NN IN NP$ NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN PP$ NN NN IN NNS , NNS , CC NNS , BEDZ PP$ NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ JJ NN . .
and it is to this problem that the Republic ultimately returns .	CC PPS BEZ IN DT NN CS AT NN-TL RB VBZ .
In More's Utopia communism is not a means of separating out a warrior elite from the lumpish mass .	IN NP$ NP-TL NN BEZ * AT NN IN VBG RP AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN .
Utopian communism applies to all Utopians .	JJ NN VBZ IN ABN NPS .
And in the economy of the book it is not peripheral but central .	CC IN AT NN IN AT NN PPS BEZ * JJ CC JJ .
The concern of Utopia is with the optimo reipublicae statu , the best ordering of a civil society ; ;	AT NN IN NP-TL BEZ IN AT FW-JJT FW-NN FW-NN , AT JJT NN IN AT JJ NN . .
and it is again and again made clear that Utopian communism provides the institutional array indispensible to that best ordering .	CC PPS BEZ RB CC RB VBN JJ CS JJ NN VBZ AT JJ NN JJ IN DT JJT NN .
To derive Utopian communism from the Jerusalem Christian community of the apostolic age or from its medieval successors-in-spirit , the monastic communities , is with an appropriate shift of adjectives , misleading in the same way as to derive it from Plato's Republic : in the Republic we have to do with an elite of physical and intellectual athletes , in the apostolic and monastic communities with an elite of spiritual and religious athletes .	TO VB JJ NN IN AT NP JJ NN IN AT JJ NN CC IN PP$ JJ NNS , AT JJ NNS , BEZ IN AT JJ NN IN NNS , VBG IN AT AP NN CS TO VB PPO IN NP$ NN-TL : IN AT NN-TL PPSS HV TO DO IN AT NN IN JJ CC JJ NNS , IN AT JJ CC JJ NNS IN AT NN IN JJ CC JJ NNS .
The apostolic community was literally an elite : chosen by Christ himself .	AT JJ NN BEDZ RB AT NN : VBN IN NP PPL .
And the monastic communities were supposed to be made up of volunteers selected only after a novitiate which would test their religious aptitude for monastic rigors , their spiritual athleticism .	CC AT JJ NNS BED VBN TO BE VBN RP IN NNS VBN RB IN AT NN WDT MD VB PP$ JJ NN IN JJ NNS , PP$ JJ NN .
Finally , the conception of the natural community of all possessions which originated with the Stoics was firmly fixed in a tradition by More's time , although it was not accepted by all the theologian-philosophers of the Middle Ages .	RB , AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN ABN NNS WDT VBD IN AT NPS BEDZ RB VBN IN AT NN IN NP$ NN , CS PPS BEDZ * VBN IN ABN AT NNS IN AT JJ-TL NNS-TL .
In that tradition communism lay a safe distance back in the age of innocence before the Fall of Man .	IN DT NN NN VBD AT JJ NN RB IN AT NN IN NN IN AT NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL .
It did not serve to contrast the existing order of society with a possible alternative order , because the age of innocence was not a possible alternative once man had sinned .	PPS DOD * VB TO VB AT VBG NN IN NN IN AT JJ NN NN , CS AT NN IN NN BEDZ * AT JJ NN CS NN HVD VBN .
The actual function of patristic communism was adequately set forth by St. Gregory almost a millenium before More wrote Utopia .	AT JJ NN IN JJ NN BEDZ RB VBN RB IN NN-TL NP RB AT NN CS NP VBD NP-TL .
`` The soil is common to all men .	`` AT NN BEZ JJ IN ABN NNS .
When we give the necessities of life to the poor , we restore to them what is already theirs .	WRB PPSS VB AT NNS IN NN IN AT JJ , PPSS VB IN PPO WDT BEZ RB PP$$ .
We should think of it more as an act of justice than compassion '' .	PPSS MD VB IN PPO AP CS AT NN IN NN CS NN '' .
Because community not severalty of property is the law of nature no man can assert an absolutely unalterable right to what is his .	CS NN * NN IN NN BEZ AT NN IN NN AT NN MD VB AT QL JJ NN IN WDT BEZ PP$$ .
Indeed , of all that is his every man is by nature and reason and therefore by conscience obligated to regard himself as a custodian .	RB , IN ABN WPS BEZ PP$$ AT NN BEZ IN NN CC NN CC RB IN NN VBN TO VB PPL CS AT NN .
He is a trustee for the common good , however feeble the safeguards which the positive or municipal law of property provides against his misuse of that share of the common fund , wisely or unwisely , entrusted to his keeping .	PPS BEZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN , WQL JJ AT NNS WDT AT JJ CC JJ NN IN NN VBZ IN PP$ NN IN DT NN IN AT JJ NN , RB CC RB , VBN IN PP$ NN .
In contrast to this Stoic-patristic view , Utopia implies that the nature of man is such that to rely on individual conscience to supply the deficiencies of municipal law is to embark on the bottomless sea of human sinfulness in a sieve .	IN NN IN DT JJ NN , NP-TL VBZ CS AT NN IN NN BEZ JJ CS TO VB IN JJ NN TO VB AT NNS IN JJ NN BEZ TO VB IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN IN AT NN .
The Utopians brace conscience with legal sanctions .	AT NPS VB NN IN JJ NNS .
In a properly ordered society the massive force of public law performs the function which in natural law theory ineptly is left altogether to a small voice so often still .	IN AT RB VBN NN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN VBZ AT NN WDT IN JJ NN NN RB BEZ VBN RB IN AT JJ NN QL RB JJ .
In all the respects just indicated Utopian communism differs from previous conceptions in which community of possessions and living plays a role .	IN ABN AT NNS RB VBN JJ NN VBZ IN AP NNS IN WDT NN IN NNS CC VBG VBZ AT NN .
Neither from one of these conceptions nor from a combination of them can it be deduced .	CC IN CD IN DTS NNS CC IN AT NN IN PPO MD PPS BE VBN .
We do not deny originality to the Agamemnon because Aeschylus found the tales of the house of Atreus among the folk lore of the Greeks .	PPSS DO * VB NN IN AT NP-TL CS NP VBD AT NNS IN AT NN IN NP IN AT NN NN IN AT NPS .
In a like sense whatever bits or shreds of previous conceptions one may find in it , Utopian communism remains , as an integral whole , original -- a new thing .	IN AT JJ NN WDT NNS CC NNS IN AP NNS PN MD VB IN PPO , JJ NN VBZ , CS AT JJ NN , JJ -- AT JJ NN .
It is not merely a new thing ; ;	PPS BEZ * RB AT JJ NN . .
it is one of the very few new things in Utopia ; ;	PPS BEZ CD IN AT QL AP JJ NNS IN NP-TL . .
most of the rest is medieval or humanist or part of an old tradition of social criticism .	AP IN AT NN BEZ JJ CC JJ CC NN IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN .
But to say that at a moment in history something is new is not necessarily to say that it is modern ; ;	CC TO VB CS IN AT NN IN NN PN BEZ JJ BEZ * RB TO VB CS PPS BEZ JJ . .
and for this statement the best evidence comes within the five years following the publication of Utopia , when Martin Luther elaborates a new perception of the nature of the Divine's encounter with man .	CC IN DT NN AT JJT NN VBZ IN AT CD NNS IN AT NN IN NP-TL , WRB NP NP VBZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT NP$ NN IN NN .
New , indeed , is Luther's perception , but not modern , as anyone knows who has ever tried to make intelligible to modern students what Luther was getting at .	JJ , RB , BEZ NP$ NN , CC * JJ , CS PN VBZ WPS HVZ RB VBN TO VB JJ IN JJ NNS WDT NP BEDZ VBG IN .
Although Utopian communism is both new in 1516 and also modern , it is not modern communism or even modern socialism , as they exist or have ever existed in theory or in practice .	CS JJ NN BEZ ABX JJ IN CD CC RB JJ , PPS BEZ * JJ NN CC RB JJ NN , CS PPSS VB CC HV RB VBN IN NN CC IN NN .
Consider the features of Utopian communism : generous public provision for the infirm ; ;	VB AT NNS IN JJ NN : JJ JJ NN IN AT JJ . .
democratic and secret elections of all officers including priests , meals taken publicly in common refectories ; ;	JJ CC JJ NNS IN ABN NNS IN NNS , NNS VBN RB IN JJ NNS . .
a common habit or uniform prescribed for all citizens ; ;	AT JJ NN CC NN VBN IN ABN NNS . .
even houses changed once a decade ; ;	RB NNS VBN RB AT NN . .
six hours of manual labor a day for all but a handful of magistrates and scholars , and careful measures to prevent anyone from shirking ; ;	CD NNS IN JJ NN AT NN IN ABN IN AT NN IN NNS CC NNS , CC JJ NNS TO VB PN IN VBG . .
no private property , no money ; ;	AT JJ NN , AT NN . .
no sort of pricing at all for any goods or services , and therefore no market in the economic sense of the term .	AT NN IN VBG IN ABN IN DTI NNS CC NNS , CC RB AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN .
Whatever the merits of its intent , Utopian communism is far too naive , far too crude , to suit any modern socialist or communist .	WDT AT NNS IN PP$ NN , JJ NN BEZ QL QL JJ , QL QL JJ , TO VB DTI JJ NN CC NN .
It is not the details of Utopian communism that make Utopia modern , it is the spirit , the attitude of mind that informs those details .	PPS BEZ * AT NNS IN JJ NN WPS VB NP-TL JJ , PPS BEZ AT NN , AT NN IN NN WPS VBZ DTS NNS .
What that spirit and attitude were we can best understand if we see more precisely how it contrasts with the communist tradition with the longest continuous history , the one which reached Christianity by the way of Stoicism through the Church Fathers of Late Antiquity .	WDT DT NN CC NN BED PPSS MD RBT VB CS PPSS VB QL RB WRB PPS VBZ IN AT NN NN IN AT JJT JJ NN , AT CD WDT VBD NP IN AT NN IN NN-TL IN AT NN-TL NNS-TL IN JJ-TL NN-TL .
During the Dorr trial the Democratic press condemned the proceedings and heralded Dorr as a martyr to the principles of the Declaration of Independence .	IN AT NP NN AT JJ-TL NN VBD AT NNS CC VBD NP CS AT NN IN AT NNS IN AT NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL .
During the Brown trial , however , the state's most powerful Democratic newspaper , the Providence Daily Post , stated that Brown was a murderer , a man of blood , and that he and his associates , with the assistance of Republicans and Abolitionists , had plotted not only the liberation of the slaves but also the overthrow of state and federal governments .	IN AT NP NN , RB , AT NN$ QL JJ JJ-TL NN , AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL , VBD CS NP BEDZ AT NN , AT NN IN NN , CC CS PPS CC PP$ NNS , IN AT NN IN NPS CC NNS-TL , HVD VBN * RB AT NN IN AT NNS CC RB AT NN IN NN CC JJ NNS .
The Providence Daily Journal answered the Daily Post by stating that the raid of John Brown was characteristic of Democratic acts of violence and that `` He was acting in direct opposition to the Republican Party , who proclaim as one of their cardinal principles that they do not interfere with slavery in the states '' .	AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL VBD AT JJ-TL NN-TL IN VBG CS AT NN IN NP NP BEDZ JJ IN JJ-TL NNS IN NN CC CS `` PPS BEDZ VBG IN JJ NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL , WPS VB CS CD IN PP$ JJ NNS CS PPSS DO * VB IN NN IN AT NNS '' .
The two major newspapers in Providence continued , throughout the crisis , to accuse each other of misrepresenting the facts and attempting to falsify history .	AT CD JJ NNS IN NP VBD , IN AT NN , TO VB DT AP IN VBG AT NNS CC VBG TO VB NN .
While the Daily Post continued to accuse Republicans and the Daily Journal continued to accuse Democrats , the Woonsocket Patriot complained that the Virginia authorities showed indecent and cowardly haste to condemn Brown and his men .	CS AT JJ-TL NN-TL VBD TO VB NPS CC AT JJ-TL NN-TL VBD TO VB NPS , AT NP-TL NN-TL VBD CS AT NP NNS VBD JJ CC JJ NN TO VB NP CC PP$ NNS .
Editor Foss stated , `` Of their guilt there can be no doubt but they are entitled to sufficient time to prepare for trial , and a fair trial '' .	NN NP VBD , `` IN PP$ NN EX MD BE AT NN CC PPSS BER VBN IN JJ NN TO VB IN NN , CC AT JJ NN '' .
The Providence Daily Post thought that there were probably good reasons for the haste in which the trial was being conducted and that the only thing gained by a delay would be calmer feelings .	AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL VBD CS EX BED RB JJ NNS IN AT NN IN WDT AT NN BEDZ BEG VBN CC CS AT AP NN VBN IN AT NN MD BE JJR NNS .
The Providence Daily Journal stated that although the guilt of Brown was evident , the South must guarantee him a fair trial to preserve domestic peace .	AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL VBD CS CS AT NN IN NP BEDZ JJ , AT NR-TL MD NN PPO AT JJ NN TO VB JJ NN .
On October 31 , 1859 , John Brown was found guilty of treason against the state of Virginia , inciting slave rebellion , and murder .	IN NP CD , CD , NP NP BEDZ VBN JJ IN NN IN AT NN IN NP , VBG NN NN , CC NN .
For these crimes he was sentenced to be hanged in public on Friday , December 2 , 1859 .	IN DTS NNS PPS BEDZ VBN TO BE VBN IN NN IN NR , NP CD , CD .
Upon receiving the news , Northern writers , editors , and clergymen heaped accusations of murder on the Southern states , particularly Virginia .	IN VBG AT NN , JJ-TL NNS , NNS , CC NNS VBD NNS IN NN IN AT JJ-TL NNS , RB NP .
Although Rhode Islanders were preparing for the state elections , they watched John Brown's trial with extreme interest .	CS NP-TL NNS-TL BED VBG IN AT NN NNS , PPSS VBD NP NP$ NN IN JJ NN .
On Wednesday morning , November 2 , 1859 , the Providence Daily Journal stated that although Brown justly deserved the extreme penalty , no man , however criminal , ought to suffer the penalty without a fair trial .	IN NR NN , NP CD , CD , AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL VBD CS CS NP RB VBD AT JJ NN , AT NN , WQL JJ , MD TO VB AT NN IN AT JJ NN .
The editor's main criticism of the trial was the haste with which it was conducted .	AT NN$ JJS NN IN AT NN BEDZ AT NN IN WDT PPS BEDZ VBN .
The readers of the Providence Daily Post , however , learned that it was generally conceded that `` Old Brown '' had a fair trial .	AT NNS IN AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL , RB , VBD CS PPS BEDZ RB VBN CS `` JJ-TL NP-TL '' HVD AT JJ NN .
Concerning the sentence the editor asked , `` What else can Virginia do than to hang the men who have defied her laws , organized treason , and butchered her citizens '' .	IN AT NN AT NN VBD , `` WDT RB MD NP DO CS TO VB AT NNS WPS HV VBN PP$ NNS , VBN NN , CC VBN PP$ NNS '' .
In the eastern section of the state the newspapers' reaction to Brown's trial and sentence were basically identical .	IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN AT NNS$ NN IN NP$ NN CC NN BED RB JJ .
J. Wheaton Smith , editor of the Warren Telegraph stated that `` the ends of justice must be satisfied , a solitary example must be set , in order that all those misnamed philantropists , who , actuated by a blind zeal , dare to instigate riot , treason , and murder , may heed it and shape their future course accordingly '' .	NP NP NP , NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL VBD CS `` AT NNS IN NN MD BE VBN , AT JJ NN MD BE VBN , IN NN CS ABN DTS VBN NNS , WPS , VBN IN AT JJ NN , VB TO VB NN , NN , CC NN , MD VB PPO CC VB PP$ JJ NN RB '' .
The editor of the Newport Advertiser could discover no evidence of extenuating circumstances in the Brown trial which would warrant making an exception to the infliction of capital punishment .	AT NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL MD VB AT NN IN VBG NNS IN AT NP NN WDT MD VB VBG AT NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
In direct contrast to the other Rhode Island editors , Samuel S. Foss of the Woonsocket Patriot outwardly condemned the trial as being completely unfair .	IN JJ NN IN AT AP NP-TL NN-TL NNS , NP NP NP IN AT NP-TL NN-TL RB VBD AT NN CS BEG QL JJ .
Concerning the sentence , Foss wrote , `` If it be possible that mercy shall override vengeance and that John Brown's sentence shall be commuted to imprisonment , it would be well -- well for the country and for Virginia '' .	IN AT NN , NP VBD , `` CS PPS BE JJ CS NN MD VB NN CC CS NP NP$ NN MD BE VBN IN NN , PPS MD BE JJ -- JJ IN AT NN CC IN NP '' .
Despite the excitement being caused by the trial and sentence of John Brown , Rhode Islanders turned their attention to the state elections .	IN AT NN BEG VBN IN AT NN CC NN IN NP NP , NP-TL NNS-TL VBD PP$ NN IN AT NN NNS .
The state had elected Republican candidates in the past two years .	AT NN HVD VBN NP NNS IN AT AP CD NNS .
There was no doubt as to the control the Republican party exercised throughout the state .	EX BEDZ AT NN IN IN AT NN AT NP NN VBD IN AT NN .
If it failed on occasion to elect its candidates for general state offices by majorities , the failure was due to a lingering remnant of the Know-Nothing party , which called itself the American Republican party .	CS PPS VBD IN NN TO VB PP$ NNS IN JJ NN NNS IN NNS , AT NN BEDZ JJ IN AT VBG NN IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL , WDT VBD PPL AT JJ-TL NP NN-TL .
The American Republicans and the Republicans both nominated Lieutenant-Governor Turner for governor .	AT JJ-TL NPS CC AT NPS ABX VBD NN-TL NP IN NN .
Elisha R. Potter was the Democratic candidate .	NP NP NP BEDZ AT JJ-TL NN .
The results of the election of 1859 found Republican candidates not only winning the offices of governor and lieutenant-governor but also obtaining the two Congressional offices from the eastern and western sections of the state . During the month of November hardly a day passed when there was not some mention of John Brown in the Rhode Island newspapers .	IN AT NN IN NP RB AT NN VBD WRB EX BEDZ * DTI NN IN NP NP IN AT NP-TL NN-TL NNS .
On November 7 , 1859 , the Providence Daily Journal reprinted a letter sent to John Brown from `` E. B. '' , a Quaker lady in Newport .	IN NP CD , CD , AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL VBD AT NN VBN IN NP NP IN `` NP NP '' , AT NP NN IN NP .
In reference to Brown's raid she wrote , `` though we are non-resistants and religiously believe it better to reform by moral and not by carnal weapons , we know thee was anemated by the most generous and philanthropic motives '' .	IN NN IN NP$ NN PPS VBD , `` CS PPSS BER NNS CC RB VB PPO JJR TO VB IN JJ CC * IN JJ NNS , PPSS VB PPS BEDZ VBN IN AT QL JJ CC JJ NNS '' .
`` E. B. '' compared John Brown to Moses in that they were both acting to deliver millions from oppression .	`` NP NP '' VBD NP NP IN NP IN CS PPSS BED ABX VBG TO VB NNS IN NN .
In contrast to `` E. B. '' , most Rhode Islanders hardly thought of John Brown as being another Moses .	IN NN IN `` NP NP '' , AP NP-TL NNS-TL RB VBD IN NP NP CS BEG DT NP .
Most attempts to develop any sympathy for Brown and his actions found an unresponsive audience in Rhode Island .	AP NNS TO VB DTI NN IN NP CC PP$ NNS VBD AT JJ NN IN NP-TL NN-TL .
On Wednesday evening , November 23 , 1859 , in Warren , Rev. Mark Trafton of New Bedford , gave a `` Mission of Sympathy '' lecture in which he favorably viewed the Harper's Ferry insurrection . The Warren Telegraph stated that many of Rev. Trafton's remarks were inappropriate and savored strongly of radicalism and fanaticism .	AT NP-TL NN-TL VBD CS AP IN NP NP$ NNS BED JJ CC VBD RB IN NN CC NN .
In its account of the Trafton lecture , the Providence Daily Post said that the remarks of Rev. Trafton made the people indignant .	IN PP$ NN IN AT NP NN , AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL VBD CS AT NNS IN NP NP VBD AT NNS JJ .
No sympathy or admiration for Brown could be found in the Providence Daily Post , for the editor claimed that there were a score of men in the state prison who were a thousand times more deserving of sympathy . The Providence Daily Journal , however , stated that Brown's courage , bravery , and heroism `` in a good cause would make a man a martyr ; ;	AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN-TL , RB , VBD CS NP$ NN , NN , CC NN `` IN AT JJ NN MD VB AT NN AT NN . .
it gives something of dignity even to a bad one '' .	PPS VBZ PN IN NN RB IN AT JJ CD '' .
The Woonsocket Patriot admitted that John Brown might deserve punishment or imprisonment `` but he should no more be hung than Henry A. Wise or James Buchanan '' .	AT NP-TL NN-TL VBD CS NP NP MD VB NN CC NN `` CC PPS MD QL RBR BE VBN CS NP NP NP CC NP NP '' .

A week later the Daily Journal had discovered the initial plans of some Providence citizens to hold a meeting honoring John Brown on the day of his execution .	AT NN RBR AT JJ-TL NN-TL HVD VBN AT JJ NNS IN DTI NP NNS TO VB AT NN VBG NP NP IN AT NN IN PP$ NN .

The Providence Daily Post's editor wrote that he could not believe that a meeting honoring Brown was to be held in Providence .	AT NP-TL JJ-TL NN$-TL NN VBD CS PPS MD * VB CS AT NN VBG NP BEDZ TO BE VBN IN NP .

On December 2 , 1859 , John Brown was hanged at Charles Town , Virginia .	IN NP CD , CD , NP NP BEDZ VBN IN NP-TL NN-TL , NP .
Extraordinary precautions were taken so that no stranger be allowed in the city and no citizen within the enclosure surrounding the scaffold .	JJ NNS BED VBN CS CS AT NN BE VBN IN AT NN CC AT NN IN AT NN VBG AT NN .
In many Northern towns and cities meetings were held and church bells were tolled .	IN AP JJ-TL NNS CC NNS NNS BED VBN CC NN NNS BED VBN .
Such was not the case in Rhode Island .	JJ BEDZ * AT NN IN NP-TL NN-TL .
The only public demonstration in honor of John Brown was held at Pratt's Hall in Providence , on the day of his execution .	AT AP JJ NN IN NN IN NP NP BEDZ VBN IN NP$-TL NN-TL IN NP , IN AT NN IN PP$ NN .
Despite the opposition of the city newspapers , the Pratt Hall meeting `` brought together a very respectable audience , composed in part of those who had been distinguished for years for their radical views upon the subject of slavery , of many of our colored citizens , and of those who were attracted to the place by the novelty of such a gathering '' .	IN AT NN IN AT NN NNS , AT NP-TL NN-TL NN `` VBD RB AT QL JJ NN , VBN IN NN IN DTS WPS HVD BEN VBN IN NNS IN PP$ JJ NNS IN AT NN IN NN , IN AP IN PP$ VBN NNS , CC IN DTS WPS BED VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN IN ABL AT NN '' .
Seated on the platform were Amos C. Barstow , ex-mayor of Providence and a wealthy Republican stove manufacturer ; ;	VBN IN AT NN BED NP NP NP , NN IN NP CC AT JJ NP NN NN . .
Thomas Davis , an uncompromising Garrisonian ; ;	NP NP , AT JJ NP . .
the Reverend Augustus Woodbury , a Unitarian minister ; ;	AT NP NP NP , AT JJ NN . .
the Reverend George T. Day , a Free-Will Baptist ; ;	AT NP NP NP NP , AT NN-TL NP-TL . .

The first speaker was Amos C. Barstow who had been unanimously chosen president of the meeting .	AT OD NN BEDZ NP NP NP WPS HVD BEN RB VBN NN IN AT NN .
He spoke of his desire to promote the abolition of slavery by peaceable means and he compared John Brown of Harper's Ferry to the John Brown of Rhode Island's colonial period .	PPS VBD IN PP$ NN TO VB AT NN IN NN IN JJ NNS CC PPS VBD NP NP IN NP$-TL NN-TL IN AT NP NP IN NP-TL NN$-TL JJ NN .
Barstow concluded that as Rhode Island's John Brown became a canonized hero , if not a saint , so would it be with John Brown of Harper's Ferry .	NP VBD CS CS NP-TL NN$-TL NP NP VBD AT VBN NN , CS * AT NN , RB MD PPS BE IN NP NP IN NP$-TL NN-TL .

his deed was not below , but above the law '' .	PP$ NN BEDZ * IN , CC IN AT NN '' .
Following Day was Woodbury who spoke of his disapproval of Brown's attempt at servile insurrection , his admiration of Brown's character , and his opposition to slavery .	VBG NP BEDZ NP WPS VBD IN PP$ NN IN NP$ NN IN JJ NN , PP$ NN IN NP$ NN , CC PP$ NN IN NN .

In the remainder of his speech Davis spoke of his admiration for Brown and warned those who took part in the meeting that they `` are liable to the charge that they are supporting traitors and upholding men whom the laws have condemned '' . He recalled that in Rhode Island a party opposed to the state's condemnation of a man ( Thomas W. Dorr ) proclaimed the state's action as a violation of the law of the land and the principles of human liberty .	PPS VBD CS IN NP-TL NN-TL AT NN VBN IN AT NN$ NN IN AT NN ( NP NP NP ) VBD AT NN$ NN CS AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN CC AT NNS IN JJ NN .
At the close of Davis' speech the following preamble and resolutions were read by the president , and on the question of their adoption passed unanimously :	IN AT NN IN NP$ NN AT VBG NN CC NNS BED VBN IN AT NN , CC IN AT NN IN PP$ NN VBN RB :

Resolved that , while we most decidedly disapprove the methods he adopted to accomplish his objects , yet in his willingness to die in aid of the great cause of human freedom , we still recognize the qualities of a noble nature and the exercise of a spirit which true men have always admired and which history never fails to honor . Resolved that his wrongs and bereavements in Kansas , occasioned by the violence and brutality of those who were intent on the propagation of slavery in that territory , call for a charitable judgment upon his recent efforts in Virginia to undermine the despotism from which he had suffered , and commend his family to the special sympathy and aid of all who pity suffering and reverence justice . Resolved that the anti-slavery sentiment is becoming ripe for resolute action .	VBN CS AT JJ NN BEZ VBG JJ IN JJ NN .
Resolved , that we find in this fearful tragedy at Harper's Ferry a reason for more earnest effort to remove the evil of slavery from the whole land as speedily as possible .	VBN , CS PPSS VB IN DT JJ NN IN NP$-TL NN-TL AT NN IN QL JJ NN TO VB AT NN IN NN IN AT JJ NN QL RB CS JJ .
On the morning following the Pratt Hall meeting the editor of the Providence Daily Journal wrote that although the meeting was milder and less extreme than those held in other areas for similar purposes , it could have been avoided completely . Rather than being deceived , the eye is puzzled ; ;	RB CS BEG VBN , AT NN BEZ VBN . .
instead of seeing objects in space , it sees nothing more than -- a picture .	RB IN VBG NNS IN NN , PPS VBZ PN AP CS -- AT NN .
Through 1911 and 1912 , as the Cubist facet-plane's tendency to adhere to the literal surface became harder and harder to deny , the task of keeping the surface at arm's length fell all the more to eye-undeceiving contrivances .	IN CD CC CD , CS AT JJ-TL NN$ NN TO VB IN AT JJ NN VBD RBR CC RBR TO VB , AT NN IN VBG AT NN IN NN$ NN VBD ABN AT RBR IN JJ NNS .
To reinforce , and sometimes to replace , the simulated typography , Braque and Picasso began to mix sand and other foreign substances with their paint ; ;	TO VB , CC RB TO VB , AT VBN NN , NP CC NP VBD TO VB NN CC AP JJ NNS IN PP$ NN . .
the granular texture thus created likewise called attention to the reality of the surface and was effective over much larger areas .	AT JJ NN RB VBD RB VBD NN IN AT NN IN AT NN CC BEDZ JJ IN QL JJR NNS .
In certain other pictures , however , Braque began to paint areas in exact simulation of wood graining or marbleizing .	IN AP AP NNS , RB , NP VBD TO VB NNS IN JJ NN IN NN NN CC VBG .
These areas , by virtue of their abrupt density of pattern , stated the literal surface with such new and superior force that the resulting contrast drove the simulated printing into a depth from which it could be rescued -- and set to shuttling again -- only by conventional perspective ; ;	DTS NNS , IN NN IN PP$ JJ NN IN NN , VBD AT JJ NN IN QL JJ CC JJ NN CS AT VBG NN VBD AT VBN NN IN AT NN IN WDT PPS MD BE VBN -- CC VBN IN VBG RB -- RB IN JJ NN . .
that is , by being placed in such relation to the forms depicted within the illusion that these forms left no room for the typography except near the surface .	DT BEZ , IN BEG VBN IN JJ NN IN AT NNS VBN IN AT NN CS DTS NNS VBD AT NN IN AT NN RB IN AT NN .
The accumulation of such devices , however , soon had the effect of telescoping , even while separating , surface and depth .	AT NN IN JJ NNS , RB , RB HVD AT NN IN VBG , RB CS VBG , NN CC NN .
The process of flattening seemed inexorable , and it became necessary to emphasize the surface still further in order to prevent it from fusing with the illusion .	AT NN IN VBG VBD JJ , CC PPS VBD JJ TO VB AT NN QL RBR IN NN TO VB PPO IN VBG IN AT NN .
It was for this reason , and no other that I can see , that in September 1912 , Braque took the radical and revolutionary step of pasting actual pieces of imitation-woodgrain wallpaper to a drawing on paper , instead of trying to simulate its texture in paint .	PPS BEDZ IN DT NN , CC AT AP WPO PPSS MD VB , CS IN NP CD , NP VBD AT JJ CC JJ NN IN VBG JJ NNS IN NN NN IN AT NN IN NN , RB IN VBG TO VB PP$ NN IN NN .
Picasso says that he himself had already made his first collage toward the end of 1911 , when he glued a piece of imitation-caning oilcloth to a painting on canvas .	NP VBZ CS PPS PPL HVD RB VBN PP$ OD NN IN AT NN IN CD , WRB PPS VBD AT NN IN NN NN IN AT NN IN NN .
It is true that his first collage looks more Analytical than Braque's , which would confirm the date he assigns it .	PPS BEZ JJ CS PP$ OD NN VBZ QL JJ-TL CS NP$ , WDT MD VB AT NN PPS VBZ PPO .
But it is also true that Braque was the consistent pioneer in the use of simulated textures as well as of typography ; ;	CC PPS BEZ RB JJ CS NP BEDZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN VBN NNS QL RB CS IN NN . .
and moreover , he had already begun to broaden and simplify the facet-planes of Analytical Cubism as far back as the end of 1910 .	CC RB , PPS HVD RB VBN TO VB CC VB AT NNS IN JJ-TL NP-TL QL RB RB CS AT NN IN CD .
When we examine what each master says was his first collage we see that much the same thing happens in each .	WRB PPSS VB WDT DT NN NNS BEDZ PP$ OD NN PPSS VB CS AP AT AP NN VBZ IN DT .
( It makes no real difference that Braque's collage is on paper and eked out in charcoal , while Picasso's is on canvas and eked out in oil .	( PPS VBZ AT JJ NN CS NP$ NN BEZ IN NN CC VBN RP IN NN , CS NP$ BEZ IN NN CC VBN RP IN NN .
) By its greater corporeal presence and its greater extraneousness , the affixed paper or cloth serves for a seeming moment to push everything else into a more vivid idea of depth than the simulated printing or simulated textures had ever done .	) IN PP$ JJR JJ NN CC PP$ JJR NN , AT VBN NN CC NN VBZ IN AT JJ NN TO VB PN RB IN AT QL JJ NN IN NN CS AT VBN NN CC VBN NNS HVD RB VBN .
But here again , the surface-declaring device both overshoots and falls short of its aim .	CC RB RB , AT JJ NN ABX VBZ CC VBZ RB IN PP$ NN .
For the illusion of depth created by the contrast between the affixed material and everything else gives way immediately to an illusion of forms in bas-relief , which gives way in turn , and with equal immediacy , to an illusion that seems to contain both -- or neither .	CS AT NN IN NN VBN IN AT NN IN AT VBN NN CC PN RB VBZ NN RB IN AT NN IN NNS IN NN , WDT VBZ NN IN NN , CC IN JJ NN , IN AT NN WPS VBZ TO VB ABX -- CC DTX .
Because of the size of the areas it covers , the pasted paper establishes undepicted flatness bodily , as more than an indication or sign .	RB IN AT NN IN AT NNS PPS VBZ , AT VBN NN VBZ JJ NN RB , CS AP CS AT NN CC NN .
Literal flatness now tends to assert itself as the main event of the picture , and the device boomerangs : the illusion of depth is rendered even more precarious than before .	JJ NN RB VBZ TO VB PPL CS AT JJS NN IN AT NN , CC AT NN VBZ : AT NN IN NN BEZ VBN QL QL JJ CS RB .
Instead of isolating the literal flatness by specifying and circumscribing it , the pasted paper or cloth releases and spreads it , and the artist seems to have nothing left but this undepicted flatness with which to finish as well as start his picture .	RB IN VBG AT JJ NN IN VBG CC VBG PPO , AT VBN NN CC NN VBZ CC VBZ PPO , CC AT NN VBZ TO HV PN VBN IN DT JJ NN IN WDT TO VB QL RB CS VB PP$ NN .
The actual surface becomes both ground and background , and it turns out -- suddenly and paradoxically -- that the only place left for a three-dimensional illusion is in front of , upon , the surface .	AT JJ NN VBZ ABX NN CC NN , CC PPS VBZ RP -- RB CC RB -- CS AT AP NN VBN IN AT JJ NN BEZ IN NN IN , IN , AT NN .
In their very first collages , Braque and Picasso draw or paint over and on the affixed paper or cloth , so that certain of the principal features of their subjects as depicted seem to thrust out into real , bas-relief space -- or to be about to do so -- while the rest of the subject remains imbedded in , or flat upon , the surface .	IN PP$ QL OD NNS , NP CC NP VB CC VB IN CC IN AT VBN NN CC NN , CS CS AP IN AT JJS NNS IN PP$ NNS CS VBN VB TO VB RP IN JJ , NN NN -- CC TO BE RB TO DO RB -- CS AT NN IN AT NN VBZ VBN IN , CC JJ IN , AT NN .
And the surface is driven back , in its very surfaceness , only by this contrast .	CC AT NN BEZ VBN RB , IN PP$ AP NN , RB IN DT NN .
In the upper center of Braque's first collage , Fruit Dish ( in Douglas Cooper's collection ) , a bunch of grapes is rendered with such conventionally vivid sculptural effect as to lift it practically off the picture plane .	IN AT JJ NN IN NP$ OD NN , NN-TL NN-TL ( IN NP NP$ NN ) , AT NN IN NNS BEZ VBN IN JJ RB JJ JJ NN CS TO VB PPO RB IN AT NN NN .
The trompe-l'oeil illusion here is no longer enclosed between parallel flatnesses , but seems to thrust through the surface of the drawing paper and establish depth on top of it .	AT FW-NN NN RB BEZ QL RBR VBN IN JJ NNS , CC VBZ TO VB IN AT NN IN AT NN NN CC VB NN IN NN IN PPO .
Yet the violent immediacy of the wallpaper strips pasted to the paper , and the only lesser immediacy of block capitals that simulate window lettering , manage somehow to push the grape cluster back into place on the picture plane so that it does not `` jump '' .	CC AT JJ NN IN AT NN NNS VBN IN AT NN , CC AT QL JJR NN IN NN NNS WPS VB NN NN , VB RB TO VB AT NN NN RB IN NN IN AT NN NN CS CS PPS DOZ * `` VB '' .
At the same time , the wallpaper strips themselves seem to be pushed into depth by the lines and patches of shading charcoaled upon them , and by their placing in relation to the block capitals ; ;	IN AT AP NN , AT NN NNS PPLS VB TO BE VBN IN NN IN AT NNS CC NNS IN VBG VBN IN PPO , CC IN PP$ NN IN NN IN AT NN NNS . .
and these capitals seem in turn to be pushed back by their placing , and by contrast with the corporeality of the woodgraining .	CC DTS NNS VB IN NN TO BE VBN RB IN PP$ NN , CC IN NN IN AT NN IN AT NN .
Thus every part and plane of the picture keeps changing place in relative depth with every other part and plane ; ;	RB AT NN CC NN IN AT NN VBZ VBG NN IN JJ NN IN AT AP NN CC NN . .
and it is as if the only stable relation left among the different parts of the picture is the ambivalent and ambiguous one that each has with the surface .	CC PPS BEZ CS CS AT AP JJ NN VBN IN AT JJ NNS IN AT NN BEZ AT JJ CC JJ CD WPO DT HVZ IN AT NN .
And the same thing , more or less , can be said of the contents of Picasso's first collage .	CC AT AP NN , AP CC AP , MD BE VBN IN AT NNS IN NP$ OD NN .
In later collages of both masters , a variety of extraneous materials are used , sometimes in the same work , and almost always in conjunction with every other eye-deceiving and eye-undeceiving device they can think of .	IN JJR NNS IN ABX NNS , AT NN IN JJ NNS BER VBN , RB IN AT AP NN , CC QL RB IN NN IN AT AP JJ CC JJ NN PPSS MD VB IN .
The area adjacent to one edge of a piece of affixed material -- or simply of a painted-in form -- will be shaded to pry that edge away from the surface , while something will be drawn , painted or even pasted over another part of the same shape to drive it back into depth .	AT NN JJ IN CD NN IN AT NN IN VBN NN -- CC RB IN AT JJ NN -- MD BE VBN TO VB DT NN RB IN AT NN , CS PN MD BE VBN , VBN CC RB VBN IN DT NN IN AT AP NN TO VB PPO RB IN NN .
Planes defined as parallel to the surface also cut through it into real space , and a depth is suggested optically which is greater than that established pictorially .	NNS VBN CS RB IN AT NN RB VB IN PPO IN JJ NN , CC AT NN BEZ VBN RB WDT BEZ JJR CS DT VBN RB .
All this expands the oscillation between surface and depth so as to encompass fictive space in front of the surface as well as behind it .	ABN DT VBZ AT NN IN NN CC NN CS CS TO VB JJ NN IN NN IN AT NN QL RB CS IN PPO .
Flatness may now monopolize everything , but it is a flatness become so ambiguous and expanded as to turn into illusion itself -- at least an optical if not , properly speaking , a pictorial illusion .	NN MD RB VB PN , CC PPS BEZ AT NN VBN QL JJ CC VBN CS TO VB IN NN PPL -- IN AP AT JJ CS * , RB VBG , AT JJ NN .
Depicted , Cubist flatness is now almost completely assimilated to the literal , undepicted kind , but at the same time it reacts upon and largely transforms the undepicted kind -- and it does so , moreover , without depriving the latter of its literalness ; ;	VBN , JJ-TL NN BEZ RB QL RB VBN IN AT JJ , JJ NN , CC IN AT AP NN PPS VBZ IN CC RB VBZ AT JJ NN -- CC PPS DOZ RB , RB , IN VBG AT AP IN PP$ NN . .
rather , it underpins and reinforces that literalness , re-creates it .	RB , PPS VBZ CC VBZ DT NN , VBZ PPO .
Out of this re-created literalness , the Cubist subject reemerged .	RP IN DT VBN NN , AT JJ-TL NN VBD .
For it had turned out , by a further paradox of Cubism , that the means to an illusion of depth and plasticity had now become widely divergent from the means of representation or imaging .	CS PPS HVD VBN RP , IN AT AP NN IN NP , CS AT NN IN AT NN IN NN CC NN HVD RB VBN QL JJ IN AT NN IN NN CC NN .
In the Analytical phase of their Cubism , Braque and Picasso had not only had to minimize three-dimensionality simply in order to preserve it ; ;	IN AT JJ-TL NN IN PP$ NP , NP CC NP HVD * RB HVN TO VB NN RB IN NN TO VB PPO . .
they had also had to generalize it -- to the point , finally , where the illusion of depth and relief became abstracted from specific three-dimensional entities and was rendered largely as the illusion of depth and relief as such : as a disembodied attribute and expropriated property detached from everything not itself .	PPSS HVD RB HVN TO VB PPO -- IN AT NN , RB , WRB AT NN IN NN CC NN VBD VBN IN JJ JJ NNS CC BEDZ VBN RB CS AT NN IN NN CC NN CS JJ : CS AT VBN NN CC VBN NN VBN IN PN * PPL .
In order to be saved , plasticity had had to be isolated ; ;	IN NN TO BE VBN , NN HVD HVN TO BE VBN . .
and as the aspect of the subject was transposed into those clusters of more or less interchangeable and contour-obliterating facet-planes by which plasticity was isolated under the Cubist method , the subject itself became largely unrecognizable .	CC CS AT NN IN AT NN BEDZ VBN IN DTS NNS IN QL CC QL JJ CC JJ NNS IN WDT NN BEDZ VBN IN AT JJ-TL NN , AT NN PPL VBD QL JJ .
Cubism , in its 1911-1912 phase ( which the French , with justice , call `` hermetic '' ) was on the verge of abstract art .	NP , IN PP$ CD NN ( WDT AT NPS , IN NN , VB `` JJ '' ) BEDZ IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
It was then that Picasso and Braque were confronted with a unique dilemma : they had to choose between illusion and representation .	PPS BEDZ RB CS NP CC NP BED VBN IN AT JJ NN : PPSS HVD TO VB IN NN CC NN .
If they opted for illusion , it could only be illusion per se -- an illusion of depth , and of relief , so general and abstracted as to exclude the representation of individual objects .	CS PPSS VBD IN NN , PPS MD RB BE NN IN FW-PPL -- AT NN IN NN , CC IN NN , QL JJ CC VBN CS TO VB AT NN IN AP NNS .
If , on the other hand , they opted for representation , it had to be representation per se -- representation as image pure and simple , without connotations ( at least , without more than schematic ones ) of the three-dimensional space in which the objects represented originally existed .	CS , IN AT AP NN , PPSS VBD IN NN , PPS HVD TO BE NN IN FW-PPL -- NN CS NN JJ CC JJ , IN NNS ( IN AP , IN AP CS JJ NNS ) IN AT JJ NN IN WDT AT NNS VBN RB VBD .
It was the collage that made the terms of this dilemma clear : the representational could be restored and preserved only on the flat and literal surface now that illusion and representation had become , for the first time , mutually exclusive alternatives .	PPS BEDZ AT NN WPS VBD AT NNS IN DT NN JJ : AT NN MD BE VBN CC VBN RB IN AT JJ CC JJ NN RB CS NN CC NN HVD VBN , IN AT OD NN , RB JJ NNS .
In the end , Picasso and Braque plumped for the representational , and it would seem they did so deliberately .	IN AT NN , NP CC NP VBD IN AT NN , CC PPS MD VB PPSS DOD RB RB .
( This provides whatever real justification there is for the talk about `` reality '' .	( DT VBZ WDT JJ NN EX BEZ IN AT NN IN `` NN '' .
) But the inner , formal logic of Cubism , as it worked itself out through the collage , had just as much to do with shaping their decision .	) CC AT JJ , JJ NN IN NP , CS PPS VBD PPL RP IN AT NN , HVD QL QL AP TO DO IN VBG PP$ NN .
When the smaller facet-planes of Analytical Cubism were placed upon or juxtaposed with the large , dense shapes formed by the affixed materials of the collage , they had to coalesce -- become `` synthesized '' -- into larger planar shapes themselves simply in order to maintain the integrity of the picture plane .	WRB AT JJR NNS IN JJ-TL NP-TL BED VBN IN CC VBN IN AT JJ , JJ NNS VBN IN AT VBN NNS IN AT NN , PPSS HVD TO VB -- VB `` VBN '' -- IN JJR JJ NNS PPLS RB IN NN TO VB AT NN IN AT NN NN .
Left in their previous atom-like smallness , they would have cut away too abruptly into depth ; ;	VBN IN PP$ AP JJ NN , PPSS MD HV VBN RB QL RB IN NN . .
and the broad , opaque shapes of pasted paper would have been isolated in such a way as to make them jump out of plane .	CC AT JJ , JJ NNS IN VBN NN MD HV BEN VBN IN ABL AT NN CS TO VB PPO VB RP IN NN .
Large planes juxtaposed with other large planes tend to assert themselves as independent shapes , and to the extent that they are flat , they also assert themselves as silhouettes ; ;	JJ NNS VBN IN AP JJ NNS VB TO VB PPLS CS JJ NNS , CC IN AT NN CS PPSS BER JJ , PPSS RB VB PPLS CS NNS . .
and independent silhouettes are apt to coincide with the recognizable contours of the subject from which a picture starts ( if it does start from a subject ) .	CC JJ NNS BER JJ TO VB IN AT JJ NNS IN AT NN IN WDT AT NN VBZ ( CS PPS DOZ VB IN AT NN ) .
It was because of this chain-reaction as much as for any other reason -- that is , because of the growing independence of the planar unit in collage as a shape -- that the identity of depicted objects , or at least parts of them , re-emerged in Braque's and Picasso's papiers colles and continued to remain more conspicuous there -- but only as flattened silhouettes -- than in any of their paintings done wholly in oil before the end of 1913 .	PPS BEDZ RB IN DT NN QL RB CS IN DTI AP NN -- DT BEZ , RB IN AT VBG NN IN AT JJ NN IN NN CS AT NN -- CS AT NN IN VBN NNS , CC IN AP NNS IN PPO , VBD IN NP$ CC NP$ FW-NNS FW-JJ CC VBD TO VB QL JJ RB -- CC RB CS VBN NNS -- CS IN DTI IN PP$ NNS VBN RB IN NN IN AT NN IN CD .
Analytical Cubism came to an end in the collage , but not conclusively ; ;	JJ NP VBD IN AT NN IN AT NN , CC * RB . .
nor did Synthetic Cubism fully begin there .	CC DOD JJ-TL NP-TL RB VB RB .
Only when the collage had been exhaustively translated into oil , and transformed by this translation , did Cubism become an affair of positive color and flat , interlocking silhouettes whose legibility and placement created allusions to , if not the illusion of , unmistakable three-dimensional identities .	RB WRB AT NN HVD BEN RB VBN IN NN , CC VBN IN DT NN , DOD NP VB AT NN IN JJ NN CC JJ , VBG NNS WP$ NN CC NN VBD NNS IN , CS * AT NN IN , JJ JJ NNS .
Synthetic Cubism began with Picasso alone , late in 1913 or early in 1914 ; ;	JJ NP VBD IN NP RB , RB IN CD CC RB IN CD . .
this was the point at which he finally took the lead in Cubist innovation away from Braque , never again to relinquish it .	DT BEDZ AT NN IN WDT PPS RB VBD AT NN IN JJ-TL NN RB IN NP , RB RB TO VB PPO .
But even before that , Picasso had glimpsed and entered , for a moment , a certain revolutionary path in which no one had preceded him .	CC RB IN DT , NP HVD VBN CC VBN , IN AT NN , AT AP JJ NN IN WDT AT PN HVD VBN PPO .
It was as though , in that instant , he had felt the flatness of collage as too constricting and had suddenly tried to escape all the way back -- or forward -- to literal three-dimensionality .	PPS BEDZ CS CS , IN DT NN , PPS HVD VBN AT NN IN NN CS QL JJ CC HVD RB VBN TO VB ABN AT NN RB -- CC RB -- IN JJ NN .
This he did by using utterly literal means to carry the forward push of the collage ( and of Cubism in general ) literally into the literal space in front of the picture plane .	DT PPS DOD IN VBG QL JJ NNS TO VB AT JJ NN IN AT NN ( CC IN NP IN JJ ) RB IN AT JJ NN IN NN IN AT NN NN .
Some time in 1912 , Picasso cut out and folded a piece of paper in the shape of a guitar ; ;	DTI NN IN CD , NP VBD RP CC VBD AT NN IN NN IN AT NN IN AT NN . .
to this he glued and fitted other pieces of paper and four taut strings , thus creating a sequence of flat surfaces in real and sculptural space to which there clung only the vestige of a picture plane .	IN DT PPS VBD CC VBD AP NNS IN NN CC CD JJ NNS , RB VBG AT NN IN JJ NNS IN JJ CC JJ NN IN WDT EX VBD RB AT NN IN AT NN NN .
The affixed elements of collage were extruded , as it were , and cut off from the literal pictorial surface to form a bas-relief .	AT VBN NNS IN NN BED VBN , CS PPS BED , CC VBN RP IN AT JJ JJ NN TO VB AT NN .
Los Angeles in 1957 finally bowed to the skyscraper .	NP NP IN CD RB VBD IN AT NN .
) And without high density in the core , rapid-transit systems cannot be maintained economically , let alone built from scratch at today's prices .	) CC IN JJ NN IN AT NN , NN NNS MD* BE VBN RB , VB RB VBN IN NN IN NR$ NNS .
However , the building of freeways and garages cannot continue forever .	RB , AT NN IN NNS CC NNS MD* VB RB .
The new interchange among the four Los Angeles freeways , including the grade-constructed accesses , occupies by itself no less than eighty acres of downtown land , one-eighth of a square mile , an area about the size of Rockefeller Center in New York .	AT JJ NN IN AT CD NP NP NNS , IN AT JJ NNS , VBZ IN PPL QL AP CS CD NNS IN NR NN , NN IN AT JJ NN , AT NN RB AT NN IN NP-TL NN-TL IN JJ-TL NP-TL .
It is hard to believe that this mass of intertwined concrete constitutes what the law calls `` the highest and best use '' of centrally located urban land .	PPS BEZ JJ TO VB CS DT NN IN VBN NN VBZ WDT AT NN VBZ `` AT JJT CC JJT NN '' IN RB VBN JJ NN .
As it affects the city's fiscal situation , such an interchange is ruinous ; ;	CS PPS VBZ AT NN$ JJ NN , ABL AT NN BEZ JJ . .
it removes forever from the tax rolls property which should be taxed to pay for the city services .	PPS VBZ RB IN AT NN NNS NN WDT MD BE VBN TO VB IN AT NN NNS .
Subways improved land values without taking away land ; ;	NNS VBD NN NNS IN VBG RB NN . .
freeways boost valuation less ( because the garages they require are not prime buildings by a long shot ) , and reduce the acreage that can be taxed .	NNS VB NN RBR ( CS AT NNS PPSS VB BER * JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN ) , CC VB AT NN WPS MD BE VBN .
Downtown Los Angeles is already two-thirds freeway , interchange , street , parking lot and garage -- one of those preposterous `` if '' statistics has already come to pass .	NR NP NP BEZ RB NNS NN , NN , NN , VBG NN CC NN -- CD IN DTS JJ `` NIL '' NNS HVZ RB VBN TO VB .
The freeway with narrowly spaced interchanges concentrates and mitigates the access problem , but it also acts inevitably as an artificial , isolating boundary .	AT NN IN RB VBN NNS VBZ CC VBZ AT NN NN , CC PPS RB VBZ RB CS AT JJ , VBG NN .
City planners do not always use this boundary as effectively as they might .	NN NNS DO * RB VB DT NN QL RB CS PPSS MD .
Less ambitious freeway plans may be more successful -- especially when the roadways and interchanges are raised , allowing for cross access at many points and providing parking areas below the ramp .	QL JJ NN NNS MD BE QL JJ -- RB WRB AT NNS CC NNS BER VBN , VBG IN JJ NN IN AP NNS CC VBG VBG NNS IN AT NN .
Meanwhile , the automobile and its friend the truck have cost the central city some of its industrial dominance .	RB , AT NN CC PP$ NN AT NN HV VBN AT JJ NN DTI IN PP$ JJ NN .
In ever greater numbers , factories are locating in the suburbs or in `` industrial parks '' removed from the city's political jurisdiction .	IN RB JJR NNS , NNS BER VBG IN AT NNS CC IN `` JJ NNS '' VBN IN AT NN$ JJ NN .
The appeal of the suburb is particularly strong for heavy industry , which must move bulky objects along a lengthy assembly line and wants enough land area to do the entire job on one floor .	AT NN IN AT NN BEZ QL JJ IN JJ NN , WDT MD VB JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN NN CC VBZ AP NN NN TO DO AT JJ NN IN CD NN .
To light industry , the economies of being on one floor are much slighter , but efficiency engineers usually believe in them , and manufacturers looking for ways to cut costs cannot be prevented from turning to efficiency engineers .	IN JJ NN , AT NNS IN BEG IN CD NN BER QL JJR , CC NN NNS RB VB IN PPO , CC NNS VBG IN NNS TO VB NNS MD* BE VBN IN VBG IN NN NNS .
This movement of industry away from the central cities is not so catastrophically new as some prophets seem to believe .	DT NN IN NN RB IN AT JJ NNS BEZ * QL QL JJ CS DTI NNS VB TO VB .
It is merely the latest example of the leapfrog growth which formed the pattern of virtually all American cities .	PPS BEZ RB AT JJT NN IN AT NN NN WDT VBD AT NN IN RB ABN JJ NNS .
The big factories which are relatively near the centers of our cities -- the rubber factories in Akron , Chrysler's Detroit plants , U.S. Steel's Pittsburgh works -- often began on these sites at a time when that was the edge of the city , yet close to transport ( river ) , storage ( piers ) and power ( river ) .	AT JJ NNS WDT BER QL IN AT NNS IN PP$ NNS -- AT NN NNS IN NP , NP$ NP NNS , NP-TL NN$-TL NP NNS -- RB VBD IN DTS NNS IN AT NN WRB DT BEDZ AT NN IN AT NN , CC RB IN NN ( NN ) , NN ( NNS ) CC NN ( NN ) .
The `` leapfrog '' was a phenomenon of the railroad and the steam turbine , and the time when the belts of residence surrounding the old factory area were not yet blighted .	AT `` NN '' BEDZ AT NN IN AT NN CC AT NN NN , CC AT NN WRB AT NNS IN NN VBG AT JJ NN NN BED * RB VBN .
The truck and the car gave the manufacturer a new degree of freedom in selecting his plant site .	AT NN CC AT NN VBD AT NN AT JJ NN IN NN IN VBG PP$ NN NN .
Until internal combustion became cheap , he had to be near a railroad siding and a trolley line or an existing large community of lower-class homes .	CS JJ NN VBD JJ , PPS HVD TO BE IN AT NN NN CC AT NN NN CC AT VBG JJ NN IN NN NNS .
The railroad siding is still important -- it is usually , though not always , true that long-haul shipment by rail is cheaper than trucking .	AT NN NN BEZ RB JJ -- PPS BEZ RB , CS * RB , JJ CS NN NN IN NN BEZ JJR CS VBG .
But anybody who promises a substantial volume of business can get a railroad to run a short spur to his plant these days , and many businesses can live without the railroad .	CC PN WPS VBZ AT JJ NN IN NN MD VB AT NN TO VB AT JJ NN IN PP$ NN DTS NNS , CC AP NNS MD VB IN AT NN .
And there are now many millions of workers for whom the factory with the big parking lot , which can be reached by driving across or against the usual pattern of rush hour traffic and grille-route bus lines , is actually more convenient than the walk-to factory .	CC EX BER RB AP NNS IN NNS IN WPO AT NN IN AT JJ VBG NN , WDT MD BE VBN IN VBG IN CC IN AT JJ NN IN NN NN NN CC NN NN NNS , BEZ RB QL JJ CS AT JJ NN .
Willow Run , General Electric's enormous installations at Louisville and Syracuse , the Pentagon , Boeing in Seattle , Douglas and Lockheed in Los Angeles , the new automobile assembly plants everywhere -- none of these is substantially served by any sort of conventional mass rapid transit . They are all suburban plants , relying on the roads to keep them supplied with workers .	PPSS BER ABN JJ NNS , VBG IN AT NNS TO VB PPO VBN IN NNS .
And wherever the new thruways go up their banks are lined by neat glass and metal and colored brick light industry .	CC WRB AT JJ NNS VB RP PP$ NNS BER VBN IN JJ NN CC NN CC VBN NN JJ NN .
The drive along Massachusetts' Route 128 , the by-pass which makes an arc about twenty miles from downtown Boston , may be a vision of the future .	AT NN IN NP$ NN-TL CD-TL , AT NN WDT VBZ AT NN RB CD NNS IN NR NP , MD BE AT NN IN AT NN .
The future could be worse .	AT NN MD BE JJR .
The plants along Route 128 are mostly well designed and nicely set against the New England rocks and trees .	AT NNS IN NN-TL CD-TL BER RB RB VBN CC RB VBN IN AT JJ-TL NP-TL NNS CC NNS .
They can even be rather grand , like Edward Land's monument to the astonishing success of Polaroid .	PPSS MD RB BE QL JJ , CS NP NP$ NN IN AT JJ NN IN NP .
But they deny the values of the city -- the crowded , competitive , tolerant city , the `` melting pot '' which gave off so many of the most admirable American qualities .	CC PPSS VB AT NNS IN AT NN -- AT VBN , JJ , JJ NN , AT `` VBG NN '' WDT VBD RP QL AP IN AT QL JJ JJ NNS .
They are segregated businesses , combining again on one site the factory and the office , drawing their work force from segregated communities .	PPSS BER VBN NNS , VBG RB IN CD NN AT NN CC AT NN , VBG PP$ NN NN IN VBN NNS .
It is interesting to note how many of the plants on Massachusetts' Route 128 draw most of their income either from the government in non-competitive cost-plus arrangements , or from the exploitation of patents which grant at least a partial monopoly .	PPS BEZ JJ TO VB WQL AP IN AT NNS IN NP$ NN-TL CD VB AP IN PP$ NN CC IN AT NN IN JJ NN NNS , CC IN AT NN IN NNS WDT VB IN AP AT JJ NN .
While the factories were always the center of the labor market , they were often on the city's periphery .	CS AT NNS BED RB AT NN IN AT NN NN , PPSS BED RB IN AT NN$ NN .
In spreading the factories even farther , the automobile may not have changed to any great extent the growth pattern of the cities .	IN VBG AT NNS QL RBR , AT NN MD * HV VBN IN DTI JJ NN AT NN NN IN AT NNS .
Even the loss of hotel business to the outskirt's motel has been relatively painless ; ;	RB AT NN IN NN NN IN AT NN$ NN HVZ BEN QL JJ . .
the hotel-motel demarcation is becoming harder to find every year .	AT NN NN BEZ VBG JJR TO VB AT NN .
What hurts most is the damage the automobile has done to central-city retailing , especially in those cities where public transit is feeble .	WDT VBZ RBT BEZ AT NN AT NN HVZ VBN IN NN NN , RB IN DTS NNS WRB JJ NN BEZ JJ .
Some retailing , of course , always spreads with the population -- grocery stores , drugstores , local haberdasheries and dress shops , candy stores and the like .	DTI NN , IN NN , RB VBZ IN AT NN -- NN NNS , NNS , JJ NNS CC NN NNS , NN NNS CC AT JJ .
But whenever a major purchase was contemplated forty years ago -- a new bedroom set or a winter coat , an Easter bonnet , a bicycle for Junior -- the family set off for the downtown department store , where the selection would be greatest .	CC WRB AT JJ NN BEDZ VBN CD NNS RB -- AT JJ NN NN CC AT NN NN , AT NP NN , AT NN IN NP -- AT NN VBD RP IN AT NR NN NN , WRB AT NN MD BE JJT .
Department stores congregated in the `` one hundred per cent location '' , where all the transit lines converged .	NN NNS VBD IN AT `` CD CD IN NN NN '' , WRB ABN AT NN NNS VBD .
These stores are still there , but the volume of the `` downtown store '' has been on a relative decline , while in many cities the suburban `` branch '' sells more and more dry goods .	DTS NNS BER RB RB , CC AT NN IN AT `` NR NN '' HVZ BEN IN AT JJ NN , CS IN AP NNS AT JJ `` NN '' VBZ AP CC AP JJ NNS .
If the retailer and hotelman's downtown unit sales have been decreasing , however , his dollar volume continues to rise , and it is dollars which you put in the bank .	CS AT NN CC NN$ NR NN NNS HV BEN VBG , RB , PP$ NN NN VBZ TO VB , CC PPS BEZ NNS WDT PPSS VB IN AT NN .
In most discussions of this phenomenon , the figures are substantially inflated .	IN AP NNS IN DT NN , AT NNS BER RB VBN .
No suburban shopping-center branch -- not even Hudson's vast Northland outside Detroit -- does anything like the unit volume of business or carries anything like the variety of merchandise to be found in the home store .	AT JJ NN NN -- * RB NP$ JJ NP IN NP -- DOZ PN CS AT NN NN IN NN CC VBZ PN CS AT NN IN NN TO BE VBN IN AT NN NN .
Telephone orders distort the picture : the suburbanite naturally calls a local rather than a central-city number if both are listed in an advertisement , especially if the local call eliminates city sales tax .	NN NNS VB AT NN : AT NN RB VBZ AT JJ RB CS AT NN NN CS ABX BER VBN IN AT NN , RB CS AT JJ NN VBZ NN NNS NN .
The suburban branch is thereby credited with a sale which would have been made even if its glass doors had never opened .	AT JJ NN BEZ RB VBN IN AT NN WDT MD HV BEN VBN RB CS PP$ NN NNS HVD RB VBN .
Accounting procedures which continue to charge a disproportionate overhead and warehouse expense to the main store make the branches seem more profitable than they are .	VBG NNS WDT VB TO VB AT JJ NN CC NN NN IN AT JJS NN VB AT NNS VB QL JJ CS PPSS BER .
In many cases that statement -- `` We break even on our downtown operation and make money on our branches '' -- would be turned around if the cost analysis were recalculated on terms less prejudicial to the old store .	IN AP NNS DT NN -- `` PPSS VB JJ IN PP$ NR NN CC VB NN IN PP$ NNS '' -- MD BE VBN RB CS AT NN NN BED VBN IN NNS QL JJ IN AT JJ NN .
Fear of the competition -- always a great motivating force in the American economy -- makes retailers who do not have suburban operations exaggerate both the volume and the profitability of their rival's shiny new branches .	NN IN AT NN -- RB AT JJ VBG NN IN AT JJ NN -- VBZ NNS WPS DO * HV JJ NNS VB ABX AT NN CC AT NN IN PP$ NN$ JJ JJ NNS .
The fact seems to be that very many large branch stores are uneconomical , that the choice of location in the suburbs is as important as it was downtown , and that even highly suburbanized cities will support only so many big branches .	AT NN VBZ TO BE CS QL AP JJ NN NNS BER JJ , CS AT NN IN NN IN AT NNS BEZ QL JJ CS PPS BEDZ NR , CC CS RB QL VBN NNS MD VB RB QL AP JJ NNS .
Moreover , the cost of operations is always high in any new store , as the conservative bankers who act as controllers for retail giants are beginning to discover .	RB , AT NN IN NNS BEZ RB JJ IN DTI JJ NN , CS AT JJ NNS WPS VB CS NNS IN JJ NNS BER VBG TO VB .
When all has been said , however , the big branch store remains a major break with history in the development of American retailing .	WRB ABN HVZ BEN VBN , RB , AT JJ NN NN VBZ AT JJ NN IN NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
Just as the suburban factory may be more convenient than the downtown plant to the worker with a car , the trip to the shopping center may seem far easier than to the downtown department store , though both are the same distance from home .	RB CS AT JJ NN MD BE QL JJ CS AT NR NN IN AT NN IN AT NN , AT NN IN AT VBG NN MD VB QL JJR CS IN AT NR NN NN , CS ABX BER AT AP NN IN NR .
Indeed , there are some cities where the suburban shopping pulls customers who are geographically much nearer to downtown .	RB , EX BER DTI NNS WRB AT JJ NN VBZ NNS WPS BER RB QL RBR IN NR .
Raymond Vernon reports that residents of East St. Louis have been driving across the Mississippi , through the heart of downtown St. Louis and out to the western suburbs for major shopping , simply because parking is easier at the big branches than it is in the heart of town . To the extent that the problem is merely parking , an aggressive downtown management , like that of Lazarus Brothers in Columbus , Ohio , can fight back successfully by building a garage on the lot next door . If the distant patron of the suburban branch has been frightened away from downtown by traffic problems , however , the city store can only pressure the politicians to do something about the highways or await the completion of the federal highway program . And if the affection for the suburban branch reflects a desire to shop with `` nice people '' , rather than with the indiscriminate urban mass which supports the downtown department store , the central location may be in serious trouble . Today , according to land economist Homer Hoyt , shopping centers and their associated parking lots cover some 46,000 acres of land , which is almost exactly the total land area in all the nation's Central Business Districts put together . The downtown store continues to offer the great inducement of variety , both within its gates and across the street , where other department stores are immediately convenient for the shopper who wants to see what is available before making up her mind . If anything may be predicted in the quicksilver world of retailing , it seems likely that the suburban branch will come to dominate children's clothing ( taking the kid downtown is too much of a production ) , household gadgetry and the discount business in big-ticket items . Department stores were built on dry goods , especially ladies' fashions , and in this area , in the long run , the suburban branches will be hard put to compete against downtown .	NN NNS BED VBN IN JJ NNS , RB NNS$ NNS , CC IN DT NN , IN AT JJ NN , AT JJ NNS MD BE RB VBN TO VB IN NR .
If this analysis is correct , the suburban branches will turn out to be what management's cost accountants refuse to acknowledge , marginal operations rather than major factors .	CS DT NN BEZ JJ , AT JJ NNS MD VB RP TO BE WDT NN$ NN NNS VB TO VB , JJ NNS RB CS JJ NNS .
Historically in America the appeal of cities has been their color and life , the variety of experience they offered .	RB IN NP AT NN IN NNS HVZ BEN PP$ NN CC NN , AT NN IN NN PPSS VBD .
`` How ya gonna keep 'em down on the farm '' ? ?	`` WRB PPSS VBG+TO VB PPO RP IN AT NN '' . .
Was a question that had to be asked long before they saw Paree .	BEDZ AT NN WPS HVD TO BE VBN RB CS PPSS VBD NP .
Though Americans usually lived in groups segregated by national origin or religious belief , they liked to work and shop in the noise and vitality of downtown .	CS NPS RB VBD IN NNS VBN IN JJ NN CC JJ NN , PPSS VBD TO VB CC VB IN AT NN CC NN IN NR .
Only a radical change in the nature of the population in the central city would be likely to destroy this preference -- and we must now turn our attention to the question of whether such a change , gloomily foreseen by so many urban diagnosticians , is actually upon us .
