Suburbs and Negroes	NNS-HL CC-HL NPS-HL
In their book , American Skyline , Christopher Tunnard and Henry Hope Reed argue that Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal was what made the modern suburb a possibility -- a fine ironical argument , when you consider how suburbanites tend to vote .	IN PP$ NN , JJ-TL NN-TL , NP NP CC NP NP NP VB CS NP NP$ JJ-TL NN-TL BEDZ WDT VBD AT JJ NN AT NN -- AT JJ JJ NN , WRB PPSS VB WRB NNS VB TO VB .
The first superhighways -- New York's Henry Hudson and Chicago's Lake Shore , San Francisco's Bay Bridge and its approaches , a good slice of the Pennsylvania Turnpike -- were built as part of the federal works program which was going to cure the depression .	AT OD NNS -- JJ-TL NP$-TL NP NP CC NP$ NN-TL NN-TL , NP NP$ NN-TL NN-TL CC PP$ NNS , AT JJ NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL -- BED VBN CS NN IN AT JJ NNS NN WDT BEDZ VBG TO VB AT NN .
At the same time , Roosevelt's Federal Housing Administration , coupled with Henry Morgenthau's cheap-money policy , permitted ordinary lower-middle-class families to build their own homes .	IN AT AP NN , NP$ JJ-TL NN-TL NN-TL , VBN IN NP NP$ NN NN , VBD JJ NN NNS TO VB PP$ JJ NNS .
Bankers who had been reluctant to lend without better security than the house itself got that security from the U. S. government ; ;	NNS WPS HVD BEN JJ TO VB IN JJR NN CS AT NN PPL VBD DT NN IN AT NP NP NN . .
householders who had been unable to pick up the burden of short-term high-interest mortgages found they could borrow for twenty-five years at 4 per cent , under government aegis .	NNS WPS HVD BEN JJ TO VB RP AT NN IN NN NN NNS VBD PPSS MD VB IN CD NNS IN CD IN NN , IN NN NN .
Before losing itself in the sands of the 19th Century , the grand stream of Italian Renaissance architectural decoration made a last appearance in the Brumidi frescos of the Capitol Rotunda in Washington .	CS VBG PPL IN AT NNS IN AT OD NN-TL , AT JJ NN IN JJ-TL NP-TL JJ NN VBD AT AP NN IN AT NP NNS IN AT NN-TL NN-TL IN NP .
The artistic generation after Brumidi was trained in the Paris of that time to a more meticulous standard of execution , and tended to overlook greatness of conception where faults and weakness were easy to find .	AT JJ NN IN NP BEDZ VBN IN AT NP IN DT NN IN AT QL JJ NN IN NN , CC VBD TO VB NN IN NN WRB NNS CC NN BED JJ TO VB .
But it is a great conception .	CC PPS BEZ AT JJ NN .
The open ceiling , with allegorical and classical figures thrown in masses against the sky : the closed frieze , formally divided into historical scenes and tightly tied to the stone walls , belong in their large ordering to the line of Correggio and his Baroque followers .	AT JJ NN , IN JJ CC JJ NNS VBN IN NNS IN AT NN : AT VBN NN , RB VBN IN JJ NNS CC RB VBN IN AT NN NNS , VB IN PP$ JJ NN IN AT NN IN NP CC PP$ JJ-TL NNS .
The descent may be remote , but this is surely the only full-scale example of that vigorous inheritance in the United States .	AT NN MD BE JJ , CC DT BEZ RB AT AP JJ NN IN DT JJ NN IN AT VBN-TL NNS-TL .
Constantino Brumidi designed the decorative scheme as a whole , in collaboration with the architect Charles U. Walter , at the time when plans were being made to replace the wooden dome of Bullfinch with the present much larger iron structure .	NP NP VBD AT JJ NN CS AT JJ , IN NN IN AT NN NP NP NP , IN AT NN WRB NNS BED BEG VBN TO VB AT JJ NN IN NP IN AT JJ QL JJR NN NN .
After many years and many interruptions he was able to finish the canopy fresco , and slightly less than half the frieze , beginning with the Liberty group opposite the East door , and ending with William Penn , all but one leg , when a tragic accident ended his career .	IN AP NNS CC AP NNS PPS BEDZ JJ TO VB AT NN NN , CC QL AP IN ABN AT NN , VBG IN AT NN-TL NN IN AT JJ-TL NN , CC VBG IN NP NP , ABN IN CD NN , WRB AT JJ NN VBD PP$ NN .
He left at his death sketches , drawn to scale , for the rest of the circle .	PPS VBD IN PP$ NN NNS , VBN IN NN , IN AT NN IN AT NN .
These were carried out not too faithfully by Filippo Costaggini , who began by supplying the missing member to the founder of Pennsylvania and noting in pencil , in Italian , that he `` began at this point '' .	DTS BED VBN RP * QL RB IN NP NP , WPS VBD IN VBG AT VBG NN IN AT NN IN NP CC VBG IN NN , IN NP , CS PPS `` VBD IN DT NN '' .
When Costaggini had used up all the sketches thirty-six feet of empty frieze were left over .	WRB NP HVD VBN RP ABN AT NNS CD NNS IN JJ NN BED VBN RP .
A blank undecorated void , plastered in roughcast , disfigured the wall of the Rotunda until 1951 .	AT JJ JJ NN , VBN IN NN , VBD AT NN IN AT NN-TL IN CD .
Then , advised by the Architect of the Capitol , the Joint Committee for the Library , traditionally responsible for the works of art in the building , ordered the space cleared and painted in fresco , to show `` the Peace after the Civil War '' , `` the Spanish-American War '' , and `` the Birth of Aviation '' , to match as nearly as feasible Brumidi's technique and composition . Later the cleaning and restoration were ordered , first of the older part of the frieze , finally of the canopy .	RBR AT NN CC NN BED VBN , RB IN AT JJR NN IN AT NN , RB IN AT NN .
What follows is therefore a description of three separate undertakings , the new frescoing of the gap , and the successive essays in conservation , with some discussion of problems that arose in connection with each .	WDT VBZ BEZ RB AT NN IN CD JJ NNS , AT JJ NN IN AT NN , CC AT JJ NNS IN NN , IN DTI NN IN NNS WPS VBD IN NN IN DT .
For the use of students and future restorers , a full , day-by-day record was kept of all three undertakings , complete technical reports on what we found and what we did .	IN AT NN IN NNS CC JJ NNS , AT JJ , JJ NN BEDZ VBN IN ABN CD NNS , JJ JJ NNS IN WDT PPSS VBD CC WDT PPSS DOD .
These may be consulted in the office of the Architect of the Capitol , or the Library of Congress .	DTS MD BE VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN-TL IN-TL AT-TL NN-TL , CC AT NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL .
The first preliminary was inspecting the unfinished length of frieze , a jumble of roughcast and finish coats , all in bad condition .	AT OD NN BEDZ VBG AT JJ NN IN NN , AT NN IN NN CC NN NNS , ABN IN JJ NN .
It was decided to strip the whole area down to the bricks , and to replace the rough coats up to one inch thickness to agree with the older artists' preparation , with a mortar , one part slaked lime , three parts sand , to be put on in two layers .	PPS BEDZ VBN TO VB AT JJ NN RP IN AT NNS , CC TO VB AT JJ NNS RP IN CD NN NN TO VB IN AT JJR NNS$ NN , IN AT NN , CD NN VBN NN , CD NNS NN , TO BE VBN RP IN CD NNS .
Cartoons were drawn full size , after sketches had been made to satisfy all the authorities .	NNS BED VBN JJ NN , CS NNS HVD BEN VBN TO VB ABN AT NNS .
There was some difficulty here .	EX BEDZ DTI NN RB .
One had to manage the given subjects , three diverse recent events , so as to make them part of a classical frieze , -- that is , a pattern of large figures filling the space , with not much else , against a blank background .	PN HVD TO VB AT VBN NNS , CD JJ JJ NNS , CS CS TO VB PPO NN IN AT JJ NN , -- DT BEZ , AT NN IN JJ NNS VBG AT NN , IN * AP RB , IN AT JJ NN .
Moreover , all three representations must be squeezed comfortably into little more than the length Brumidi allowed for each one of his .	RB , ABN CD NNS MD BE VBN RB IN QL AP CS AT NN NP VBD IN DT CD IN PP$$ .
When it was all arranged to fit , and not to interrupt the lengthwise flow of movement in the frieze , the cartoons were tried in place .	WRB PPS BEDZ ABN VBN TO VB , CC * TO VB AT JJ NN IN NN IN AT NN , AT NNS BED VBN IN NN .
The scaffolding , a confusion of heavy beams hanging from the gallery above , was strong and safe , but obscured visibility .	AT NN , AT NN IN JJ NNS VBG IN AT NN RB , BEDZ JJ CC JJ , CC VBD NN .
Nothing could be seen from the floor , but by moving around the gallery one could get glimpses ; ;	PN MD BE VBN IN AT NN , CC IN VBG IN AT NN PN MD VB NNS . .
and we were able to decide on some amplification of scale .	CC PPSS BED JJ TO VB IN DTI NN IN NN .
To be sure of matching color as well as form , pieces of cartoon were traced on the roughcast , and large samples painted in fresco , then left two months to dry out to their final key .	TO BE JJ IN VBG NN QL RB CS NN , NNS IN NN BED VBN IN AT NN , CC JJ NNS VBN IN NN , RB VBN CD NNS TO VB RP IN PP$ JJ NN .
Later it was gratifying to note that they had set so solidly as to be hard to remove when the time came .	RBR PPS BEDZ JJ TO VB CS PPSS HVD VBN QL RB CS TO BE JJ TO VB WRB AT NN VBD .
The scaffold was the length of the space to be painted .	AT NN BEDZ AT NN IN AT NN TO BE VBN .
What bits of Brumidi and Costaggini could be reached at either end seemed in good order , though the roughish sandy surface was thick with dust .	WDT NNS IN NP CC NP MD BE VBN IN CC NN VBD IN JJ NN , CS AT JJ JJ NN BEDZ JJ IN NN .
Washed , they came out surprisingly clear and bright .	VBN , PPSS VBD RP QL JJ CC JJ .
It could be seen that both artists used a very thick final coat of plaster , one half inch , and that both followed the traditional Italian fresco technique as described by Cennino Cennini in the 14th Century , and current in Italy to this day .	PPS MD BE VBN CS ABX NNS VBD AT QL JJ AP NN IN NN , CD ABN NN , CC CS ABX VBD AT JJ JJ NN NN CS VBN IN NP NP IN AT OD NN-TL , CC JJ IN NP IN DT NN .
That is , they used opaque color throughout , getting solid highlights with active lime white .	DT BEZ , PPSS VBD JJ NN RB , VBG JJ NNS IN JJ NN NN .
Painting `` a secco '' is much in evidence .	VBG `` AT FW-NN '' BEZ RB IN NN .
A brown hatching reinforces and broadens shadows , and much of the background is solidly covered with a dark coat .	AT JJ NN VBZ CC VBZ NNS , CC AP IN AT NN BEZ RB VBN IN AT JJ NN .
This brown is sometimes so rich in medium as to appear to be oil paint .	DT NN BEZ RB QL JJ IN NN CS TO VB TO BE NN NN .
In our own practice , to have the last `` intonaco '' plaster coat thick enough to match , and at the same time to avoid fine cracks in drying , we found that it had to be put on in two layers , letting the first set awhile before applying the second .	IN PP$ JJ NN , TO HV AT AP `` FW-NN '' NN NN JJ QLP TO VB , CC IN AT AP NN TO VB JJ NNS IN VBG , PPSS VBD CS PPS HVD TO BE VBN RP IN CD NNS , VBG AT OD VB RB CS VBG AT OD .
The mortar was three parts sand to two of lime .	AT NN BEDZ CD NNS NN IN CD IN NN .
Some of the lime that is always on hand in the Capitol basement for plaster repairs was slaked several months for us ; ;	DTI IN AT NN WPS BEZ RB IN NN IN AT NN-TL NN IN NN NNS BEDZ VBN AP NNS IN PPO . .
but to make it stiffer , of a really putty-like consistency to avoid cracking , we added a little hydrated lime -- hard on the hands , but we could see no other disadvantage .	CC TO VB PPO JJR , IN AT QL JJ NN TO VB VBG , PPSS VBD AT AP VBN NN -- JJ IN AT NNS , CC PPSS MD VB AT AP NN .
I am told that a mortar longer slaked might have remained longer in condition for painting .	PPSS BEM VBN CS AT NN RBR VBN MD HV VBN RBR IN NN IN VBG .
As it was , it took the pigment well for six hours , enough for our purpose , and held it firmly in setting .	CS PPS BEDZ , PPS VBD AT NN RB IN CD NNS , AP IN PP$ NN , CC VBD PPO RB IN VBG .
It was obvious that to match Brumidi , white must be mixed with all but the darkest tones .	PPS BEDZ JJ CS TO VB NP , NN MD BE VBN IN ABN IN AT JJT NNS .
Lime white , hard and brilliant , has a tendency to `` jump '' away from the other colors in drying , and also by its capacity to set , to preclude the use of ready-made gradations , so useful in decorative work .	NN NN , JJ CC JJ , HVZ AT NN TO `` VB '' RB IN AT AP NNS IN VBG , CC RB IN PP$ NN TO VB , TO VB AT NN IN JJ NNS , QL JJ IN JJ NN .
In older Italian practice , lime , dried and reground `` bianco sangiovanni '' , entered into such prepared shades .	IN JJR JJ NN , NN , VBN CC VBN `` NIL NIL '' , VBD IN JJ VBN NNS .
For convenience we chose a stronger pigment , unknown to the early Italians or to Brumidi , titanium oxide , reserving the active lime white for highest lights , put on at the end of the day's stint .	IN NN PPSS VBD AT JJR NN , JJ IN AT JJ NPS CC IN NP , NN NN , VBG AT JJ NN NN IN JJT NNS , VBN RP IN AT NN IN AT NN$ NN .
Other pigments were mostly raw umber , some burnt umber , and a little yellow ochre .	AP NNS BED RB JJ NN , DTI VBN NN , CC AT AP JJ NN .
This last was probably not in Brumidi's palette , but was needed to take the chill , bluish look off the new work next to the old , where softening effects of time were seen , even after thorough cleaning .	DT AP BEDZ RB * IN NP$ NN , CC BEDZ VBN TO VB AT NN , JJ NN IN AT JJ NN RB IN AT JJ , WRB VBG NNS IN NN BED VBN , RB IN JJ NN .
The use of `` secco '' we tried to restrict to covering joints .	AT NN IN `` FW-NN '' PPSS VBD TO VB IN VBG NNS .
Experience showed , however , that it is very difficult to paint a dark umber background in fresco that will not dry out spotty and uneven .	NN VBD , RB , CS PPS BEZ QL JJ TO VB AT JJ NN NN IN NN WPS MD * VB RP JJ CC JJ .
Later Brumidi and Costaggini will be seen coping with this same problem .	RBR NP CC NP MD BE VBN VBG IN DT AP NN .
We were forced , as they were , to work a good deal of tempera into background and dark areas .	PPSS BED VBN , CS PPSS BED , TO VB AT JJ NN IN NN IN NN CC JJ NNS .
We made it by Doerner's recipe , five parts thoroughly washed cheese curd to one of lime putty ; ;	PPSS VBD PPO IN NP$ NN , CD NNS RB VBN NN NN IN CD IN NN NN . .
ground together they made a strong adhesive , which became waterproof in drying .	VBN RB PPSS VBD AT JJ NN , WDT VBD JJ IN VBG .

One is led to speculate as to why the empty space was there , left for our century to finish .	PN BEZ VBN TO VB IN IN WRB AT JJ NN BEDZ RB , VBN IN PP$ NN TO VB .
Costaggini said it was Brumidi's fault in not providing enough material to fill the circle .	NP VBD PPS BEDZ NP$ NN IN * VBG AP NN TO VB AT NN .
Brumidi's son later maintained that Costaggini had compressed and mutilated his father's designs , ambitiously coveting a bit he could claim for his very own .	NP$ NN RBR VBD CS NP HVD VBN CC VBN PP$ NN$ NNS , RB VBG AT NN PPS MD VB IN PP$ AP JJ .
This question might be settled by comparing the measurement of the actual circumference with the dimensions noted , presumably in Brumidi's hand , above the various sections of his long preparatory drawing , which has been kept . Whosever fault , it is evident that Brumidi intended to fill out the whole frieze with his `` histories '' and come full circle with the scene of the discovery of California gold .	WP$ NN , PPS BEZ JJ CS NP VBD TO VB RP AT JJ NN IN PP$ `` NNS '' CC VB JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT NN IN NP NN .
In painting a fresco , the handling of wet mortar compels one always to move from top to bottom and from left to right , not to spoil yesterday's work with today's plastering .	IN VBG AT NN , AT NN IN JJ NN VBZ PN RB TO VB IN NN IN NN CC IN NR IN NR , * TO VB NR$ NN IN NR$ NN .
At the very first , then , Brumidi was required , by the classically pyramidal shape of his central group , to fill in the triangular space above the seated girl on Liberty's right , before starting on the allegorical figures themselves . One sees Costaggini's rendering of the same figure more than thirty feet away .	PN VBZ NP$ NN IN AT AP NN AP IN CD NNS RB .
The photograph , Figure 1 of the completed frieze , shows how , having been separated from his fellows in useless isolation for eighty years , he has now been given a hand , and by juxtaposition ( and the permission of the Committee ) , given a new job , to represent the witnesses of the first flight at Kitty Hawk in 1903 . The startlingly bright effect of the first washings led the Committee to order the rest of the Brumidi-Costaggini cycle cleaned and restored to go with them .	AT RB JJ NN IN AT OD NNS VBD AT NN-TL TO VB AT NN IN AT NP NN VBN CC VBN TO VB IN PPO .
The fixed wooden scaffold was removed , and , so as to reach all the frieze , one of pipe , on wheels , built up from the floor .	AT VBN JJ NN BEDZ VBN , CC , CS CS TO VB ABN AT NN , CD IN NN , IN NNS , VBN RP IN AT NN .
Every few days , in the early morning , as the work progressed , twenty men would appear to push it ahead and to shift the plank foundation that distributed its weight widely on the Rotunda pavement , supported as it is by ancient brick vaulting . On this giddy and oscillating platform over fifty feet from the floor , after a first dusting , we began to wash .	IN DT JJ CC VBG NN RP CD NNS IN AT NN , IN AT OD NN , PPSS VBD TO VB .
A most useful tool for wetting the surface without running down was made from a greenhouse `` mist spray '' nozzle welded to a hose connection , to be used at low water pressure .	AT QL JJ NN IN VBG AT NN IN VBG RP BEDZ VBN IN AT NN `` NN NN '' NN VBN IN AT NN NN , TO BE VBN IN JJ NN NN .
A valve in the handle let us cut the pressure still lower .	AT NN IN AT NN VBD PPO VB AT NN RB JJR .
One man sprayed , with a sponge in hand to check excess wetting .	CD NN VBD , IN AT NN IN NN TO VB JJ NN .
A second assistant mopped with two sponges .	AT OD NN VBD IN CD NNS .
In parts a repeated sponging was needed , but everywhere we found that water alone was enough to restore the original brightness .	IN NNS AT VBN NN BEDZ VBN , CC RB PPSS VBD CS NN RB BEDZ AP TO VB AT JJ NN .
No soap or other cleaning agent was used that might bring in unwanted chemical reactions .	AT NN CC AP VBG NN BEDZ VBN WPS MD VB RP JJ NN NNS .
The painting `` a fresco '' stood up superbly ; ;	AT NN `` NIL NIL '' VBD RP RB . .
a little of the `` secco '' came off .	AT JJ IN AT `` FW-NN '' VBD RP .
Necessary retouching was put on at once .	JJ NN BEDZ VBN RP IN RB .
Altogether we found the craftsmanship first rate , especially Brumidi's .	RB PPSS VBD AT NN OD NN , RB NP$ .
We were greatly helped by there being no traces of former restoring .	PPSS BED RB VBN IN EX BEG AT NNS IN AP NN .
Apparently not more than dusting had ever been done , and not much of that .	RB * AP CS NN HVD RB BEN VBN , CC * AP IN DT .
The plaster was sound , the intonaco firmly attached all over , and the pigment solidly incorporated with it in all but a few unimportant places .	AT NN BEDZ JJ , AT FW-NN RB VBN QL RP , CC AT NN RB VBN IN PPO IN ABN IN AT AP JJ NNS .
The greatest source of trouble was rain which had repeatedly flowed from openings above , soaking the surface and leaving streaks of dissolved lime , very conspicuous even after cleaning , particularly in the `` Landing of Columbus '' , `` Oglethorpe and the Indians '' , and `` Yorktown '' . Here the Architect , referring to the use of the Capitol as a public building , not a museum , requested some repainting to maintain decorative effect , rather than leaving blank , unsightly patches . These frescos have had no care for eighty years .	DTS NNS HV HVN AT NN IN CD NNS .
With naked gas jets below and leaky windows above , enough to ruin wall paintings in any medium , they have survived , in a building long unheated in winter , hot and damp under the iron dome in summer .	IN JJ NN NNS RB CC JJ NNS RB , AP TO VB NN NNS IN DTI NN , PPSS HV VBN , IN AT NN RB JJ IN NN , JJ CC JJ IN AT NN NN IN NN .
Those whom I wish to address with this letter are for the most part unknown to me .	DTS WPO PPSS VB TO VB IN DT NN BER IN AT AP NN JJ IN PPO .
It may well be that , when Rudy Pozzatti and I visited your country last spring , you were living and working close to the places we saw and the streets we walked .	PPS MD RB BE CS , WRB NP NP CC PPSS VBD PP$ NN AP NN , PPSS BED VBG CC VBG RB IN AT NNS PPSS VBD CC AT NNS PPSS VBD .
As American artists , it was natural that we would want to meet as many Soviet artists as possible .	CS JJ NNS , PPS BEDZ JJ CS PPSS MD VB TO VB QL AP NP NNS CS JJ .
This letter might not have been necessary had our efforts to meet and talk with you been more successful .	DT NN MD * HV BEN JJ HVD PP$ NNS TO VB CC VB IN PPO BEN QL JJ .
Even though we did not see many of your faces , it appears now quite evident that a considerable number of your profession heard , from those whom we had the fortune to encounter , that we had been in your midst . I am very pleased that quite a number of you found ways to communicate to me your desire to hear of our reactions and experiences in the U.S.S.R. .	PPSS BEM QL VBN CS ABL AT NN IN PPO VBD NNS TO VB IN PPO PP$ NN TO VB IN PP$ NNS CC NNS IN AT NP .
I can well understand your curiosity .	PPSS MD RB VB PP$ NN .
We , ourselves , are always eager to know how others feel about us and the way in which we live .	PPSS , PPLS , BER RB JJ TO VB WRB NNS VB IN PPO CC AT NN IN WDT PPSS VB .
It is my hope that this written message and report will reach you through the good offices of the Union of Soviet Artists .	PPS BEZ PP$ NN CS DT VBN NN CC NN MD VB PPO IN AT JJ NNS IN AT NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL NNS-TL .
There should be no reason to misinterpret or ignore the intent of this letter .	EX MD BE AT NN TO VB CC VB AT NN IN DT NN .
Pozzatti and I endeavored earnestly to record our impressions without the prejudice that the anxiety of our time so easily provokes .	NP CC PPSS VBD RB TO VB PP$ NNS IN AT NN WPO AT NN IN PP$ NN QL RB VBZ .
The time-span of little more than a month cannot entitle me to pose as an expert on anything I saw .	AT NN IN QL AP CS AT NN MD* VB PPO TO VB CS AT NN IN PN PPSS VBD .
Too much damage is done by `` experts '' who have spent even less time , if any at all , in the U.S.S.R. .	QL AP NN BEZ VBN IN `` NNS '' WPS HV VBN RB AP NN , CS DTI IN ABN , IN AT NP .
Nevertheless I consider it reasonable , because of my commitment as an artist , to assume that the rights and responsibilities of creative individuals are related to humanity as a whole rather than to specific geo-political interests .	RB PPSS VB PPO JJ , RB IN PP$ NN CS AT NN , TO VB CS AT NNS CC NNS IN JJ NNS BER VBN IN NN CS AT NN RB CS IN JJ JJ NNS .
If this attitude is seriously questioned in the Soviet Union , it does not necessarily follow that the majority of the society in which I live is too aware of the necessity for clarity on this ethical as well as aesthetic point of view .	CS DT NN BEZ RB VBN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL , PPS DOZ * RB VB CS AT NN IN AT NN IN WDT PPSS VB BEZ QL JJ IN AT NN IN NN IN DT JJ QL RB CS JJ NN IN NN .
It is a matter of some disappointment to me that still many of my own countrymen are too shortsighted to ascribe any symbolic significance to the plight of a minority , such as artists , in any social order .	PPS BEZ AT NN IN DTI NN IN PPO CS RB AP IN PP$ JJ NNS BER QL JJ TO VB DTI JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT NN , JJ CS NNS , IN DTI JJ NN .
I encountered many questions and great interest upon my return from the Soviet Union about my reactions to that experience .	PPSS VBD AP NNS CC JJ NN IN PP$ NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL IN PP$ NNS IN DT NN .
That which I found most profound and most disturbing appeared to evoke a curiously muted reaction .	DT WDT PPSS VBD QL JJ CC QL JJ VBD TO VB AT RB VBN NN .
Almost as if I were talking about something quite unreal .	RB CS CS PPSS BED VBG IN PN QL JJ .
Apparently this is not the time and the climate in which people will listen objectively , or at least dispassionately , to individual impressions of a subject which preoccupies a good deal of their waking moments . Personal predispositions tend to blunt the ear and , in turn , the voice as well .	JJ NNS VB TO VB AT NN CC , IN NN , AT NN QL RB .
I cannot be content with the anecdotal small talk of a somewhat unusual travelogue .	PPSS MD* BE JJ IN AT JJ JJ NN IN AT QL JJ NN .
I am equally impatient with the shrug of the shoulder , shake of the head of those who no longer care because they have known it for so long ; ;	PPSS BEM RB JJ IN AT NN IN AT NN , NN IN AT NN IN DTS WPS QL RBR VB CS PPSS HV VBN PPO IN QL RB . .

Difficult as it may have been at times , Pozzatti and I saw enough , talked to enough artists , historians and others to realize that the issue is quite clear .	JJ CS PPS MD HV BEN IN NNS , NP CC PPSS VBD AP , VBD IN AP NNS , NNS CC NNS TO VB CS AT NN BEZ QL JJ .
Artists and poets are the raw nerve-ends of humanity ; ;	NNS CC NNS BER AT JJ NNS IN NN . .
they are small in number and their contribution is not immediately decisive in everyday life .	PPSS BER JJ IN NN CC PP$ NN BEZ * RB JJ IN JJ NN .
By themselves they may not be able to save the life on this planet , but without them there would be very little left worth saving .	IN PPLS PPSS MD * BE JJ TO VB AT NN IN DT NN , CC IN PPO EX MD BE QL AP VBN JJ VBG .
It cannot be said that our very first day in the Soviet Union turned out to be an ordinary one .	PPS MD* BE VBN CS PP$ QL OD NN IN AT NP-TL NN-TL VBD RP TO BE AT JJ CD .
On that cold , but bright , April day we were guests of your government in the reviewing stand of Red Square to witness the poeple's celebration for Yuri Gagarin and later on that day we attended the somewhat more exclusive reception for him in one of the impressive palaces of the Kremlin .	IN DT JJ , CC JJ , NP NN PPSS BED NNS IN PP$ NN IN AT VBG NN IN JJ-TL NN-TL TO VB AT NNS$ NN IN NP NP CC RBR RP DT NN PPSS VBD AT QL QL JJ NN IN PPO IN CD IN AT JJ NNS IN AT NP .
If we thus spent our very first day in the midst of a large number of your people honoring a new hero and a great national achievement , our last day , to us at least , was equally impressive and very moving , even though the crowds were absent and there was almost complete silence .	CS PPSS RB VBD PP$ QL OD NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN PP$ NNS VBG AT JJ NN CC AT JJ JJ NN , PP$ AP NN , IN PPO IN AP , BEDZ QL JJ CC QL JJ , RB CS AT NNS BED JJ CC EX BEDZ QL JJ NN .
We stood under a gigantic tree in the rolling country just outside of Moscow looking at silent flowers on the grave of a Russian poet and writer who cherished the love for his country to the point of foregoing the highest international honor .	PPSS VBD IN AT JJ NN IN AT VBG NN QL RB IN NP VBG IN JJ NNS IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN CC NN WPS VBD AT NN IN PP$ NN IN AT NN IN VBG AT JJT JJ NN .
The grave , about half-way between his home and the blue turrets of a small church , rose above the forms and spaces of gently undisciplined pastures of green , the sounds of birds , the silence of other graves and the casual paths through small forests .	AT NN , RB RB IN PP$ NN CC AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN , VBD IN AT NNS CC NNS IN RB JJ NNS IN NN , AT NNS IN NNS , AT NN IN AP NNS CC AT JJ NNS IN JJ NNS .
Just yesterday we had met and talked with a living writer , a contemporary of the dead poet , who is known for his ability of manipulating his ideas and his craft more advantageously .	RB NR PPSS HVD VBN CC VBN IN AT VBG NN , AT NN IN AT JJ NN , WPS BEZ VBN IN PP$ NN IN VBG PP$ NNS CC PP$ NN QL RB .
But today we were aware of only two men .	CC NR PPSS BED JJ IN AP CD NNS .
One had taken a flight into uncharted space , in the service of science , to return as a living hero .	CD HVD VBN AT NN IN JJ NN , IN AT NN IN NN , TO VB CS AT VBG NN .
The other had assumed the right to explore the equally uncharted space of the human spirit .	AT AP HVD VBN AT NN TO VB AT RB JJ NN IN AT JJ NN .
The flowers on his grave attested to the fact that he as well was somebody's hero .	AT NNS IN PP$ NN VBD IN AT NN CS PPS QL RB BEDZ PN$ NN .
These two recollections form the frame around a series of experiences and sights which , to me at least , symbolize the extremes in the aesthetic as well as ethical conflict between materialism and humanism .	DTS CD NNS VB AT NN IN AT NN IN NNS CC NNS WDT , IN PPO IN AP , VB AT NNS IN AT JJ QL RB CS JJ NN IN NN CC NN .
A struggle that is being waged all over the world in the half-light of disinterest .	AT NN WPS BEZ BEG VBN QL IN AT NN IN AT NN IN NN .
The prevalent opinion which we encountered in a variety of expressions in your country denied not only the existence of this conflict but it was elaborated even further with an incredible semantic dexterity .	AT JJ NN WDT PPSS VBD IN AT NN IN NNS IN PP$ NN VBD * RB AT NN IN DT NN CC PPS BEDZ VBN RB RBR IN AT JJ JJ NN .
The socialist environment , it was stated , had cross-fertilized these two extreme seeds and was about to produce a new plant and fruit .	AT NN NN , PPS BEDZ VBN , HVD VBN DTS CD JJ NNS CC BEDZ RB TO VB AT JJ NN CC NN .
When I speculated on one such occasion that the new growth , like other mutations , might be unable to propagate , I was immediately accused of preaching racial prejudice .	WRB PPSS VBD IN CD JJ NN CS AT JJ NN , CS AP NNS , MD BE JJ TO VB , PPSS BEDZ RB VBN IN VBG JJ NN .
I could not bring myself to answer that `` some of my best friends are non-propagating mules '' .	PPSS MD * VB PPL TO VB CS `` DTI IN PP$ JJT NNS BER JJ NNS '' .
This kind of reasoning and logic takes a little time to get used to .	DT NN IN VBG CC NN VBZ AT AP NN TO VB VBN IN .

The following is a statement read to a large and friendly group of your fellow artists in Leningrad :	AT VBG BEZ AT NN VBN IN AT JJ CC JJ NN IN PP$ NN NNS IN NP :
`` We have come to your land with the express intention of understanding and respecting your ideas and your ways .	`` PPSS HV VBN IN PP$ NN IN AT JJ NN IN VBG CC VBG PP$ NNS CC PP$ NNS .

While we , as American artists , believe deeply in the universal character of all intellectual activity , we would be less than honest with you , or ourselves , if we failed to state a specific attitude toward our own society as well as the international community as a whole . The Sane Society is an ambitious work .	AT-TL JJ-TL NN-TL BEZ AT JJ NN .
Its scope is as broad as the question : What does it mean to live in modern society ? ?	PP$ NN BEZ QL JJ CS AT NN : WDT DOZ PPS VB TO VB IN JJ NN . .
A work so broad , even when it is directed by a leading idea and informed by a moral vision , must necessarily `` fail '' .	AT NN QL JJ , RB WRB PPS BEZ VBN IN AT VBG NN CC VBN IN AT JJ NN , MD RB `` VB '' .
Even a hasty reader will easily find in it numerous blind spots , errors of fact and argument , important exclusions , areas of ignorance and prejudice , undue emphases on trivia , examples of broad positions supported by flimsy evidence , and the like . Such books are easy prey for critics .	JJ NNS BER JJ NN IN NNS .
Nor need the critic be captious .	CC VB AT NN BE JJ .
A careful and orderly man , who values precision and a kind of tough intellectual responsibility , might easily be put off by such a book .	AT JJ CC JJ NN , WPS VBZ NN CC AT NN IN JJ JJ NN , MD RB BE VBN RP IN ABL AT NN .
It is a simple matter , for one so disposed , to take a work like The Sane Society and shred it into odds and ends .	PPS BEZ AT JJ NN , IN PN RB VBN , TO VB AT NN CS AT-TL JJ-TL NN-TL CC VB PPO IN NNS CC NNS .
The thing can be made to look like the cluttered attic of a large and vigorous family -- a motley jumble of discarded objects , some outworn and some that were never useful , some once whole and bright but now chipped and tarnished , some odd pieces whose history no one remembers , here and there a gem , everything fascinating because it suggests some part of the human condition -- the whole adding up to nothing more than a glimpse into the disorderly history of the makers and users . That could be easily done , but there is little reason in it .	DT MD BE RB VBN , CC EX BEZ AP NN IN PPO .
It would come down to saying that Fromm paints with a broad brush , and that , after all , is not a conclusion one must work toward but an impression he has from the outset .	PPS MD VB RP IN VBG CS NP VBZ IN AT JJ NN , CC CS , IN ABN , BEZ * AT NN PN MD VB IN CC AT NN PPS HVZ IN AT NN .
I mention these features of the book because they are inherent in the book's character and therefore must be mentioned .	PPSS VB DTS NNS IN AT NN CS PPSS BER JJ IN AT NN$ NN CC RB MD BE VBN .

There are more substantial criticisms to be made of Fromm's account of capitalist civilization .	EX BER QL JJ NNS TO BE VBN IN NP$ NN IN NN NN .
It is worthwhile to recall that Fromm's treatment has both descriptive and normative aspects .	PPS BEZ JJ TO VB CS NP$ NN HVZ ABX JJ CC JJ NNS .
Since I have already discussed his moral position , that discussion is incorporated by reference into the following pages , which will focus on the empirical and analytic side of Fromm's treatment . I shall first indicate a couple of weaknesses in Fromm's analysis , then argue that , granted these weaknesses , he still has much left that is valuable , and , finally , raise the general question of a philosophical versus a sociological approach to the question of alienation .	PPSS MD RB VB AT NN IN NNS IN NP$ NN , RB VB CS , VBN DTS NNS , PPS RB HVZ AP VBN WPS BEZ JJ , CC , RB , VB AT JJ NN IN AT JJ IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN NN .
Almost no empirical work has been done on the problem of alienation .	RB AT JJ NN HVZ BEN VBN IN AT NN IN NN .
Despite its rather long intellectual history , alienation is still a promising hypothesis and not a verified theory .	IN PP$ QL JJ JJ NN , NN BEZ RB AT JJ NN CC * AT VBN NN .
The idea has received much attention in philosophy , in literature , and in a few works of general social criticism , such as The Sane Society .	AT NN HVZ VBN AP NN IN NN , IN NN , CC IN AT AP NNS IN JJ JJ NN , JJ CS AT-TL JJ-TL NN-TL .
What is missing is work that would answer , presumably by the use of survey methods and Guttman-type attitude scales , such questions as these : What are the components of the feeling-state described as alienation ? ?	WDT BEZ VBG BEZ NN WPS MD VB , RB IN AT NN IN NN NNS CC JJ NN NNS , JJ NNS CS DTS : WDT BER AT NNS IN AT NN VBN CS NN . .
How widespread is alienation ? ?	WQL JJ BEZ NN . .
What is its incidence among the various classes and subgroups of the population ? ?	WDT BEZ PP$ NN IN AT AP NNS CC NNS IN AT NN . .
Taking alienation as a dependent variable , with what socio-structural factors is it most highly associated ? ?	VBG NN CS AT JJ NN , IN WDT JJ NNS BEZ PPS QL RB VBN . .
Considered as an independent variable , how does it affect behavior in various sectors of life ? ?	VBN CS AT JJ NN , WRB DOZ PPS VB NN IN AP NNS IN NN . .
Until such work is done , there must remain the nagging suspicion that alienation may be little more than an expression of the malaise of the intellectual , who , rejected by and in turn rejecting the larger society , projects his own fear and despair onto the broader social screen . I am not suggesting that Fromm ought to do this kind of work .	PPSS BEM * VBG CS NP MD TO DO DT NN IN NN .
Nor do I think that alienation is nothing more than a projection of the malaise of the intellectual .	CC DO PPSS VB CS NN BEZ PN AP CS AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN .
I am saying only that until a fuller and different kind of evidence comes in , any discussion of alienation must be understood to have certain important limitations .	PPSS BEM VBG RB CS CS AT JJR CC JJ NN IN NN VBZ RP , DTI NN IN NN MD BE VBN TO HV AP JJ NNS .
Until such evidence appears , we must make do with the evidence we have .	CS JJ NN VBZ , PPSS MD VB DO IN AT NN PPSS HV .
Here , perhaps , Fromm is vulnerable , for he does not always use the best and most recent evidence available , and he sometimes selects and interprets the evidence in rather special ways .	RB , RB , NP BEZ JJ , CS PPS DOZ * RB VB AT JJT CC QL JJ NN JJ , CC PPS RB VBZ CC VBZ AT NN IN QL JJ NNS .
Three examples follow .	CD NNS VB .
Fromm's analysis of alienation in the sphere of production centers around the concepts of the bureaucratization of the corporation , the separation of ownership from control , and the broad ( and thus from the point of view of corporate control , ineffective ) dispersion of stock ownership .	NP$ NN IN NN IN AT NN IN NN VBZ IN AT NNS IN AT NN IN AT NN , AT NN IN NN IN NN , CC AT JJ ( CC RB IN AT NN IN NN IN JJ NN , JJ ) NN IN NN NN .
For all these points he relies exclusively on Berle and Means's study of 1932 , The Modern Corporation And Private Property .	IN ABN DTS NNS PPS VBZ RB IN NP CC NP$ NN IN CD , AT-TL JJ-TL NN-TL CC-TL JJ-TL NN-TL .
The broad conclusions of that pioneering work remain undisturbed , but subsequent research has expanded and somewhat altered their empirical support , has suggested important revisions in the general analytic frame of reference , and has sharpened the meaning of particular analytic concepts in this area .	AT JJ NNS IN DT VBG NN VB JJ , CC JJ NN HVZ VBN CC RB VBN PP$ JJ NN , HVZ VBN JJ NNS IN AT JJ JJ NN IN NN , CC HVZ VBN AT NN IN AP JJ NNS IN DT NN .
Fromm seems unaware of these developments .	NP VBZ JJ IN DTS NNS .
Another example is his very infrequent use of the large amount of data from surveys designed to discover what and how people actually do feel and think on a broad range of topics : he cites such survey-type findings just three times . For example , he cites the following data from two studies on job satisfaction : in the first study , 85 per cent of professionals and executives , 64 per cent of white collar people , and 41 per cent of factory workers expressed satisfaction with their jobs ; ;	IN NN , PPS VBZ AT VBG NN IN CD NNS IN NN NN : IN AT OD NN , CD IN NN IN NNS CC NNS , CD IN NN IN JJ NN NNS , CC CD IN NN IN NN NNS VBD NN IN PP$ NNS . .

He concludes that these data show a `` remarkably high '' percentage of consciously dissatisfied and unhappy persons among factory and clerical workers .	PPS VBZ CS DTS NNS VB AT `` QL JJ '' NN IN RB VBN CC JJ NNS IN NN CC JJ NNS .
Starting from other value premises than Fromm's , some analysts might conclude that the percentages really tell us very little at all , while others might even conclude that the figures are remarkably low . Eric Hoffer , for example , once said that America was a paradise -- the only one in the history of the world -- for workingmen and small children .	NP NP , IN NN , RB VBD CS NP BEDZ AT NN -- AT AP CD IN AT NN IN AT NN -- IN NNS CC JJ NNS .
What matters is that while Fromm's reading of the data is not the only one possible , it is precisely the one we would expect from a writer who earnestly believes that every man can and ought to be happy and satisfied . Fromm also cites a poll on attitudes toward work restriction conducted by the Opinion Research Corporation in 1945 , in which 49 per cent of manual workers said a man ought to turn out as much as he could in a day's work , while 41 per cent said he should not do his best but should turn out only the average amount . Fromm says these data show that job dissatisfaction and resentment are widespread .	NP VBZ DTS NNS VB DT NN NN CC NN BER JJ .

One might use such findings to indicate the strength of informal primary associations in the factory , an interpretation which would run counter to Fromm's theory of alienation .	PN MD VB JJ NNS TO VB AT NN IN JJ JJ NNS IN AT NN , AT NN WDT MD VB RB IN NP$ NN IN NN .

In view of these shortcomings in both the amount and the interpretation of survey-type findings on public opinion , and considering the criticisms which can be brought against Fromm's philosophical anthropology , such a passage as the following cannot be taken seriously . `` Are people happy , are they as satisfied , unconsciously , as they believe themselves to be ? ?	`` BER NNS JJ , BER PPSS QL VBN , RB , CS PPSS VB PPLS TO BE . .

The ambiguities suggested above stem from a more basic difficulty in Fromm's style of thought .	AT NNS VBN RB VB IN AT QL JJ NN IN NP$ NN IN NN .
He seems to use the term alienation in two different ways .	PPS VBZ TO VB AT NN NN-NC IN CD JJ NNS .
Sometimes he uses it as a subjective , descriptive term , and sometimes as an objective , diagnostic one .	RB PPS VBZ PPO CS AT JJ , JJ NN , CC RB CS AT JJ , JJ CD .
That is , sometimes it is used to describe felt human misery , and other times it is postulated to explain unfelt anxiety and discontent .	DT BEZ , RB PPS BEZ VBN TO VB VBN JJ NN , CC AP NNS PPS BEZ VBN TO VB JJ NN CC NN .
The failure to keep these two usages distinct presents hazards to the reader .	AT NN TO VB DTS CD NNS JJ VBZ NNS IN AT NN .
It also permits Fromm to do some dubious things with empirical findings .	PPS RB VBZ NP TO DO DTI JJ NNS IN JJ NNS .
When alienation is used as an objective and diagnostic category , for example , it becomes clear that Fromm would have to say that awareness of alienation goes far toward conquering it .	WRB NN BEZ VBN CS AT JJ CC JJ NN , IN NN , PPS VBZ JJ CS NP MD HV TO VB DT NN IN NN VBZ RB IN VBG PPO .
( He , in effect , does say this in his discussion of the pseudo-happiness of the automaton conformist .	( PPS , IN NN , DOZ VB DT IN PP$ NN IN AT NN IN AT NN NN .
) Starting from this , and accepting his estimate of the iniquities of modern society , it would follow that the really disturbing evidence of alienation would be that of a work-satisfaction survey which reported widespread , stated worker satisfaction , rather than widespread , stated worker dissatisfaction .	) VBG IN DT , CC VBG PP$ NN IN AT NNS IN JJ NN , PPS MD VB CS AT QL JJ NN IN NN MD BE CS IN AT NN NN WDT VBD JJ , VBN NN NN , RB CS JJ , VBN NN NN .
The point is that in a system such as Fromm's which recognizes unconscious motivations , and which rests on certain ethical absolutes , empirical data can be used to support whatever proposition the writer is urging at the moment .	AT NN BEZ CS IN AT NN JJ CS NP$ WDT VBZ JJ NNS , CC WDT VBZ IN AP JJ NNS , JJ NNS MD BE VBN TO VB WDT NN AT NN BEZ VBG IN AT NN .
Thus , in the example cited above Fromm rests his whole case on the premise that the workers are being deprived unconsciously , unknowingly , of fulfillment , and then supports this with survey data reporting conscious , experienced frustrations .	RB , IN AT NN VBN RB NP VBZ PP$ JJ NN IN AT NN CS AT NNS BER BEG VBN RB , RB , IN NN , CC RB VBZ DT IN NN NNS VBG JJ , VBN NNS .
He has his cake and eats it too : if the workers say they are dissatisfied , this shows conscious alienation ; ;	PPS HVZ PP$ NN CC VBZ PPO RB : CS AT NNS VB PPSS BER VBN , DT VBZ JJ NN . .
if they say they are satisfied , this shows unconscious alienation .	CS PPSS VB PPSS BER VBN , DT VBZ JJ NN .
This sort of manipulation is especially troublesome in Fromm's work because , although his system is derived largely from certain philosophic convictions , he asserts that it is based on empirical findings drawn both from social science and from his own consulting room . While the `` empirical psychoanalytic '' label which Fromm claims sheds no light on the validity of his underlying philosophy , it does increase the marketability of his product .	CS AT `` JJ JJ '' NN WDT NP VBZ VBZ AT NN IN AT NN IN PP$ VBG NN , PPS DOZ VB AT NN IN PP$ NN .
The final example of the failure to use available evidence , though evidence of a different kind from that which has so far been considered , comes from Fromm's treatment of some other writers who have dealt with the same themes . In a brief chapter dealing with `` Various Other Diagnoses '' , he quotes isolated passages from some writers whose views seem to corroborate his own , and finds it `` most remarkable that a critical view of twentieth-century society was already held by a number of thinkers living in the nineteenth . '' He finds it equally `` remarkable that their critical diagnosis and prognosis should have so much in common among themselves and with the critics of the twentieth century '' .	'' PPS VBZ PPO RB `` JJ CS PP$ JJ NN CC NN MD HV QL AP IN JJ IN PPLS CC IN AT NNS IN AT OD NN '' .
There is nothing remarkable about this at all .	EX BEZ PN JJ IN DT IN ABN .
It is largely a matter of finding passages that suit one's purposes .	PPS BEZ RB AT NN IN VBG NNS WPS VB PN$ NNS .
There is a difference between evidence and illustration , and Fromm's citation of the other diagnosticians fits the latter category .	EX BEZ AT NN IN NN CC NN , CC NP$ NN IN AT AP NNS VBZ AT AP NN .
Glance at the list : Burckhardt , Tolstoy , Proudhon , Thoreau , London , Marx , Tawney , Mayo , Durkheim , Tannenbaum , Mumford , A. R. Heron , Huxley , Schweitzer , and Einstein .	VB IN AT NN : NP , NP , NP , NP , NP , NP , NP , NP , NP , NP , NP , NP NP NP , NP , NP , CC NP .
This is a delightfully motley collection .	DT BEZ AT QL JJ NN .
One can make them say the same thing only by not listening to them very carefully and hearing only what one wants to hear .	PN MD VB PPO VB AT AP NN RB IN * VBG IN PPO QL RB CC VBG RB WDT PN VBZ TO VB .
The method of selection Fromm uses achieves exactly that .	AT NN IN NN NP VBZ VBZ RB DT .
Furthermore , the list is interesting for its omissions .	RB , AT NN BEZ JJ IN PP$ NNS .
It omits , for example , practically the whole line of great nineteenth century English social critics , nearly all the great writers whose basic position is religious , and all those who are with more or less accuracy called Existentialists . these , almost by definition , are spokesmen for an alienated ideology .	DTS , RB IN NN , BER NNS IN AT VBN NN .
It is not hard to find that concurrence of opinion which Fromm finds so remarkable when you ignore all who hold a different opinion .	PPS BEZ * JJ TO VB DT NN IN NN WDT NP VBZ QL JJ WRB PPSS VB ABN WPS VB AT JJ NN .
Turning from these problems of the use of evidence , one meets another type of difficulty in Fromm's analysis , which is his loose and ambiguous use of certain important terms .	VBG IN DTS NNS IN AT NN IN NN , PN VBZ DT NN IN NN IN NP$ NN , WDT BEZ PP$ JJ CC JJ NN IN AP JJ NNS .
One such instance has already been presented : his use of alienation .	CD JJ NN HVZ RB BEN VBN : PP$ NN IN NN-NC .
The only other one I shall mention here is his use of the term capitalism .	AT AP AP CD PPSS MD VB RB BEZ PP$ NN IN AT NN NN-NC .
For Fromm , capitalism is the enemy , the root of all evil .	IN NP , NN BEZ AT NN , AT NN IN ABN NN .
It is of course useful to have a sovereign cause on one's social criticism , for it makes diagnosis and prescription much easier than they might otherwise be .	PPS BEZ IN NN JJ TO HV AT JJ NN IN PN$ JJ NN , CS PPS VBZ NN CC NN QL JJR CS PPSS MD RB BE .
If one characteristic distinguishes Boris Godunov , it is the consistency with which every person on the stage -- including the chorus -- comes alive in the music .	CS CD NN VBZ NP-TL NP-TL , PPS BEZ AT NN IN WDT AT NN IN AT NN -- IN AT NN -- VBZ JJ IN AT NN .
Much of this lifelike quality results from Mussorgsky's care in basing his vocal line on natural speech inflections .	AP IN DT JJ NN VBZ IN NP$ NN IN VBG PP$ JJ NN IN JJ NN NNS .
In this he followed a path that led back to the very source of opera ; ;	IN DT PPS VBD AT NN WPS VBD RB IN AT AP NN IN NN . .
such composers as Monteverdi , Lully and Purcell , with the same goal in mind , had developed styles of recitative sensitively attuned to their own languages .	JJ NNS CS NP , NP CC NP , IN AT AP NN IN NN , HVD VBN NNS IN NN RB VBN IN PP$ JJ NNS .
Through long experimentation in his songs , Mussorgsky developed a Russian recitative as different from others as the language itself .	IN JJ NN IN PP$ NNS , NP VBD AT JJ NN QL JJ IN NNS CS AT NN PPL .
Giving most of his musical continuity to the orchestra , he lets the speech fall into place as if by coincidence , but controlling the pace and emphasis of the words .	VBG AP IN PP$ JJ NN IN AT NN , PPS VBZ AT NN VB IN NN CS CS IN NN , CC VBG AT NN CC NN IN AT NNS .
The moments of sung melody , in the usual sense , come most often when the character is actually supposed to be singing , as in folk songs and liturgical chants .	AT NNS IN VBN NN , IN AT JJ NN , VB QL RB WRB AT NN BEZ RB VBN TO BE VBG , CS IN NN NNS CC JJ NNS .
Otherwise Mussorgsky reserves his vocal melodies for prolonged expressions of emotion -- Boris' first monologue , for example .	RB NP VBZ PP$ JJ NNS IN VBN NNS IN NN -- NP$ OD NN , IN NN .
Even then , the flexibility of the phrasing suggests that the word comes first in importance .	RB RB , AT NN IN AT NN VBZ CS AT NN VBZ RB IN NN .
Aside from Boris himself , one need but examine the secondary roles to place Mussorgsky among the masters of musical portraiture .	RB IN NP PPL , PN VB CC VB AT JJ NNS TO VB NP IN AT NNS IN JJ NN .
Even those who appear in only one or two scenes are full personalities , defined with economical precision .	RB DTS WPS VB IN AP CD CC CD NNS BER JJ NNS , VBN IN JJ NN .
Consider the four monks who figure prominently in the action : Pimen , Varlaam , Missail and the Jesuit Rangoni .	VB AT CD NNS WPS VB RB IN AT NN : NP , NP , NP CC AT NP NP .
Under no circumstances could we mistake one for the other ; ;	IN AT NNS MD PPSS VB CD IN AT AP . .
each musical setting has an individual touch .	DT NN NN HVZ AT JJ NN .
Pimen is an old man , weak in body -- his voice rarely rises to a full forte -- but firm and clear of mind .	NP BEZ AT JJ NN , JJ IN NN -- PP$ NN RB VBZ IN AT JJ NN -- CC JJ CC JJ IN NN .
His calmness offers contrast to Grigori's youthful excitement .	PP$ NN VBZ NN IN NP$ JJ NN .
A quiet but sturdy theme , somewhat folklike in character , appears whenever the old monk speaks of the history he is recording or of his own past life :	AT JJ CC JJ NN , QL JJ IN NN , VBZ WRB AT JJ NN VBZ IN AT NN PPS BEZ VBG CC IN PP$ JJ AP NN :
This theme comes to represent the outer world , the realm of battles and banquets -- seen from a distance , quite distinct from the quieter spiritual life in the monastery .	DT NN VBZ TO VB AT JJ NN , AT NN IN NNS CC NNS -- VBN IN AT NN , QL JJ IN AT JJR JJ NN IN AT NN .
It changes and develops according to the text ; ;	PPS VBZ CC VBZ RB IN AT NN . .
it introduces Pimen when he comes before Boris in the last act .	PPS VBZ NP WRB PPS VBZ IN NP IN AT AP NN .
Once he has been identified , however , a new melody is used to accompany his narrative , a bleak motif with barren octaves creating a rather ancient effect :	CS PPS HVZ BEN VBN , RB , AT JJ NN BEZ VBN TO VB PP$ NN , AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS VBG AT QL JJ NN :
An imaginative storyteller , Pimen takes on the character he describes , as if he were experiencing the old shepherd's blindness and miraculous cure .	AT JJ NN , NP VBZ RP AT NN PPS VBZ , CS CS PPS BED VBG AT JJ NN$ NN CC JJ NN .
Here the composer uses a favorite device of his , the intensification of the mood through key relationships .	RB AT NN VBZ AT JJ NN IN PP$$ , AT NN IN AT NN IN JJS NNS .
The original D minor seems to symbolize blindness , inescapable in spite of all attempts to move away from it .	AT JJ NN JJ VBZ TO VB NN , JJ IN NN IN ABN NNS TO VB RB IN PPO .
As the child addresses the shepherd in a dream , light -- in the form of the major mode -- begins to appear , and at the moment of the miracle we hear a clear and shining D major .	CS AT NN VBZ AT NN IN AT NN , NN -- IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN -- VBZ TO VB , CC IN AT NN IN AT NN PPSS VB AT JJ CC VBG NN JJ .
Varlaam and Missail always appear together and often sing together , in a straightforward , rhythmically vigorous idiom that distinguishes them from the more subtle and well-educated Pimen .	NP CC NP RB VB RB CC RB VB RB , IN AT JJ , RB JJ NN WPS VBZ PPO IN AT QL JJ CC JJ NP .
Their begging song might easily be a folk melody :	PP$ VBG NN MD RB BE AT NN NN :
The same could be said for the song to which they make their entrance in the final scene .	AT AP MD BE VBN IN AT NN IN WDT PPSS VB PP$ NN IN AT AP NN .
Apparently their origin is humble , their approach to life direct and unsophisticated .	RB PP$ NN BEZ JJ , PP$ NN IN NN JJ CC JJ .
Whatever learning they may have had in their order doesn't disturb them now .	WDT NN PPSS MD HV HVN IN PP$ NN DOZ* VB PPO RB .
Missail is the straight man , not very talkative , mild-mannered when he does speak .	NP BEZ AT JJ NN , * QL JJ , JJ WRB PPS DOZ VB .
Varlaam is loud , rowdy , uninhibited in his pleasures and impatient with anyone who is not the same .	NP BEZ JJ , JJ , JJ IN PP$ NNS CC JJ IN PN WPS BEZ * AT AP .
A rough ostinato figure , heard first in the introduction to the inn scene , characterizes him amusingly and reappears whenever he comes into the action :	AT JJ FW-JJ NN , VBN RB IN AT NN IN AT NN NN , VBZ PPO RB CC VBZ WRB PPS VBZ IN AT NN :
The Song Of Kazan , in which this figure becomes a wild-sounding accompaniment , fills in the picture of undisciplined high spirits .	AT-TL NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL , IN WDT DT NN VBZ AT JJ NN , VBZ RP AT NN IN JJ JJ NNS .
The phrasing is irregular , and the abrupt key changes have a primitive forcefulness .	AT NN BEZ JJ , CC AT JJ NN NNS HV AT JJ NN .
( We can imagine how they startled audiences of the 1870's .	( PPSS MD VB WRB PPSS VBD NNS IN AT NNS .
)	)
Varlaam's music begins to ramble as he feels the effects of the wine , but he pulls himself together when the need arises .	NP$ NN VBZ TO VB CS PPS VBZ AT NNS IN AT NN , CC PPS VBZ PPL RB WRB AT NN VBZ .
Both monks respond to the guard's challenge with a few phrases of their begging song ; ;	ABX NNS VB IN AT NN$ NN IN AT AP NNS IN PP$ VBG NN . .
a clever naturalistic touch is Varlaam's labored reading of the warrant .	AT JJ JJ NN BEZ NP$ VBN NN IN AT NN .
As the knack gradually comes back to him , his rhythm becomes steadier , with the rigid monotony of an unskilled reader .	CS AT NN RB VBZ RB IN PPO , PP$ NN VBZ JJR , IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN .
For the only time in the opera , words are not set according to their natural inflection ; ;	IN AT AP NN IN AT NN , NNS BER * VBN RB IN PP$ JJ NN . .
to do so would have spoiled the dramatic point of the scene .	TO DO RB MD HV VBN AT JJ NN IN AT NN .
Musically and dramatically , Rangoni is as far removed from the conventional monk as Varlaam .	RB CC RB , NP BEZ QL RB VBN IN AT JJ NN CS NP .
His music shows a sensuality coupled with an eerie quality that suggest somehow a blood-kinship with Dappertutto in Offenbach's Hoffman .	PP$ NN VBZ AT NN VBN IN AT JJ NN WPS VB RB AT NN IN NP IN NP$ NP-TL .
His speech shows none of the native accent of the Russian characters ; ;	PP$ NN VBZ PN IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NNS . .
in spite of the Italian name , he sounds French .	IN NN IN AT JJ NN , PPS VBZ JJ .
His personality appears more striking by contrast with Marina , who is -- perhaps purposely -- rather superficially characterized .	PP$ NN VBZ QL JJ IN NN IN NP , WPS BEZ -- RB RB -- QL RB VBN .
Rangoni's first entrance is a musical shock , a sudden open fifth in a key totally unrelated to what has preceded it .	NP$ OD NN BEZ AT JJ NN , AT JJ JJ OD IN AT NN QL JJ IN WDT HVZ VBN PPO .
The effect is as if he had materialized out of nowhere .	AT NN BEZ CS CS PPS HVD VBN RP IN RB .
He speaks quietly , concealing his authority beneath a smooth humility , just as the shifting harmonies that accompany him all but hide the firm pedal point beneath them .	PPS VBZ RB , VBG PP$ NN IN AT JJ NN , RB CS AT VBG NNS WPS VB PPO ABN IN VB AT JJ NN NN IN PPO .
He addresses Marina with great deference , calling her `` Princess '' at first ; ;	PPS VBZ NP IN JJ NN , VBG PP$ `` NN-TL '' IN RB . .
it is only after he has involved her emotions in his scheme that he uses her given name , placing himself by implication in the position of a solicitous father .	PPS BEZ RB CS PPS HVZ VBN PP$ NNS IN PP$ NN CS PPS VBZ PP$ VBN NN , VBG PPL IN NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN .
Curiously , this scene is a close parallel to one that Verdi was writing at the same time , the scene between Amonasro and Aida .	RB , DT NN BEZ AT JJ NN IN CD WPS NP BEDZ VBG IN AT AP NN , AT NN IN NP CC NP .
Rangoni and Amonasro have the same purpose -- forcing the girl to charm the man she loves into serving her country's cause -- and their tactics are much the same .	NP CC NP HV AT AP NN -- VBG AT NN TO VB AT NN PPS VBZ IN VBG PP$ NN$ NN -- CC PP$ NNS BER RB AT AP .
Rangoni begins by describing the sad state of the Church ; ;	NP VBZ IN VBG AT JJ NN IN AT NN-TL . .
this brings a reaction of distress from Marina .	DT VBZ AT NN IN NN IN NP .
The music becomes ethereal as he calls up a vision of her own sainthood : it is she , he tells her , who can bring the truth to Russia and convert the heretics .	AT NN VBZ JJ CS PPS VBZ RP AT NN IN PP$ JJ NN : PPS BEZ PPS , PPS VBZ PPO , WPS MD VB AT NN IN NP CC VB AT NNS .
As if in a trance , she repeats his words -- then realizes , with a shock , her own audacity .	CS CS IN AT NN , PPS VBZ PP$ NNS -- RB VBZ , IN AT NN , PP$ JJ NN .
This is no assignment for a frivolous girl , she assures him .	DT BEZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN , PPS VBZ PPO .
Now Rangoni comes to the point , and we hear , for the first time , a long , downward chromatic scale that will become the characteristic motif of his sinister power .	RB NP VBZ IN AT NN , CC PPSS VB , IN AT OD NN , AT JJ , JJ JJ NN WPS MD VB AT JJ NN IN PP$ JJ NN .
It is a phrase as arresting as a magician's gesture , with a piquant turn of harmony giving an effect of strangeness .	PPS BEZ AT NN QL JJ CS AT NN$ NN , IN AT JJ NN IN NN VBG AT NN IN NN .
Another theme , sinuously chromatic , appears as he directs her to gain power over Grigori by any means , even at the cost of her honor .	DT NN , RB JJ , VBZ CS PPS VBZ PPO TO VB NN IN NP IN DTI NNS , RB IN AT NN IN PP$ NN .
Coming from a priest , the music sounds as odd as the advice :	VBG IN AT NN , AT NN VBZ QL JJ CS AT NN :
Marina rebels at this suggestion .	NP VBZ IN DT NN .
Her pride is as much at stake as her virtue ; ;	PP$ NN BEZ QL RB IN NN CS PP$ NN . .
she is the unattainable beauty , the princess who turns away suitors by the dozen .	PPS BEZ AT JJ NN , AT NN WPS VBZ RB NNS IN AT NN .
Indignantly she denounces Rangoni for his evil thoughts and orders him to leave her .	RB PPS VBZ NP IN PP$ JJ NNS CC VBZ PPO TO VB PPO .
At once the Jesuit pulls out all the stops .	IN RB AT NP VBZ RP ABN AT NNS .
To music of a menacing darkness , he describes the powers of Satan gaining control of the girl , poisoning her soul with pride and destroying her beauty .	IN NN IN AT VBG NN , PPS VBZ AT NNS IN NP VBG NN IN AT NN , VBG PP$ NN IN NN CC VBG PP$ NN .
The combined threat of hell-fire and ugliness is too much for her , and she falls terrified at his feet .	AT VBN NN IN NN CC NN BEZ QL AP IN PPO , CC PPS VBZ VBN IN PP$ NNS .
With another sudden change of mood , he is again calm and protective , exhorting her to trust and obey him as God's spokesman -- and the chromatic scale descends in ominous contradiction .	IN DT JJ NN IN NN , PPS BEZ RB JJ CC JJ , VBG PPO TO VB CC VB PPO CS NP$ NN -- CC AT JJ NN VBZ IN JJ NN .
Whatever the source of Rangoni's power , Marina is his captive now ; ;	WDT AT NN IN NP$ NN , NP BEZ PP$ NN RB . .
we are reminded of this at the end of the next scene , when his theme cuts through the warmth of the love duet , again throwing a chill over the atmosphere .	PPSS BER VBN IN DT IN AT NN IN AT AP NN , WRB PP$ NN VBZ IN AT NN IN AT NN NN , RB VBG AT NN IN AT NN .
The most unusual feature of Boris , however , is the use of the greatest character of all , the chorus .	AT QL JJ NN IN NP , RB , BEZ AT NN IN AT JJT NN IN ABN , AT NN .
This is the real protagonist of the drama ; ;	DT BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN . .
the conflict is not Boris versus Grigori or Shuiski or even the ghost of the murdered child , but Boris versus the Russian people .	AT NN BEZ * NP IN NP CC NP CC RB AT NN IN AT VBN NN , CC NP IN AT JJ NNS .
Mussorgsky makes this quite clear by the extent to which choral scenes propel the action .	NP VBZ DT QL JJ IN AT NN IN WDT JJ NNS VB AT NN .
Boris' first entrance seems almost a footnote to the splendor of the Coronation Scene , with its dazzling confusion of tonalities .	NP$ OD NN VBZ RB AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN-TL NN-TL , IN PP$ VBG NN IN NNS .
We have a brief glimpse of the Tsar's public personality , the `` official Boris '' , but our real focus is on the excitement of the crowd -- a significant contrast with its halfhearted acclamation in the opening scene , its bitter resentment and fury in the final act .	PPSS HV AT JJ NN IN AT NP$ JJ NN , AT `` JJ NP '' , CC PP$ JJ NN BEZ IN AT NN IN AT NN -- AT JJ NN IN PP$ JJ NN IN AT VBG NN , PP$ JJ NN CC NN IN AT AP NN .
One reason for the unique vitality of the chorus is its great variety in expression .	CD NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN BEZ PP$ JJ NN IN NN .
It rarely speaks as a unit .	PPS RB VBZ CS AT NN .
Even in its most conventional appearance , the guests' song of praise to Marina , there are a few female dissenters criticizing the princess for her coldness .	RB IN PP$ QL JJ NN , AT NNS$ NN IN NN IN NP , EX BER AT AP JJ NNS VBG AT NN IN PP$ NN .
In many passages -- for example , the council of boyars -- each section of the chorus becomes a character group with a particular opinion .	IN AP NNS -- IN NN , AT NN IN NNS -- DT NN IN AT NN VBZ AT NN NN IN AT AP NN .
Hot arguments arise between tenors and basses , who will sing in harmony only when they agree on an idea .	JJ NNS VB IN NNS CC NNS , WPS MD VB IN NN RB WRB PPSS VB IN AT NN .
The opening scene shows this method at its most individual .	AT VBG NN VBZ DT NN IN PP$ QL JJ .
Mussorgsky paints a telling picture of the common people , those who must suffer the effects of their rulers' struggle for power without understanding the causes .	NP VBZ AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NNS , DTS WPS MD VB AT NNS IN PP$ NNS$ NN IN NN IN VBG AT NNS .
They are held in control by force , but barely .	PPSS BER VBN IN NN IN NN , CC RB .
They will kneel and plead for Boris' leadership in a strangely intense song , its phrases irregularly broken as if gasping for breath , but when the police with their cudgels move away , they mock and grumble and fight among themselves .	PPSS MD VB CC VB IN NP$ NN IN AT RB JJ NN , PP$ NNS RB VBN CS CS VBG IN NN , CC WRB AT NNS IN PP$ NNS VB RB , PPSS VB CC VB CC VB IN PPLS .
There is a quick change from the plaintive song to a conversational tone .	EX BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN .
`` Hey , Mityukh '' , asks one group , `` what are we shouting about '' ? ?	`` UH , NP '' , VBZ CD NN , `` WDT BER PPSS VBG IN '' . .
And Mityukh , apparently the intellectual leader of the crowd , replies that he has no notion .	CC NP , RB AT JJ NN IN AT NN , VBZ CS PPS HVZ AT NN .
The jokes and arguments grow louder until the police return ; ;	AT NNS CC NNS VB JJR CS AT NNS VB . .
then the people strike up their song with even more fervor than before , ending it with a wail of despair .	RB AT NNS VB RP PP$ NN IN QL AP NN CS RB , VBG PPO IN AT NN IN NN .
Mussorgsky frequently uses liturgical music with considerable dramatic force .	NP RB VBZ JJ NN IN JJ JJ NN .
In Pimen's cell the soft prayers of the monks , heard from offstage , not only help to set the scene but emphasize the contrast between young Grigori's thoughts and his situation .	IN NP$ NN AT JJ NNS IN AT NNS , VBN IN RB , * RB VB TO VB AT NN CC VB AT NN IN JJ NP$ NNS CC PP$ NN .
This is especially striking between Pimen's quiet exit and Grigori's vehement outburst against Boris .	DT BEZ QL JJ IN NP$ JJ NN CC NP$ JJ NN IN NP .
Again , as Boris feels himself nearing death , a procession files into the hall singing a hymn , its modal harmonies adding a churchly touch to the grim atmosphere : The words are hardly calculated to put the Tsar's mind at ease .	RB , CS NP VBZ PPL VBG NN , AT NN VBZ IN AT NN VBG AT NN , PP$ JJ NNS VBG AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN : AT NNS BER RB VBN TO VB AT NP$ NN IN NN .
They echo the words with which he has described his own vision of the dying child who `` trembles and begs for mercy -- and there is no mercy '' .	PPSS VB AT NNS IN WDT PPS HVZ VBN PP$ JJ NN IN AT VBG NN WPS `` VBZ CC VBZ IN NN -- CC EX BEZ AT NN '' .
The living as well as the dead now accuse him ; ;	AT NN QL RB CS AT JJ RB VB PPO . .
this final reminder of his guilt is the fatal one .	DT AP NN IN PP$ NN BEZ AT JJ CD .
One of the outstanding assets of the present production is the restoration of the St. Basil's scene , usually omitted from performances and rarely included in a published score .	CD IN AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN BEZ AT NN IN AT NN-TL NP$ NN , RB VBN IN NNS CC RB VBN IN AT VBN NN .
Though brief , it has a sharp dramatic edge and great poignancy .	CS JJ , PPS HVZ AT JJ JJ NN CC JJ NN .
In addition , it is an important link in the plot , giving us a revealing glimpse of the people's attitude toward Boris and the false Dimitri .	IN NN , PPS BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN , VBG PPO AT VBG NN IN AT NNS$ NN IN NP CC AT JJ NP .
The mayhem in the forest of Kromy is a natural sequel .	AT NN IN AT NN IN NP BEZ AT JJ NN .
The St. Basil's scene opens with little groups of beggars milling around the square , the ever present police keeping them under scrutiny .	AT NN-TL NP$ NN VBZ IN JJ NNS IN NNS VBG IN AT NN , AT RB JJ NNS VBG PPO IN NN .
In the orchestra we hear first a hushed , hesitant pizzicato figure , then the insistent `` police '' motif as it appeared in the opening scene .	IN AT NN PPSS VB RB AT VBN , JJ NN NN , RB AT JJ `` NNS '' NN CS PPS VBD IN AT VBG NN .
The service is over , and a number of people come from the church with their spokesman Mityukh in the lead .	AT NN BEZ JJ , CC AT NN IN NNS VB IN AT NN IN PP$ NN NP IN AT NN .
They bring the news that the Pretender has been excommunicated ; ;	PPSS VB AT NN CS AT NN-TL HVZ BEN VBN . .
this is met with scorn by the hearers , who claim that Mityukh is lying or drunk .	DT BEZ VBN IN NN IN AT NNS , WPS VB CS NP BEZ VBG CC JJ .
( Mussorgsky cleverly contrasts the two groups by their orchestral accompaniment , solemn chords or mocking staccatos .	( NP RB VBZ AT CD NNS IN PP$ JJ NN , JJ NNS CC VBG NNS .
) There is still more news , Mityukh announces : they have prayed for the soul of the Tsarevich .	) EX BEZ RB AP NN , NP VBZ : PPSS HV VBN IN AT NN IN AT NP .
So far these remarks , like most criticisms of Hardy , have tacitly assumed that his poetry is all of a piece , one solid mass of verse expressing a sensibility at a single stage of development .	QL RB DTS NNS , CS AP NNS IN NP , HV RB VBN CS PP$ NN BEZ ABN IN AT NN , CD JJ NN IN NN VBG AT NN IN AT AP NN IN NN .
For critics , Hardy has had no poetic periods -- one does not speak of early Hardy or late Hardy , or of the London or Max Gate period , but simply of Hardy , as of a poetic monolith .	IN NNS , NP HVZ HVN AT JJ NNS -- PN DOZ * VB IN JJ NP CC JJ NP , CC IN AT NP CC NP-TL NN-TL NN , CC RB IN NP , CS IN AT JJ NN .
This seems odd when one recalls that he wrote poetry longer than any other major English poet : `` Domicilium '' is dated `` between 1857 and 1860 '' ; ;	DT VBZ JJ WRB PN VBZ CS PPS VBD NN RBR CS DTI AP JJ JJ NN : `` NP-TL '' BEZ VBN `` IN CD CC CD '' . .
`` Seeing The Moon Rise '' is dated August , 1927 .	`` VBG-TL AT-TL NN-TL VB-TL '' BEZ VBN NP , CD .
One might expect that in a poetic career of seventy-odd years , some changes in style and method would have occurred , some development taken place .	PN MD VB CS IN AT JJ NN IN CD NNS , DTI NNS IN NN CC NN MD HV VBN , DTI NN VBN NN .
This is not , however , the case , and development is a term which we can apply to Hardy only in a very limited sense .	DT BEZ * , RB , AT NN , CC NN BEZ AT NN WDT PPSS MD VB IN NP RB IN AT QL VBN NN .
In a time when poetic style , and poetic belief as well , seem in a state of continual flux , Hardy stands out as a poet of almost perverse consistency .	IN AT NN WRB JJ NN , CC JJ NN QL RB , VB IN AT NN IN JJ NN , NP VBZ RP CS AT NN IN QL JJ NN .
Though he struggled with philosophy all his life , he never got much beyond the pessimism of his twenties ; ;	CS PPS VBD IN NN ABN PP$ NN , PPS RB VBD RB IN AT NN IN PP$ NNS . .
the `` sober opinion '' of his letter to Noyes , written when Hardy was eighty years old , is essentially that of his first `` philosophical '' notebook entry , made when he was twenty-five : `` The world does not despise us : it only neglects us '' ( Early Life , p. 63 ) .	AT `` JJ NN '' IN PP$ NN IN NP , VBN WRB NP BEDZ CD NNS JJ , BEZ RB DT IN PP$ OD `` JJ '' NN NN , VBN WRB PPS BEDZ CD : `` AT NN DOZ * VB PPO : PPS RB VBZ PPO '' ( JJ-TL NN-TL , NN CD ) .
And though in his later years he revised his poems many times , the revisions did not alter the essential nature of the style which he had established before he was thirty ; ;	CC CS IN PP$ JJR NNS PPS VBD PP$ NNS AP NNS , AT NNS DOD * VB AT JJ NN IN AT NN WDT PPS HVD VBN CS PPS BEDZ CD . .
so that , while it usually is easy to recognize a poem by Hardy , it is difficult to date one .	CS CS , CS PPS RB BEZ JJ TO VB AT NN IN NP , PPS BEZ JJ TO VB CD .
There is only one sense in which it is valid to talk about Hardy's development : he did develop toward a more consistent and more effective control of that tone which we recognize as uniquely his .	EX BEZ AP CD NN IN WDT PPS BEZ JJ TO VB IN NP$ NN : PPS DOD VB IN AT QL JJ CC QL JJ NN IN DT NN WDT PPSS VB CS RB PP$$ .
There is only one Hardy style , but in the earlier poems that style is only intermittently evident , and when it is not , the style is the style of another poet , or of the fashion of the time .	EX BEZ AP CD NP NN , CC IN AT JJR NNS DT NN BEZ RB RB JJ , CC WRB PPS BEZ * , AT NN BEZ AT NN IN DT NN , CC IN AT NN IN AT NN .
In the later poems , however , the personal tone predominates .	IN AT JJR NNS , RB , AT JJ NN VBZ .
The bad early poems are bad Shakespeare or bad Swinburne ; ;	AT JJ JJ NNS BER JJ NP CC JJ NP . .
the bad late poems are bad Hardy .	AT JJ JJ NNS BER JJ NP .
There are two ways of getting at a poet's development : through his dated poems , and through the revisions which he made in later editions of his work .	EX BER CD NNS IN VBG IN AT NN$ NN : IN PP$ VBN NNS , CC IN AT NNS WDT PPS VBD IN JJR NNS IN PP$ NN .
About a quarter of Hardy's poems carry an appended date line , usually the year of completion , but sometimes inclusive years ( `` 1908 - 1910 '' ) or two separate dates when Hardy worked on the poem ( `` 1905 and 1926 '' ) or an approximate date ( `` During the War '' ) .	RB AT NN IN NP$ NNS VB AT VBN NN NN , RB AT NN IN NN , CC RB JJ NNS ( `` CD IN CD '' ) CC CD JJ NNS WRB NP VBD IN AT NN ( `` CD CC CD '' ) CC AT JJ NN ( `` IN AT NN-TL '' ) .
These dates are virtually the only clues we have to the chronology of the poems , since the separate volumes are neither chronological within themselves nor in relation to each other .	DTS NNS BER RB AT AP NNS PPSS HV IN AT NN IN AT NNS , CS AT JJ NNS BER CC JJ IN PPLS CC IN NN IN DT AP .
With the exception of Satires Of Circumstance , each volume contains dated poems ranging over several decades ( Winter Words spans sixty-one years ) ; ;	IN AT NN IN NNS-TL IN-TL NN-TL , DT NN VBZ VBN NNS VBG IN AP NNS ( NN-TL NNS-TL VBZ CD NNS ) . .
the internal organization rarely has any chronological order , except in obvious groups like the `` Poems of Pilgrimage '' , the `` Poems of 1912 - 13 '' , and the war poems .	AT JJ NN RB HVZ DTI JJ NN , IN IN JJ NNS CS AT `` NNS-TL IN-TL NN-TL '' , AT `` NNS-TL IN-TL CD-TL IN-TL CD-TL '' , CC AT NN NNS .
From the dated poems we can venture certain conclusions about Hardy's career in poetry , always remembering that conclusions based on a fraction of the whole must remain tentative .	IN AT VBN NNS PPSS MD VB AP NNS IN NP$ NN IN NN , RB VBG CS NNS VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN MD VB JJ .
The dated poems suggest that while Hardy's concern with poetry may have been constant , his production was not .	AT VBN NNS VB CS CS NP$ NN IN NN MD HV BEN JJ , PP$ NN BEDZ * .
He had two productive periods , one in the late 1860's , the other in the decade from 1910 to 1920 ( half of the dated poems are from the latter period , and these alone total about one-tenth of all Hardy's poems ) .	PPS HVD CD JJ NNS , CD IN AT JJ NNS , AT AP IN AT NN IN CD IN CD ( NN IN AT VBN NNS BER IN AT AP NN , CC DTS RB VB RB NN IN ABN NP$ NNS ) .
There was one sterile period : only one poem is dated between 1872 and 1882 and , except for the poems written on the trip to Italy in 1887 , very few from 1882 to 1890 .	EX BEDZ CD JJ NN : RB CD NN BEZ VBN IN CD CC CD CC , IN IN AT NNS VBN IN AT NN IN NP IN CD , QL AP IN CD IN CD .
The dated poems also give us an idea of the degree to which Hardy drew upon past productions for his various volumes , and therefore probably are an indication of the amount of poetry he was writing at the time . Poems Of The Past And The Present and Time's Laughing Stocks , both published while Hardy was at work on The Dynasts , draw heavily on poems written before 1900 . During the poetically sterile years he was writing novels at the rate of almost one a year and was , in addition , burdened with bad health ( he spent six months in bed in 1881 , too ill to do more than work slowly and painfully at A Laodicean ) . The second productive period , the decade from 1910 to 1920 , can be related to three events : the completion of The Dynasts in 1909 , which left Hardy free of pressure for the first time in forty years ; ;	AT OD JJ NN , AT NN IN CD IN CD , MD BE VBN IN CD NNS : AT NN IN AT-TL NNS-TL IN CD , WDT VBD NP JJ IN NN IN AT OD NN IN CD NNS . .
the death of Emma Hardy in 1912 , which had a profound emotional effect on Hardy for which he found release in poetry ; ;	AT NN IN NP NP IN CD , WDT HVD AT JJ JJ NN IN NP IN WDT PPS VBD NN IN NN . .
and the First World War .	CC AT OD-TL NN-TL NN-TL .
It may seem strange that a poet should come to full fruition in his seventies , but we have it on Hardy's own authority that `` he was a child till he was sixteen , a youth till he was five-and-twenty , and a young man till he was nearly fifty '' ( Early Life , p. 42 ) . We may carry this sequence one step further and say that at seventy he was a poet at the height of his powers , wanting only the impetus of two tragedies , one personal , the other national , to loose those powers in poetry . Hardy's two productive decades were separated by forty years , yet between them he developed only in that he became more steadily himself -- it was a narrowing , not an expanding process . Like a wise gardener , Hardy pruned away the Shakespearian sonnets and songs , and the elements of meter and poetic diction to which his personal style was not suited , and let the main stock of his talent flourish . The range of the later poetry is considerably narrower , but the number of successful poems is far greater .	AT NN IN AT JJR NN BEZ QL JJR , CC AT NN IN JJ NNS BEZ QL JJR .
We can see the general characteristics of the earlier decade if we look at two poems of very different qualities : `` Revulsion '' ( 1866 ) and `` Neutral Tones '' ( 1867 ) .	PPSS MD VB AT JJ NNS IN AT JJR NN CS PPSS VB IN CD NNS IN QL JJ NNS : `` NN-TL '' ( CD ) CC `` JJ-TL NNS-TL '' ( CD ) .
There is not much to be said for `` Revulsion '' .	EX BEZ * AP TO BE VBN IN `` NN-TL '' .
Like about half of the 1860 - 70 poems , it is a sonnet on a conventional theme -- the unhappiness of love .	CS RB ABN IN AT CD IN CD NNS , PPS BEZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN -- AT NN IN NN .
Almost anyone could have written it ; ;	RB PN MD HV VBN PPO . .
it is competent in the sense that it makes a coherent statement without violating the rules of the sonnet form , but it is entirely undistinguished and entirely unlike Hardy .	PPS BEZ JJ IN AT NN CS PPS VBZ AT JJ NN IN VBG AT NNS IN AT NN NN , CC PPS BEZ QL JJ CC RB IN NP .
The language is the conventional language of the form ; ;	AT NN BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN . .
there is no phrase or image that sounds like Hardy or that is striking enough to give individuality to the poem .	EX BEZ AT NN CC NN WPS VBZ CS NP CC WPS BEZ JJ QLP TO VB NN IN AT NN .

It is obviously a young man's poem , written out of books and not out of experience ; ;	PPS BEZ RB AT JJ NN$ NN , VBN RP IN NNS CC * RP IN NN . .
it asserts emotion without evoking it -- that is to say , it is sentimental .	PPS VBZ NN IN VBG PPO -- DT BEZ TO VB , PPS BEZ JJ .
There are many such competently anonymous performances among the earlier poems .	EX BER AP JJ RB JJ NNS IN AT JJR NNS .
`` Neutral Tones '' we immediately recognize as a fine poem in Hardy's most characteristic style : the plain but not quite colloquial language , the hard , particular , colorless images , the slightly odd stanza-form , the dramatic handling of the occasion , the refusal to resolve the issue -- all these we have seen in Hardy's best poems .	`` JJ-TL NNS-TL '' PPSS RB VB CS AT JJ NN IN NP$ QL JJ NN : AT JJ CC * QL JJ NN , AT JJ , JJ , JJ NNS , AT QL JJ NN , AT JJ NN IN AT NN , AT NN TO VB AT NN -- ABN DTS PPSS HV VBN IN NP$ JJT NNS .
The poem does not distort the syntax of ordinary speech nor draw on exotic sources of diction , yet it is obviously not ordinary speech -- only Hardy would say `` a grin of bitterness swept thereby ; ;	AT NN DOZ * VB AT NN IN JJ NN CC VB IN JJ NNS IN NN , CC PPS BEZ RB * JJ NN -- AP NP MD VB `` AT NN IN NN VBD RB . .
like an ominous bird a-wing '' , or `` wrings with wrong '' , or would describe a winter sun as `` God-curst '' .	CS AT JJ NN RB '' , CC `` VBZ IN JJ '' , CC MD VB AT NN NN CS `` JJ '' .
The details of the setting of `` Neutral Tones '' are not , strictly speaking , metaphorical , but they combine to create a mood which is appropriate both to a dismal winter day and to the end of love , and in this way love and weather , the emotions and the elements , symbolize each other in a way that is common to many of Hardy's best poems ( `` Weathers '' , `` The Darkling Thrush '' , and `` During Wind and Rain '' , for example ) and to some moving passages in the novels as well ( Far From The Madding Crowd is full of scenes constructed in this way ) . `` Neutral Tones '' is an excellent example of Hardy's mature style , drawn from his earliest productive period ; ;	`` JJ-TL NNS-TL '' BEZ AT JJ NN IN NP$ JJ NN , VBN IN PP$ JJT JJ NN . .
I cite it as evidence that he did not develop through new styles as he grew older ( as Yeats did ) , but that he simply learned to use better what he already had .	PPSS VB PPO CS NN CS PPS DOD * VB IN JJ NNS CS PPS VBD JJR ( CS NP DOD ) , CC CS PPS RB VBD TO VB RBR WDT PPS RB HVD .

if it is somber , it is also precise , and the precision lends authority to the vision .	CS PPS BEZ JJ , PPS BEZ RB JJ , CC AT NN VBZ NN IN AT NN .

they compose a painful elegy to what might have been , to a marriage that began with a promise of happiness , and ended in long years of suffering and hatred .	PPSS VB AT JJ NN IN WDT MD HV BEN , IN AT NN WPS VBD IN AT NN IN NN , CC VBD IN JJ NNS IN VBG CC NN .

he sometimes called them `` an expiation '' , and he would not allow them to be published in periodicals .	PPS RB VBD PPO `` AT NN '' , CC PPS MD * VB PPO TO BE VBN IN NNS .

The elegiac tone is Hardy's natural tone of voice , and it is not surprising that the 1912 - 13 poems are consistently and unmistakably his .	AT JJ NN BEZ NP$ JJ NN IN NN , CC PPS BEZ * JJ CS AT CD IN CD NNS BER RB CC RB PP$$ .

but the mood is not quite nostalgic -- Hardy would not allow sentiment to soften his sense of the irredeemable pastness of the past , and the eternal deadness of the dead .	CC AT NN BEZ * QL JJ -- NP MD * VB NN TO VB PP$ NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN , CC AT JJ NN IN AT JJ .

the fire of love is dead , and Hardy stands , as the speaker does in the last poem of the sequence , over the burnt circle of charred sticks , and thinks of past happiness and present grief , honest and uncomforted . Like the pillars of Hercules , like two ruined Titans guarding the entrance to one of Dante's circles , stand two great dead juvenile delinquents -- the heroes of the post-war generation : the great saxophonist , Charlie Parker , and Dylan Thomas .	CS AT NNS IN NP , CS CD VBN NPS VBG AT NN IN CD IN NP$ NNS , VB CD JJ JJ JJ NNS -- AT NNS IN AT JJ NN : AT JJ NN , NP NP , CC NP NP .
If the word deliberate means anything , both of them certainly deliberately destroyed themselves .	CS AT NN JJ-NC VBZ PN , ABX IN PPO RB RB VBD PPLS .
Both of them were overcome by the horror of the world in which they found themselves , because at last they could no longer overcome that world with the weapon of a purely lyrical art .
