Living in San Francisco I saw them seldom enough to see them with a perspective which was not distorted by exasperation or fatigue .	VBG IN NP NP PPSS VBD PPO RB QLP TO VB PPO IN AT NN WDT BEDZ * VBN IN NN CC NN .
So as the years passed , I saw them each time in the light of an accelerated personal conflagration .	RB CS AT NNS VBD , PPSS VBD PPO DT NN IN AT NN IN AT VBN JJ NN .

About dawn he got up to blow .	RB NN PPS VBD RP TO VB .
The rowdy crowd chilled into stillness and the fluent melody spiraled through it .	AT JJ NN VBD IN NN CC AT JJ NN VBD IN PPO .
The last time I saw Dylan , his self-destruction had not just passed the limits of rationality .	AT AP NN PPSS VBD NP , PP$ NN HVD * RB VBN AT NNS IN NN .

Now Dylan Thomas and Charlie Parker have a great deal more in common than the same disastrous end .	RB NP NP CC NP NP HV AT JJ NN AP IN JJ CS AT AP JJ NN .
As artists , they were very similar .	CS NNS , PPSS BED QL JJ .
They were both very fluent .	PPSS BED ABX QL JJ .
But this fluent , enchanting utterance had , compared with important artists of the past , relatively little content .	CC DT JJ , JJ NN HVD , VBN IN JJ NNS IN AT NN , QL AP NN .
Neither of them got very far beyond a sort of entranced rapture at his own creativity .	DTX IN PPO VBD QL RB IN AT NN IN VBN NN IN PP$ JJ NN .
The principal theme of Thomas's poetry was the ambivalence of birth and death -- the pain of blood-stained creation .	AT JJS NN IN NP$ NN BEDZ AT NN IN NN CC NN -- AT NN IN JJ NN .
Music , of course , is not so explicit an art , but anybody who knew Charlie Parker knows that he felt much the same way about his own gift .	NN , IN NN , BEZ * QL JJ AT NN , CC PN WPS VBD NP NP VBZ CS PPS VBD RB AT AP NN IN PP$ JJ NN .
Both of them did communicate one central theme : Against the ruin of the world , there is only one defense -- the creative act .	ABX IN PPO DOD VB CD JJ NN : IN AT NN IN AT NN , EX BEZ RB CD NN -- AT JJ NN .
This , of course , is the theme of much art -- perhaps most poetry .	DT , IN NN , BEZ AT NN IN AP NN -- RB AP NN .
It is the theme of Horace , who certainly otherwise bears little resemblance to Parker or Thomas .	PPS BEZ AT NN IN NP , WPS RB RB VBZ AP NN IN NP CC NP .
The difference is that Horace accepted his theme with a kind of silken assurance .	AT NN BEZ CS NP VBD PP$ NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
To Dylan and Bird it was an agony and terror .	IN NP CC NP PPS BEDZ AT NN CC NN .
I do not believe that this is due to anything especially frightful about their relationship to their own creativity .	PPSS DO * VB CS DT BEZ JJ IN PN QL JJ IN PP$ NN IN PP$ JJ NN .
I believe rather that it is due to the catastrophic world in which that creativity seemed to be the sole value .	PPSS VB RB CS PPS BEZ JJ IN AT JJ NN IN WDT DT NN VBD TO BE AT JJ NN .
Horace's column of imperishable verse shines quietly enough in the lucid air of Augustan Rome .	NP$ NN IN JJ NN VBZ RB QLP IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NP .
Art may have been for him the most enduring , orderly , and noble activity of man .	NN MD HV BEN IN PPO AT QL VBG , JJ , CC JJ NN IN NN .
But the other activities of his life partook of these values .	CC AT AP NNS IN PP$ NN VBD IN DTS NNS .
They did not actively negate them .	PPSS DOD * RB VB PPO .
Dylan Thomas's verse had to find endurance in a world of burning cities and burning Jews .	NP NP$ NN HVD TO VB NN IN AT NN IN VBG NNS CC VBG NPS .
He was able to find meaning in his art as long as it was the answer to air raids and gas ovens .	PPS BEDZ JJ TO VB NN IN PP$ NN QL RB CS PPS BEDZ AT NN IN NN NNS CC NN NNS .
As the world began to take on the guise of an immense air raid or gas oven , I believe his art became meaningless to him .	CS AT NN VBD TO VB RP AT NN IN AT JJ NN NN CC NN NN , PPSS VB PP$ NN VBD JJ IN PPO .
I think all this could apply to Parker just as well , although , because of the nature of music , it is not demonstrable -- at least not conclusively .	PPSS VB ABN DT MD VB IN NP QL QL RB , CS , RB IN AT NN IN NN , PPS BEZ * JJ -- IN AP * RB .
Thomas and Parker have more in common than theme , attitude , life pattern .	NP CC NP HV AP IN JJ CS NN , NN , NN NN .
In the practice of their art , there is an obvious technical resemblance .	IN AT NN IN PP$ NN , EX BEZ AT JJ JJ NN .
Contrary to popular belief , they were not great technical innovators .	JJ IN JJ NN , PPSS BED * JJ JJ NNS .
Their effects are only superficially startling .	PP$ NNS BER RB RB JJ .
Thomas is a regression from the technical originality and ingenuity of writers like Pierre Reverdy or Apollinaire .	NP BEZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN CC NN IN NNS CS NP NP CC NP .
Similarly , the innovations of bop , and of Parker particularly , have been vastly overrated by people unfamiliar with music , especially by that ignoramus , the intellectual jitterbug , the jazz aficionado .	RB , AT NNS IN NN , CC IN NP RB , HV BEN RB VBN IN NNS JJ IN NN , RB IN DT NN , AT JJ NN , AT NN NN .
The tonal novelties consist in the introduction of a few chords used in classical music for centuries .	AT JJ NNS VB IN AT NN IN AT AP NNS VBN IN JJ NN IN NNS .
And there is less rhythmic difference between progressive jazz , no matter how progressive , and Dixieland , than there is between two movements of many conventional symphonies .	CC EX BEZ AP JJ NN IN JJ NN , AT NN WQL JJ , CC NP , CS EX BEZ IN CD NNS IN AP JJ NNS .
What Parker and his contemporaries -- Gillespie , Davis , Monk , Roach ( Tristano is an anomaly ) , etc. -- did was to absorb the musical ornamentation of the older jazz into the basic structure , of which it then became an integral part , and with which it then developed .	WDT NP CC PP$ NNS -- NP , NP , NP , NP ( NP BEZ AT NN ) , RB -- DOD BEDZ TO VB AT JJ NN IN AT JJR NN IN AT JJ NN , IN WDT PPS RB VBD AT JJ NN , CC IN WDT PPS RB VBD .
This is true of the melodic line which could be put together from selected passages of almost anybody -- Benny Carter , Johnny Hodges .	DT BEZ JJ IN AT JJ NN WDT MD BE VBN RB IN VBN NNS IN RB PN -- NP NP , NP NP .
It is true of the rhythmic pattern in which the beat shifts continuously , or at least is continuously sprung , so that it becomes ambiguous enough to allow the pattern to be dominated by the long pulsations of the phrase or strophe .	PPS BEZ JJ IN AT JJ NN IN WDT AT NN VBZ RB , CC IN AP BEZ RB VBN , CS CS PPS VBZ JJ QLP TO VB AT NN TO BE VBN IN AT JJ NNS IN AT NN CC NN .
This is exactly what happened in the transition from baroque to rococo music .	DT BEZ RB WDT VBD IN AT NN IN JJ IN JJ NN .
It is the difference between Bach and Mozart .	PPS BEZ AT NN IN NP CC NP .
It is not a farfetched analogy to say that this is what Thomas did to poetry .	PPS BEZ * AT JJ NN TO VB CS DT BEZ WDT NP DOD IN NN .
The special syntactical effects of a Rimbaud or an Edith Sitwell -- actually ornaments -- become the main concern .	AT JJ JJ NNS IN AT NP CC AT NP NP -- RB NNS -- VB AT JJS NN .
The metaphysical conceits , which fascinate the Reactionary Generation still dominant in backwater American colleges , were embroideries .	AT JJ NNS , WDT VB AT JJ-TL NN-TL RB JJ IN JJ JJ NNS , BED NNS .
Thomas's ellipses and ambiguities are ends in themselves .	NP$ NNS CC NNS BER NNS IN PPLS .
The immediate theme , if it exists , is incidental , and his main theme -- the terror of birth -- is simply reiterated .	AT JJ NN , CS PPS VBZ , BEZ JJ , CC PP$ JJS NN -- AT NN IN NN -- BEZ RB VBN .
This is one difference between Bird and Dylan which should be pointed out .	DT BEZ CD NN IN NP CC NP WDT MD BE VBN RP .
Again , contrary to popular belief , there is nothing crazy or frantic about Parker either musically or emotionally .	RB , JJ IN JJ NN , EX BEZ PN JJ CC JJ IN NP CC RB CC RB .
His sinuous melody is a sort of naive transcendence of all experience .	PP$ JJ NN BEZ AT NN IN JJ NN IN ABN NN .
Emotionally it does not resemble Berlioz or Wagner ; ;	RB PPS DOZ * VB NP CC NP . .
it resembles Mozart .	PPS VBZ NP .
This is true also of a painter like Jackson Pollock .	DT BEZ JJ RB IN AT NN CS NP NP .
He may have been eccentric in his behavior , but his paintings are as impassive as Persian tiles .	PPS MD HV BEN JJ IN PP$ NN , CC PP$ NNS BER QL JJ CS JJ NNS .
Partly this difference is due to the nature of verbal communication .	RB DT NN BEZ JJ IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
The insistent talk-aboutiveness of the general environment obtrudes into even the most idyllic poetry .	AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN VBZ IN RB AT QL JJ NN .
It is much more a personal difference .	PPS BEZ QL AP AT JJ NN .
Thomas certainly wanted to tell people about the ruin and disorder of the world .	NP RB VBD TO VB NNS IN AT NN CC NN IN AT NN .
Parker and Pollock wanted to substitute a work of art for the world .	NP CC NP VBD TO VB AT NN IN NN IN AT NN .
Technique pure and simple , rendition , is not of major importance , but it is interesting that Parker , following Lester Young , was one of the leaders of the so-called saxophone revolution .	NN JJ CC JJ , NN , BEZ * IN JJ NN , CC PPS BEZ JJ CS NP , VBG NP NP , BEDZ CD IN AT NNS IN AT JJ NN NN .
In modern jazz , the saxophone is treated as a woodwind and played with conventional embouchure .	IN JJ NN , AT NN BEZ VBN CS AT NN CC VBN IN JJ NN .
Metrically , Thomas's verse was extremely conventional , as was , incidentally , the verse of that other tragic enrage , Hart Crane .	RB , NP$ NN BEDZ QL JJ , CS BEDZ , RB , AT NN IN DT AP JJ NN , NP NP .
I want to make clear what I consider the one technical development in the first wave of significant post-war arts .	PPSS VB TO VB JJ WDT PPSS VB AT CD JJ NN IN AT OD NN IN JJ JJ NNS .
Ornament is confabulation in the interstices of structure .	NN BEZ NN IN AT NNS IN NN .
A poem by Dylan Thomas , a saxophone solo by Charles Parker , a painting by Jackson Pollock -- these are pure confabulations as ends in themselves .	AT NN IN NP NP , AT NN NN IN NP NP , AT NN IN NP NP -- DTS BER JJ NNS CS NNS IN PPLS .
Confabulation has come to determine structure .	NN HVZ VBN TO VB NN .
Uninhibited lyricism should be distinguished from its exact opposite -- the sterile , extraneous invention of the corn-belt metaphysicals , or present blight of poetic professors .	JJ NN MD BE VBN IN PP$ JJ NN -- AT JJ , JJ NN IN AT NN NNS , CC JJ NN IN JJ NNS .
Just as Hart Crane had little influence on anyone except very reactionary writers -- like Allen Tate , for instance , to whom Valery was the last word in modern poetry and the felicities of an Apollinaire , let alone a Paul Eluard were nonsense -- so Dylan Thomas's influence has been slight indeed .	RB CS NP NP HVD AP NN IN PN IN QL JJ NNS -- CS NP NP , IN NN , IN WPO NP BEDZ AT AP NN IN JJ NN CC AT NNS IN AT NP , VB RB AT NP NP BED NN -- RB NP NP$ NN HVZ BEN JJ QLP .
In fact , his only disciple -- the only person to imitate his style -- was W. S. Graham , who seems to have imitated him without much understanding , and who has since moved on to other methods .	IN NN , PP$ AP NN -- AT AP NN TO VB PP$ NN -- BEDZ NP NP NP , WPS VBZ TO HV VBN PPO IN AP NN , CC WPS HVZ RB VBD RP IN AP NNS .
Thomas's principal influence lay in the communication of an attitude -- that of the now extinct British romantic school of the New Apocalypse -- Henry Treece , J. F. Hendry , and others -- all of whom were quite conventional poets . Parker certainly had much more of an influence .	NP RB HVD QL AP IN AT NN .
At one time it was the ambition of every saxophone player in every high school band in America to blow like Bird .	IN CD NN PPS BEDZ AT NN IN AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN NN IN NP TO VB CS NP .
Even before his death this influence had begun to ebb .	RB IN PP$ NN DT NN HVD VBN TO VB .
In fact , the whole generation of the founding fathers of bop -- Gillespie , Monk , Davis , Blakey , and the rest -- are just now at a considerable discount .	IN NN , AT JJ NN IN AT VBG NNS IN NN -- NP , NP , NP , NP , CC AT NN -- BER RB RB IN AT JJ NN .
The main line of development today goes back to Lester Young and by-passes them .	AT JJS NN IN NN NR VBZ RB IN NP NP CC VBZ PPO .
The point is that many of the most impressive developments in the arts nowadays are aberrant , idiosyncratic .	AT NN BEZ CS AP IN AT QL JJ NNS IN AT NNS RB BER JJ , JJ .
There is no longer any sense of continuing development of the sort that can be traced from Baudelaire to Eluard , or for that matter , from Hawthorne through Henry James to Gertrude Stein .	EX BEZ QL RBR DTI NN IN VBG NN IN AT NN WPS MD BE VBN IN NP IN NP , CC IN DT NN , IN NP IN NP NP IN NP NP .
The cubist generation before World War 1 , , and , on a lower level , the surrealists of the period between the wars , both assumed an accepted universe of discourse , in which , to quote Andre Breton , it was possible to make definite advances , exactly as in the sciences . Continuity exits , but like the neo-swing music developed from Lester Young , it is a continuity sustained by popular demand .	NN VBZ , CC CS AT NN NN VBN IN NP NP , PPS BEZ AT NN VBN IN JJ NN .
In the plastic arts , a very similar situation exists .	IN AT JJ NNS , AT QL JJ NN VBZ .
Surrealists like Hans Arp and Max Ernst might talk of creation by hazard -- of composing pictures by walking on them with painted soles , or by tossing bits of paper up in the air .	NNS CS NP NP CC NP NP MD VB IN NN IN NN -- IN VBG NNS IN VBG IN PPO IN VBN NNS , CC IN VBG NNS IN NN RP IN AT NN .
But it is obvious that they were self-deluded .	CC PPS BEZ JJ CS PPSS BED JJ .

Nothing looks less like their work than the happenings of random occasion .	PN VBZ RBR CS PP$ NN CS AT NNS IN JJ NN .

The aesthetic appeal of pure paint laid on at random may exist , but it is a very impoverished appeal .	AT JJ NN IN JJ NN VBN RP IN NN MD VB , CC PPS BEZ AT QL JJ NN .
Once again what has happened is an all-consuming confabulation of the incidentals , the accidents of painting .	RB RB WDT HVZ VBN BEZ AT JJ NN IN AT NNS , AT NNS IN VBG .
It is curious that at its best , the work of this school of painting -- Mark Rothko , Jackson Pollock , Clyfford Still , Robert Motherwell , Willem De-Kooning , and the rest -- resembles nothing so much as the passage painting of quite unimpressive painters : the mother-of-pearl shimmer in the background of a Henry McFee , itself a formula derived from Renoir ; ;	PPS BEZ JJ CS IN PP$ JJT , AT NN IN DT NN IN VBG -- NP NP , NP NP , NP NP , NP NP , NP NP , CC AT NN -- VBZ PN QL RB CS AT NN NN IN QL JJ NNS : AT NN NN IN AT NN IN AT NP NP , PPL AT NN VBN IN NP . .
the splashes of light and black which fake drapery in the fashionable imitators of Hals and Sargent .	AT NNS IN NN CC NN WDT VB NN IN AT JJ NNS IN NP CC NP .
Often work of this sort is presented as calligraphy -- the pure utterance of the brush stroke seeking only absolute painteresque values .	RB NN IN DT NN BEZ VBN CS NN -- AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN VBG AP JJ JJ NNS .

At its best the abstract expressionists achieve a simple rococo decorative surface .	IN PP$ JJT AT JJ NNS VB AT JJ JJ JJ NN .
Its poverty shows up immediately when compared with Tiepolo , where the rococo rises to painting of extraordinary profundity and power .	PP$ NN VBZ RP RB WRB VBN IN NP , WRB AT NN VBZ IN VBG IN JJ NN CC NN .

So , in the last couple of years , abstract expressionism has tended toward romantic suggestion -- indications of landscape or living figures .	RB , IN AT AP NN IN NNS , JJ NN HVZ VBN IN JJ NN -- NNS IN NN CC VBG NNS .
Anglo-Saxon and Greek epic each provide on two occasions a seemingly authentic account of the narration of verse in the heroic age .	JJ CC JJ NN DT VB IN CD NNS AT RB JJ NN IN AT NN IN NN IN AT JJ NN .

Nothing in all this is autobiographical : unlike the poets of Deor and Widsith , the poet of Beowulf is not concerned with his own identity ; ;	PN IN ABN DT BEZ JJ : IN AT NNS IN NP-TL CC NP-TL , AT NN IN NP-TL BEZ * VBN IN PP$ JJ NN . .

Since none of these glimpses of poetizing without writing is intended to incorporate a signature into the epic matter , there is prima-facie evidence that Beowulf and the Homeric poems each derive from an oral tradition . That such a tradition lies behind The Iliad and The Odyssey , at least , is hard to deny .	CS ABL AT NN VBZ IN AT-TL NP-TL CC AT-TL NP-TL , IN AP , BEZ JJ TO VB .
Milman Parry rigorously defended the observation that the extant Homeric poems are largely formulaic , and was led to postulate that they could be shown entirely formulaic if the complete corpus of Greek epic survived ; ;	NP NP RB VBD AT NN CS AT JJ JJ NNS BER RB JJ , CC BEDZ VBN TO VB CS PPSS MD BE VBN RB JJ CS AT JJ NN IN JJ NN VBD . .
he further reasoned that frequent formulas in epic verse indicate oral composition , and assumed the slightly less likely corollary that oral epic is inclined towards the use of formulas .	PPS RBR VBD CS JJ NNS IN NN NN VB JJ NN , CC VBD AT QL QL JJ NN CS JJ NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN NNS .
Proceeding from Parry's conclusions and adopting one of his schemata , Francis P. Magoun , Jr. , argues that Beowulf likewise was created from a legacy of oral formulas inherited and extended by bards of successive generations , and the thesis is striking and compelling . Yet a fresh inspection will indicate one crucial amendment : Beowulf and the Homeric poems are not at all formulaic to the same extent .	CC AT JJ NN MD VB CD JJ NN : NP-TL CC AT JJ NNS BER * IN ABN JJ IN AT AP NN .
The bondage endurable by an oral poet is to be estimated only by a very skilful oral poet , but it appears safe to assume that no sustained narrative in rhyme could be composed without extreme difficulty , even in a language of many terminal inflections . Assonance seems nearly as severe a curb , although in a celebrated passage William of Malmesbury declares that A Song Of Roland was intoned before the battle commenced at Hastings .	NN VBZ RB QL JJ AT NN , CS IN AT VBN NN NP IN-TL NP VBZ CS AT-TL NN-TL IN-TL NP-TL BEDZ VBD CS AT NN VBD IN NP .
The Anglo-Saxon alliterative line and the Homeric hexameter probably imposed less of a restraint ; ;	AT JJ JJ NN CC AT JJ NN RB VBD AP IN AT NN . .
the verse of Beowulf or of The Iliad and The Odyssey was not easy to create but was not impossible for poets who had developed their talents perforce in earning a livelihood .	AT NN IN NP-TL CC IN AT-TL NP-TL CC AT-TL NP-TL BEDZ * JJ TO VB CC BEDZ * JJ IN NNS WPS HVD VBN PP$ NNS RB IN VBG AT NN .
Yet certain aids were valuable and quite credibly necessary for reciting long stretches of verse without a pause .	CC AP NNS BED JJ CC QL RB JJ IN VBG JJ NNS IN NN IN AT NN .
The poet in a written tradition who generally never blots a line may once in a while pause and polish without incurring blame .	AT NN IN AT VBN NN WPS RB RB VBZ AT NN MD RB IN AT NN VB CC VB IN VBG NN .
But the oral poet cannot pause ; ;	CC AT JJ NN MD* VB . .
he must improvise continuously with no apparent effort .	PPS MD VB RB IN AT JJ NN .
Even though the bondage of his verse is not so great as the writing poet can manage , it is still great enough for him often to be seriously impeded unless he has aids to facilitate rapid composition .	RB CS AT NN IN PP$ NN BEZ * QL JJ CS AT VBG NN MD VB , PPS BEZ RB JJ QLP CS PPO RB TO BE RB VBN CS PPS HVZ NNS TO VB JJ NN .
The Germanic poet had such aids in the kennings , which provided for the difficulties of alliteration ; ;	AT JJ NN HVD JJ NNS IN AT NNS , WDT VBD IN AT NNS IN NN . .
the Homeric poet had epithets , which provided for recurring needs in the hexameter .	AT JJ NN HVD NNS , WDT VBD IN VBG NNS IN AT NN .
Either poet could quickly and easily select words or phrases to supply his immediate requirements as he chanted out his lines , because the kennings and the epithets made possible the construction of systems of numerous synonyms for the chief common and proper nouns .	DTX NN MD RB CC RB VB NNS CC NNS TO VB PP$ JJ NNS CS PPS VBD RP PP$ NNS , CS AT NNS CC AT NNS VBD JJ AT NN IN NNS IN JJ NNS IN AT JJS JJ CC JJ NNS .
Other synonyms could of course serve the same function , and for the sake of ease I shall speak of kennings and epithets in the widest and loosest possible sense , and name , for example , Gar-Dene a kenning for the Danes . Verbal and adverbial elements too participated in each epic diction , but it is for the present sufficient to mark the large nominal and adjectival supply of semantic near-equivalents , and to designate the members of any system of equivalents as basic formulas of the poetic language . Limited to a few thousand lines of heroic verse in Anglo-Saxon as in the other Germanic dialects , we cannot say how frequently the kennings in Beowulf recurred in contemporary epic on the same soil . But we can say that since a writing poet , with leisure before him , would seem unlikely to invent a technique based upon frequent and substantial circumlocution , the kennings like the epithets must reasonably be ascribed to an oral tradition . One of the greatest Homerists of our time , Frederick M. Combellack , argues that when it is assumed The Iliad and The Odyssey are oral poems , the postulated single redactor called Homer cannot be either credited with or denied originality in choice of phrasing . Any example of grand or exquisite diction may have been created by the poet who compiled numerous lays into the two works we possess or may be due to one of his completely unknown fellow-craftsmen . The quest of the historical Homer is likely never to have further success ; ;	AT NN IN AT JJ NP BEZ JJ RB TO HV AP NN . .
no individual word in The Iliad or The Odyssey can be credited to any one man ; ;	AT AP NN IN AT-TL NP-TL CC AT-TL NP-TL MD BE VBN IN DTI CD NN . .
no strikingly effective element of speech in the extant poems can with assurance be said not to have been a commonplace in the vaster epic corpus that may have existed at the beginning of the first millennium before Christ . This observation is of interest not only to students of Homeric poetry but to students of Anglo-Saxon poetry as well .	DT NN BEZ IN NN * RB IN NNS IN JJ NN CC IN NNS IN JJ NN QL RB .
To the extent that a tale is twice told , its final author must be suspect , although plagiarism in an oral tradition is less a misdemeanor than the standard modus dicendi .	IN AT NN CS AT NN BEZ RB VBN , PP$ AP NN MD BE JJ , CS NN IN AT JJ NN BEZ AP AT NN CS AT JJ FW-NN FW-VBG .
Combellack argues further , and here he makes his main point , that once The Iliad and The Odyssey are thought formulaic poems composed for an audience accustomed to formulaic poetry , Homeric critics are deprived of an entire domain they previously found arable . With a few important and a few more unimportant exceptions , no expression can be deemed le mot juste for its context , because each was very probably the only expression that long-established practice and ease of rapid recitation would allow . Words or phrases that connoisseurs have admired as handsome or ironic or humorous must therefore lose merit and become regarded as mere inevitable time-servers , sometimes accurate and sometimes not .	NNS CC NNS WPO NNS HV VBN CS JJ CC JJ CC JJ MD RB VB NN CC VB VBN CS JJ JJ NNS , RB JJ CC RB * .
This observation too may have reference to Anglo-Saxon poetry .	DT NN RB MD HV NN IN JJ NN .
To the extent that a language is formulaic , its individual components must be regarded as no more distinguished than other cliches .	IN AT NN CS AT NN BEZ JJ , PP$ AP NNS MD BE VBN CS QL QL VBN CS AP NNS .
W. F. Bryan suggests that certain kennings in Beowulf were selected sometimes for appropriateness and sometimes for ironic inappropriateness , but such a view would appear untenable unless it is denied that the language of Beowulf is formulaic . If the master of scops who was most responsible for the poem ever used kennings that were traditional , he was at least partly deprived of free will and not inclined towards shrewd and sophisticated misuse of speech elements . Yet , if the argument is turned awry , there may be found a great deal in Bryan's view , after all .	RB , CS AT NN BEZ VBN JJ , EX MD BE VBN AT JJ NN IN NP$ NN , IN ABN .
A formulaic element need not be held meaningless merely because it was selected with little conscious reflection .	AT JJ NN MD * BE VBN JJ RB CS PPS BEDZ VBN IN AP JJ NN .
Time-servers , though the periphrastic expressions are , they may nevertheless be handsome or ironic or humorous .	NNS , CS AT JJ NNS BER , PPSS MD RB BE JJ CC JJ CC JJ .
A long evolution in an oral tradition caused the poetic language of the heroic age to be based upon formulas that show the important qualities of things , and these formulas are therefore potentially rather than always actually accurate . True , we do not know how they were regarded in their day , but we need not believe the epic audience to have been more insensitive to the formulas than the numerous scholars of modern times who have read Germanic or Homeric poetry all their lives and still found much to admire in occasional occurrences of the most familiar phrases . Nouns and adjectives in a written tradition are chosen for the nonce ; ;	NNS CC NNS IN AT VBN NN BER VBN IN AT NN . .
in an oral tradition they may be chosen for the entire epic corpus , and tend towards idealization rather than distinctive delineation .	IN AT JJ NN PPSS MD BE VBN IN AT JJ NN NN , CC VB IN NN RB CS JJ NN .

no-one today would hope to discover the unmistakable ruins of Heorot or the palace of Priam .	PN NR MD VB TO VB AT JJ NNS IN NP CC AT NN IN NP .
A ship at dry-dock could be called a foamy-necked floater in Anglo-Saxon or a swift ship in Greek .	AT NN IN NN MD BE VBN AT JJ NN IN NP CC AT JJ NN IN NP .

In Coriolanus the agnomen of Marcius is used deliberately and pointedly , but the Homeric epithets and the Anglo-Saxon kennings are used casually and recall to the hearer `` a familiar story or situation or a useful or pleasant quality of the referent '' . The epic language was not entirely the servant of the poet ; ;	AT NN NN BEDZ * RB AT NN IN AT NN . .

The poet's intentions are difficult to discern and , except to biographers , unimportant ; ;	AT NN$ NNS BER JJ TO VB CC , IN IN NNS , JJ . .

Beowulf and the Homeric poems appear oral compositions .	NP-TL CC AT JJ NNS VB JJ NNS .

Albert B. Lord suggests that the Homeric poems were dictated to a scribe by a minstrel who held in his mind the poems fully matured but did not himself possess the knowledge of writing since it would be useless to his guild , and Magoun argues that the Beowulf poet and Cynewulf may have dictated their verse in the same fashion . This explanation is attractive , but is vitiated at least in part by the observation that Cynewulf , though he used kennings in the traditional manner , was a literate man who four times inscribed his name by runes into his works . In lieu of the amanuensis to the blind or illiterate bard , one may conceive of a man who heard a vast store of oral poetry recited , and became intimately familiar with the established aids to poetizing , and himself wrote his own compositions or his edition of the compositions of the past . Other theories of origin are compatible with the formulaic theory : Beowulf may contain a design for terror , and The Iliad may have a vast hysteron-proteron pattern answering to a ceramic pattern produced during the Geometric Period in pottery . The account of the growth and final transcription of these epics rests partly , however , upon the degree to which they were formulaic .	AT NN IN AT NN CC AP NN IN DTS NNS VBZ RB , RB , IN AT NN IN WDT PPSS BED JJ .
Carl Eduard Schmidt counted 1804 different lines repeated exactly in the two Homeric poems , and by increasing this figure so as to include lines repeated with very slight modifications he counted 2118 different lines used a total of 5612 times .	NP NP NP VBD CD JJ NNS VBN RB IN AT CD JJ NNS , CC IN VBG DT NN CS CS TO VB NNS VBN IN QL JJ NNS PPS VBD CD JJ NNS VBN AT NN IN CD NNS .
Thus one line in five from The Iliad and The Odyssey is to be found somewhere else in the two poems .	RB CD NN IN CD IN AT-TL NP-TL CC AT-TL NP-TL BEZ TO BE VBN RB RB IN AT CD NNS .
The ratio is thoroughly remarkable , because the lines are so long -- half again as long as those of Beowulf .	AT NN BEZ QL JJ , CS AT NNS BER QL JJ -- ABN RB QL JJ CS DTS IN NP-TL .
Anglo-Saxon poetry appears to have no comparable amount of repetition ; ;	JJ NN VBZ TO HV AT JJ NN IN NN . .
there is no reason to think that the scop used and re-used whole lines and even lengthy passages after the manner of his Homeric colleague .	EX BEZ AT NN TO VB CS AT NN VBD CC VBD JJ NNS CC RB JJ NNS IN AT NN IN PP$ JJ NN .
In determining the extent to which any poem is formulaic it is idle , however , to inspect nothing besides lines repeated in their entirety , for a stock of line-fragments would be sufficient to permit the poet to extemporize with deftness if they provided for prosodic needs . if any words or phrases are formulaic , they will be .	CS DTI NNS CC NNS BER JJ , PPSS MD BE .
The Iliad has two words for the shield , ASPIS and SAKOS .	AT-TL NP-TL HVZ CD NNS IN AT NN , FW-NN-NC CC FW-NN-NC .
Recent criticism of Great Expectations has tended to emphasize its symbolic and mythic content , to show , as M. D. Zabel has said of Dickens generally , that much of the novel's impact resides in its `` allegoric insight and moral metaphor '' . J. H. Miller's excellent chapter on Great Expectations has lately illustrated how fruitfully that novel can be read from such a perspective .	NP NP NP$ JJ NN IN JJ-TL NNS-TL HVZ RB VBN WQL RB DT NN MD BE VBN IN ABL AT NN .
In his analysis , however , he touches upon but fails to explore an idea , generally neglected in discussions of the book , which I believe is central to its art -- the importance of human hands as a recurring feature of the narrative .	IN PP$ NN , RB , PPS VBZ IN CC VBZ TO VB AT NN , RB VBN IN NNS IN AT NN , WDT PPSS VB BEZ JJ IN PP$ NN -- AT NN IN JJ NNS CS AT VBG NN IN AT NN .
This essay seeks to make that exploration .	DT NN VBZ TO VB DT NN .
Dickens was not for nothing the most theatrical of the great Victorian writers .	NP BEDZ * IN PN AT QL JJ IN AT JJ JJ NNS .
He knew instinctively that next to voice and face an actor's hands are his most useful possession -- that in fiction as in the theatre , gesture is an indispensable shorthand for individualizing character and dramatizing action and response . It is hardly accidental , therefore , that many of his most vivid figures do suggestive or eccentric things with their hands .	PPS BEZ QL JJ , RB , CS AP IN PP$ QL JJ NNS DO JJ CC JJ NNS IN PP$ NNS .
In Great Expectations the hands become almost an obsession .	IN JJ-TL NNS-TL AT NNS VB RB AT NN .
Mr. Jaggers habitually bites his forefinger , a gesture which conveys both contempt and the inscrutable abstractedness that half fascinates , half terrifies all who have dealings with him .	NP NP RB VBZ PP$ NN , AT NN WDT VBZ ABX NN CC AT JJ NN WPS RB VBZ , RB VBZ ABN WPS HV NNS IN PPO .
Miss Havisham's withered hands , heavy as if her unhappiness were somehow concentrated in them , move in restless self-pity between her broken heart and her walking stick .	NP NP$ VBN NNS , JJ CS CS PP$ NN BED RB VBN IN PPO , VB IN JJ NN IN PP$ VBN NN CC PP$ VBG NN .
Pumblechook's `` signature '' is the perpetually extended glad hand .	NP$ `` NN '' BEZ AT RB VBN JJ NN .
Wemmick reveals his self-satisfaction by regularly rubbing his hands together .	NP VBZ PP$ NN IN RB VBG PP$ NNS RB .
Old Mr. Pocket's frantic response to life imprisonment with a useless , social-climbing wife is to `` put his two hands into his disturbed hair '' and `` make an extraordinary effort to lift himself up by it '' , whereas Joe Gargery endures the shrewish onslaughts of Mrs. Joe by apologetically drawing `` the back of his hand across and across his nose '' .	JJ NP NP$ JJ NN IN NN NN IN AT JJ , JJ NN BEZ TO `` VB PP$ CD NNS IN PP$ VBN NN '' CC `` VB AT JJ NN TO VB PPL RP IN PPO '' , CS NP NP VBZ AT JJ NNS IN NP NP IN RB VBG `` AT NN IN PP$ NN IN CC IN PP$ NN '' .
Such mannerisms would be less worthy of remark , were it not that in Great Expectations , as in no other of Dickens' novels , hands serve as a leitmotif of plot and theme -- a kind of unifying symbol or natural metaphor for the book's complex of human interrelationships and the values and attitudes that motivate them .	JJ NNS MD BE QL JJ IN NN , BED PPS * CS IN JJ-TL NNS-TL , CS IN AT AP IN NP$ NNS , NNS VB CS AT NN IN NN CC NN -- AT NN IN VBG NN CC JJ NN IN AT NN$ NN IN JJ NNS CC AT NNS CC NNS WPS VB PPO .
Dickens not only reveals character through gesture , he makes hands a crucial element of the plot , a means of clarifying the structure of the novel by helping to define the hero's relations with all the major characters , and a device for ordering such diverse themes as guilt , pursuit , crime , greed , education , materialism , enslavement ( by both people and institutions ) , friendship , romantic love , forgiveness , and redemption .	NP * RB VBZ NN IN NN , PPS VBZ NNS AT JJ NN IN AT NN , AT NN IN VBG AT NN IN AT NN IN VBG TO VB AT NN$ NNS IN ABN AT JJ NNS , CC AT NN IN VBG JJ JJ NNS CS NN , NN , NN , NN , NN , NN , NN ( IN ABX NNS CC NNS ) , NN , JJ NN , NN , CC NN .
We have only to think of Lady Macbeth or the policeman-murderer in Thomas Burke's famous story , `` The Hands Of Mr. Ottermole '' , to realize that hands often call up ideas of crime and punishment .	PPSS HV RB TO VB IN NN-TL NP CC AT NN IN NP NP$ JJ NN , `` AT-TL NNS-TL IN-TL NP-TL NP-TL '' , TO VB CS NNS RB VB RP NNS IN NN CC NN .
So it is with Great Expectations , whether the hands be Orlick's as he strikes down Mrs. Gargery or Pip's as he steals a pie from her pantry .	RB PPS BEZ IN JJ-TL NNS-TL , CS AT NNS BE NP$ CS PPS VBZ RP NP NP CC NP$ CS PPS VBZ AT NN IN PP$ NN .
Such associations suit well with the gothic or mystery-story aspects of Dickens' novel , but , on a deeper plane , they relate to the themes of sin , guilt , and pursuit that have recently been analyzed by other critics .	JJ NNS VB RB IN AT JJ CC NN NNS IN NP$ NN , CC , IN AT JJR NN , PPSS VB IN AT NNS IN NN , NN , CC NN WPS HV RB BEN VBN IN AP NNS .
The novel opens with a fugitive convict frantically trying to avoid the nemesis of being `` laid hands on '' -- a mysterious figure who looks into Pip's frightened eyes in the churchyard `` as if he were eluding the hands of the dead people , stretching up cautiously out of their graves , to get a twist upon his ankle and pull him in '' .	AT NN VBZ IN AT NN NN RB VBG TO VB AT NN IN BEG `` VBN NNS IN '' -- AT JJ NN WPS VBZ IN NP$ VBN NNS IN AT NN `` CS CS PPS BED VBG AT NNS IN AT JJ NNS , VBG RP RB RP IN PP$ NNS , TO VB AT NN IN PP$ NN CC VB PPO RP '' .
Magwitch terrifies Pip into stealing a pork pie for him by creating the image in the boy's imagination of a bogy man who may `` softly creep his way to him and tear him open '' , `` imbruing his hands '' in him .	NP VBZ NP IN VBG AT NN NN IN PPO IN VBG AT NN IN AT NN$ NN IN AT NN NN WPS MD `` RB VB PP$ NN IN PPO CC VB PPO JJ '' , `` VBG PP$ NNS '' IN PPO .
As Pip agonizes over the theft that his own hands have committed , his guilty conscience projects itself upon the wooden finger of a local signpost , transforming it into `` a phantom devoting me to the Hulks '' . later he flees in panic from the family table just as his theft is about to be discovered and is blocked at the front door by a soldier who accusingly holds out a pair of handcuffs which he has brought to Gargery's forge for mending . Through such details Dickens indicates at the outset that guilt is a part of the ironic bond between Pip and Magwitch which is so unpredictably to alter both their lives .	IN JJ NNS NP VBZ IN AT NN CS NN BEZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN NP CC NP WDT BEZ QL RB TO VB ABX PP$ NNS .
Since they commonly translate thoughts and feelings into deeds , hands naturally represent action , and since nearly half the characters in Great Expectations are of the underworld or closely allied to it , the linking of hands with crime or violence is not to be wondered at .	CS PPSS RB VB NNS CC NNS IN NNS , NNS RB VB NN , CC CS RB ABN AT NNS IN JJ-TL NNS-TL BER IN AT NN CC RB VBN IN PPO , AT NN IN NNS IN NN CC NN BEZ * TO BE VBN IN .
Dickens , for excellent psychological reasons , never fully reveals Magwitch's felonious past , but Pip , at the convict's climactic reappearance in London , shrinks from clasping a hand which he fears `` might be stained with blood '' .	NP , IN JJ JJ NNS , RB RB VBZ NP$ JJ NN , CC NP , IN AT NN$ JJ NN IN NP , VBZ IN VBG AT NN WDT PPS VBZ `` MD BE VBN IN NN '' .
Orlick slouches about the forge `` like Cain '' with `` his hands in his pockets '' , and when he shouts abuse at Mrs. Joe for objecting to his holiday , she claps her hands in a tantrum , beats them `` upon her bosom and upon her knees '' , and clenches them in her husband's hair .	NP VBZ IN AT NN `` CS NP '' IN `` PP$ NNS IN PP$ NNS '' , CC WRB PPS VBZ NN IN NP NP IN VBG IN PP$ NN , PPS VBZ PP$ NNS IN AT NN , VBZ PPO `` IN PP$ NN CC IN PP$ NNS '' , CC VBZ PPO IN PP$ NN$ NN .
This last `` rampage '' is only the prelude to the vicious blow upon her head , `` dealt by some unknown hand '' whose identity is later revealed not verbally but through a manual action -- the tracing of Orlick's hammer upon a slate . Pip himself is to feel the terror of Orlick's `` murderous hand '' in his secret rendezvous at the sluicehouse on the marshes .	NP PPL BEZ TO VB AT NN IN NP$ `` JJ NN '' IN PP$ JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT NNS .
Dickens lays great emphasis on the hands in this scene .	NP VBZ JJ NN IN AT NNS IN DT NN .
Orlick shakes his hand at Pip , bangs the table with his fist , draws his unclenched hand `` across his mouth as if his mouth watered '' for his victim , lets his hands hang `` loose and heavy at his sides '' , and Pip observes him so intensely that he knows `` of the slightest action of his fingers '' . Orlick might almost be Magwitch's bogy man come alive , a figure of nemesis from Pip's phantasy of guilt .	NP MD RB BE NP$ NN NN VBN JJ , AT NN IN NN IN NP$ NN IN NN .
The scarred , disfigured wrists of Mr. Jaggers' housekeeper are the tell-tale marks of her sinister past , for her master , coolly exhibiting them to his dinner guests , makes a point of the `` force of grip there is in these hands '' .	AT VBN , VBN NNS IN NP NP$ NN BER AT JJ NNS IN PP$ JJ NN , CS PP$ NN , RB VBG PPO IN PP$ NN NNS , VBZ AT NN IN AT `` NN IN NN EX BEZ IN DTS NNS '' .
Jaggers' iron control over her ( `` she would remove her hands from any dish she put before him , hesitatingly , as if she dreaded his calling her back ) '' ) rests on his having once got her acquitted of a murder charge by cleverly contriving her sleeves at the trial to conceal her strength and by passing off the lacerations on the backs of her hands as the scratches of brambles rather than of human fingernails .	NP$ JJ NN IN PPO ( `` PPS MD VB PP$ NNS IN DTI NN PPS VBD IN PPO , RB , CS CS PPS VBD PP$ VBG PPO RB ) '' ) VBZ IN PP$ HVG RB VBN PPO VBN IN AT NN NN IN RB VBG PP$ NNS IN AT NN TO VB PP$ NN CC IN VBG RP AT NNS IN AT NNS IN PP$ NNS CS AT NNS IN NNS RB CS IN JJ NNS .
It is the similarity between Estella's hands and Molly's ( `` The action of her fingers was like the action of knitting '' ) that provides Pip with a vital clue to the real identity of both and establishes a symbolic connection between the underworld of crime and the genteel cruelty of Satis House . Finally , Magwitch's pursuit of Compeyson , his archenemy and betrayer , begins by his holding him in a vicelike grip on the river flats to frustrate his escape and culminates in his `` laying his hand on his cloak to identify him '' , thus precipitating the death-locked struggle in the water during which Compeyson drowns . Magwitch's hand here ironically becomes the agent of justice .	NP$ NN RB RB VBZ AT NN IN NN .
But only in one of its aspects is Great Expectations a tale of violence , revenge , and retribution .	CC RB IN CD IN PP$ NNS BEZ JJ-TL NNS-TL AT NN IN NN , NN , CC NN .
Money , so important a theme elsewhere in Dickens , is here central , and hands are often associated in some way with the false values -- acquisitiveness , snobbery , self-interest , hypocrisy , toadyism , irresponsibility , injustice -- that attach to a society based upon the pursuit of wealth .	NN , QL JJ AT NN RB IN NP , BEZ RB JJ , CC NNS BER RB VBN IN DTI NN IN AT JJ NNS -- NN , NN , NN , NN , NN , NN , NN -- WPS VB IN AT NN VBN IN AT NN IN NN .
Dickens suggests the economic evils of such a society on the first page of his novel in the description of Pip's five little dead brothers `` who gave up trying to get a living exceedingly early in that universal struggle '' , who seemed to have `` all been born on their backs with their hands in their trousers-pockets , and had never taken them out in this state of existence '' .	NP VBZ AT JJ NNS IN ABL AT NN IN AT OD NN IN PP$ NN IN AT NN IN NP$ CD JJ JJ NNS `` WPS VBD RP VBG TO VB AT NN QL RB IN DT JJ NN '' , WPS VBD TO HV `` ABN BEN VBN IN PP$ NNS IN PP$ NNS IN PP$ NNS , CC HVD RB VBN PPO RP IN DT NN IN NN '' .
Pip's great expectations , his progress through illusion and disillusionment , turn , somewhat as they do for the naive hero of Dreiser's American Tragedy , upon the lure of genteel prosperity through unearned income -- what Wemmick calls `` portable property '' and what Jaggers reproaches Pip for letting `` slip through ( his ) fingers '' .	NP$ JJ NNS , PP$ NN IN NN CC NN , VB , RB CS PPSS DO IN AT JJ NN IN NP$ JJ-TL NN-TL , IN AT NN IN JJ NN IN JJ NN -- WDT NP VBZ `` JJ NN '' CC WDT NP VBZ NP IN VBG `` NN IN ( PP$ ) NNS '' .
Since a gentleman must , if possible , avoid sullying them by work , his hands , as importantly as his accent , become the index of social status .	CS AT NN MD , CS JJ , VB VBG PPO IN NN , PP$ NNS , QL RB CS PP$ NN , VB AT NN IN JJ NN .
Almost the first step in the corruption of Pip's values is the unworthy shame he feels when Estella cruelly remarks the coarseness of his hands : `` They had never troubled me before , but they troubled me now , as vulgar appendages '' .	RB AT OD NN IN AT NN IN NP$ NNS BEZ AT JJ NN PPS VBZ WRB NP RB VBZ AT NN IN PP$ NNS : `` PPSS HVD RB VBN PPO RB , CC PPSS VBD PPO RB , CS JJ NNS '' .
Pip imagines how Estella would look down upon Joe's hands , roughened by work in the smithy , and the deliberate contrast between her white hands and his blackened ones is made to symbolize the opposition of values between which Pip struggles -- idleness and work , artificiality and naturalness , gentility and commonness , coldness and affection -- in fact , between Satis House and the forge .	NP VBZ WRB NP MD VB RP IN NP$ NNS , VBN IN NN IN AT NN , CC AT JJ NN IN PP$ JJ NNS CC PP$ VBN NNS BEZ VBN TO VB AT NN IN NNS IN WDT NP VBZ -- NN CC NN , NN CC NN , NN CC NN , NN CC NN -- IN NN , IN NP-TL NN-TL CC AT NN .
When the snobbery that alienates Pip from Joe finally gives way before the deeper and stronger force of love , the reunion is marked by an embarrassed handshake at which Pip exclaims : `` No , don't wipe it off -- for God's sake , give me your blackened hand '' ! ! Pip's abject leave-taking of Miss Havisham , during which he kneels to kiss her hand , signalizes his homage to a supposed patroness who seems to be opening up for him a new world of glamour ; ;	NP$ JJ NN IN NP NP , IN WDT PPS VBZ TO VB PP$ NN , VBZ PP$ NN IN AT VBN NN WPS VBZ TO BE VBG RP IN PPO AT JJ NN IN NN . .
when , on the journey to London that immediately follows , he pauses nostalgically to lay his hand upon the finger-post at the end of the village , the wooden pointer symbolically designates a spiritual frontier between innocence and the corruption of worldly vanity . Incidentally , one cannot miss the significance of this gesture , for Dickens reintroduces it associatively in Pip's mind at another moral and psychological crisis -- his painful recognition , in a talk with Herbert Pocket , that his hopeless attachment to Estella is as self-destructive as it is romantic .	RB , PN MD* VB AT NN IN DT NN , CS NP VBZ PPO RB IN NP$ NN IN DT JJ CC JJ NN -- PP$ JJ NN , IN AT NN IN NP NP , CS PP$ JJ NN IN NP BEZ QL JJ CS PPS BEZ JJ .
In both cases the finger-post represents Pip's heightened awareness of contrary magnetisms .	IN ABX NNS AT NN VBZ NP$ VBN NN IN JJ NNS .
A variety of hand movements helps dramatize the moral climate of the fallen world Pip encounters beyond the forge .	AT NN IN NN NNS VBZ VB AT JJ NN IN AT VBN NN NP VBZ IN AT NN .
The vulture-like attendance of the Pocket family upon Miss Havisham is summed up in the hypocritical gestures of Miss Camilla Pocket , who puts her hand to her throat in a feigned spasm of grief-stricken choking , then lays it `` upon her heaving bosom '' with `` an unnatural fortitude of manner '' , and finally kisses it to Miss Havisham in a parody of the lady's own mannerism toward Estella .	AT JJ NN IN AT NP NN IN NP NP BEZ VBN RP IN AT JJ NNS IN NP NP NP , WPS VBZ PP$ NN IN PP$ NN IN AT VBN NN IN JJ NN , RB VBZ PPO `` IN PP$ VBG NN '' IN `` AT JJ NN IN NN '' , CC RB VBZ PPO IN NP NP IN AT NN IN AT NN$ JJ NN IN NP .
Pumblechook's hands throughout the novel serve to travesty greed and hypocritical self-aggrandizement .	NP$ NNS IN AT NN VB TO VB NN CC JJ NN .
We first see him shaking Mrs. Joe's hand on discovering the sizable amount of the premium paid to her husband for Pip's indenture as an apprentice and later pumping Pip's hands `` for the hundredth time at least '' ( `` May I -- may I -- '' ? ? ) in effusive congratulation to Pip on his expectations .	) IN JJ NN IN NP IN PP$ NNS .
We take leave of Pumblechook as he gloats over Pip's loss of fortune , extending his hand `` with a magnificently forgiving air '' and exhibiting `` the same fat five fingers '' , one of which he identifies with `` the finger of Providence '' and shakes at Pip in a canting imputation of the latter's `` ingratitoode '' and his own generosity as Pip's `` earliest benefactor '' .	PPSS VB NN IN NP CS PPS VBZ IN NP$ NN IN NN , VBG PP$ NN `` IN AT RB JJ NN '' CC VBG `` AT AP JJ CD NNS '' , CD IN WDT PPS VBZ IN `` AT NN IN NP '' CC VBZ IN NP IN AT VBG NN IN AT NN$ `` NN '' CC PP$ JJ NN CS NP$ `` JJT NN '' .
Pip first learns `` the stupendous power of money '' from the sycophantic tailor , Mr. Trabb , whose brutality to his boy helper exactly matches the financial resource of each new customer , and whose fawning hands touch `` the outside of each elbow '' and `` rub '' Pip out of the shop .	NP RB VBZ `` AT JJ NN IN NN '' IN AT JJ NN , NP NP , WP$ NN IN PP$ NN NN RB VBZ AT JJ NN IN DT JJ NN , CC WP$ VBG NNS VB `` AT NN IN DT NN '' CC `` VB '' NP RP IN AT NN .
The respectability which money confers implies a different etiquette , and , upon taking up the life of a London gentleman , Pip must learn from Herbert Pocket that `` the spoon is not generally used over-hand , but under '' .
