Urethane foams	NN-HL NNS-HL
Since the mid 1950s , when urethane foam first made its appearance in the American market , growth has been little short of fantastic .	IN AT JJ NNS , WRB NN NN RB VBD PP$ NN IN AT JJ NN , NN HVZ BEN QL RB IN JJ .
Present estimates are that production topped the 100-million-lb. mark in 1960 ( 85 to 90 million lb. for flexible , 10 or 11 million lb. for rigid ) ; ;	JJ NNS BER CS NN VBD AT JJ NN IN CD ( CD IN CD CD NNS IN JJ , CD CC CD CD NNS IN JJ ) . .
by 1965 , production may range from 200 to 350 million lb. for flexible and from 115 to 150 million lb. for rigid .	IN CD , NN MD VB IN CD IN CD CD NNS IN JJ CC IN CD IN CD CD NNS IN JJ .
The markets that have started to open up for the foam in the past year or so seem to justify the expectations .	AT NNS WPS HV VBN TO VB RP IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN CC RB VB TO VB AT NNS .
Furniture upholstery , as just one example , can easily take millions of pounds ; ;	NN NN , CS RB CD NN , MD RB VB NNS IN NNS . .
foamed refrigerator insulation is under intensive evaluation by every major manufacturer ; ;	VBN NN NN BEZ IN JJ NN IN AT JJ NN . .
and use of the foam for garment interlining is only now getting off the ground , with volume potential in the offing .	CC NN IN AT NN IN NN NN BEZ RB RB VBG IN AT NN , IN NN NN IN AT NN .
Basic chemistry	JJ-HL NN-HL
Urethane foams are , basically , reaction products of hydroxyl-rich materials and polyisocyanates ( usually tolylene diisocyanate ) .	NN NNS BER , RB , NN NNS IN JJ NNS CC NNS ( RB NN NN ) .
Blowing can be either one of two types -- carbon dioxide gas generated by the reaction of water on the polyisocyanate or mechanical blowing through the use of a low-boiling liquid such as a fluorinated hydrocarbon .	VBG MD BE CC CD IN CD NNS -- NN NN NN VBN IN AT NN IN NN IN AT NN CC JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN JJ CS AT VBN NN .
The most important factor in determining what properties the end-product will have is quite naturally the type of hydroxyl-rich compound that is used in its production .	AT QL JJ NN IN VBG WDT NNS AT NN MD HV BEZ QL RB AT NN IN JJ NN WPS BEZ VBN IN PP$ NN .
Originally , the main types used were various compositions of polyesters .	RB , AT JJS NNS VBN BED AP NNS IN NNS .
These are still in wide use today , particularly in semi-rigid formulations , for such applications as cores for sandwich-type structural panels , foamed-in-place insulation , automotive safety padding , arm rests , etc. .	DTS BER RB IN JJ NN NR , RB IN JJ NNS , IN JJ NNS CS NNS IN JJ JJ NNS , JJ NN , JJ NN NN , NN NNS , RB .
More recently , polyethers -- again in varied compositions , molecular weights , and branching -- have come into use at first for the flexible foams , just lately for the rigids .	QL RB , NNS -- RB IN VBN NNS , JJ NNS , CC VBG -- HV VBN IN NN IN RB IN AT JJ NNS , QL RB IN AT NNS .
The polyether glycols are claimed to give flexible urethanes a spring-back action which is much desired in cushioning .	AT NN NNS BER VBN TO VB JJ NNS AT JJ NN WDT BEZ QL VBN IN NN .
Although the first polyether foams on the market had to be produced by the two-step prepolymer method , today , thanks to new catalysts , they can be produced by a one-shot technique .	CS AT OD NN NNS IN AT NN HVD TO BE VBN IN AT JJ NN NN , NR , NNS IN JJ NNS , PPSS MD BE VBN IN AT JJ NN .
It is possible that the polyether foams may soon be molded on a production basis in low-cost molds with more intricate contours and with superior properties to latex foam .	PPS BEZ JJ CS AT NN NNS MD RB BE VBN IN AT NN NN IN NN NNS IN QL JJ NNS CC IN JJ NNS IN NN NN .
The polyester urethane foam is generally produced with adipic acid polyesters ; ;	AT NN NN NN BEZ RB VBN IN JJ NN NNS . .
the polyether group generally consists of foams produced with polypropylene glycol or polypropylene glycol modified with a triol .	AT NN NN RB VBZ IN NNS VBN IN NN NN CC NN NN VBN IN AT NN .
One shot vs. prepolymer	CD-HL NN-HL IN-HL NN-HL
In the prepolymer system , the isocyanate and resin are mixed anhydrously and no foaming occurs .	IN AT NN NN , AT NN CC NN BER VBN RB CC AT NN VBZ .
The foaming can be accomplished at some future time at a different location by the addition of the correct proportion of catalyst in solution .	AT NN MD BE VBN IN DTI JJ NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN NN IN NN .
In one-shot , the isocyanate , polyester or polyether resin , catalyst , and other additives are mixed directly and a foam is produced immediately .	IN JJ , AT NN , NN CC NN NN , NN , CC AP NNS BER VBN RB CC AT NN BEZ VBN RB .
Basically , this means that simpler processing equipment ( the mixture has good flowing characteristics ) and less external heat ( the foaming reaction is exothermic and develops internal heat ) are required in one-shot foaming , although , at the same time , the problems of controlling the conditions of one-shot foaming are critical ones .	RB , DT VBZ CS JJR VBG NN ( AT NN HVZ JJ VBG NNS ) CC AP JJ NN ( AT VBG NN BEZ JJ CC VBZ JJ NN ) BER VBN IN JJ NN , CS , IN AT AP NN , AT NNS IN VBG AT NNS IN JJ NN BER JJ NNS .
Properties	NNS-HL
Most commercial uses of urethane foams require densities between 2 and 30 lb. / cu. ft. for rigid foams , between 1 and 3 lb. / cu. ft. for flexible foams .	AP JJ NNS IN NN NNS VB NNS IN CD CC CD NNS IN JJ NN IN JJ NNS , IN CD CC CD NNS IN JJ NN IN JJ NNS .
This latter figure compares with latex foam rubber at an average of 5.5 lb. / cu. ft. in commercial grades .	DT AP NN VBZ IN NN NN NN IN AT NN IN CD NNS IN JJ NN IN JJ NNS .
Compression strength :	NN-HL NN-HL :-HL
Graph in Fig. 1 , p. 392 , indicates how the ratio of compressive strength to density varies as the latter is increased or decreased .	NN IN NN-TL CD-TL , NN CD , VBZ WRB AT NN IN JJ NN IN NN VBZ CS AT AP BEZ VBN CC VBN .
The single curve line represents a specific formulation in a test example .	AT AP NN NN VBZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN .
By varying the formula , this curve may be moved forward or backward along the coordinates to produce any desired compression strength / density ratio .	IN VBG AT NN , DT NN MD BE VBN RB CC RB IN AT NNS TO VB DTI VBN NN NN IN NN NN .
Thermal conductivity and temperature resistance :	JJ-HL NN-HL CC-HL NN-HL NN-HL :-HL
In flexible urethane foams , we are referring to the range between the highest and lowest temperatures under which the materials' primary performance remains functionally useful .	IN JJ NN NNS , PPSS BER VBG IN AT NN IN AT JJT CC JJT NNS IN WDT AT NNS$ JJ NN VBZ RB JJ .
In temperature resistance , this quality is usually related to specific properties , e.g. , flexural , tensile strengths , etc. .	IN NN NN , DT NN BEZ RB VBN IN JJ NNS , RB , JJ , JJ NNS , RB .
Thermal conductivity is directly traceable to the material's porous , air-cell construction which effectively traps air or a gas in the maze of minute bubbles which form its composition .	JJ NN BEZ RB JJ IN AT NN$ JJ , NN NN WDT RB VBZ NN CC AT NN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS WDT VB PP$ NN .
These air or gas bubbles make highly functional thermal barriers .	DTS NN CC NN NNS VB QL JJ JJ NNS .
The K factor , a term used to denote the rate of heat transmission through a material ( B.t.u./sq. ft. of material/hr./*0F./in. of thickness ) ranges from 0.24 to 0.28 for flexible urethane foams and from 0.12 to 0.16 for rigid urethane foams , depending upon the formulation , density , cell size , and nature of blowing agents used .	AT NN NN , AT NN VBN TO VB AT NN IN NN NN IN AT NN NIL NIL NIL NIL NIL NIL NIL NIL VBZ IN CD IN CD IN JJ NN NNS CC IN CD IN CD IN JJ NN NNS , IN IN AT NN , NN , NN NN , CC NN IN VBG NNS VBN .
Table 1 , , p. 394 , shows a comparison of K factor ratings of a number of commercial insulating materials in common use , including two different types of rigid urethane foam .	NN-TL CD-TL , , NN CD , VBZ AT NN IN NN NN NNS IN AT NN IN JJ VBG NNS IN JJ NN , IN CD JJ NNS IN JJ NN NN .
Flexural strength :	JJ-HL NN-HL :-HL
This term refers to the ability of a material to resist bending stress and is determined by measuring the load required to cause failure by bending .	DT NN VBZ IN AT NN IN AT NN TO VB VBG NN CC BEZ VBN IN VBG AT NN VBN TO VB NN IN VBG .
The higher-density urethane semi-rigid foams usually have stronger flex fatigue resistance , i.e. , the 12 lb. / cu. ft. foam has 8 times the flexural strength of the 3 lb. / cu. ft. density .	AT NN NN JJ NNS RB HV JJR NN NN NN , RB , AT CD NNS IN JJ NN NN HVZ CD NNS AT JJ NN IN AT CD NNS IN JJ NN NN .
Note that flexural strength is not always improved by simply increasing the density , nor is the change always proportional from one formulation to another .	VB CS JJ NN BEZ * RB VBN IN RB VBG AT NN , CC BEZ AT NN RB JJ IN CD NN IN DT .
Where flexural strength is an important factor , be sure that your urethane foam processor is aware of it .	WRB JJ NN BEZ AT JJ NN , BE JJ CS PP$ NN NN NN BEZ JJ IN PPO .
Tensile strength :	JJ-HL NN-HL :-HL
This property refers to the greatest longitudinal stress or tension a material can endure without tearing apart .	DT NN VBZ IN AT JJT JJ NN CC NN AT NN MD VB IN VBG RB .
( like compression strength of urethane foams , it has a direct relationship to formulation .	( CS NN NN IN NN NNS , PPS HVZ AT JJ NN IN NN .
) Exceptional tensile strength is another of urethane foam's strong features .	) JJ JJ NN BEZ DT IN NN NN$ JJ NNS .
Figure 2 , above , shows the aging properties of urethane foams as determined by the percent of change in tensile strength during exposure to ultra-violet light .	NN-TL CD-TL , RB , VBZ AT VBG NNS IN NN NNS CS VBN IN AT NN IN NN IN JJ NN IN NN IN JJ NN .
Processing urethanes	VBG-HL NNS-HL
There are many ways of producing a foamed urethane product .	EX BER AP NNS IN VBG AT VBN NN NN .
The foam can be made into slab stock and cut to shape , it can be molded , it can be poured-in-place , it can be applied by spray guns , etc. .	AT NN MD BE VBN IN NN NN CC VBN IN NN , PPS MD BE VBN , PPS MD BE VBN , PPS MD BE VBN IN NN NNS , RB .
Slab stock is still one of the most important forms of urethane end-product in use today .	NN NN BEZ RB CD IN AT QL JJ NNS IN NN NN IN NN NR .
Basically , the foam machines that produce such stock consist of two or more pumping units , a variable mixer , a nozzle carriage assembly , and , in many cases , a conveyor belt to transport and contain the liquid during the reaction process and until it solidifies into foam .	RB , AT NN NNS WPS VB JJ NN VB IN CD CC AP VBG NNS , AT JJ NN , AT NN NN NN , CC , IN AP NNS , AT NN NN TO VB CC VB AT NN IN AT NN NN CC CS PPS VBZ IN NN .
The ingredients are fed from tanks through a hose and into the mixer at a predetermined rate .	AT NNS BER VBN IN NNS IN AT NN CC IN AT NN IN AT VBN NN .
The mixing head moves back and forth slowly across the width of the receptacle .	AT VBG NN VBZ RB CC RB RB IN AT NN IN AT NN .
It only takes a few minutes for the foaming action to be completed and after a short cure , the material can be cut into lengths as desired .	PPS RB VBZ AT AP NNS IN AT VBG NN TO BE VBN CC IN AT JJ NN , AT NN MD BE VBN IN NNS CS VBN .
Much has been done in the way of ingenious slitters to fabricate the slab stock into finished products .	AP HVZ BEN VBN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS TO VB AT NN NN IN VBN NNS .
Profile cutting machines are available which can split foam to any desired thickness and produce sine , triangle , trapezoid , and other profiles in variable heights , dimensions , etc. .	NN VBG NNS BER JJ WDT MD VB NN IN DTI VBN NN CC VB NN , NN , NN , CC AP NNS IN JJ NNS , NNS , RB .
The convoluted sheets can be combined to attain certain cushioning effects mechanically rather than chemically .	AT VBN NNS MD BE VBN TO VB AP VBG NNS RB RB CS RB .
Also available is a slitter which `` peels '' the inside of a folded block of foam and can be used to slit continuous sheets up to 300 yd. in length , down to 1/16 in. thick .	RB JJ BEZ AT NN WDT `` VBZ '' AT NN IN AT VBN NN IN NN CC MD BE VBN TO VB JJ NNS RP IN CD NNS IN NN , RP IN CD NN NN .
The low cost and ease of fabrication of the dies for three-dimensional foam cutting plus the wide variety of shapes , dimensions , and contours that can be tailor-made to customer requirements has made the technique useful for producing case liners , materials handling containers , packaging and cushioning devices , and such novelties as soap dishes , toys , head rests , arch supports , and gas pedal covers .	AT JJ NN CC NN IN NN IN AT NNS IN JJ NN NN CC AT JJ NN IN NNS , NNS , CC NNS WPS MD BE VBN IN NN NNS HVZ VBN AT NN JJ IN VBG NN NNS , NNS NN NNS , VBG CC VBG NNS , CC JJ NNS CS NN NNS , NNS , NN NNS , NN NNS , CC NN NN NNS .
Molding	VBG-HL
Although slab stock appeared first , it soon became apparent that for the production of cushions with irregular shapes , crowned contours , or rounded edges , the cutting of slab stock is a wasteful and uneconomical process .	CS NN NN VBD RB , PPS RB VBD JJ CS IN AT NN IN NNS IN JJ NNS , VBN NNS , CC VBN NNS , AT NN IN NN NN BEZ AT JJ CC JJ NN .
Only by resorting to molding techniques can the cushion manufacturer hope to compete satisfactorily in the established cushion market .	RB IN VBG IN VBG NNS MD AT NN NN VB TO VB RB IN AT VBN NN NN .
The closed molding of flexible urethane foams has been a problem ever since the introduction of the material ( molding in open molds was more feasible ) .	AT VBN NN IN JJ NN NNS HVZ BEN AT NN RB IN AT NN IN AT NN ( VBG IN JJ NNS BEDZ QL JJ ) .
Satisfactory methods for polyester foams and even prepolymer polyether foams were never fully achieved .	JJ NNS IN NN NNS CC RB NN NN NNS BED RB RB VBN .
Closed molding generally resulted in parts weighing more ( because of higher density ) than parts fabricated from free-blown foams .	VBN NN RB VBD IN NNS VBG AP ( RB IN JJR NN ) CS NNS VBN IN JJ NNS .
This counteracted the gain from having no scrap loss .	DT VBD AT NN IN HVG AT NN NN .
In addition , there were difficulties with the flow and spreading of the foam mixture over the mold surface , trouble with lack of gel strength in the rising foam , and problems of splits .	IN NN , EX BED NNS IN AT NN CC NN IN AT NN NN IN AT NN NN , NN IN NN IN NN NN IN AT VBG NN , CC NNS IN NNS .
The introduction of one-shot polyether foam systems , aided by the development of new catalysts , helped to alleviate some of the problems of closed molding .	AT NN IN JJ NN NN NNS , VBN IN AT NN IN JJ NNS , VBD TO VB DTI IN AT NNS IN VBN NN .
While there are still many bugs to be ironed out , the technique is fast developing .	CS EX BER RB AP NNS TO BE VBN RP , AT NN BEZ RB VBG .
Other techniques	AP-HL NNS-HL
Simple systems are available that make it possible for urethane foam components to be poured , pumped , etc. , into a void where they foam up to fill the void .	JJ NNS BER JJ WPS VB PPO JJ IN NN NN NNS TO BE VBN , VBN , RB , IN AT NN WRB PPSS VB RP TO VB AT NN .
In a typical application -- the making of rigid urethane foam sandwich panels -- an amount of foam mixture calculated to expand 10 to 20% more than the volume of the panel is poured into the panel void and the top of the panel is locked in place by a jig .	IN AT JJ NN -- AT NN IN JJ NN NN NN NNS -- AT NN IN NN NN VBN TO VB CD IN NN RBR CS AT NN IN AT NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN NN CC AT NN IN AT NN BEZ VBN IN NN IN AT NN .
Temperature of the wash and rinse waters is maintained at 85 - 90-degrees-F ( 29 - 32-degrees-C ) .	NN IN AT NN CC NN NNS BEZ VBN IN CD IN NNS NIL NIL NIL NIL NIL .
The top rolls are loaded with 40 lbs. .	AT JJS NNS BER VBN IN CD NNS .
Sixty lbs. loading is possible but 40 lbs. is adequate .	CD NNS NN BEZ JJ CC CD NNS BEZ JJ .
The suds box drain is arranged at the start to deliver into the raised main drain pipe ( thus returning suds to soap box ) and the machine is started .	AT NNS NN NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN TO VB IN AT VBN JJS NN NN ( RB VBG NNS IN NN NN ) CC AT NN BEZ VBN .
The 160-ml. bath containing the calculated amount of detergent is applied slowly and directly to the running specimen .	AT JJ NN VBG AT VBN NN IN NN BEZ VBN RB CC RB IN AT VBG NN .
Washing is continued for 30 minutes or for a period of time sufficient to allow 100 nips or passes through the squeeze rolls .	VBG BEZ VBN IN CD NNS CC IN AT NN IN NN JJ TO VB CD NNS CC NNS IN AT NN NNS .
At the conclusion of the washing , 8 liters of water at 90-degrees-F ( 32*0C. ) are automatically metered from the rinse reservoir to the washing tubs , 4 liters to each tub .	IN AT NN IN AT NN , CD NNS IN NN IN NNS NIL NIL NIL BER RB VBN IN AT NN NN IN AT VBG NNS , CD NNS IN DT NN .
This operation requires from 10 to 12 minutes .	DT NN VBZ IN CD IN CD NNS .
During the rinsing operation the volume in the tubs gradually increases until overflow from the main drain begins .	IN AT VBG NN AT NN IN AT NNS RB VBZ CS NN IN AT JJS NN VBZ .
At this point the drains are readjusted so that the suds box drain will discharge directly into the waste line and the main tub drain is set at the 2-1/2 mark on the drain gauge .	IN DT NN AT NNS BER VBN CS CS AT NNS NN NN MD VB RB IN AT NN NN CC AT JJS NN NN BEZ VBN IN AT CD NN IN AT NN NN .
When all of the rinse water has passed from the reservoir to the tubs the main drains are lowered to permit complete draining of the tubs .	WRB ABN IN AT NN NN HVZ VBN IN AT NN IN AT NNS AT JJS NNS BER VBN TO VB JJ NN IN AT NNS .
The run is complete when all the water has drained off into the waste line .	AT NN BEZ JJ WRB ABN AT NN HVZ VBN RP IN AT NN NN .
By this procedure rinsing progresses in two stages , first by dilution until the time when the drains are separated and thereafter by displacement of the soil-bearing liquor by clean rinse water , since soiled liquor squeezed from the specimens at the nip passes directly to waste from the suds box drains .	IN DT NN VBG VBZ IN CD NNS , RB IN NN IN AT NN WRB AT NNS BER VBN CC RB IN NN IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NN NN , CS VBN NN VBN IN AT NNS IN AT NN VBZ RB IN NN IN AT NNS NN NNS .
This method of rinsing appears to produce maximum cleansing with minimum soil redeposition .	DT NN IN VBG VBZ TO VB JJ NN IN JJ NN NN .
Suggested evaluation and classification	VBN-HL NN-HL CC-HL NN-HL
Evaluation may be made on either a soil-removal or a grease-removal basis as desired .	NN MD BE VBN IN CC AT NN CC AT NN NN CS VBN .
A reflectance-measuring instrument may be desirable to measure cleaning , whereas Soxhlet extraction is necessary to measure grease removal .	AT JJ NN MD BE JJ TO VB VBG , CS NP NN BEZ JJ TO VB NN NN .
Purpose and scope	NN-HL CC-HL NN-HL
This test method is intended for determining the dimensional changes of woven or knitted fabrics , made of fibers other than wool , to be expected when the cloth is subjected to laundering procedures commonly used in the commercial laundry and the home .	DT NN NN BEZ VBN IN VBG AT JJ NNS IN VBN CC VBN NNS , VBN IN NNS AP CS NN , TO BE VBN WRB AT NN BEZ VBN IN VBG NNS RB VBN IN AT JJ NN CC AT NN .
Four washing test procedures are established , varying in severity from very severe to very mild , and are intended to cover the range of practical washing from commercial procedure to hand washing .	CD VBG NN NNS BER VBN , VBG IN NN IN QL JJ IN QL JJ , CC BER VBN TO VB AT NN IN JJ VBG IN JJ NN IN NN NN .
Five drying test procedures are established to cover the range of drying techniques used in the home and commercial laundry .	CD VBG NN NNS BER VBN TO VB AT NN IN VBG NNS VBN IN AT NN CC JJ NN .
Three methods for determining the dimensional restorability characteristics are established for those textiles which require restoration by ironing or wearing after laundering .	CD NNS IN VBG AT JJ NN NNS BER VBN IN DTS NNS WDT VB NN IN VBG CC VBG IN VBG .
These tests are not accelerated and must be repeated to evaluate dimensional changes after repeated launderings .	DTS NNS BER * VBN CC MD BE VBN TO VB JJ NNS IN VBN NNS .
Table 1 , summarizes all of the various washing , drying , and restoration procedures available .	NN-TL CD-TL , VBZ ABN IN AT AP VBG , VBG , CC NN NNS JJ .
The person using these tests must determine which combination of procedures is practical for any specific item in order to evaluate the dimensional changes of textile fabrics or garments after laundering procedures commonly used in the home or commercial laundry .	AT NN VBG DTS NNS MD VB WDT NN IN NNS BEZ JJ IN DTI JJ NN IN NN TO VB AT JJ NNS IN NN NNS CC NNS IN VBG NNS RB VBN IN AT NN CC JJ NN .
It is possible to identify the test procedure completely with a code consisting of a Roman Numeral , a letter , and an Arabic number .	PPS BEZ JJ TO VB AT NN NN RB IN AT NN VBG IN AT JJ-TL NN-TL , AT NN , CC AT JJ NN .
For example Test 3 , E 1 refers to a specimen which has been washed by procedure `` 3 ( '' ( at 160-degrees-F ) for a total of 60 minutes in the machine , has been dried in a tumble dryer by procedure `` E '' and has been subjected to restorative forces on the Tension Presser by procedure `` 1 '' .	IN NN NN-TL CD-TL , NN CD VBZ IN AT NN WDT HVZ BEN VBN IN NN `` CD ( '' ( IN NNS ) IN AT NN IN CD NNS IN AT NN , HVZ BEN VBN IN AT NN NN IN NN `` NN '' CC HVZ BEN VBN IN JJ NNS IN AT NN-TL NN-TL IN NN `` CD-TL '' .
Principle	NN-HL
A specimen or garment is washed in a cylindrical reversing wash wheel , dried and subjected to restorative forces where necessary .	AT NN CC NN BEZ VBN IN AT JJ VBG NN NN , VBN CC VBN IN JJ NNS WRB JJ .
Temperature and time of agitation in the wash wheel are varied to obtain different degrees of severity .	NN CC NN IN NN IN AT NN NN BER VBN TO VB JJ NNS IN NN .
Drying procedures and application of restorative force procedures are varied to conform with end-use handling during home or commercial laundering .	VBG NNS CC NN IN JJ NN NNS BER VBN TO VB IN JJ NN IN NN CC JJ NN .
Distances marked on the specimen in warp and filling directions ( or wales and courses for knitted fabrics ) are measured before and after laundering .	NNS VBN IN AT NN IN NN CC VBG NNS ( CC NNS CC NNS IN VBN NNS ) BER VBN IN CC IN VBG .
Apparatus and materials	NN-HL CC-HL NNS-HL
wash wheel -- cylindrical wash wheel of the reversing type .	NN-HL NN-HL ---HL JJ-HL NN-HL NN-HL IN-HL AT-HL VBG-HL NN-HL .-HL
The wheel ( cage ) is 20 to 24 inches inside diameter and 20 to 24 inches inside length .	AT NN ( NN ) BEZ CD IN CD NNS JJ NN CC CD IN CD NNS JJ NN .
There are three fins each approximately three inches wide extending the full length of the inside of the wheel .	EX BER CD NNS DT RB CD NNS JJ VBG AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT NN .
One fin is located every 120-degrees around the inside diameter of the wheel .	CD NN BEZ VBN AT NNS IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN .
The wash wheel rotates at a speed of 30 revolutions per minute , making five to ten revolutions before reversing .	AT NN NN VBZ IN AT NN IN CD NNS IN NN , VBG CD IN CD NNS IN VBG .
The water inlets are large enough to permit filling the wheel to an eight-inch level in less than two minutes , and the outlet is large enough to permit discharge of this same amount of water in less than two minutes .	AT NN NNS BER JJ QLP TO VB VBG AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN AP IN CD NNS , CC AT NN BEZ JJ QLP TO VB NN IN DT AP NN IN NN IN AP IN CD NNS .
The machine is equipped with a pipe for injecting live steam that is capable of raising the temperature of water at an eight-inch level from 110-degrees to 140-degrees-F ( 38*0 to 60*0C. ) in less than two minutes .	AT NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN VBG JJ NN WPS BEZ JJ IN VBG AT NN IN NN IN AT NN NN IN NNS IN NNS NIL NIL NIL NIL NIL IN AP IN CD NNS .
The machine shall contain an opening for the insertion of a thermometer or other equivalent equipment for determining the temperature of the water during the washing and rinsing procedures .	AT NN MD VB AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN CC AP JJ NN IN VBG AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN CC VBG NNS .
It is equipped with an outside water gauge that will indicate the level of the water in the wheel .	PPS BEZ VBN IN AT JJ NN NN WPS MD VB AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN .
A domestic automatic washer that will give equivalent results may be used .	AT JJ JJ NN WPS MD VB JJ NNS MD BE VBN .
The wash wheel is the equipment preferred for the test .	AT NN NN BEZ AT NN VBN IN AT NN .
Pressing equipment -- flat-bed press measuring 24 inches by 50 inches or larger .	VBG-HL NN-HL ---HL NN-HL NN-HL VBG-HL CD-HL NNS-HL IN-HL CD-HL NNS-HL CC-HL JJR-HL .-HL
Any flat-bed press capable of pressing a specimen 22 inches square may be used as an alternative .	DTI NN NN JJ IN VBG AT NN CD NNS JJ MD BE VBN CS AT NN .
The flat-bed press is maintained at a temperature not less than 275-degrees-F ( 135*0C. ) .	AT NN NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN * AP IN NNS NIL NIL NIL .
Dryer -- dryer of the rotary tumble type , having a cylindrical basket approximately 30 inches in diameter and 24 inches in length and rotating at approximately 35 r.p.m. . The tensioning members have a common drive so that the application of restorative force takes place simultaneously in all directions in the plane of the test specimen .	AT VBG NNS HV AT JJ NN CS CS AT NN IN JJ NN VBZ NN RB IN ABN NNS IN AT NN IN AT NN NN .
The minimum diameter of the pin frame in the collapsed state is 11 inches and the maximum diameter in the freely extended state ( unloaded ) is 14 inches .	AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN IN AT VBN NN BEZ CD NNS CC AT JJ NN IN AT RB VBN NN ( VBN ) BEZ CD NNS .

Test specimens	NN NNS
The preparation of test specimens will vary depending upon the type of dimensional restorability procedure ( if any ) to be used .	AT NN IN NN NNS MD VB IN IN AT NN IN JJ NN NN ( CS DTI ) TO BE VBN .
Three specimens for each sample to be tested are required in order to arrive at a satisfactory average of performance .	CD NNS IN DT NN TO BE VBN BER VBN IN NN TO VB IN AT JJ NN IN NN .
This is especially true for knitted fabrics .	DT BEZ QL JJ IN VBN NNS .
Specimens are allowed to reach moisture equilibrium with a standard atmosphere of Af and Af and then laid out without tension on a flat , polished surface , care being taken that the fabric is free from wrinkles or creases .	NNS BER VBN TO VB NN NN IN AT JJ NN IN NN CC NN CC RB VBN RP IN NN IN AT JJ , VBN NN , NN BEG VBN CS AT NN BEZ JJ IN NNS CC NNS .
Fabrics that are badly distorted in their unlaundered state due to faulty finishing may give deceptive dimensional change results when laundered by any procedure .	NNS WPS BER RB VBN IN PP$ JJ NN RB IN JJ NN MD VB JJ JJ NN NNS WRB VBN IN DTI NN .
This also holds true if restorative forces are applied .	DT RB VBZ JJ CS JJ NNS BER VBN .
Therefore , it is recommended that in such cases the sample be replaced , or if used , the results of dimensional change or dimensional restorability tests be considered as indicative only .	RB , PPS BEZ VBN CS IN JJ NNS AT NN BE VBN , CC CS VBN , AT NNS IN JJ NN CC JJ NN NNS BE VBN CS JJ RB .
Generally , it is necessary to mark distances on a specimen ( or garment ) in both lengthwise and widthwise directions and to measure before and after laundering .	RB , PPS BEZ JJ TO VB NNS IN AT NN ( CC NN ) IN ABX JJ CC JJ NNS CC TO VB IN CC IN VBG .
The distances may be marked with indelible ink and a fine-point pen , by sewing fine threads into the fabric , or by a specially designed stamping machine .	AT NNS MD BE VBN IN JJ NN CC AT NN NN , IN VBG JJ NNS IN AT NN , CC IN AT RB VBN VBG NN .
The marked distances are parallel to the respective yarns .	AT VBN NNS BER RB IN AT JJ NNS .
Usually , the greater the original distances marked , the greater will be the accuracy of the test .	RB , AT JJR AT JJ NNS VBN , AT JJR MD BE AT NN IN AT NN .
Distances of less than 10 inches are not recommended .	NNS IN AP IN CD NNS BER * VBN .

High-gain , photoelectronic image intensification is applied under conditions of low incident light levels whenever the integration time required by a sensor or recording instrument exceeds the limits of practicability .	NN , JJ NN NN BEZ VBN IN NNS IN JJ JJ NN NNS WRB AT NN NN VBN IN AT NN CC VBG NN VBZ AT NNS IN NN .
Examples of such situations are ( aerial ) night reconnaissance , the recording of radioactive tracers in live body tissues , special radiography in medical or industrial applications , track recording of high energy particles , etc. .	NNS IN JJ NNS BER ( JJ ) NN NN , AT NN IN JJ NNS IN JJ NN NNS , JJ NN IN JJ CC JJ NNS , NN NN IN JJ NN NNS , RB .
High-gain photoelectronic image intensification may be achieved by several methods ; ;	NN JJ NN NN MD BE VBN IN AP NNS . .
some of these are listed below : ( A )	DTI IN DTS BER VBN RB : (-HL NP-HL )-HL
Cascading single stages by coupling lens systems , ( B )	VBG AP NNS IN VBG NN NNS , (-HL NP-HL )-HL
Channel-type , secondary emission image intensifier , ( C )	JJ , JJ NN NN NN , (-HL NP-HL )-HL
Image intensifier based upon the `` multipactor '' principle , ( D )	NN NN VBN IN AT `` NN '' NN , (-HL NP-HL )-HL
Transmission secondary electron multiplication image intensifiers ( TSEM tubes ) , ( E )	NN JJ NN NN NN NNS ( NP NNS ) , (-HL NP-HL )-HL
Cascading of single stages , enclosed in one common envelope .	VBG IN AP NNS , VBN IN CD JJ NN .
Cascading single stages by coupling lens systems is rather inefficient as the lens systems limit the obtainable gain quite severely .	VBG AP NNS IN VBG NN NNS BEZ QL JJ CS AT NN NNS VB AT JJ NN QL RB .
Channel-type image intensifiers are capable of achieving high-gain values ; ;	JJ NN NNS BER JJ IN VBG NN NNS . .
they suffer , however , from an inherently low resolution .	PPSS VB , RB , IN AT RB JJ NN .
Image intensifiers based upon the multipactor principle appear to hold promise as far as obtainable resolution is concerned .	NN NNS VBN IN AT NN NN VB TO VB NN QL RB CS JJ NN BEZ VBN .
However , the unavoidable low-duty cycle restricts the effective gain .	RB , AT JJ NN NN VBZ AT JJ NN .
TSEM tubes have been constructed showing high gain and resolution .	NP NNS HV BEN VBN VBG JJ NN CC NN .
However , electrostatic focus , important for many applications , has not been realized for these devices .	RB , JJ NN , JJ IN AP NNS , HVZ * BEN VBN IN DTS NNS .
Resolution limitations with electrostatic focus might be anticipated due to chromatic aberrations .	NN NNS IN JJ NN MD BE VBN RB IN JJ NNS .
Furthermore , the thin film dynodes appear to have a natural diameter limitation wherever a mesh support cannot be tolerated .	RB , AT JJ NN NNS VB TO HV AT JJ NN NN WRB AT NN NN MD* BE VBN .
Cascaded single stages enclosed by a common envelope have been constructed with high gain and high resolution .	VBN AP NNS VBN IN AT JJ NN HV BEN VBN IN JJ NN CC JJ NN .
These tubes may differ both in the choice of the electron optical system and in the design of the coupling members .	DTS NNS MD VB ABX IN AT NN IN AT NN JJ NN CC IN AT NN IN AT VBG NNS .
The electron optical system may be either a magnetic or electrostatic one .	AT NN JJ NN MD BE CC AT JJ CC JJ CD .
The magnification may be smaller , equal , or larger than unity .	AT NN MD BE JJR , JJ , CC JJR CS NN .
An electrostatic system suffers generally from image plane curvature leading to defocusing in the peripheral image region if a flat viewing screen ( or interstage coupler ) is utilized , while a magnetic system requires accurate adjustment of the solenoid , which is heavy and bulky .	AT JJ NN VBZ RB IN NN NN NN VBG IN VBG IN AT JJ NN NN CS AT JJ VBG NN ( CC JJ NN ) BEZ VBN , CS AT JJ NN VBZ JJ NN IN AT NN , WDT BEZ JJ CC JJ .
As it will be discussed later , peripheral defocusing can be improved on by utilizing curved fiber couplers .	CS PPS MD BE VBN RBR , JJ VBG MD BE VBN RP IN VBG VBN NN NNS .
It should be noted , however , that the paraxial resolution is quite similar for both electron optical systems .	PPS MD BE VBN , RB , CS AT JJ NN BEZ QL JJ IN ABX NN JJ NNS .
It is felt that fiber-coupled double- ( and multi- ) stage image intensifiers will gain considerable importance in the future .	PPS BEZ VBN CS JJ JJ ( CC JJ ) NN NN NNS MD VB JJ NN IN AT NN .
Therefore , we shall consider in this paper the theoretical gain and resolution capabilities of such tubes .	RB , PPSS MD VB IN DT NN AT JJ NN CC NN NNS IN JJ NNS .
The luminous efficiency and resolution of single stages , fiber couplers , and finally of the composite tube will be computed .	AT JJ NN CC NN IN AP NNS , NN NNS , CC RB IN AT JJ NN MD BE VBN .
It will be shown theoretically that the high image intensification obtainable with such a tube and contact photography permits the utilization of extremely low incident light levels .	PPS MD BE VBN RB CS AT JJ NN NN JJ IN ABL AT NN CC NN NN VBZ AT NN IN QL JJ JJ NN NNS .
The effect of device and quantum noise , associated with such low input levels , will be described .	AT NN IN NN CC NN NN , VBN IN QL JJ NN NNS , MD BE VBN .
After these theoretical considerations , constructional details of a fiber-coupled , double-stage X-ray image intensifier will be discussed .	IN DTS JJ NNS , JJ NNS IN AT JJ , NN NN-TL NN NN MD BE VBN .
Measured performance characteristics for this experimental tube will be listed .	VBN NN NNS IN DT JJ NN MD BE VBN .
The conclusion shall be reached that fiber-coupled , double-stage tubes represent a sensible and practical approach to high-gain image intensification .	AT NN MD BE VBN CS JJ , NN NNS VB AT JJ CC JJ NN IN NN NN NN .
Basic design of a fiber-coupled , double-stage image intensifier	JJ-HL NN-HL IN-HL AT-HL JJ-HL ,-HL NN-HL NN-HL NN-HL
The tube design which forms the basis of the theoretical discussion shall be described now .	AT NN NN WDT VBZ AT NN IN AT JJ NN MD BE VBN RB .
The electron optical system ( see fig. 14-1 ) is based in principle on the focusing action of concentric spherical cathode and anode surfaces .	AT NN JJ NN ( VB NN CD ) BEZ VBN IN NN IN AT VBG NN IN JJ JJ NN CC NN NNS .
The inner ( anode ) sphere is pierced , elongated into a cup , and terminated by the phosphor screen .	AT JJ ( NN ) NN BEZ VBN , VBN IN AT NN , CC VBN IN AT NN NN .
The photoelectrons emitted from a circular segment of the cathode sphere are focused by the positive lens action of the two concentric spheres , pass through the ( negative ) lens formed by the anode aperture , and impinge upon the cathodoluminescent viewing screen .	AT NNS VBN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN BER VBN IN AT JJ NN NN IN AT CD JJ NNS , VB IN AT ( JJ ) NN VBN IN AT NN NN , CC VB IN AT JJ VBG NN .
The cylindrical focusing electrode permits adjustment of the positive lens part by varying the focusing potential .	AT JJ VBG NN VBZ NN IN AT JJ NN NN IN VBG AT VBG NN .
The anode potential codetermines the gain , G , and magnification , M , of the stage .	AT NN NN VBZ AT NN , NN , CC NN , NN , IN AT NN .
Both the photocathode and the image plane of such an electrode configuration are curved concave as seen from the anode aperture .	ABX AT NN CC AT NN NN IN ABL AT NN NN BER VBN JJ CS VBN IN AT NN NN .
The field-flattening property of the biconcave fiber coupler can be utilized to alleviate the peripheral resolution losses resulting with a flat phosphor-screen or coupling member .	AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN NN MD BE VBN TO VB AT JJ NN NNS VBG IN AT JJ NN CC VBG NN .
For the same reason , the output fiber plate is planoconcave , its exposed flat side permitting contact photography if a permanent record is desired .	IN AT AP NN , AT NN NN NN BEZ JJ , PP$ VBN JJ NN VBG NN NN CS AT JJ NN BEZ VBN .
As it will be shown later , the field-flattening properties of the interstage and output fiber coupler comprise indeed the main advantage of such a design .	CS PPS MD BE VBN RBR , AT JJ NNS IN AT JJ CC NN NN NN VB RB AT JJS NN IN ABL AT NN .
The second photocathode and both phosphor surfaces are deposited on the fiber plate substrates .	AT OD NN CC ABX NN NNS BER VBN IN AT NN NN NNS .
The photocathode sensitivities S , phosphor efficiencies P , and anode potentials V of the individual stages shall be distinguished by means of subscripts 1 , and 2 , in the text , where required .	AT NN NNS NN , NN NNS NN , CC NN NNS NN IN AT JJ NNS MD BE VBN IN NN IN NNS CD , CC CD , IN AT NN , WRB VBN .
Both stages are assumed to have unity magnification .	ABX NNS BER VBN TO HV NN NN .
Theoretical discussion of flux gain	JJ-HL NN-HL IN-HL NN-HL NN-HL
flux gain of a single stage	NN-HL NN-HL IN-HL AT-HL AP-HL NN-HL
The luminous gain of a single stage with Af ( flux gain ) is , to a first approximation , given by the product of the photocathode sensitivity S ( amp / lumen ) , the anode potential V ( volts ) , and the phosphor conversion efficiency P ( lumen/watt ) .	AT JJ NN IN AT AP NN IN NN ( NN NN ) BEZ , IN AT OD NN , VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN NN NN ( NN IN NN ) , AT NN NN NN ( NNS ) , CC AT NN NN NN NN ( NN ) .
In general , P is a function of V and the current density , but it shall here be assumed as a constant .	IN JJ , NN BEZ AT NN IN NN CC AT JJ NN , CC PPS MD RB BE VBN CS AT NN .
The luminous efficiency Af of a photocathode depends on the maximum radiant sensitivity Af and on the spectral distribution of the incident light Af by the relation : Af where Af is normalized radiant photocathode sensitivity .	AT JJ NN NN IN AT NN VBZ IN AT JJ JJ NN NN CC IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN NN IN AT NN : NN WRB NN BEZ VBN JJ NN NN .
Af is standard visibility function .	NN BEZ JJ NN NN .
The luminous flux gain of a single stage is given by : Af .	AT JJ NN NN IN AT AP NN BEZ VBN IN : NN .
If the input light distribution falls beyond the visible range , Af as expected , since Af .	CS AT NN NN NN VBZ IN AT JJ NN , NN CS VBN , CS NN .
Such cases are not considered here .	JJ NNS BER * VBN RB .
Efficiency of fiber couplers	NN-HL IN-HL NN-HL NNS-HL
The efficiency of fiber optics plates depends on four factors : ( A )	AT NN IN NN NN NNS VBZ IN CD NNS : (-HL NP-HL )-HL
numerical aperture ( N.A. ) ; ;	JJ NN ( NP ) . .
( B )	(-HL NP-HL )-HL
end ( Fresnel reflection ) losses ( R ) ; ;	NN ( NP NN ) NNS ( NP ) . .
( C )	(-HL NP-HL )-HL
internal losses ( I.L. ) ; ;	JJ NNS ( NP ) . .
( D )	(-HL NP-HL )-HL
packing efficiency ( F.R. ) .	VBG NN ( NP ) .
The numerical aperture of the fibers is given by : Af where Af .	AT JJ NN IN AT NNS BEZ VBN IN : NN WRB NN .
The angle Af is measured in the medium of index Af .	AT NN NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN NN NN .
Settled phosphors , as generally used in image intensifiers , have low optical contact with the substrate surface , hence Af shall be assumed .	VBN NNS , QL RB VBN IN NN NNS , HV JJ JJ NN IN AT NN NN , RB NN MD BE VBN .
The numerical aperture should be in general close to unity .	AT JJ NN MD BE IN JJ RB IN NN .
This condition can be satisfied , e.g. , with Af and Af or equivalent glass combinations .	DT NN MD BE VBN , RB , IN NN CC NN CC JJ NN NNS .
A sufficiently good approximation for determining the end reflection losses R can be obtained from the angle independent Fresnel formula : Af .	AT QL JJ NN IN VBG AT NN NN NNS NN MD BE VBN IN AT NN JJ NP NN : NN .
For phosphor to fiber and fiber to air surfaces , and assuming Af , we obtain Af percent .	IN NN IN NN CC NN IN NN NNS , CC VBG NN , PPSS VB NN NN .
This value may be reduced to 4.6 percent by means of a ( very thin ) glass layer of index 1.5 .	DT NN MD BE VBN IN CD NN IN NN IN AT ( QL JJ ) NN NN IN NN CD .
Hence , the Af factor for the output fiber coupler is Af .	RB , AT NN NN IN AT NN NN NN BEZ NN .
As the index of refraction of photosensitive surfaces of the SbCs-type lies around 2 , the Fresnel losses at the fiber-photocathode interface are about 0.5 percent and the Af factor for the interstage coupler is 0.95 .	CS AT NN IN NN IN JJ NNS IN AT NN VBZ IN CD , AT NP NNS IN AT NN NN BER RB CD NN CC AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN BEZ CD .
It might be anticipated that multiple coatings will reduce end reflection losses even further .	PPS MD BE VBN CS JJ NNS MD VB NN NN NNS QL RBR .
The internal losses are due to absorption and the small but finite losses suffered in the numerous internal reflections due to deviations from the prescribed , cylindrical fiber cross-section and minute imperfections of the core-jacket interface .	AT JJ NNS BER JJ IN NN CC AT JJ CC JJ NNS VBN IN AT JJ JJ NNS JJ IN NNS IN AT VBN , JJ NN NN CC JJ NNS IN AT NN NN .
These losses depend on fiber diameter and length , absorption coefficient , the mean value of the loss per internal reflection and last , but not least , on the angular distribution of the incident light .	DTS NNS VB IN NN NN CC NN , NN NN , AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN JJ NN CC AP , CC * AP , IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN .
Explicit expressions ( integral averages ) are given in the literature .	JJ NNS ( JJ NNS ) BER VBN IN AT NN .
Lacking reliable data for some of the variables , we are relying on experimental data of about 20 percent internal losses for 1/4-inch long , small ( 5 - 10 M ) diameter fibers .	VBG JJ NN IN DTI IN AT NNS , PPSS BER VBG IN JJ NN IN RB CD NN JJ NNS IN NN JJ , JJ ( CD IN CD NP ) NN NNS .
This relatively high value is probably due to the small fiber diameters increasing the number of internal reflections .	DT QL JJ NN BEZ RB JJ IN AT JJ NN NNS VBG AT NN IN JJ NNS .
Since we are considering here relatively small diameter ( 1 - 1.5 inches ) fiber plates , their average thickness can be kept below 1/4 inch and their internal losses may be assumed as 15 percent ( per plate ) . Theoretical discussion of paraxial device resolution	JJ-HL NN-HL IN-HL JJ-HL NN-HL NN-HL
resolution limitations in a single stage	NN-HL NNS-HL IN-HL AT-HL AP-HL NN-HL
The resolution limitations for a single stage are given by the inherent resolution of the electron optical system as well as the resolution capabilities of the cathodoluminescent viewing screen .	AT NN NNS IN AT AP NN BER VBN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN JJ NN QL RB CS AT NN NNS IN AT JJ VBG NN .
The resolution capabilities of an electrostatic system depend on both the choice of magnification and chromatic aberrations .	AT NN NNS IN AT JJ NN VB IN ABX AT NN IN NN CC JJ NNS .
It has been stated previously that a minifying electrostatic system yields a lower resolution than a magnifying system or a system with unity magnification .	PPS HVZ BEN VBN RB CS AT VBG JJ NN VBZ AT JJR NN CS AT VBG NN CC AT NN IN NN NN .
Furthermore , the chromatic aberrations depend on the chosen high voltage .	RB , AT JJ NNS VB IN AT VBN JJ NN .
In general , a high anode voltage reduces chromatic aberrations and thus increases the obtainable resolution .	IN JJ , AT JJ NN NN VBZ JJ NNS CC RB VBZ AT JJ NN .

( The P-20 input is of interest because it corresponds roughly to the light emission of conventional X-ray fluorescent screens ) .	( AT NN NN BEZ IN NN CS PPS VBZ RB IN AT NN NN IN JJ NN-TL JJ NNS ) .

The possibility of a space charge blowup of the screen crossover of the elementary electron bundles has been pointed out .	AT NN IN AT NN NN NN IN AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN NNS HVZ BEN VBN RP .
It is obvious that such an influence can only be expected in the final stage of an image intensifier at rather high output levels .	PPS BEZ JJ CS ABL AT NN MD RB BE VBN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN IN QL JJ NN NNS .
Space charge influences will also decrease at increased voltages .	NN NN NNS MD RB VB IN VBN NNS .
Electrostatic systems of the pseudo-symmetric type have been tested for resolution capabilities by applying electronography .	JJ NNS IN AT JJ NN HV BEN VBN IN NN NNS IN VBG NN .
A resolution of 70 - 80 line-pairs per millimeter appears to be feasible .	AT NN IN CD IN CD NNS IN NN VBZ TO BE JJ .
The inherent resolution of a cathodoluminescent phosphor screen decreases with increasingly aggregate thickness ( with increasing anode voltage ) , decreases with decreasing porosity ( thus the advantage of cathodophoretic phosphor deposition ) and might be impaired by the normally used aluminum mirror .	AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN NN VBZ IN QL JJ NN ( IN VBG NN NN ) , VBZ IN VBG NN ( RB AT NN IN JJ NN NN ) CC MD BE VBN IN AT RB VBN NN NN .
Thus , in general , elementary light optical effects , light scatter , and electron scatter determine the obtainable resolution limit .	RB , IN JJ , JJ NN JJ NNS , NN NN , CC NN NN VB AT JJ NN NN .
It should be noted that photoluminescence , due to `` Bremsstrahlung '' generated within the viewing screen by electron impact , appears to be important only if anode voltages in excess of 30 KV are utilized .	PPS MD BE VBN CS NN , RB IN `` FW-NN '' VBN IN AT VBG NN IN NN NN , VBZ TO BE JJ RB CS NN NNS IN NN IN CD NN BER VBN .
It has been stated that settled cathodoluminescent phosphor screens may have a limiting resolution of 60 Af at high voltage values of approximately 20 Aj .	PPS HVZ BEN VBN CS VBN JJ NN NNS MD HV AT VBG NN IN CD NN IN JJ NN NNS IN RB CD NN .
For the further discussion , we shall thus assume an electron optical resolution of 80 Af and phosphor screen resolution of 60 Af .	IN AT JJR NN , PPSS MD RB VB AT NN JJ NN IN CD NN CC NN NN NN IN CD NN .
The set of all decisions is called the operating policy or , more simply , the policy .	AT NN IN ABN NNS BEZ VBN AT VBG NN CC , QL RB , AT NN .
An optimal policy is one which in some sense gets the best out of the process as a whole by maximizing the value of the product .	AT JJ NN BEZ CD WDT IN DTI NN VBZ AT JJT RP IN AT NN CS AT NN IN VBG AT NN IN AT NN .
There are thus three components to an optimal design problem : ( 1 )	EX BER RB CD NNS IN AT JJ NN NN : (-HL CD-HL )-HL
The specification of the state of the process stream ; ;	AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN NN . .
( 2 )	(-HL CD-HL )-HL
The specification of the operating variables and the transformation they effect ; ;	AT NN IN AT VBG NNS CC AT NN PPSS VB . .
( 3 )	(-HL CD-HL )-HL
The specification of the objective function of which the optimization is desired .	AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN WDT AT NN BEZ VBN .
For a chemical process the first of these might involve the concentrations of the different chemical species , and the temperature or pressure of the stream .	IN AT NN NN AT OD IN DTS MD VB AT NNS IN AT JJ NN NNS , CC AT NN CC NN IN AT NN .
For the second we might have to choose the volume of reactor or amount of cooling to be supplied ; ;	IN AT OD PPSS MD HV TO VB AT NN IN NN CC NN IN VBG TO BE VBN . .
the way in which the transformation of state depends on the operating variables for the main types of reactors is discussed in the next chapter .	AT NN IN WDT AT NN IN NN VBZ IN AT VBG NNS IN AT JJS NNS IN NNS BEZ VBN IN AT AP NN .
The objective function is some measure of the increase in value of the stream by processing ; ;	AT JJ NN BEZ DTI NN IN AT NN IN NN IN AT NN IN VBG . .
it is the subject of Chapter 4 .	PPS BEZ AT NN IN NN-TL CD-TL .
The essential characteristic of an optimal policy when the state of the stream is transformed in a sequence of stages with no feedback was first isolated by Bellman .	AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN WRB AT NN IN AT NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN NNS IN AT NN BEDZ RB VBN IN NP .
He recognized that whatever transformation may be effected in the first stage of an R-stage process , the remaining stages must use an optimal Af-stage policy with respect to the state resulting from the first stage , if there is to be any chance of optimizing the complete process .	PPS VBD CS WDT NN MD BE VBN IN AT OD NN IN AT NN NN , AT VBG NNS MD VB AT JJ NN NN IN NN IN AT NN VBG IN AT OD NN , CS EX BEZ TO BE DTI NN IN VBG AT JJ NN .
Moreover , by systematically varying the operating conditions in the first stage and always using the optimal Af-stage policy for the remaining stages , we shall eventually find the optimal policy for all R stages .	RB , IN RB VBG AT VBG NNS IN AT OD NN CC RB VBG AT JJ NN NN IN AT VBG NNS , PPSS MD RB VB AT JJ NN IN ABN NN NNS .
Proceeding in this way , from one to two and from two to three stages , we may gradually build up the policy for any number .	VBG IN DT NN , IN CD IN CD CC IN CD IN CD NNS , PPSS MD RB VB RP AT NN IN DTI NN .
At each step of the calculation the operating variables of only one stage need be varied .	IN DT NN IN AT NN AT VBG NNS IN RB CD NN MD BE VBN .
To see how important this economy is , let us suppose that there are M operating variables at each stage and that the state is specified by N variables ; ;	TO VB WRB JJ DT NN BEZ , VB PPO VB CS EX BER NP VBG NNS IN DT NN CC CS AT NN BEZ VBN IN NP NNS . .
then the search for the maximum at any one stage will require a number of operations of order Af ( where a is some number not unreasonably large ) .	RB AT NN IN AT JJ IN DTI CD NN MD VB AT NN IN NNS IN NN NN ( WRB NN BEZ DTI NN * QL JJ ) .
To proceed from one stage to the next a sufficient number of feed states must be investigated to allow for interpolation ; ;	TO VB IN CD NN IN AT AP AT JJ NN IN NN NNS MD BE VBN TO VB IN NN . .
this number will be of the order of Af .	DT NN MD BE IN AT NN IN NN .
If , however , we are seeking the optimal R-stage policy for a given feed state , only one search for a maximum is required at the final step .	CS , RB , PPSS BER VBG AT JJ NN NN IN AT VBN NN NN , RB CD NN IN AT JJ BEZ VBN IN AT JJ NN .
Thus a number of operations of the order of Af are required .	RB AT NN IN NNS IN AT NN IN NN BER VBN .
If all the operating variables were varied simultaneously , Af operations would be required to do the same job , and as R increases this increases very much more rapidly than the number of operations required by the dynamic program .	CS ABN AT VBG NNS BED VBN RB , NN NNS MD BE VBN TO DO AT AP NN , CC CS NN VBZ DT VBZ QL QL QL RB CS AT NN IN NNS VBN IN AT JJ NN .
But even more important than this is the fact that the direct search by simultaneously varying all operating conditions has produced only one optimal policy , namely , that for the given feed state and R stages .	CC QL QL JJ CS DT BEZ AT NN CS AT JJ NN IN RB VBG ABN VBG NNS HVZ VBN RB CD JJ NN , RB , DT IN AT VBN NN NN CC NN NNS .
In contrast , the dynamic program produces this policy and a whole family of policies for any smaller number of stages .	IN NN , AT JJ NN VBZ DT NN CC AT JJ NN IN NNS IN DTI JJR NN IN NNS .
If the problem is enlarged to require a complete coverage of feed states , Af operations are needed by the dynamic program and Af by the direct search .	CS AT NN BEZ VBN TO VB AT JJ NN IN NN NNS , NN NNS BER VBN IN AT JJ NN CC NN IN AT JJ NN .
But Af is vastly larger than R .	CC NN BEZ QL JJR CS NN .
No optimism is more baseless than that which believes that the high speed of modern digital computers allows for use of the crudest of methods in searching out a result .	AT NN BEZ QL JJ CS DT WDT VBZ CS AT JJ NN IN JJ JJ NNS VBZ IN NN IN AT JJT IN NNS IN VBG RP AT NN .
Suppose that Af , and that the average operation requires only Af sec. .	VB CS NN , CC CS AT JJ NN VBZ RB NN NNS .
Then the dynamic program would require about a minute whereas the direct search would take more than three millennia ! !	RB AT JJ NN MD VB RB AT NN CS AT JJ NN MD VB AP IN CD NNS . .
The principle of optimality thus brings a vital organization into the search for the optimal policy of a multistage decision process .	AT NN IN NN RB VBZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN NN .
Bellman ( 1957 ) has annunciated in the following terms :	NP ( CD ) HVZ VBN IN AT VBG NNS :
`` An optimal policy has the property that whatever the initial state and initial decision are , the remaining decisions must constitute an optimal policy with respect to the state resulting from the first decision '' .	`` AT JJ NN HVZ AT NN CS WDT AT JJ NN CC JJ NN BER , AT VBG NNS MD VB AT JJ NN IN NN IN AT NN VBG IN AT OD NN '' .
This is the principle which we will invoke in every case to set up a functional equation .	DT BEZ AT NN WDT PPSS MD VB IN AT NN TO VB RP AT JJ NN .
It appears in a form that is admirably suited to the powers of the digital computer .	PPS VBZ IN AT NN WPS BEZ RB VBN IN AT NNS IN AT JJ NN .
At the same time , every device that can be employed to reduce the number of variables is of the greatest value , and it is one of the attractive features of dynamic programming that room is left for ingenuity in using the special features of the problem to this end .	IN AT AP NN , AT NN WPS MD BE VBN TO VB AT NN IN NNS BEZ IN AT JJT NN , CC PPS BEZ CD IN AT JJ NNS IN JJ NN CS NN BEZ VBN IN NN IN VBG AT JJ NNS IN AT NN IN DT NN .
2.2 the discrete deterministic process	CD-HL AT JJ JJ NN
Consider the process illustrated in Fig. 2.1 , consisting of R distinct stages .	VB AT NN VBN IN NN-TL CD-TL , VBG IN NN JJ NNS .
These will be numbered in the direction opposite to the flow of the process stream , so that stage R is the T stage from the end .	DTS MD BE VBN IN AT NN RB IN AT NN IN AT NN NN , CS CS NN NP BEZ AT NP NN IN AT NN .
Let the state of the stream leaving stage R be denoted by a vector Af and the operating variables of stage R by Af .	VB AT NN IN AT NN VBG NN NP BE VBN IN AT NN NN CC AT VBG NNS IN NN NP IN NN .
Thus Af denotes the state of the feed to the R-stage process , and Af the state of the product from the last stage .	RB NN VBZ AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN NN , CC NN AT NN IN AT NN IN AT AP NN .
Each stage transforms the state Af of its feed to the state Af in a way that depends on the operating variables Af .	DT NN VBZ AT NN NN IN PP$ NN IN AT NN NN IN AT NN WPS VBZ IN AT VBG NNS NN .
We write this Af .	PPSS VB DT NN .
This transformation is uniquely determined by Af and we therefore speak of the process as deterministic .	DT NN BEZ RB VBN IN NN CC PPSS RB VB IN AT NN CS JJ .
In practical situations there will be restrictions on the admissible operating conditions , and we regard the vectors as belonging to a fixed and bounded set S .	IN JJ NNS EX MD BE NNS IN AT JJ VBG NNS , CC PPSS VB AT NNS CS VBG IN AT VBN CC VBN NN NN .
The set of vectors Af constitutes the operating policy or , more briefly , the policy , and a policy is admissible if all the Af belong to S .	AT NN IN NNS NN VBZ AT VBG NN CC , QL RB , AT NN , CC AT NN BEZ JJ CS ABN AT NN VB IN NN .
When the policy has been chosen , the state of the product can be obtained from the state of the feed by repeated application of the transformation ( 1 ) ; ;	WRB AT NN HVZ BEN VBN , AT NN IN AT NN MD BE VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN IN VBN NN IN AT NN ( CD ) . .
thus Af .	RB NN .
The objective function , which is to be maximized , is some function , usually piecewise continuous , of the product state .	AT JJ NN , WDT BEZ TO BE VBN , BEZ DTI NN , RB RB JJ , IN AT NN NN .
Let this be denoted by Af .	VB DT BE VBN IN NN .
An optimal policy is an admissible policy Af which maximizes the objective function P .	AT JJ NN BEZ AT JJ NN NN WDT VBZ AT JJ NN NN .
The policy may not be unique but the maximum value of P certainly is , and once the policy is specified this maximum can be calculated by ( 2 ) and ( 3 ) as a function of the feed state Af .	AT NN MD * BE JJ CC AT JJ NN IN NN RB BEZ , CC CS AT NN BEZ VBN DT NN MD BE VBN IN ( CD ) CC ( CD ) CS AT NN IN AT NN NN NN .
Let Af where the maximization is over all admissible policies Af .	VB NN WRB AT NN BEZ IN ABN JJ NNS NN .
When it is necessary to be specific we say that the optimal policy is an optimal R-stage policy with respect to the feed state Af .	WRB PPS BEZ JJ TO BE JJ PPSS VB CS AT JJ NN BEZ AT JJ NN NN IN NN IN AT NN NN NN .
For any choice of admissible policy Af in the first stage , the state of the stream leaving this stage is given by Af .	IN DTI NN IN JJ NN NN IN AT OD NN , AT NN IN AT NN VBG DT NN BEZ VBN IN NN .
This is the feed state of the subsequent Af stages which , according to the principle of optimality , must use an optimal Af-stage policy with respect to this state .	DT BEZ AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN NNS WDT , RB IN AT NN IN NN , MD VB AT JJ NN NN IN NN IN DT NN .
This will result in a value Af of the objective function , and when Af is chosen correctly this will give Af , the maximum of the objective function .	DT NN VB IN AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN , CC WRB NN BEZ VBN RB DT MD VB NN , AT NN IN AT JJ NN .
Thus Af where the maximization is over all admissible policies Af , and Af is related to Af by ( 5 ) .	RB NN WRB AT NN BEZ IN ABN JJ NNS NN , CC NN BEZ VBN IN NN IN ( CD ) .

The set of equations ( 5 ) , ( 6 ) , and the starting equation ( 7 ) is of a recursive type well suited to programming on the digital computer .	AT NN IN NNS ( CD ) , ( CD ) , CC AT VBG NN ( CD ) BEZ IN AT JJ NN RB VBN IN VBG IN AT JJ NN .
In finding the optimal R-stage policy from that of Af stages , only the function Af is needed .	IN VBG AT JJ NN NN IN DT IN NN NNS , RB AT NN NN BEZ VBN .
When Af has been found it may be transferred into the storage location of Af and the whole calculation repeated .	WRB NN HVZ BEN VBN PPS MD BE VBN IN AT NN NN IN NN CC AT JJ NN VBN .
We also see how the results may be presented , although if n , the number of state variables , is large any tabulation will become cumbersome .	PPSS RB VB WRB AT NNS MD BE VBN , CS CS NN , AT NN IN NN NNS , BEZ JJ DTI NN MD VB JJ .

To extract the optimal R-stage policy with respect to the feed state Af , we enter section R of this table at the state Af and find immediately from the last column the maximum value of the objective function .	TO VB AT JJ NN NN IN NN IN AT NN NN NN , PPSS VB NN NN IN DT NN IN AT NN NN CC VB RB IN AT AP NN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN .

Since by the principle of optimality the remaining stages use an optimal Af-stage policy with respect to Af , we may enter section Af of the table at this state Af and read off the optimal policy for stage Af and the resulting state Af . It may be that the objective function depends not only on Af but also on Af , as when the cost of the operating policy is considered .	PPS MD BE CS AT JJ NN VBZ * RB IN NN CC RB IN NN , CS WRB AT NN IN AT VBG NN BEZ VBN .
A moment's reflection shows that the above algorithm and presentation work equally well in this case .	AT NN$ NN VBZ CS AT JJ NN CC NN VB QL RB IN DT NN .
A form of objective function that we shall often have occasion to consider is Af .	AT NN IN JJ NN WPO PPSS MD RB HV NN TO VB BEZ NN .
Here P represents the value of the stream in state P and Q the cost of operating the stage with conditions Q .	RB NP VBZ AT NN IN AT NN IN NN NP CC NP AT NN IN VBG AT NN IN NNS NP .
Hence P is the increase in value of the stream minus the cost of operation , that is , the net profit .	RB NN BEZ AT NN IN NN IN AT NN IN AT NN IN NN , DT BEZ , AT JJ NN .
