2.3 the discrete stochastic process	CD-HL AT JJ JJ NN
The process in which the outcome of any one stage is known only statistically is also of interest , although for chemical reactor design it is not as important as the deterministic process .	AT NN IN WDT AT NN IN DTI CD NN BEZ VBN RB RB BEZ RB IN NN , CS IN NN NN NN PPS BEZ * QL JJ CS AT JJ NN .
In this case the stage R operating with conditions Af transforms the state of the stream from Af to Af , but only the probability distribution of Af is known .	IN DT NN AT NN NP VBG IN NNS NN VBZ AT NN IN AT NN IN NN IN NN , CC RB AT NN NN IN NN BEZ VBN .
This is specified by a distribution function Af such that the probability that Af lies in some region D of the stage space is Af .	DT BEZ VBN IN AT NN NN NN JJ CS AT NN CS NN VBZ IN DTI NN NN IN AT NN NN BEZ NN .
We cannot now speak of maximizing the value of the objective function , since this function is now known only in a probabilistic sense .	PPSS MD* RB VB IN VBG AT NN IN AT JJ NN , CS DT NN BEZ RB VBN RB IN AT JJ NN .
We can , however , maximize its expected value .	PPSS MD , RB , VB PP$ VBN NN .
For a single stage we may define Af where the maximization is by choice of Af .	IN AT AP NN PPSS MD VB NN WRB AT NN BEZ IN NN IN NN .
We thus have an optimal policy which maximizes the expected value of the objective function for a given Af .	PPSS RB HV AT JJ NN WDT VBZ AT VBN NN IN AT JJ NN IN AT VBN NN .
If we consider a process in which the outcome of one stage is known before passage to the next , then the principle of optimality shows that the policy in subsequent stages should be optimal with respect to the outcome of the first .	CS PPSS VB AT NN IN WDT AT NN IN CD NN BEZ VBN IN NN IN AT AP , RB AT NN IN NN VBZ CS AT NN IN JJ NNS MD BE JJ IN NN IN AT NN IN AT OD .
Then Af , the maximization being over all admissible Af and the integration over the whole of stage space .	RB NN , AT NN BEG IN ABN JJ NN CC AT NN IN AT NN IN NN NN .
The type of presentation of results used in the deterministic process may be used here , except that now the fourth column is redundant .	AT NN IN NN IN NNS VBN IN AT JJ NN MD BE VBN RB , IN CS RB AT OD NN BEZ JJ .
The third column gives the optimal policy , but we must wait to see the outcome of stage R and enter the preceding section of the table at this state .	AT OD NN VBZ AT JJ NN , CC PPSS MD VB TO VB AT NN IN NN NN CC VB AT VBG NN IN AT NN IN DT NN .
The discussion of the optimal policy when the outcome of one stage is not known before passing to the next is a very much more difficult matter .	AT NN IN AT JJ NN WRB AT NN IN CD NN BEZ * VBN CS VBG IN AT AP BEZ AT QL QL QL JJ NN .
2.4 the continuous deterministic process	CD-HL AT JJ JJ NN
In many cases it is not possible to divide the process into a finite number of discrete stages , since the state of the stream is transformed in a continuous manner through the process .	IN AP NNS PPS BEZ * JJ TO VB AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN JJ NNS , CS AT NN IN AT NN BEZ VBN IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN .
We replace r , the number of the stage from the end of the process , by t , a continuous variable which measures the `` distance '' of the point considered from the end of the process .	PPSS VB NN , AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN , IN NN , AT JJ JJ WDT VBZ AT `` NN '' IN AT NN VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN .
The word distance is used here in a rather general sense ; ;	AT NN NN-NC BEZ VBN RB IN AT QL JJ NN . .
it may in fact be the time that will elapse before the end of the process .	PPS MD IN NN BE AT NN WPS MD VB IN AT NN IN AT NN .
If T is the total `` length '' of the process , its feed state may be denoted by a vector p(T) and the product state by p(Q) .	CS NN BEZ AT JJ `` NN '' IN AT NN , PP$ NN NN MD BE VBN IN AT NN NN CC AT NN NN IN NN .
P denotes the state at any point T and Q the vector of operating variables there .	NP VBZ AT NN IN DTI NN NP CC NP AT NN IN VBG NNS RB .
A gyro-stabilized platform system , using restrained gyros , is well suited for automatic leveling because of the characteristics of the gyro-platform-servo combination .	AT JJ NN NN , VBG VBN NNS , BEZ QL VBN IN JJ NN RB IN AT NNS IN AT NN NN .
The restrained gyro-stabilized platform with reasonable response characteristics operates with an approximate equation of motion , neglecting transient effects , as follows : Af where U is a torque applied about the output axis of the controlling gyro .	AT VBN JJ NN IN JJ NN NNS VBZ IN AT JJ NN IN NN , VBG JJ NNS , CS VBZ : NN WRB NN BEZ AT NN VBN IN AT NN NN IN AT VBG NN .
The platform angle **yf is the angle about which the gyro is controlling .	AT NN NN NN BEZ AT NN IN WDT AT NN BEZ VBG .
This is normally termed the gyro input axis , 90-degrees away from the gyro output or **yj axis .	DT BEZ RB VBN AT NN NN NN , NNS RB IN AT NN NN CC NN NN .
The gyro angular momentum is defined by H .	AT NN JJ NN BEZ VBN IN NN .
Thus if the gyro and platform-controller combination maintains the platform with zero angular deviation about the **yf axis , the system can be rotated with an angular velocity Af if a torque is supplied to the gyro output axis Aj .	RB CS AT NN CC NN NN VBZ AT NN IN CD JJ NN IN AT NN NN , AT NN MD BE VBN IN AT JJ NN NN CS AT NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN NN NN NN .
It is assumed that the gyros are designed with electrical torquers so that a torque can be applied about their output axes .	PPS BEZ VBN CS AT NNS BER VBN IN JJ NNS CS CS AT NN MD BE VBN IN PP$ NN NNS .
In the system shown in Fig. 7-1 , the accelerometer output is amplified and the resulting voltage is applied to the gyro output-axis torquer .	IN AT NN VBN IN NN-TL CD-TL , AT NN NN BEZ VBN CC AT VBG NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN NN NN .
This torque causes the entire system to rotate about the **yf axis , since the response to Af .	DT NN VBZ AT JJ NN TO VB IN AT NN NN , CS AT NN IN NN .
If the polarities are correct , the platform rotates in such a direction as to reduce the accelerometer output to zero .	CS AT NNS BER JJ , AT NN VBZ IN ABL AT NN CS TO VB AT NN NN IN CD .
As the accelerometer output is decreasing , the torque applied to the gyro output axis decreases and , therefore , the rate decreases .	CS AT NN NN BEZ VBG , AT NN VBN IN AT NN NN NN VBZ CC , RB , AT NN VBZ .
Finally , when the accelerometer output is zero , the entire system remains stationary , and the platform is , by definition , leveled .	RB , WRB AT NN NN BEZ CD , AT JJ NN VBZ JJ , CC AT NN BEZ , IN NN , VBN .
A mathematical block diagram for the leveling system is shown in Fig. 7-2 .	AT JJ NN NN IN AT VBG NN BEZ VBN IN NN-TL CD-TL .
The platform is initially off level by the angle Aj .	AT NN BEZ RB IN JJ IN AT NN NN .
The angle generated by the platform servo **yf multiplied by G is the effective acceleration acting on the accelerometer .	AT NN VBN IN AT NN NN NN VBN IN NP BEZ AT JJ NN VBG IN AT NN .
Af is the scale factor of the accelerometer ( Af ) .	NN BEZ AT NN NN IN AT NN ( NN ) .
The voltage Af is amplified by Af and applied to the gyro torquer with scale factor Af .	AT NN NN BEZ VBN IN NN CC VBN IN AT NN NN IN NN NN NN .
Finally , the gyro-stabilized platform characteristic is represented by Af .	RB , AT JJ NN NN BEZ VBN IN NN .
The system as indicated in Fig. 7-2 is fundamental and simple because the transient effects of both the platform servo and the accelerometer have been neglected .	AT NN CS VBN IN NN-TL CD-TL BEZ JJ CC JJ CS AT JJ NNS IN ABX AT NN NN CC AT NN HV BEN VBN .
With these factors included , an upper limit is placed on the allowable loop gain by stability considerations .	IN DTS NNS VBN , AT JJ NN BEZ VBN IN AT JJ NN NN IN NN NNS .
In this type of system , a high loop gain is desirable because it provides a fast response time .	IN DT NN IN NN , AT JJ NN NN BEZ JJ CS PPS VBZ AT JJ NN NN .
When the frequency response characteristics of practical components are considered , their effect on stability does not present the most serious limit on the system loop gain .	WRB AT NN NN NNS IN JJ NNS BER VBN , PP$ NN IN NN DOZ * VB AT QL JJ NN IN AT NN NN NN .
The time required for the system to reach a level position is approximately inversely proportional to the servo loop gain .	AT NN VBN IN AT NN TO VB AT JJ NN BEZ QL RB JJ IN AT NN NN NN .
In addition , the cutoff frequency for input accelerations is approximately proportional to the servo loop gain ; ;	IN NN , AT NN NN IN NN NNS BEZ QL JJ IN AT NN NN NN . .
i.e. , high loop gain causes the system to respond to horizontal components of accelerations .	RB , JJ NN NN VBZ AT NN TO VB IN JJ NNS IN NNS .
This problem usually determines the lower limit of loop gain rather than response time .	DT NN RB VBZ AT JJR NN IN NN NN RB CS NN NN .
It must be noticed in Fig. 7-1 that the accelerometer responds to any input acceleration .	PPS MD BE VBN IN NN-TL CD-TL CS AT NN VBZ IN DTI NN NN .
The equation relating input acceleration to output platform angle is Af .	AT NN VBG NN NN IN NN NN NN BEZ NN .
In practice , the preflight leveling process takes place with the system mounted in the airframe .	IN NN , AT JJ VBG NN VBZ NN IN AT NN VBN IN AT NN .
When the system is arranged for automatic leveling , the platform angles respond to any horizontal components of acceleration acting on the accelerometers .	WRB AT NN BEZ VBN IN JJ NN , AT NN NNS VB IN DTI JJ NNS IN NN VBG IN AT NNS .
There are many such components of acceleration present due to the effect of wind gusts , engine noise , turbulence around the vehicle , etc. .	EX BER AP JJ NNS IN NN RB RB IN AT NN IN NN NNS , NN NN , NN IN AT NN , RB .
One of the greatest problems associated with automatic leveling is establishing a true level in the presence of high-level acceleration noise .	CD IN AT JJT NNS VBN IN JJ NN BEZ VBG AT JJ NN IN AT NN IN NN NN NN .
One solution to the problem is to operate with a low loop gain and to include low-pass filters .	CD NN IN AT NN BEZ TO VB IN AT JJ NN NN CC TO VB NN NNS .
This technique causes the system to respond only to low frequency acceleration components such as the platform tilt .	DT NN VBZ AT NN TO VB RB IN JJ NN NN NNS JJ CS AT NN NN .
Since a lower loop gain and low-pass filtering increases the response time , a practical compromise must be reached .	CS AT JJR NN NN CC NN NN VBZ AT NN NN , AT JJ NN MD BE VBN .
One of the most desirable solutions is achieved by the use of a non-linear amplifier for Af .	CD IN AT QL JJ NNS BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN IN NN .
The amplifier is designed so that its gain is large for accelerometer signals above a certain threshold level .	AT NN BEZ VBN CS CS PP$ NN BEZ JJ IN NN NNS IN AT AP NN NN .
Below this level , the amplifier gain Af is proportional and is of small value , in order to provide adequate noise filtering .	IN DT NN , AT NN NN NN BEZ JJ CC BEZ IN JJ NN , IN NN TO VB JJ NN NN .
The effect is that the platform returns from an off-level position at a rapid rate until it is nearly level , at which point the platform is controlled by a proportional servo with low enough frequency response so that the noise has little effect on the leveling process .	AT NN BEZ CS AT NN VBZ IN AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN CS PPS BEZ QL JJ , IN WDT NN AT NN BEZ VBN IN AT JJ NN IN JJ QLP NN NN CS CS AT NN HVZ AP NN IN AT VBG NN .
When the system is on automatic leveling , the gyro drift is canceled by the output of the leveling system ( amplifier Af ) .	WRB AT NN BEZ IN JJ NN , AT NN NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN AT VBG NN ( NN NN ) .
The platform actually tilts off level so that the accelerometer output , when amplified by Af , will supply the correct current to the gyro torquer to cancel the gyro drift .	AT NN RB VBZ IN JJ CS CS AT NN NN , WRB VBN IN NN , MD VB AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN TO VB AT NN NN .
The amount of platform dip required depends upon the scale factors of the system .	AT NN IN NN NN VBN VBZ IN AT NN NNS IN AT NN .
7-3 .	CD .
Practical leveling considerations .	JJ-HL VBG-HL NNS-HL .-HL
The automatic leveling system described in this section is readily adaptable to a gyro-stabilized platform consisting of three integrating gyros .	AT JJ VBG NN VBN IN DT NN BEZ RB JJ IN AT JJ NN VBG IN CD VBG NNS .
The system requires some switching of flight equipment circuits .	AT NN VBZ DTI NN IN NN NN NNS .
However , the leveling operation can be maintained and controlled remotely with no mechanical or optical contact with the platform .	RB , AT VBG NN MD BE VBN CC VBN RB IN AT JJ CC JJ NN IN AT NN .
This leveling system will hold the platform on-level , automatically , as long as the system is actuated .	DT VBG NN MD VB AT NN JJ , RB , QL RB CS AT NN BEZ VBN .
A useful by-product of this system is that the information necessary to set the gyro drift biases is available from the currents necessary to hold the system in level .	AT JJ NN IN DT NN BEZ CS AT NN JJ TO VB AT NN NN NNS BEZ JJ IN AT NNS JJ TO VB AT NN IN JJ .
The leveling process can be accomplished manually , and the results are as satisfactory as those obtained with automatic equipment .	AT VBG NN MD BE VBN RB , CC AT NNS BER QL JJ CS DTS VBN IN JJ NN .
The process consists in turning the platform manually until the outputs of both accelerometers are zero .	AT NN VBZ IN VBG AT NN RB CS AT NNS IN ABX NNS BER CD .
The turning is accomplished by applying voltage to the gyro torquers described above .	AT NN BEZ VBN IN VBG NN IN AT NN NNS VBN RB .
In brief , the human replaces amplifier Af in Figs. 7-1 and 7-2 .	IN JJ , AT NN VBZ NN NN IN NNS-TL CD-TL CC CD-TL .
Manual leveling requires an appropriate display of the accelerometer outputs .	JJ NN VBZ AT JJ NN IN AT NN NNS .
If high accuracy is required in preflight leveling , it is usually necessary to integrate or doubly integrate the accelerometer outputs ( this also minimizes the noise problem ) .	CS JJ NN BEZ VBN IN JJ NN , PPS BEZ RB JJ TO VB CC RB VB AT NN NNS ( DT RB VBZ AT NN NN ) .
With integration , the effect of a small acceleration ( or small platform tilt angle ) can be seen after a time .	IN NN , AT NN IN AT JJ NN ( CC JJ NN NN NN ) MD BE VBN IN AT NN .
However , skill is required on the part of an operator to level a platform to any degree of accuracy .	RB , NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN AT NN TO VB AT NN IN DTI NN IN NN .
Also , it requires more time as compared to the automatic approach .	RB , PPS VBZ AP NN CS VBN IN AT JJ NN .
Manual leveling is inconvenient if the platform must be maintained accurately level for any prolonged period of time .	JJ NN BEZ JJ CS AT NN MD BE VBN RB JJ IN DTI VBN NN IN NN .
The operator must continually supply the correct amount of turning current to the gyro torquers so that the effect of gyro drift is canceled .	AT NN MD RB VB AT JJ NN IN VBG NN IN AT NN NNS CS CS AT NN IN NN NN BEZ VBN .
This process is especially difficult since gyro drifting is typically random .	DT NN BEZ QL JJ CS NN VBG BEZ RB JJ .
7-4 .	CD-HL .-HL
Platform heading .	NN NN .
Platform heading consists of orienting the sensitive axis of the accelerometers parallel to the desired coordinate system of the navigator .	NN NN VBZ IN VBG AT JJ NN IN AT NNS RB IN AT VBN NN NN IN AT NN .
In simpler terms , it amounts to pointing the platform in the proper direction .	IN JJR NNS , PPS VBZ IN VBG AT NN IN AT JJ NN .
For purely inertial navigators , two techniques are available to accomplish the platform heading : Use of external or surveying equipment to establish proper heading ; ;	IN QL JJ NNS , CD NNS BER JJ TO VB AT NN NN : NN IN JJ CC VBG NN TO VB JJ NN . .
Use of the characteristics of the platform components for an indication of true heading .	NN IN AT NNS IN AT NN NNS IN AT NN IN JJ NN .
The choice of the heading technique is dependent upon the accuracy requirements , field conditions , and the time available to accomplish the heading .	AT NN IN AT NN NN BEZ JJ IN AT NN NNS , NN NNS , CC AT NN JJ TO VB AT NN .
7-5 .	CD .
External determination of heading -- surveying technique .	JJ-HL NN-HL IN-HL VBG-HL ---HL VBG-HL NN-HL .-HL
With the gyro-stabilized platform leveled , it can be headed in the proper direction by using surveying techniques .	IN AT JJ NN VBN , PPS MD BE VBN IN AT JJ NN IN VBG VBG NNS .
The platform accelerometers must be slightly modified for this procedure .	AT NN NNS MD BE QL VBN IN DT NN .
Before the accelerometers are mounted on the platform , the direction of their sensitive axis must be accurately determined .	CS AT NNS BER VBN IN AT NN , AT NN IN PP$ JJ NN MD BE RB VBN .
A mirror is mounted on each accelerometer so that the plane of the mirror is perpendicular to the sensitive axis of the unit .	AT NN BEZ VBN IN DT NN CS CS AT NN IN AT NN BEZ JJ IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN .
Transit .	NN-HL .-HL
A precision transit is set up so that it is aligned with respect to true north .	AT NN NN BEZ VBN RP CS CS PPS BEZ VBN IN NN IN JJ NN .
This can be done to a high degree of accuracy by existing surveying techniques .	DT MD BE VBN IN AT JJ NN IN NN IN VBG VBG NNS .
With the transit set up , a mirror on one of the accelerometers is sighted and the platform is turned until it is aligned .	IN AT NN VBN RP , AT NN IN CD IN AT NNS BEZ VBN CC AT NN BEZ VBN CS PPS BEZ VBN .
The sighting procedure includes the use of a fixture for the transit to project a beam of light , which is darkened by crossed hairs , on the accelerometer mirror .	AT VBG NN VBZ AT NN IN AT NN IN AT NN TO VB AT NN IN NN , WDT BEZ VBN IN VBN NNS , IN AT NN NN .
When the platform is aligned , the reflected image of the crossed hairs can be seen exactly superimposed upon the original crossed hairs .	WRB AT NN BEZ VBN , AT VBN NN IN AT VBN NNS MD BE VBN RB VBN IN AT JJ VBN NNS .
The images can easily be aligned with a high degree of accuracy .	AT NNS MD RB BE VBN IN AT JJ NN IN NN .
The platform is turned as required by supplying currents to the appropriate gyro torquers .	AT NN BEZ VBN CS VBN IN VBG NNS IN AT JJ NN NNS .
Although this technique is simple and satisfactory , one practical difficulty does exist : the direction of true north must be known for each launch point .	CS DT NN BEZ JJ CC JJ , CD JJ NN DOZ VB : AT NN IN JJ NN MD BE VBN IN DT NN NN .
However , this difficulty is not too serious if it is realized that a surveying team can establish a true north base line with a few days' work .	RB , DT NN BEZ * QL JJ CS PPS BEZ VBN CS AT VBG NN MD VB AT JJ NN NN NN IN AT AP NNS$ NN .
In many installations , the inertial platform is raised off the ground a considerable height when it is mounted in the vehicle before flight .	IN AP NNS , AT JJ NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN AT JJ NN WRB PPS BEZ VBN IN AT NN IN NN .
With this situation , it is difficult to sight in on the platform with surveying equipment .	IN DT NN , PPS BEZ JJ TO VB RP IN AT NN IN VBG NN .
If the platform is not too high off the ground , a transit can be mounted on a stand to raise it up to the platform .	CS AT NN BEZ * QL RB IN AT NN , AT NN MD BE VBN IN AT NN TO VB PPO RP IN AT NN .
Obviously , the heading accuracy is lessened by such techniques since errors are introduced because of motion of the stand .	RB , AT NN NN BEZ VBN IN JJ NNS CS NNS BER VBN RB IN NN IN AT NN .
Autocollimator .	NN-HL .-HL
The transit can be replaced by an autocollimator .	AT NN MD BE VBN IN AT NN .
This instrument provides an electrical signal proportional to the angular deviations of the platform and can be used to automatically hold the platform on true heading .	DT NN VBZ AT JJ NN JJ IN AT JJ NNS IN AT NN CC MD BE VBN TO RB VB AT NN IN JJ NN .
The electrical signal from the autocollimator is amplified and supplied to the Z-gyro torquer .	AT JJ NN IN AT NN BEZ VBN CC VBN IN AT NN NN .
If the polarity is correct , the platform will turn until the heading error angle is zero .	CS AT NN BEZ JJ , AT NN MD VB CS AT NN NN NN BEZ CD .
Information is also available from this autocollimator system to set the drift bias for the Z-axis gyro .	NN BEZ RB JJ IN DT NN NN TO VB AT NN NN IN AT NN NN .
If the Z gyro is drifting , a current generated by the autocollimator is delivered to the gyro torquer to cancel the drift .	CS AT NN NN BEZ VBG , AT NN VBN IN AT NN BEZ VBN IN AT NN NN TO VB AT NN .
If the drift error is systematic , it can be canceled with a bias circuit which can be arranged and adjusted to supply the required compensating current .	CS AT NN NN BEZ JJ , PPS MD BE VBN IN AT NN NN WDT MD BE VBN CC VBN TO VB AT VBN VBG NN .
Electrical pickoffs .	JJ-HL NNS-HL .-HL
It is possible to locate an angular electrical pickoff , which will indicate the angular deviation between the true heading direction and the platform .	PPS BEZ JJ TO VB AT JJ JJ NN , WDT MD VB AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN NN CC AT NN .
Essentially , the stator or reference portion of the pickoff is established with respect to the true heading direction , and the platform is turned either manually or automatically until the angular electrical pickoff signal is reduced to zero .	RB , AT NN CC NN NN IN AT NN BEZ VBN IN NN IN AT JJ NN NN , CC AT NN BEZ VBN CC RB CC RB CS AT JJ JJ NN NN BEZ VBN IN CD .
7-6 .	CD-HL .-HL
Gyrocompass heading .	NN-HL VBG-HL .
Gyrocompass alignment is an automatic heading system which depends upon the characteristic of one gyro to establish true heading .	NN NN BEZ AT JJ NN NN WDT VBZ IN AT NN IN CD NN TO VB JJ NN .
For the case of a purely inertial autonavigator consisting of three restrained gyros , a coordinate system is used where the sensitive axis of the X accelerometer is parallel to the east-west direction at the base point , and the Y accelerometer sensitive axis is parallel to the north-south direction at the base point .	IN AT NN IN AT QL JJ NN VBG IN CD VBN NNS , AT NN NN BEZ VBN WRB AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN BEZ RB IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN , CC AT NN NN JJ NN BEZ RB IN AT JJ NN IN AT NN NN .
The accelerometers are mounted rigidly on the platform .	AT NNS BER VBN RB IN AT NN .
Thus , if one accelerometer is properly aligned , the other is also .	RB , CS CD NN BEZ RB VBN , AT AP BEZ RB .
The input axis of the appropriate gyros are parallel to the sensitive direction of the accelerometers .	AT NN NN IN AT JJ NNS BER RB IN AT JJ NN IN AT NNS .
Figure 7-3 shows a platform system with the gyro vectors arranged as described above .	NN-TL CD-TL VBZ AT NN NN IN AT NN NNS VBN CS VBN RB .
The platform is leveled and properly headed , so that the X-gyro input axis is parallel to the east-west direction and the Y-gyro input axis is parallel to the north-south direction .	AT NN BEZ VBN CC RB VBN , CS CS AT NN NN NN BEZ RB IN AT JJ NN CC AT NN NN NN BEZ RB IN AT JJ NN .
The input axis of the X gyro , when pointing in the east-west direction , is always perpendicular to the spin axis of earth .	AT NN NN IN AT NN NN , WRB VBG IN AT JJ NN , BEZ RB JJ IN AT NN NN IN NN .
If the platform is not properly headed , the X-gyro input axis will see a component of the earth's rotation .	CS AT NN BEZ * RB VBN , AT NN NN NN MD VB AT NN IN AT NN$ NN .
The sensing of this rotation by the X gyro can be utilized to direct the platform into proper heading .	AT NN IN DT NN IN AT NN NN MD BE VBN TO VB AT NN IN JJ NN .
In Fig. 7-4 , the input axis of the three-axis platform is shown at some point on the earth .	IN NN-TL CD-TL , AT NN NN IN AT JJ NN BEZ VBN IN DTI NN IN AT NN .
The point is at a latitude **yl , and the platform is at an error in heading east .	AT NN BEZ IN AT NN NN , CC AT NN BEZ IN AT NN IN VBG NR .
The earth is spinning at an angular velocity **zq equal to one revolution per 24 hr. .	AT NN BEZ VBG IN AT JJ NN NN JJ IN CD NN IN CD NNS .
When the platform is level , **ye is a rotation about the Z axis of the platform Af .	WRB AT NN BEZ JJ , NN BEZ AT NN IN AT NN NN IN AT NN NN .
Since the earth is rotating and the unleveled gyro-stabilized platform is fixed with respect to a reference in space , an observer on the earth will see the platform rotating ( with respect to the earth ) .	CS AT NN BEZ VBG CC AT JJ JJ NN BEZ VBN IN NN IN AT NN IN NN , AT NN IN AT NN MD VB AT NN VBG ( IN NN IN AT NN ) .
Thirty-three	CD-HL
Scotty did not go back to school .	NP DOD * VB RB IN NN .
His parents talked seriously and lengthily to their own doctor and to a specialist at the University Hospital -- Mr. McKinley was entitled to a discount for members of his family -- and it was decided it would be best for him to take the remainder of the term off , spend a lot of time in bed and , for the rest , do pretty much as he chose -- provided , of course , he chose to do nothing too exciting or too debilitating .	PP$ NNS VBD RB CC RB IN PP$ JJ NN CC IN AT NN IN AT NN-TL NN-TL -- NP NP BEDZ VBN IN AT NN IN NNS IN PP$ NN -- CC PPS BEDZ VBN PPS MD BE JJT CS PPO TO VB AT NN IN AT NN RP , VB AT NN IN NN IN NN CC , IN AT NN , DO QL RB CS PPS VBD -- VBN , IN NN , PPS VBD TO DO PN QL JJ CC QL JJ .
His teacher and his school principal were conferred with and everyone agreed that , if he kept up with a certain amount of work at home , there was little danger of his losing a term .	PP$ NN CC PP$ NN NN BED VBN IN CC PN VBD CS , CS PPS VBD RP IN AT AP NN IN NN IN NN , EX BEDZ AP NN IN PP$ VBG AT NN .
Scotty accepted the decision with indifference and did not enter the arguments .	NP VBD AT NN IN NN CC DOD * VB AT NNS .
He was discharged from the hospital after a two-day checkup and he and his parents had what Mr. McKinley described as a `` celebration lunch '' at the cafeteria on the campus .	PPS BEDZ VBN IN AT NN IN AT JJ NN CC PPS CC PP$ NNS HVD WDT NP NP VBD CS AT `` NN NN '' IN AT NN IN AT NN .
Rachel wore a smart hat and , because she had been warned recently about smoking , puffed at her cigarettes through a long ivory holder stained with lipstick .	NP VBD AT JJ NN CC , CS PPS HVD BEN VBN RB IN VBG , VBD IN PP$ NNS IN AT JJ JJ NN VBN IN NN .
Scotty's father sat sprawled in his chair , angular , alert as a cricket , looking about at the huge stainless-steel appointments of the room with an expression of proprietorship .	NP$ NN VBD VBN IN PP$ NN , JJ , JJ CS AT NN , VBG RB IN AT JJ NN NNS IN AT NN IN AT NN IN NN .
Teachers -- men who wore brown suits and had gray hair and pleasant smiles -- came to their table to talk shop and to be introduced to Scotty and Rachel .	NNS -- NNS WPS VBD JJ NNS CC HVD JJ NN CC JJ NNS -- VBD IN PP$ NN TO VB NN CC TO BE VBN IN NP CC NP .
Rachel was polite , Scotty indifferent .	NP BEDZ JJ , NP JJ .
They ate the cafeteria food with its orange sauces and Scotty gazed without interest at his food , the teachers , the heroic baronial windows , and the bright ranks of college banners .	PPSS VBD AT NN NN IN PP$ JJ NNS CC NP VBD IN NN IN PP$ NN , AT NNS , AT JJ JJ NNS , CC AT JJ NNS IN NN NNS .
His father tried to make the food a topic .	PP$ NN VBD TO VB AT NN AT NN .
`` The blueberry pie is good , Scotty .	`` AT NN NN BEZ JJ , NP .
I recommend it '' .	PPSS VB PPO '' .
He looked at his son , his face worried .	PPS VBD IN PP$ NN , PP$ NN VBN .
Scotty murmured , `` No , thanks '' , so softly his father had to bend his gaunt height across the table and turn a round brown ear to him .	NP VBD , `` RB , NNS '' , QL RB PP$ NN HVD TO VB PP$ JJ NN IN AT NN CC VB AT JJ JJ NN IN PPO .
Scotty regarded the ear and the grizzled hair around it with a moment of interest .	NP VBD AT NN CC AT JJ NN IN PPO IN AT NN IN NN .
He said more loudly , `` I'm full , old Pop '' .	PPS VBD QL RB , `` PPSS+BEM JJ , JJ NP '' .
He had eaten almost nothing on the crested , three-sectioned plate and had drunk about half the milk in its paper container .	PPS HVD VBN RB PN IN AT JJ , JJ NN CC HVD JJ RB ABN AT NN IN PP$ NN NN .
`` He's all right , Craig '' , Rachel said .	`` PPS+BEZ QL JJ , NP '' , NP VBD .

yet his changed appearance , surprisingly , was one of plumpness .	CC PP$ VBN NN , RB , BEDZ CD IN NN .
His face was fuller ; ;	PP$ NN BEDZ JJR . .
his lips and the usually sharp lines of his jaw had become swollen-looking .	PP$ NNS CC AT RB JJ NNS IN PP$ NN HVD VBN JJ .

he kept his eyes , with their puffed blurred lids , always lowered , though not , apparently , focusing .	PPS VBD PP$ NNS , IN PP$ VBN VBN NNS , RB VBN , CS * , RB , VBG .
Even his neck seemed thicker and , therefore , shorter .	RB PP$ NN VBD JJR CC , RB , JJR .
His hands , which had been as quick as a pair of fluttering birds , were now neither active nor really relaxed .	PP$ NNS , WDT HVD BEN QL JJ CS AT NN IN VBG NNS , BED RB CC JJ CC QL VBN .

Altogether he had , since the seizure , the appearance of a boy who overindulged in food and took no exercise .	RB PPS HVD , IN AT NN , AT NN IN AT NN WPS VBD IN NN CC VBD AT NN .
He looked lazy , spoiled , a little querulous .	PPS VBD JJ , VBN , AT QL JJ .
Rachel had little to say .	NP HVD AP TO VB .
She greeted her husband's colleagues with smiling politeness , offering nothing .	PPS VBD PP$ NN$ NNS IN VBG NN , VBG PN .
Mr. McKinley , for all his sprawling and his easy familiarity , was completely alert to his son , eyes always on the still face , jumping to anticipate Scotty's desires .	NP NP , IN ABN PP$ VBG CC PP$ JJ NN , BEDZ QL JJ IN PP$ NN , NNS RB IN AT JJ NN , VBG TO VB NP$ NNS .
It was a strained , silent lunch .	PPS BEDZ AT VBN , JJ NN .
Rachel said , `` I'd better get him to bed '' .	NP VBD , `` PPSS+MD RBR VB PPO IN NN '' .
The doctors had suggested Scotty remain most of every afternoon in bed until he was stronger .	AT NNS HVD VBN NP VB AP IN AT NN IN NN CS PPS BEDZ JJR .
Since Mr. McKinley had to give a lecture , Rachel and Scotty drove home alone in the Plymouth .	CS NP NP HVD TO VB AT NN , NP CC NP VBD NR RB IN AT NP .
They did not speak much .	PPSS DOD * VB RB .

Thirty-four	CD-HL
the days seemed short , perhaps because his routine was , each day , almost the same .	AT NNS VBD JJ , RB CS PP$ NN BEDZ , DT NN , RB AT AP .

Wilson came by train from Birmingham and looked the city over ; ;	NP VBD IN NN IN NP CC VBD AT NN RP . .
the rather pleasant white city was on the hill where the chief stores were .	AT QL JJ JJ NN BEDZ IN AT NN WRB AT JJS NNS BED .
Beyond were industries and factories .	RB BED NNS CC NNS .
Then they went down to Black Bottom .	RB PPSS VBD RP IN JJ-TL NN-TL .
In the midst of this crowded region was the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church .	IN AT NN IN DT VBN NN BEDZ AT NP-TL JJ-TL JJ-TL JJ-TL NN-TL .
It was an old and dirty wooden structure , sadly in need of repair .	PPS BEDZ AT JJ CC JJ JJ NN , RB IN NN IN NN .
But it was a landmark .	CC PPS BEDZ AT NN .
It had been there 50 years or more and everybody in town , black and white , knew of it .	PPS HVD BEN RB CD NNS CC AP CC PN IN NN , JJ CC JJ , VBD IN PPO .
It had just suffered a calamity , the final crisis in a long series of calamities .	PPS HVD RB VBN AT NN , AT JJ NN IN AT JJ NN IN NNS .
For the old preacher who had been there twenty-five years was dead , and the city mourned him .	CS AT JJ NN WPS HVD BEN RB CD NNS BEDZ JJ , CC AT NN VBD PPO .
He was a loud-voiced man , once vigorous but for many years now declining in strength and ability .	PPS BEDZ AT JJ NN , RB JJ CC IN AP NNS RB VBG IN NN CC NN .
He was stern and overbearing with his flock , but obsequious and conciliatory with the whites , especially the rich who partly supported the church .	PPS BEDZ JJ CC JJ IN PP$ NN , CC JJ CC JJ IN AT NNS , RB AT JJ WPS RB VBD AT NN .
The Deacon Board , headed by a black man named Carlson , had practically taken over as the pastor grew old , and had its way with the support of the Amen corner .	AT NN-TL NN-TL , VBN IN AT JJ NN VBN NP , HVD RB VBN RP CS AT NN VBD JJ , CC HVD PP$ NN IN AT NN IN AT JJ-TL NN .
The characteristic thing about this church was its Amen corner and the weekly religious orgy .	AT JJ NN IN DT NN BEDZ PP$ JJ-TL NN CC AT JJ JJ NN .
A knot of old worshippers , chiefly women , listened weekly to a sermon .	AT NN IN JJ NNS , RB NNS , VBD RB IN AT NN .
It began invariably in low tones , almost conversational , and then gradually worked up to high , shrill appeals to God and man .	PPS VBD RB IN JJ NNS , QL JJ , CC RB RB VBD RP IN JJ , JJ NNS IN NP CC NN .
And then the Amen corner took hold , re-enacting a form of group participation in worship that stemmed from years before the Greek chorus , spreading down through the African forest , overseas to the West Indies , and then here in Alabama .	CC RB AT JJ-TL NN VBD NN , VBG AT NN IN NN NN IN NN WPS VBD IN NNS IN AT JJ NN , VBG RP IN AT JJ NN , RB IN AT JJ-TL NPS-TL , CC RB RB IN NP .
With shout and slow dance , with tears and song , with scream and contortion , the corner group was beset by hysteria and shivering , wailing , shouting , possession of something that seemed like an alien and outside force .	IN NN CC JJ NN , IN NNS CC NN , IN NN CC NN , AT NN NN BEDZ VBN IN NN CC VBG , VBG , VBG , NN IN PN WPS VBD CS AT JJ CC JJ NN .
It spread to most of the audience and was often viewed by visiting whites who snickered behind handkerchief and afterward discussed Negro religion .	PPS VBD IN AP IN AT NN CC BEDZ RB VBN IN VBG NNS WPS VBD IN NN CC RB VBD NP NN .
It sometimes ended in death-like trances with many lying exhausted and panting on chair and floor .	PPS RB VBD IN JJ NNS IN AP VBG VBN CC VBG IN NN CC NN .
To most of those who composed the Amen corner it was a magnificent and beautiful experience , something for which they lived from week to week .	IN AP IN DTS WPS VBD AT JJ-TL NN PPS BEDZ AT JJ CC JJ NN , PN IN WDT PPSS VBD IN NN IN NN .
It was often re-enacted in less wild form at the Wednesday night prayer meeting .	PPS BEDZ RB VBN IN QL JJ NN IN AT NR NN NN NN .
Wilson , on his first Sunday , witnessed this with something like disgust .	NP , IN PP$ OD NR , VBD DT IN PN CS NN .
He had preached a short sermon , trying to talk man-to-man to the audience , to tell them who he was , what he had done in Macon and Birmingham , and what he proposed to do here .	PPS HVD VBN AT JJ NN , VBG TO VB RB IN AT NN , TO VB PPO WPS PPS BEDZ , WDT PPS HVD VBN IN NP CC NP , CC WDT PPS VBD TO DO RB .
He sympathized with them on the loss of their old pastor .	PPS VBD IN PPO IN AT NN IN PP$ JJ NN .
But then , at mention of that name , the Amen corner broke loose .	CC RB , IN NN IN DT NN , AT JJ-TL NN VBD RB .
He had no chance to say another word .	PPS HVD AT NN TO VB DT NN .
At the very end , when the audience was silent and breathless , a collection was taken and then slowly everyone filed out .	IN AT AP NN , WRB AT NN BEDZ JJ CC JJ , AT NN BEDZ VBN CC RB RB PN VBD RP .
The audience did not think much of the new pastor , and what the new pastor thought of the audience he did not dare at the time to say .	AT NN DOD * VB AP IN AT JJ NN , CC WDT AT JJ NN VBD IN AT NN PPS DOD * VB IN AT NN TO VB .
During the next weeks he looked over the situation .	IN AT AP NNS PPS VBD RP AT NN .
First of all there was the parsonage , an utterly impossible place for civilized people to live in , originally poorly conceived , apparently not repaired for years , with no plumbing or sewage , with rat-holes and rot . It was arranged that he would board in the home of one of the old members of the church , a woman named Catt who , as Wilson afterward found , was briefly referred to as The Cat because of her sharp tongue and fierce initiative . Ann Catt was a lonely , devoted soul , never married , conducting a spotless home and devoted to her church , but a perpetual dissenter and born critic .	NP NP BEDZ AT JJ , VBN NN , RB VBN , VBG AT JJ NN CC VBN IN PP$ NN , CC AT JJ NN CC VBN NN .
She soared over the new pastor like an avenging angel lest he stray from the path and not know all the truth and gossip of which she was chief repository .	PPS VBD IN AT JJ NN CS AT VBG NN CS PPS VB IN AT NN CC * VB ABN AT NN CC NN IN WDT PPS BEDZ JJS NN .
Then Wilson looked over the church and studied its condition .	RB NP VBD RP AT NN CC VBD PP$ NN .
The salary of the pastor had for years been $500 annually and even this was in arrears .	AT NN IN AT NN HVD IN NNS BEN NNS RB CC RB DT BEDZ IN NNS .
Wilson made up his mind that he must receive at least $2,500 , but when he mentioned this to the Deacons they said nothing .	NP VBD RP PP$ NN CS PPS MD VB IN AP NNS , CC WRB PPS VBD DT IN AT NNS-TL PPSS VBD PN .
The church itself must be repaired .	AT NN PPL MD BE VBN .
It was dirty and neglected .	PPS BEDZ JJ CC VBN .
It really ought to be rebuilt , and he determined to go up and talk to the city banks about this .	PPS RB MD TO BE VBN , CC PPS VBD TO VB RP CC VB IN AT NN NNS IN DT .
Meanwhile , the city itself should be talked to .	RB , AT NN PPL MD BE VBN IN .
The streets in the colored section were dirty .	AT NNS IN AT VBN NN BED JJ .
There was typhoid and malaria .	EX BEDZ NN CC NN .
The children had nowhere to go and no place to play , not even sidewalks .	AT NNS HVD RB TO VB CC AT NN TO VB , * RB NNS .
The school was small , dark and ill-equipped .	AT NN BEDZ JJ , JJ CC JJ .
The teacher was a pliant fool .	AT NN BEDZ AT JJ NN .
There were two liquor saloons not very far from the church , one white , that is conducted for white people with a side entrance for Negroes ; ;	EX BED CD NN NNS * QL RB IN AT NN , CD JJ , WPS BEZ VBN IN JJ NNS IN AT NN NN IN NPS . .
the other exclusively Negro .	AT AP QL NP .

The rest of Black Bottom was a rabbit warren of homes in every condition of neglect , disrepair and careful upkeep .	AT NN IN JJ-TL NN-TL BEDZ AT NN NN IN NNS IN AT NN IN NN , NN CC JJ NN .
Dives , carefully repaired huts , and nicely painted and ornamented cottages were jumbled together cheek by jowl with little distinction .	NNS , RB VBN NNS , CC RB VBN CC VBN NNS BED VBN RB NN IN NN IN AP NN .

some were trash dumps , some had flower gardens .	DTI BED NN NNS , DTI HVD NN NNS .

After looking about a bit , Wilson discovered beyond Black Bottom , across the river and far removed from the white city , a considerable tract of land , and it occurred to him that the church and the better Negro homes might gradually be moved to this plot . Wilson stressed the fact that clear as this was , they must have a better church , a more business-like conduct of the church organization , and an effort to get this religious center out of its rut of wild worship into a modern church organization . The bank which held the mortgage on the old church declared that the interest was considerably in arrears , and the real estate people said flatly that the land across the river was being held for an eventual development for white working people who were coming in , and that none would be sold to colored folk . And after Wilson had talked to Mrs. Catt and to others , he was absolutely amazed .	CC CS NP HVD VBN IN NP NP CC IN NNS , PPS BEDZ QL VBN .
This , of course , was the sort of thing that used to take place in Southern cities -- putting white houses of prostitution with colored girls in colored neighborhoods and carrying them on openly .	DT , IN NN , BEDZ AT NN IN NN WPS VBD TO VB NN IN JJ-TL NNS -- VBG JJ NNS IN NN IN VBN NNS IN VBN NNS CC VBG PPO RP RB .
But it had largely disappeared on account of protest by the whites and through growing resentment on the part of the Negroes as they became more educated and got better wages .	CC PPS HVD RB VBN IN NN IN NN IN AT NNS CC IN VBG NN IN AT NN IN AT NPS CS PPSS VBD QL VBN CC VBD JJR NNS .
But this situation of Kent House was more subtle .	CC DT NN IN NP-TL NN-TL BEDZ QL JJ .
The wages involved were larger and more regular .	AT NNS VBN BED JJR CC QL JJ .

The backing from the white town was greater and there was little publicity .	AT NN IN AT JJ NN BEDZ JJR CC EX BEDZ AP NN .

And yet Wilson knew that this place must go or he must go .	CC RB NP VBD CS DT NN MD VB CC PPS MD VB .

Secretary of State Seward was a sick man .	NN-TL IN-TL NN-TL NP BEDZ AT JJ NN .
The idea had come from Herold , who had once been a chemist's clerk .	AT NN HVD VBN IN NP , WPS HVD RB BEN AT NN$ NN .

He did not really want to kill , but as in the sexual act , there was a moment when the impulse took over and could not be downed , even while you watched yourself giving way to it .
